 (v. t.) To beautify; to dandify.

ADOPTER
 (n.) A receiver, with two necks, opposite to each other, one of which admits the neck of a retort, and the other is joined to another receiver. It is used in distillations, to give more space to elastic vapors, to increase the length of the neck of a re

ADORING
 (imp. & p. p. Adored (/); p. pr. & vb. n.) of Adore

ADULATE
 (v. t.) To flatter in a servile way.

ADUSTED
 (a.) Burnt; adust.

ADVANCE
 (v. t.) To bring to view or notice; to offer or propose; to show; as, to advance an argument.

ADVANCE
 (v. i.) To move or go forward; to proceed; as, he advanced to greet me.

ADVANCE
 (v.) An addition to the price; rise in price or value; as, an advance on the prime cost of goods.

ADVISER
 (n.) One who advises.

ADVOYER
 (n.) See Avoyer.

ADYNAMY
 (n.) Adynamia.

AFFIXES
 (pl. ) of Affix

AFFLICT
 (v. t.) To inflict some great injury or hurt upon, causing continued pain or mental distress; to trouble grievously; to torment.

AFFRONT
 (v. t.) To offend by some manifestation of disrespect; to insult to the face by demeanor or language; to treat with marked incivility.

AFLAUNT
 (adv. & a.) In a flaunting state or position.

AFTMOST
 (a.) Nearest the stern.

AGAINST
 (prep.) From an opposite direction so as to strike or come in contact with; in contact with; upon; as, hail beats against the roof.

AGAMOUS
 (a.) Having no visible sexual organs; asexual.

AGATIZE
 (v. t.) To convert into agate; to make resemble agate.

AGGRATE
 (a.) To please.

AGILITY
 (n.) Activity; powerful agency.

AGITATE
 (v. t.) To revolve in the mind, or view in all its aspects; to contrive busily; to devise; to plot; as, politicians agitate desperate designs.

AGNOMEN
 (n.) An additional name, or an epithet appended to a name; as, Aristides the Just.

AGONIST
 (n.) One who contends for the prize in public games.

AGOUARA
 (n.) The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus), found in the tropical parts of America.

AGRAFFE
 (n.) A hook or clasp.

AHEIGHT
 (adv.) Aloft; on high.

AILMENT
 (n.) Indisposition; morbid affection of the body; -- not applied ordinarily to acute diseases.

AIRLIKE
 (a.) Resembling air.

ALARMED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Alarm

ALBINOS
 (pl. ) of Albino

ALBUMEN
 (n.) Nourishing matter stored up within the integuments of the seed in many plants, but not incorporated in the embryo. It is the floury part in corn, wheat, and like grains, the oily part in poppy seeds, the fleshy part in the cocoanut, etc.

ALBUMIN
 (n.) A thick, viscous nitrogenous substance, which is the chief and characteristic constituent of white of eggs and of the serum of blood, and is found in other animal substances, both fluid and solid, also in many plants. It is soluble in water and is

ALCALDE
 (n.) A magistrate or judge in Spain and in Spanish America, etc.

ALCAYDE
 (n.) Same as Alcaid.

ALEMBIC
 (n.) An apparatus formerly used in distillation, usually made of glass or metal. It has mostly given place to the retort and worm still.

ALEPOLE
 (n.) A pole set up as the sign of an alehouse.

ALEUTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a chain of islands between Alaska and Kamtchatka; also, designating these islands.

ALGATES
 (adv.) Always; wholly; everywhere.

ALGEBRA
 (n.) A treatise on this science.

ALIASES
 (pl. ) of Alias

ALIMENT
 (v. t.) To nourish; to support.

ALIMONY
 (n.) Maintenance; means of living.

ALKANET
 (n.) The similar plant Anchusa officinalis; bugloss; also, the American puccoon.

ALLEGED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Allege

ALLEGGE
 (v. t.) See Alegge and Allay.

ALLEYED
 (a.) Furnished with alleys; forming an alley.

ALLHEAL
 (n.) A name popularly given to the officinal valerian, and to some other plants.

ALLNESS
 (n.) Totality; completeness.

ALLONYM
 (n.) A work published under the name of some one other than the author.

ALLOQUY
 (n.) A speaking to another; an address.

ALLOWED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Allow

ALLOWER
 (n.) One who allows or permits.

ALLUDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Allure

ALMADIE
 (n.) A boat used at Calicut, in India, about eighty feet long, and six or seven broad.

ALMESSE
 (n.) See Alms.

ALOETIC
 (n.) A medicine containing chiefly aloes.

ALUMISH
 (a.) Somewhat like alum.

ALUNITE
 (n.) Alum stone.

ALVEOLI
 (pl. ) of Alveolus

ALYSSUM
 (n.) A genus of cruciferous plants; madwort. The sweet alyssum (A. maritimum), cultivated for bouquets, bears small, white, sweet-scented flowers.

AMALGAM
 (n.) An alloy of mercury with another metal or metals; as, an amalgam of tin, bismuth, etc.

AMBROSE
 (n.) A sweet-scented herb; ambrosia. See Ambrosia, 3.

AMENAGE
 (v. t.) To manage.

AMENTIA
 (n.) Imbecility; total want of understanding.

AMENUSE
 (v. t.) To lessen.

AMHARIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Amhara, a division of Abyssinia; as, the Amharic language is closely allied to the Ethiopic.

AMIABLE
 (a.) Friendly; kindly; sweet; gracious; as, an amiable temper or mood; amiable ideas.

AMIANTH
 (n.) See Amianthus.

AMMIRAL
 (n.) An obsolete form of admiral.

AMNESIA
 (n.) Forgetfulness; also, a defect of speech, from cerebral disease, in which the patient substitutes wrong words or names in the place of those he wishes to employ.

AMOEBAS
 (pl. ) of Amoeba

AMONGST
 (prep.) Expressing a relation of dispersion, distribution, etc.; also, a relation of reciprocal action.

AMOROSO
 (adv.) In a soft, tender, amatory style.

AMOTION
 (n.) Deprivation of possession.

AMPHORA
 (n.) Among the ancients, a two-handled vessel, tapering at the bottom, used for holding wine, oil, etc.

AMPLIFY
 (v. t.) To render larger, more extended, or more intense, and the like; -- used especially of telescopes, microscopes, etc.

AMUSIVE
 (a.) Having power to amuse or entertain the mind; fitted to excite mirth.

ANADROM
 (n.) A fish that leaves the sea and ascends rivers.

ANAGOGE
 (n.) An elevation of mind to things celestial.

ANAGOGY
 (n.) Same as Anagoge.

ANALOGY
 (n.) Conformity of words to the genius, structure, or general rules of a language; similarity of origin, inflection, or principle of pronunciation, and the like, as opposed to anomaly.

ANALYZE
 (v. t.) To subject to analysis; to resolve (anything complex) into its elements; to separate into the constituent parts, for the purpose of an examination of each separately; to examine in such a manner as to ascertain the elements or nature of the thin

ANARCHY
 (n.) Hence, confusion or disorder, in general.

ANATOMY
 (n.) The science which treats of the structure of organic bodies; anatomical structure or organization.

ANATRON
 (n.) Native carbonate of soda; natron.

ANCIENT
 (a.) Dignified, like an aged man; magisterial; venerable.

ANCIENT
 (n.) A senior; an elder; a predecessor.

ANCONES
 (pl. ) of Ancon

ANCONAL
 (a.) Alt. of Anconeal

ANELACE
 (n.) Same as Anlace.

ANGELOT
 (n.) An instrument of music, of the lute kind, now disused.

ANGERLY
 (adv.) Angrily.

ANGLIAN
 (n.) One of the Angles.

ANGLIFY
 (v. t.) To convert into English; to anglicize.

ANGULAR
 (a.) Fig.: Lean; lank; raw-boned; ungraceful; sharp and stiff in character; as, remarkably angular in his habits and appearance; an angular female.

ANNICUT
 (n.) A dam or mole made in the course of a stream for the purpose of regulating the flow of a system of irrigation.

ANIMATE
 (a.) Endowed with life; alive; living; animated; lively.

ANIMOSE
 (a.) Alt. of Animous

ANNOTTO
 (n.) Alt. of Arnotto

ANNOYER
 (n.) One who, or that which, annoys.

ANNUENT
 (a.) Nodding; as, annuent muscles (used in nodding).

ANNULET
 (n.) A small, flat fillet, encircling a column, etc., used by itself, or with other moldings. It is used, several times repeated, under the Doric capital.

ANNULUS
 (n.) The solid formed by a circle revolving around a line which is the plane of the circle but does not cut it.

ANODYNE
 (a.) Any medicine which allays pain, as an opiate or narcotic; anything that soothes disturbed feelings.

ANOMALY
 (n.) Deviation from the common rule; an irregularity; anything anomalous.

ANOTHER
 (pron. & a.) Any or some; any different person, indefinitely; any one else; some one else.

ANTACID
 (n.) A remedy for acidity of the stomach, as an alkali or absorbent.

ANTHRAX
 (n.) A microscopic, bacterial organism (Bacillus anthracis), resembling transparent rods. [See Illust. under Bacillus.]

ANTIQUE
 (a.) Odd; fantastic.

ANXIOUS
 (a.) Accompanied with, or causing, anxiety; worrying; -- applied to things; as, anxious labor.

APANAGE
 (n.) Same as Appanage.

APHETIC
 (a.) Shortened by dropping a letter or a syllable from the beginning of a word; as, an aphetic word or form.

APHIDES
 (pl. ) of Aphis

APHONIC
 (a.) Alt. of Aphonous

APIECES
 (adv.) In pieces or to pieces.

APOCOPE
 (n.) A cutting off; abscission.

APOGEAN
 (a.) Connected with the apogee; as, apogean (neap) tides, which occur when the moon has passed her apogee.

APORIAS
 (pl. ) of Aporia

APOSTLE
 (n.) The missionary who first plants the Christian faith in any part of the world; also, one who initiates any great moral reform, or first advocates any important belief; one who has extraordinary success as a missionary or reformer; as, Dionysius of C

APOTOME
 (n.) The difference between two quantities commensurable only in power, as between A2 and 1 or between the diagonal and side of a square.

APPAREL
 (v. t.) To dress or clothe; to attire.

APPLAUD
 (v. i.) To express approbation loudly or significantly.

APPLIED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Apply

APPOINT
 (v. t.) To furnish in all points; to provide with everything necessary by way of equipment; to equip; to fit out.

APPREST
 (a.) Pressed close to, or lying against, something for its whole length, as against a stem,

APPROMT
 (v. t.) To quicken; to prompt.

APPROVE
 (v. t.) To make or show to be worthy of approbation or acceptance.

APSIDES
 (n. pl.) See Apsis.

APTABLE
 (a.) Capable of being adapted.

APTERAN
 (n.) One of the Aptera.

APTERYX
 (n.) A genus of New Zealand birds about the size of a hen, with only short rudiments of wings, armed with a claw and without a tail; the kiwi. It is allied to the gigantic extinct moas of the same country. Five species are known.

ARABIST
 (n.) One well versed in the Arabic language or literature; also, formerly, one who followed the Arabic system of surgery.

ARCADIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Arcadia; pastoral; ideally rural; as, Arcadian simplicity or scenery.

ARCHERY
 (n.) Archers, or bowmen, collectively.

ARCHING
 (n.) The arched part of a structure.

ARCUBUS
 (n.) See Arquebus.

ARICINE
 (n.) An alkaloid, first found in white cinchona bark.

ARMIGER
 (n.) Formerly, an armor bearer, as of a knight, an esquire who bore his shield and rendered other services. In later use, one next in degree to a knight, and entitled to armorial bearings. The term is now superseded by esquire.

ARMLESS
 (a.) Without any arm or branch.

ARMORER
 (n.) Formerly, one who had care of the arms and armor of a knight, and who dressed him in armor.

ARNATTO
 (n.) See Annotto.

AROUSED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Arouse

ARRAIGN
 (v. t.) To appeal to; to demand; as, to arraign an assize of novel disseizin.

ARRIVER
 (n.) One who arrives.

ARTICLE
 (n.) A distinct part.

ARTICLE
 (v. i.) To agree by articles; to stipulate; to bargain; to covenant.

ARTISAN
 (n.) One trained to manual dexterity in some mechanic art or trade; and handicraftsman; a mechanic.

ARTISTE
 (n.) One peculiarly dexterous and tasteful in almost any employment, as an opera dancer, a hairdresser, a cook.

ASBOLIN
 (n.) A peculiar acrid and bitter oil, obtained from wood soot.

ASCITIC
 (a.) Alt. of Ascitical

ASEPTIC
 (n.) An aseptic substance.

ASPERNE
 (v. t.) To spurn; to despise.

ASPIRED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Aspire

ASSAULT
 (n.) A violent onset or attack with moral weapons, as words, arguments, appeals, and the like; as, to make an assault on the prerogatives of a prince, or on the constitution of a government.

ASSAULT
 (n.) To attack with moral means, or with a view of producing moral effects; to attack by words, arguments, or unfriendly measures; to assail; as, to assault a reputation or an administration.

ASSIZER
 (n.) An officer who has the care or inspection of weights and measures, etc.

ASSUAGE
 (v. i.) To abate or subside.

ASSUMPT
 (v. t.) To take up; to elevate; to assume.

ASTACUS
 (n.) A genus of crustaceans, containing the crawfish of fresh-water lobster of Europe, and allied species of western North America. See Crawfish.

ASTATIC
 (a.) Having little or no tendency to take a fixed or definite position or direction: thus, a suspended magnetic needle, when rendered astatic, loses its polarity, or tendency to point in a given direction.

ASTOUND
 (a.) To stun; to stupefy.

ASTRICT
 (v. t.) To restrict the tenure of; as, to astrict lands. See Astriction, 4.

ASTRIDE
 (adv.) With one leg on each side, as a man when on horseback; with the legs stretched wide apart; astraddle.

ASTYLAR
 (a.) Without columns or pilasters.

ATELLAN
 (n.) A farcical drama performed at Atella.

ATHIRST
 (a.) Having a keen appetite or desire; eager; longing.

ATHWART
 (prep.) Across the direction or course of; as, a fleet standing athwart our course.

ATOMIST
 (n.) One who holds to the atomic philosophy or theory.

ATRENNE
 (v. t.) To outrun.

ATROPHY
 (n.) A wasting away from want of nourishment; diminution in bulk or slow emaciation of the body or of any part.

ATTABAL
 (n.) See Atabal.

ATTAGEN
 (n.) A species of sand grouse (Syrrghaptes Pallasii) found in Asia and rarely in southern Europe.

ATTAINT
 (v. t.) To subject (a person) to the legal condition formerly resulting from a sentence of death or outlawry, pronounced in respect of treason or felony; to affect by attainder.

ATTAINT
 (v.) A touch or hit.

ATTEMPT
 (v. t.) To make trial or experiment of; to try; to endeavor to do or perform (some action); to assay; as, to attempt to sing; to attempt a bold flight.

ATTEMPT
 (n.) A essay, trial, or endeavor; an undertaking; an attack, or an effort to gain a point; esp. an unsuccessful, as contrasted with a successful, effort.

ATTIRED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Attire

ATTRACT
 (n.) Attraction.

ATTRITE
 (a.) Repentant from fear of punishment; having attrition of grief for sin; -- opposed to contrite.

ATTUNED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Attune

AUBERGE
 (n.) An inn.

AUCTARY
 (n.) That which is superadded; augmentation.

AUGMENT
 (n.) Enlargement by addition; increase.

AUGURED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Augur

AUGURAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to augurs or to augury; betokening; ominous; significant; as, an augural staff; augural books.

AULNAGE
 (n.) Alt. of Aulnager

AURATED
 (a.) Resembling or containing gold; gold-colored; gilded.

AURELIA
 (n.) A genus of jellyfishes. See Discophora.

AUREOLE
 (n.) The circle of rays, or halo of light, with which painters surround the figure and represent the glory of Christ, saints, and others held in special reverence.

AURICLE
 (n.) An instrument applied to the ears to give aid in hearing; a kind of ear trumpet.

AURORAL
 (a.) Belonging to, or resembling, the aurora (the dawn or the northern lights); rosy.

AUSPICE
 (a.) A divining or taking of omens by observing birds; an omen as to an undertaking, drawn from birds; an augury; an omen or sign in general; an indication as to the future.

AVARICE
 (n.) An excessive or inordinate desire of gain; greediness after wealth; covetousness; cupidity.

AVENAGE
 (n.) A quantity of oats paid by a tenant to a landlord in lieu of rent.

AVENTRE
 (v. t.) To thrust forward (at a venture), as a spear.

AVERAGE
 (n.) A tariff or duty on goods, etc.

AVERAGE
 (n.) Any medial estimate or general statement derived from a comparison of diverse specific cases; a medium or usual size, quantity, quality, rate, etc.

AVICULA
 (n.) A genus of marine bivalves, having a pearly interior, allied to the pearl oyster; -- so called from a supposed resemblance of the typical species to a bird.

AVIGATO
 (n.) See Avocado.

AVOIDER
 (n.) The person who carries anything away, or the vessel in which things are carried away.

AWARDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Award

AWKWARD
 (a.) Not easily managed or effected; embarrassing.

AZORIAN
 (n.) A native of the Azores.

AZOTITE
 (n.) A salt formed by the combination of azotous, or nitrous, acid with a base; a nitrite.

AZOTOUS
 (a.) Nitrous; as, azotous acid.

AZYGOUS
 (a.) Odd; having no fellow; not one of a pair; single; as, the azygous muscle of the uvula.

AZYMOUS
 (a.) Unleavened; unfermented.

BAALIST
 (n.) Alt. of Baalite

BABBLER
 (n.) An idle talker; an irrational prater; a teller of secrets.

BABYING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Baby

BABYISM
 (n.) The state of being a baby.

BACCARA
 (n.) Alt. of Baccarat

BACKING
 (n.) The preparation of the back of a book with glue, etc., before putting on the cover.

BACKSAW
 (n.) A saw (as a tenon saw) whose blade is stiffened by an added metallic back.

BADIAGA
 (n.) A fresh-water sponge (Spongilla), common in the north of Europe, the powder of which is used to take away the livid marks of bruises.

BAGGAGE
 (n.) A man of bad character.

BAGGILY
 (adv.) In a loose, baggy way.

BAGPIPE
 (n.) A musical wind instrument, now used chiefly in the Highlands of Scotland.

BAILING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bail

BAJOCCO
 (n.) A small copper coin formerly current in the Roman States, worth about a cent and a half.

BALANCE
 (n.) An apparatus for weighing.

BALANCE
 (n.) A balance wheel, as of a watch, or clock. See Balance wheel (in the Vocabulary).

BALANCE
 (n.) To settle and adjust, as an account; to make two accounts equal by paying the difference between them.

BALANCE
 (v. i.) To have equal weight on each side; to be in equipoise; as, the scales balance.

BALCONY
 (n.) A projecting gallery once common at the stern of large ships.

BALDRIC
 (n.) A broad belt, sometimes richly ornamented, worn over one shoulder, across the breast, and under the opposite arm; less properly, any belt.

BALKISH
 (a.) Uneven; ridgy.

BALLADE
 (n.) A form of French versification, sometimes imitated in English, in which three or four rhymes recur through three stanzas of eight or ten lines each, the stanzas concluding with a refrain, and the whole poem with an envoy.

BALLAST
 (a.) Fig.: That which gives, or helps to maintain, uprightness, steadiness, and security.

BALLAST
 (v. t.) To keep steady; to steady, morally.

BALLOON
 (v. t.) To take up in, or as if in, a balloon.

BANDAGE
 (n.) Something resembling a bandage; that which is bound over or round something to cover, strengthen, or compress it; a ligature.

BANDEAU
 (n.) A narrow band or fillet; a part of a head-dress.

BANDROL
 (n.) A little banner, flag, or streamer.

BANDORE
 (n.) A musical stringed instrument, similar in form to a guitar; a pandore.

BAPTIST
 (n.) One who administers baptism; -- specifically applied to John, the forerunner of Christ.

BARBARA
 (n.) The first word in certain mnemonic lines which represent the various forms of the syllogism. It indicates a syllogism whose three propositions are universal affirmatives.

BARBATE
 (a.) Bearded; beset with long and weak hairs.

BARGAIN
 (n.) A purchase; also ( when not qualified), a gainful transaction; an advantageous purchase; as, to buy a thing at a bargain.

BARGAIN
 (v. t.) To transfer for a consideration; to barter; to trade; as, to bargain one horse for another.

BARILLA
 (n.) The alkali produced from the plant, being an impure carbonate of soda, used for making soap, glass, etc., and for bleaching purposes.

BARKERY
 (n.) A tanhouse.

BARMAID
 (n.) A girl or woman who attends the customers of a bar, as in a tavern or beershop.

BARMOTE
 (n.) A court held in Derbyshire, in England, for deciding controversies between miners.

BARRAGE
 (n.) An artificial bar or obstruction placed in a river or water course to increase the depth of water; as, the barrages of the Nile.

BARRIER
 (n.) A fence or railing to mark the limits of a place, or to keep back a crowd.

BARTERY
 (n.) Barter.

BASENET
 (n.) See Bascinet.

BASHFUL
 (a.) Abashed; daunted; dismayed.

BASHYLE
 (n.) See Basyle.

BASILIC
 (n.) Basilica.

BASKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bask

BASTARD
 (n.) A natural child; a child begotten and born out of wedlock; an illegitimate child; one born of an illicit union.

BASTARD
 (a.) Begotten and born out of lawful matrimony; illegitimate. See Bastard, n., note.

BASTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Baste

BATABLE
 (a.) Disputable.

BATTERY
 (v. t.) A company or division of artillery, including the gunners, guns, horses, and all equipments. In the United States, a battery of flying artillery consists usually of six guns.

BATTERY
 (v. t.) The box in which the stamps for crushing ore play up and down.

BAVAROY
 (n.) A kind of cloak or surtout.

BAWDILY
 (adv.) Obscenely; lewdly.

BAYATTE
 (n.) A large, edible, siluroid fish of the Nile, of two species (Bagrina bayad and B. docmac).

BAYONET
 (n.) A pointed instrument of the dagger kind fitted on the muzzle of a musket or rifle, so as to give the soldier increased means of offense and defense.

BAYONET
 (v. t.) To compel or drive by the bayonet.

BEADING
 (n.) The beads or bead-forming quality of certain liquors; as, the beading of a brand of whisky.

BEAMING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Beam

BEAMFUL
 (a.) Beamy; radiant.

BEARDIE
 (n.) The bearded loach (Nemachilus barbatus) of Europe.

BEARING
 (n.) Purport; meaning; intended significance; aspect.

BEARING
 (n.) The part of an axle or shaft in contact with its support, collar, or boxing; the journal.

BEARING
 (n.) The line of flotation of a vessel when properly trimmed with cargo or ballast.

BEASTLY
 (a.) Characterizing the nature of a beast; contrary to the nature and dignity of man; brutal; filthy.

BEATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Beat

BEATING
 (n.) Pulsation; throbbing; as, the beating of the heart.

BECAUSE
 (conj.) In order that; that.

BECLOUD
 (v. t.) To cause obscurity or dimness to; to dim; to cloud.

BEDDING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bed

BEDDING
 (n.) A bed and its furniture; the materials of a bed, whether for man or beast; bedclothes; litter.

BEDIGHT
 (v. t.) To bedeck; to array or equip; to adorn.

BEDOUIN
 (a.) Pertaining to the Bedouins; nomad.

BEDROOM
 (n.) A room or apartment intended or used for a bed; a lodging room.

BEDSITE
 (n.) A recess in a room for a bed.

BEDTICK
 (n.) A tick or bag made of cloth, used for inclosing the materials of a bed.

BEDWARF
 (v. t.) To make a dwarf of; to stunt or hinder the growth of; to dwarf.

BEGGARY
 (n.) Beggarly appearance.

BEGRIME
 (v. t.) To soil with grime or dirt deeply impressed or rubbed in.

BEGUINE
 (n.) A woman belonging to one of the religious and charitable associations or communities in the Netherlands, and elsewhere, whose members live in beguinages and are not bound by perpetual vows.

BEHAVED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Behave

BEHIGHT
 (imp.) of Behight

BEHIGHT
 (v.) To adjudge; to assign by authority.

BEHIGHT
 (n.) A vow; a promise.

BELATED
 (a.) Delayed beyond the usual time; too late; overtaken by night; benighted.

BELEAVE
 (v. t. & i.) To leave or to be left.

BELGIAN
 (n.) A native or inhabitant of Belgium.

BELIBEL
 (v. t.) To libel or traduce; to calumniate.

BELIMED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Belime

BELLMAN
 (n.) A man who rings a bell, especially to give notice of anything in the streets. Formerly, also, a night watchman who called the hours.

BELOVED
 (n.) One greatly loved.

BELSIRE
 (n.) A grandfather, or ancestor.

BELTANE
 (n.) The first day of May (Old Style).

BELTEIN
 (n.) Alt. of Beltin

BENEMPT
 () of Bename

BENCHER
 (n.) An alderman of a corporation.

BENDING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bend

BENEATH
 (adv.) In a lower place; underneath.

BENEFIT
 (n.) A theatrical performance, a concert, or the like, the proceeds of which do not go to the lessee of the theater or to the company, but to some individual actor, or to some charitable use.

BENEFIT
 (v. t.) To be beneficial to; to do good to; to advantage; to advance in health or prosperity; to be useful to; to profit.

BENEMPT
 (p. p.) Named; styled.

BENGOLA
 (n.) A Bengal light.

BENIGHT
 (v. t.) To involve in moral darkness, or ignorance; to debar from intellectual light.

BENZENE
 (n.) A volatile, very inflammable liquid, C6H6, contained in the naphtha produced by the destructive distillation of coal, from which it is separated by fractional distillation. The name is sometimes applied also to the impure commercial product or benz

BENZOIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or obtained from, benzoin.

BENZOLE

CHALKED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Chalk

CHAMBER
 (n.) A compartment or cell; an inclosed space or cavity; as, the chamber of a canal lock; the chamber of a furnace; the chamber of the eye.

CHAMBER
 (n.) A short piece of ordnance or cannon, which stood on its breech, without any carriage, formerly used chiefly for rejoicings and theatrical cannonades.

CHAMBER
 (v. t.) To shut up, as in a chamber.

CHAMECK
 (n.) A kind of spider monkey (Ateles chameck), having the thumbs rudimentary and without a nail.

CHAMPED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Champ

CHAMPER
 (n.) One who champs, or bites.

CHANCRE
 (n.) A venereal sore or ulcer; specifically, the initial lesion of T syphilis, whether forming a distinct ulcer or not; -- called also hard chancre, indurated chancre, and Hunterian chancre.

CHANDRY
 (n.) Chandlery.

CHANNEL
 (n.) The hollow bed where a stream of water runs or may run.

CHANNEL
 (n.) Flat ledges of heavy plank bolted edgewise to the outside of a vessel, to increase the spread of the shrouds and carry them clear of the bulwarks.

CHANNEL
 (v. t.) To form a channel in; to cut or wear a channel or channels in; to groove.

CHANTER
 (n.) The chief singer of the chantry.

CHANTRY
 (n.) A chapel or altar so endowed.

CHAOTIC
 (a.) Resembling chaos; confused.

CHAPLET
 (n.) A garland or wreath to be worn on the head.

CHAPMAN
 (n.) One who buys and sells; a merchant; a buyer or a seller.

CHAPTER
 (n.) An assembly of monks, or of the prebends and other clergymen connected with a cathedral, conventual, or collegiate church, or of a diocese, usually presided over by the dean.

CHAPTER
 (n.) A meeting of certain organized societies or orders.

CHAPTER
 (v. t.) To correct; to bring to book, i. e., to demand chapter and verse.

CHARGER
 (n.) A horse for battle or parade.

CHARIOT
 (n.) A four-wheeled pleasure or state carriage, having one seat.

CHARITY
 (n.) Whatever is bestowed gratuitously on the needy or suffering for their relief; alms; any act of kindness.

CHARKED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Chark

CHARMER
 (n.) One who charms, or has power to charm; one who uses the power of enchantment; a magician.

CHARTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Chart

CHARTER
 (n.) The letting or hiring a vessel by special contract, or the contract or instrument whereby a vessel is hired or let; as, a ship is offered for sale or charter. See Charter party, below.

CHASSIS
 (n.) A traversing base frame, or movable railway, along which the carriage of a barbette or casemate gun moves backward and forward. [See Gun carriage.]

CHASTEN
 (v. t.) To purify from errors or faults; to refine.

CHATEUX
 (pl. ) of Chateau

CHATTEL
 (n.) Any item of movable or immovable property except the freehold, or the things which are parcel of it. It is a more extensive term than goods or effects.

CHATTER
 (v. i.) To talk idly, carelessly, or with undue rapidity; to jabber; to prate.

CHEAPLY
 (adv.) At a small price; at a low value; in a common or inferior manner.

CHEATER
 (n.) One who cheats.

CHECKER
 (v. t.) A pattern in checks; a single check.

CHEDDAR
 (a.) Of or pertaining to, or made at, Cheddar, in England; as, Cheddar cheese.

CHEEPED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Cheep

CHEKMAK
 (n.) A turkish fabric of silk and cotton, with gold thread interwoven.

CHEMISM
 (n.) The force exerted between the atoms of elementary substance whereby they unite to form chemical compounds; chemical attaction; affinity; -- sometimes used as a general expression for chemical activity or relationship.

CHERUBS
 (pl. ) of Cherub

CHEVIOT
 (n.) A valuable breed of mountain sheep in Scotland, which takes its name from the Cheviot hills.

CHEVRON
 (n.) A zigzag molding, or group of moldings, common in Norman architecture.

CHIASMA
 (n.) A commissure; especially, the optic commissure, or crucial union of the optic nerves.

CHIBOUK
 (n.) A Turkish pipe, usually with a mouthpiece of amber, a stem, four or five feet long and not pliant, of some valuable wood, and a bowl of baked clay.

CHICANE
 (n.) The use of artful subterfuge, designed to draw away attention from the merits of a case or question; -- specifically applied to legal proceedings; trickery; chicanery; caviling; sophistry.

CHICHES
 (pl. ) of Chich

CHIKARA
 (n.) The Indian four-horned antelope (Tetraceros quadricornis).

CHILDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Child

CHILDLY
 (adv.) Like a child.

CHILIAD
 (n.) A thousand; the aggregate of a thousand things; especially, a period of a thousand years.

CHILIAN
 (n.) Alt. of Chiliarch

CHIMERE
 (n.) The upper robe worn by a bishop, to which lawn sleeves are usually attached.

CHINESE
 (n. sing. & pl.) The language of China, which is monosyllabic.

CHINONE
 (n.) See Quinone.

CHINSED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Chinse

CHIPPER
 (a.) Lively; cheerful; talkative.

CHIRRUP
 (n.) The act of chirping; a chirp.

CHISLEY
 (a.) Having a large admixture of small pebbles or gravel; -- said of a soil.

CHLORAL
 (n.) A colorless oily liquid, CCl3.CHO, of a pungent odor and harsh taste, obtained by the action of chlorine upon ordinary or ethyl alcohol.

CHLORIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or obtained from, chlorine; -- said of those compounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of five, or the next to its highest; as, chloric acid, HClO3.

CHOKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Choke

CHOLEIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or obtained from, bile; as, choleic acid.

CHOLINE
 (n.) See Neurine.

CHORDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Chord

CHORDAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a chord.

CHORING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Chore

CHORION
 (n.) The outer membrane of seeds of plants.

CHUCKLE
 (v. t.) To call, as a hen her chickens; to cluck.

CHURRUS
 (n.) A powerfully narcotic and intoxicating gum resin which exudes from the flower heads, seeds, etc., of Indian hemp.

CHUTNEY
 (n.) Alt. of Chutnee

CILIATE
 (a.) Alt. of Ciliated

CIPOLIN
 (n.) A whitish marble, from Rome, containiing pale greenish zones. It consists of calcium carbonate, with zones and cloudings of talc.

CIRCLET
 (n.) A circular piece of wood put under a dish at table.

CIRCUIT
 (n.) The space inclosed within a circle, or within limits.

CIRCUIT
 (v. i.) To move in a circle; to go round; to circulate.

CIRROUS
 (a.) Tufted; -- said of certain feathers of birds.

CITATOR
 (n.) One who cites.

CITIZEN
 (n.) A person, native or naturalized, of either sex, who owes allegiance to a government, and is entitled to reciprocal protection from it.

CLACHAN
 (n.) A small village containing a church.

CLACKER
 (n.) One who clacks; that which clacks; especially, the clapper of a mill.

CLAMBER
 (v. i.) To climb with difficulty, or with hands and feet; -- also used figuratively.

CLAMPED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Clamp

CLARIFY
 (v. i.) To grow or become clear or transparent; to become free from feculent impurities, as wine or other liquid under clarification.

CLARION
 (n.) A kind of trumpet, whose note is clear and shrill.

CLASHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Clash

CLASPER
 (n.) One who, or that which, clasps, as a tendril.

CLASSIC
 (n.) Alt. of Classical

CLASSIC
 (n.) One learned in the literature of Greece and Rome, or a student of classical literature.

CLASSIS
 (n.) An ecclesiastical body or judicatory in certain churches, as the Reformed Dutch. It is intermediate between the consistory and the synod, and corresponds to the presbytery in the Presbyterian church.

CLASTIC
 (a.) Pertaining to what may be taken apart; as, clastic anatomy (of models).

CLATTER
 (n.) Commotion; disturbance.

CLAVATE
 (a.) Alt. of Clavated

CLAVIER
 (n.) The keyboard of an organ, pianoforte, or harmonium.

CLEANED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Clean

CLEANLY
 (superl.) Adroit; skillful; dexterous; artful.

CLEARED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Clear

CLEARER
 (n.) One who, or that which, clears.

CLEMENT
 (a.) Mild in temper and disposition; merciful; compassionate.

YCLEPED
 () of Clepe

CLICKET
 (n.) A latch key.

CLIMATE
 (v. i.) One of thirty regions or zones, parallel to the equator, into which the surface of the earth from the equator to the pole was divided, according to the successive increase of the length of the midsummer day.

CLIMBER
 (n.) One who, or that which, climbs

CLINKER
 (n.) A mass composed of several bricks run together by the action of the fire in the kiln.

CLIPPED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Clip

CLIPPER
 (n.) A vessel with a sharp bow, built and rigged for fast sailing.

CLIVERS
 (n.) See Cleavers.

CLUBBED

 (imp. & p. p.) of Cluck

CLUMPER
 (n.) To form into clumps or masses.

CLUSTER
 (n.) A number of similar things collected together or lying contiguous; a group; as, a cluster of islands.

CLUSTER
 (v. t.) To collect into a cluster or clusters; to gather into a bunch or close body.

CLYPEUS
 (n.) The frontal plate of the head of an insect.

COATING

COBBLER
 (n.) A mender of shoes.

COBWALL
 (n.) A wall made of clay mixed with straw.

COCAGNE
 (n.) The land of cockneys; cockneydom; -- a term applied to London and its suburbs.

COCKEYE
 (n.) The socket in the ball of a millstone, which sits on the cockhead.

COCKING
 (n.) Cockfighting.

COCKLER
 (n.) One who takes and sells cockles.

COCKPIT
 (n.) The Privy Council room at Westminster; -- so called because built on the site of the cockpit of Whitehall palace.

COCTION
 (n.) Digestion.

CODDLED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Coddle

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cog

COGNATE
 (n.) One of a number of things allied in origin or nature; as, certain letters are cognates.

COHABIT
 (v.) To inhabit or reside in company, or in the same place or country.

COHERED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Cohere

COALTIT
 (n.) A small European titmouse (Parus ater), so named from its black color; -- called also coalmouse and colemouse.

COLLATE
 (v. t.) To gather and place in order, as the sheets of a book for binding.

COLLECT
 (v. t.) To infer from observed facts; to conclude from premises.

COLLEGE
 (n.) A building, or number of buildings, used by a college.

COLLOID
 (n.) A substance (as albumin, gum, gelatin, etc.) which is of a gelatinous rather than a crystalline nature, and which diffuses itself through animal membranes or vegetable parchment more slowly than crystalloids do; -- opposed to crystalloid.

COLONEL
 (n.) The chief officer of a regiment; an officer ranking next above a lieutenant colonel and next below a brigadier general.

COLORED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Color

COLORED
 (a.) Of some other color than green.

COLUMBA
 (n.) See Calumba.

COMBINE
 (v. i.) In the game of casino, to play a card which will take two or more cards whose aggregate number of pips equals those of the card played.

COMBING
 (n.) That which is caught or collected with a comb, as loose, tangled hair.

COMBUST
 (a.) Burnt; consumed.

COMFORT
 (n.) Assistance; relief; support.

COMFREY
 (n.) A rough, hairy, perennial plant of several species, of the genus Symphytum.

COMICAL
 (a.) Exciting mirth; droll; laughable; as, a comical story.

COMMAND
 (v. t.) To direct to come; to bestow.

COMMAND
 (n.) Authority; power or right of control; leadership; as, the forces under his command.

COMMEND
 (v. t.) To mention by way of courtesy, implying remembrance and good will.

COMMENT
 (v. i.) To make remarks, observations, or criticism; especially, to write notes on the works of an author, with a view to illustrate his meaning, or to explain particular passages; to write annotations; -- often followed by on or upon.

COMMODE
 (n.) A chest of drawers or a bureau.

COMMONS
 (n. pl.) The House of Commons, or lower house of the British Parliament, consisting of representatives elected by the qualified voters of counties, boroughs, and universities.

COMMOVE
 (v. t.) To put in motion; to disturb; to unsettle.

COMMUNE
 (n.) The commonalty; the common people.

COMPACT
 (p. p. & a) Brief; close; pithy; not diffuse; not verbose; as, a compact discourse.

COMPACT
 (n.) An agreement between parties; a covenant or contract.

COMPANY
 (n.) Guests or visitors, in distinction from the members of a family; as, to invite company to dine.

COMPANY
 (v. i.) To associate.

COMPARE
 (v. i.) To be like or equal; to admit, or be worthy of, comparison; as, his later work does not compare with his earlier.

COMPART
 (v. t.) To divide; to mark out into parts or subdivisions.

COMPASS
 (n.) A passing round; circuit; circuitous course.

COMPASS
 (n.) The range of notes, or tones, within the capacity of a voice or instrument.

COMPASS
 (v. t.) To purpose; to intend; to imagine; to plot.

COMPEAR
 (v. i.) To appear.

COMPEIR
 (v. i.) See Compear.

COMPEND
 (n.) A compendium; an epitome; a summary.

COMPLEX
 (n.) Involving many parts; complicated; intricate.

COMPLOT
 (n.) A plotting together; a confederacy in some evil design; a conspiracy.

COMPONE
 (a.) See Compony.

COMPORT
 (v. t.) To carry; to conduct; -- with a reflexive pronoun.

COMPOSE
 (v. t.) To construct by mental labor; to design and execute, or put together, in a manner involving the adaptation of forms of expression to ideas, or to the laws of harmony or proportion; as, to compose a sentence, a sermon, a symphony, or a picture.

COMPOST
 (v. t.) To mingle, as different fertilizing substances, in a mass where they will decompose and form into a compost.

COMTISM
 (n.) Positivism; the positive philosophy. See Positivism.

CONACRE
 (n.) Also used adjectively; as, the conacre system or principle.

CONCAVE
 (a.) Hollow and curved or rounded; vaulted; -- said of the interior of a curved surface or line, as of the curve of the of the inner surface of an eggshell, in opposition to convex; as, a concave mirror; the concave arch of the sky.

CONCEDE
 (v. t.) To grant, as a right or privilege; to make concession of.

CONCEIT
 (n.) Quickness of apprehension; active imagination; lively fancy.

CONCEIT
 (v. i.) To form an idea; to think.

CONCERN
 (v. i.) To be of importance.

CONCERT
 (v. t.) To plan together; to settle or adjust by conference, agreement, or consultation.

CONCERT
 (v. t.) A musical entertainment in which several voices or instruments take part.

CONCOCT
 (v. t.) To digest; to convert into nourishment by the organs of nutrition.

CONCORD
 (n.) A state of agreement; harmony; union.

CONCORD
 (n.) A variety of American grape, with large dark blue (almost black) grapes in compact clusters.

CONCUSS
 (v. t.) To force (a person) to do something, or give up something, by intimidation; to coerce.

CONDEMN
 (v. t.) To declare the guilt of; to make manifest the faults or unworthiness of; to convict of guilt.

CONDIGN
 (a.) Deserved; adequate; suitable to the fault or crime.

CONDOLE
 (v. i.) To express sympathetic sorrow; to grieve in sympathy; -- followed by with.

CONDONE
 (v. t.) To pardon; to forgive.

CONDUCT
 (n.) To lead, as a commander; to direct; to manage; to carry on; as, to conduct the affairs of a kingdom.

CONDYLE
 (n.) A bony prominence; particularly, an eminence at the end of a bone bearing a rounded articular surface; -- sometimes applied also to a concave articular surface.

CONFECT
 (n.) A comfit; a confection.

CONFESS
 (v. t.) To acknowledge faith in; to profess belief in.

CONFESS
 (v. i.) To make confession; to disclose sins or faults, or the state of the conscience.

CONFINE
 (n.) Common boundary; border; limit; -- used chiefly in the plural.

CONFIRM
 (v. t.) To make firm or firmer; to add strength to; to establish; as, health is confirmed by exercise.

CONFUSE
 (v. t.) To perplex; to disconcert; to abash; to cause to lose self-possession.

CONFUTE
 (v. t.) To overwhelm by argument; to refute conclusively; to prove or show to be F or defective; to overcome; to silence.

CONGIUS
 (n.) A liquid measure containing about three quarts.

CONGRUE
 (v. i.) To agree; to be suitable.

CONICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a cone; as, conic sections.

CONIFER
 (n.) A tree or shrub bearing cones; one of the order Coniferae, which includes the pine, cypress, and (according to some) the yew.

CONIINE
 (n.) See Conine.

CONJURY
 (n.) The practice of magic; enchantment.

CONNECT
 (v. t.) To join, or fasten together, as by something intervening; to associate; to combine; to unite or link together; to establish a bond or relation between.

CONNIVE
 (v. i.) To close the eyes upon a fault; to wink (at); to fail or forbear by intention to discover an act; to permit a proceeding, as if not aware of it; -- usually followed by at.

CONNOTE
 (v. t.) To mark along with; to suggest or indicate as additional; to designate by implication; to include in the meaning; to imply.

CONQUER
 (v. t.) To gain or obtain, overcoming obstacles in the way; to win; as, to conquer freedom; to conquer a peace.

CONSENT
 (v. i.) To agree in opinion or sentiment; to be of the same mind; to accord; to concur.

CONSENT
 (n.) Voluntary accordance with, or concurrence in, what is done or proposed by another; acquiescence; compliance; approval; permission.

CONSIGN
 (v. t.) To assign; to devote; to set apart.

CONSIST
 (v. i.) To have as its substance or character, or as its foundation; to be; -- followed by in.

CONSOLE
 (v. t.) To cheer in distress or depression; to alleviate the grief and raise the spirits of; to relieve; to comfort; to soothe.

CONSORT
 (n.) Concurrence; conjunction; combination; association; union.

CONSORT
 (v. i.) To unite or to keep company; to associate; -- used with with.

CONSULT
 (n.) Agreement; concert

CONTACT
 (n.) The plane between two adjacent bodies of dissimilar rock.

CONTEND
 (v. t.) To struggle for; to contest.

CONTENT
 (a.) Contained within limits; hence, having the desires limited by that which one has; not disposed to repine or grumble; satisfied; contented; at rest.

CONTENT
 (a.) To satisfy the desires of; to make easy in any situation; to appease or quiet; to gratify; to please.

CONTENT
 (n.) An expression of assent to a bill or motion; an affirmative vote; also, a member who votes Content..

CONTEST
 (v. i.) To engage in contention, or emulation; to contend; to strive; to vie; to emulate; -- followed usually by with.

CONTEXT
 (n.) The part or parts of something written or printed, as of Scripture, which precede or follow a text or quoted sentence, or are so intimately associated with it as to throw light upon its meaning.

CONTOUR
 (n.) The outline of a figure or body, or the line or lines representing such an outline; the line that bounds; periphery.

CONVENT
 (v. i.) To meet together; to concur.

CONVERT
 (v. t.) To produce the spiritual change called conversion in (any one); to turn from a bad life to a good one; to change the heart and moral character of (any one) from the controlling power of sin to that of holiness.

CONVERT
 (v. i.) To be turned or changed in character or direction; to undergo a change, physically or morally.

CONVIVE
 (n.) A quest at a banquet.

 (p. pr & vb. n.) of Cook

CORANTO

CORDIAL

CORDIAL

CORKAGE

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Corn

CORNAGE

 (a.) Of or pertaining to the shell of a sea urchin.

CORONET

CORONIS

COROSSO

CORPORA
 (pl. ) of Corpus

CORRADE
 (v. t.) To erode, as the bed of a stream. See Corrosion.

CORRECT
 (a.) Set right, or made straight; hence, conformable to truth, rectitude, or propriety, or to a just standard; not faulty or imperfect; free from error; as, correct behavior; correct views.

CORRECT
 (v. t.) To bring back, or attempt to bring back, to propriety in morals; to reprove or punish for faults or deviations from moral rectitude; to chastise; to discipline; as, a child should be corrected for lying.

CORRODE
 (v. t.) To consume; to wear away; to prey upon; to impair.

CORRUMP
 (v. t.) To corrupt. See Corrupt.

CORRUPT
 (v. t.) To debase or render impure by alterations or innovations; to falsify; as, to corrupt language; to corrupt the sacred text.

CORSAIR
 (n.) A piratical vessel.

CORTILE
 (n.) An open internal courtyard inclosed by the walls of a large dwelling house or other large and stately building.

COUNSEL

COUNTER

COUNTER
 (adv.) At or against the front or face.

COUNTER
 (adv.) The back leather or heel part of a boot.

COUNTRY
 (adv.) Rural regions, as opposed to a city or town.

COUNTRY
 (a.) Pertaining to the regions remote from a city; rural; rustic; as, a country life; a country town; the country party, as opposed to city.

CRABBED
 (n.) Obscure; difficult; perplexing; trying; as, a crabbed author.

CRACKED
 (a.) Crack-brained.

CRACKER
 (n.) A nickname to designate a poor white in some parts of the Southern United States.

CRACKLE
 (n.) A kind of crackling sound or r/le, heard in some abnormal states of the lungs; as, dry crackle; moist crackle.

CRAMMER
 (n.) One who crams; esp., one who prepares a pupil hastily for an examination, or a pupil who is thus prepared.

CRANNOG
 (n.) Alt. of Crannoge

CRAPPIE
 (n.) A kind of fresh-water bass of the genus Pomoxys, found in the rivers of the Southern United States and Mississippi valley. There are several species.

CREASER
 (n.) A tool for making the band impression distinct on the back.

CREEPER
 (n.) A spurlike device strapped to the boot, which enables one to climb a tree or pole; -- called often telegraph creepers.

CRENATE
 (a.) Alt. of Crenated

CRESTED
 (a.) Bearing any elevated appendage like a crest, as an elevated line or ridge, or a tuft.

 (n.) A coarse sieve or screen.

CRIBBLE
 (a.) Coarse; as, cribble bread.

CRICKET
 (n.) An orthopterous insect of the genus Gryllus, and allied genera. The males make chirping, musical notes by rubbing together the basal parts of the veins of the front wings.

CRIMPED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Crimp

CRIMPER
 (n.) A curved board or frame over which the upper of a boot or shoe is stretched to the required shape.

CRIMPLE
 (v. t.) To cause to shrink or draw together; to contract; to curl.

CRINKLE
 (n.) A winding or turn; wrinkle; sinuosity.

CRINOSE
 (a.) Hairy.

CRIPPLE
 (a.) Lame; halting.

CROAKED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Croak

CROESUS
 (n.) A king of Lydia who flourished in the 6th century b. c., and was renowned for his vast wealth; hence, a common appellation for a very rich man; as, he is a veritable Croesus.

CROOKED
 (a.) Characterized by a crook or curve; not straight; turning; bent; twisted; deformed.

CROOKEN
 (v. t.) To make crooked.

CROPFUL
 (a.) Having a full crop or belly; satiated.

CROUPER
 (n.) See Crupper.

CROWNED
 (p. p. & a.) Having or wearing a crown; surmounted, invested, or adorned, with a crown, wreath, garland, etc.; honored; rewarded; completed; consummated; perfected.

CROWNET
 (n.) The ultimate end and result of an undertaking; a chief end.

CROWTOE
 (n.) The Lotus corniculatus.

CROZIER
 (n.) See Crosier.

CRUCIFY
 (v. t.) To destroy the power or ruling influence of; to subdue completely; to mortify.

CRUDITY
 (n.) That which is in a crude or undigested state; hence, superficial, undigested views, not reduced to order or form.

CRUISED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Cruise

CRUISER
 (n.) One who, or a vessel that, cruises; -- usually an armed vessel.

CRUMBLY
 (a.) EAsily crumbled; friable; brittle.

CRUMPLE
 (v. t.) To draw or press into wrinkles or folds; to crush together; to rumple; as, to crumple paper.

CRUNKLE
 (v. i.) To cry like a crane.

CRUSADE
 (n.) Any one of the military expeditions undertaken by Christian powers, in the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries, for the recovery of the Holy Land from the Mohammedans.

CRUSADE
 (v. i.) To engage in a crusade; to attack in a zealous or hot-headed manner.

CRYPTIC
 (a.) Alt. of Cryptical

CRYSTAL
 (n.) The glass over the dial of a watch case.

CTENOID
 (a.) Having a comblike margin, as a ctenoid scale

CUBITAL
 (n.) A sleeve covering the arm from the elbow to the hand.

CUDBEAR
 (n.) A lichen (Lecanora tartarea), from which the powder is obtained.

CUDWEED
 (n.) A small composite plant with cottony or silky stem and leaves, primarily a species of Gnaphalium, but the name is now given to many plants of different genera, as Filago, Antennaria, etc.; cottonweed.

CUINAGE
 (n.) The stamping of pigs of tin, by the proper officer, with the arms of the duchy of Cornwall.

CUISINE
 (n.) Manner or style of cooking.

CULLION
 (n.) A mean wretch; a base fellow; a poltroon; a scullion.

CULPRIT
 (p. p.) One accused of, or arraigned for, a crime, as before a judge.

CULTURE
 (n.) The act of, or any labor or means employed for, training, disciplining, or refining the moral and intellectual nature of man; as, the culture of the mind.

CUMINOL
 (n.) A liquid, C3H7.C6H4.CHO, obtained from oil of caraway; -- called also cuminic aldehyde.

CUNNING
 (a.) Pretty or pleasing; as, a cunning little boy.

CUPROUS
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper; -- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is present in its highest proportion.

CURACAO
 (n.) Alt. of Curacoa

CURATOR
 (n.) One appointed to act as guardian of the estate of a person not legally competent to manage it, or of an absentee; a trustee; a guardian.

CURBING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Curb

CURIOUS
 (a.) Exhibiting care or nicety; artfully constructed; elaborate; wrought with elegance or skill.

CURRANT
 (n.) A small kind of seedless raisin, imported from the Levant, chiefly from Zante and Cephalonia; -- used in cookery.

CURRENT
 (a.) Now passing, as time; as, the current month.

CURRENT
 (a.) General course; ordinary procedure; progressive and connected movement; as, the current of time, of events, of opinion, etc.

CURRIED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Curry

CURSHIP
 (n.) The state of being a cur; one who is currish.

CURSIVE
 (n.) A character used in cursive writing.

CURSORY
 (a.) Running about; not stationary.

CURTAIL
 (n.) The scroll termination of any architectural member, as of a step, etc.

CURTAIN
 (n.) That part of a wall of a building which is between two pavilions, towers, etc.

CUSHION
 (n.) a mass of steam in the end of the cylinder of a steam engine to receive the impact of the piston

CUSHION
 (v. t.) To seat or place on, or as on a cushion.

CUTAWAY
 (a.) Having a part cut off or away; having the corners rounded or cut away.

CUTTING
 (a.) Severe; sarcastic; biting; as, a cutting reply.

CUVETTE
 (n.) A small vessel with at least two flat and transparent sides, used to hold a liquid sample to be analysed in the light path of a spectrometer.

CYANEAN
 (a.) Having an azure color.

CYANINE
 (n.) One of a series of artificial blue or red dyes obtained from quinoline and lepidine and used in calico printing.

CYCLOID
 (n.) A curve generated by a point in the plane of a circle when the circle is rolled along a straight line, keeping always in the same plane.

CYMBIUM
 (n.) A genus of marine univalve shells; the gondola.

CYNICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to the Dog Star; as, the cynic, or Sothic, year; cynic cycle.

CYPRAEA
 (n.) A genus of mollusks, including the cowries. See Cowrie.

CYPRIAN
 (a.) Of, pertaining, or conducing to, lewdness.

CYSTOSE
 (a.) Containing, or resembling, a cyst or cysts; cystic; bladdery.

DACOITY
 (n.) The practice of gang robbery in India; robbery committed by dacoits.

DAHLIAS
 (pl. ) of Dahlia

 (pl. ) of Daily

 (pl. ) of Daisy

 (imp. & p. p.) of Dally

 (imp. & p. p.) of Dandle

 (n.) One who dandles or fondles.

DANKISH
 (a.) Somewhat dank.

DANTEAN
 (a.) Relating to, emanating from or resembling, the poet Dante or his writings.

DAPHNIN
 (n.) A white, crystalline, bitter substance, regarded as a glucoside, and extracted from Daphne mezereum and D. alpina.

DARREIN
 (a.) Last; as, darrein continuance, the last continuance.

DASHPOT
 (n.) A pneumatic or hydraulic cushion for a falling weight, as in the valve gear of a steam engine, to prevent shock.

DATABLE
 (a.) That may be dated; having a known or ascertainable date.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Deal

 (n.) The office or the revenue of a dean. See the Note under Benefice, n., 3.

DEBASED
 (a.) Turned upside down from its proper position; inverted; reversed.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Debate

DEBEIGE
 (n.) A kind of woolen or mixed dress goods.

DEBITED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Debit

DECIMAL
 (n.) A number expressed in the scale of tens; specifically, and almost exclusively, used as synonymous with a decimal fraction.

DECLINE
 (v. i.) To tend or draw towards a close, decay, or extinction; to tend to a less perfect state; to become diminished or impaired; to fail; to sink; to diminish; to lessen; as, the day declines; virtue declines; religion declines; business declines.

DECLINE
 (v. t.) To put or turn aside; to turn off or away from; to refuse to undertake or comply with; reject; to shun; to avoid; as, to decline an offer; to decline a contest; he declined any participation with them.

DECLINE
 (v. i.) A gradual sinking and wasting away of the physical faculties; any wasting disease, esp. pulmonary consumption; as, to die of a decline.

DECUPLE
 (n.) A number ten times repeated.

DEDIMUS
 (n.) A writ to commission private persons to do some act in place of a judge, as to examine a witness, etc.

DEFACED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Deface

DEFAULT
 (n.) A neglect of, or failure to take, some step necessary to secure the benefit of law, as a failure to appear in court at a day assigned, especially of the defendant in a suit when called to make answer; also of jurors, witnesses, etc.

DEFAULT
 (v. i.) To fail to appear in court; to let a case go by default.

DEFENCE
 (n.) That which defends or protects; anything employed to oppose attack, ward off violence or danger, or maintain security; a guard; a protection.

DEFENSE
 (v. t.) To furnish with defenses; to fortify.

DEFILED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Defile

DEFLATE
 (v. t.) To reduce from an inflated condition.

DEFLOUR
 (v. t.) To take away the prime beauty and grace of; to rob of the choicest ornament.

DEGRADE
 (v. i.) To degenerate; to pass from a higher to a lower type of structure; as, a family of plants or animals degrades through this or that genus or group of genera.

DEICIDE
 (n.) The act of killing a being of a divine nature; particularly, the putting to death of Jesus Christ.

DEIFORM
 (a.) Conformable to the will of God.

DEITATE
 (a.) Deified.

DELAPSE
 (v. i.) To pass down by inheritance; to lapse.

DELENDA
 (n. pl.) Things to be erased or blotted out.

DELIVER
 (v. t.) To give forth in action or exercise; to discharge; as, to deliver a blow; to deliver a broadside, or a ball.

DELIVER

 (a.) Alt. of Delphine

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Delve

 (imp. & p. p.) of Denote

 (n.) The quality of being dense, close, or thick; compactness; -- opposed to rarity.

 (a.) Last; final.

 (n.) Alt. of Dervis

 (v. i.) The upper voice in part music.

DESCANT
 (v. i.) To sing a variation or accomplishment.

DESCEND
 (v. i.) To pass from a higher to a lower place; to move downwards; to come or go down in any way, as by falling, flowing, walking, etc.; to plunge; to fall; to incline downward; -- the opposite of ascend.

DESCEND
 (v. i.) To come down, as from a source, original, or stock; to be derived; to proceed by generation or by transmission; to fall or pass by inheritance; as, the beggar may descend from a prince; a crown descends to the heir.

DESCENT
 (n.) Derivation, as from an ancestor; procedure by generation; lineage; birth; extraction.

DESCENT
 (n.) Lowest place; extreme downward place.

DESIRER
 (n.) One who desires, asks, or wishes.

DESKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Desk

DESMOID
 (a.) Resembling, or having the characteristics of, a ligament; ligamentous.

 (v. t.) To give up as beyond hope or expectation; to despair of.

DESPISE
 (v. t.) To look down upon with disfavor or contempt; to contemn; to scorn; to disdain; to have a low opinion or contemptuous dislike of.

DESPITE
 (n.) Malice; malignity; spite; malicious anger; contemptuous hate.

DESPITE
 (prep.) In spite of; against, or in defiance of; notwithstanding; as, despite his prejudices.

DESPOND
 (v. i.) To give up, the will, courage, or spirit; to be thoroughly disheartened; to lose all courage; to become dispirited or depressed; to take an unhopeful view.

DESTINY
 (n.) That to which any person or thing is destined; predetermined state; condition foreordained by the Divine or by human will; fate; lot; doom.

DETERGE
 (v. t.) To cleanse; to purge away, as foul or offending matter from the body, or from an ulcer.

DETRUDE
 (v. t.) To thrust down or out; to push down with force.

DEUTZIA
 (n.) A genus of shrubs with pretty white flowers, much cultivated.

DEVELIN
 (n.) The European swift.

 (v. t.) To advance; to further; to prefect; to make to increase; to promote the growth of.

 (n.) In any animal, esp. of the Herbivora, a rudimentary claw or small hoof not reaching the ground.

 (n.) A war horse; a destrer.

DHOURRA
 (n.) Alt. of Dhurra

DIADROM
 (n.) A complete course or vibration; time of vibration, as of a pendulum.

DIAGRAM
 (v. t.) To put into the form of a diagram.

DIALING
 (n.) A method of surveying, especially in mines, in which the bearings of the courses, or the angles which they make with each other, are determined by means of the circumferentor.

DIALLYL
 (n.) A volatile, pungent, liquid hydrocarbon, C6H10, consisting of two allyl radicals, and belonging to the acetylene series.

DIAMOND
 (n.) A precious stone or gem excelling in brilliancy and beautiful play of prismatic colors, and remarkable for extreme hardness.

DIAMOND
 (n.) The smallest kind of type in English printing, except that called brilliant, which is seldom seen.

 (n.) Same as Diapason.

 (a.) Alt. of Diarian

 (n.) An interval.

DIECIAN
 (a.) Alt. of Diecious

DIFFIND
 (v. t.) To split.

DIFFUSE
 (v. t.) To pour out and cause to spread, as a fluid; to cause to flow on all sides; to send out, or extend, in all directions; to spread; to circulate; to disseminate; to scatter; as to diffuse information.

DIGAMMA
 (n.) A letter (/, /) of the Greek alphabet, which early fell into disuse.

DIGGING
 (n.) The act or the place of excavating.

DIGNITY
 (n.) One holding high rank; a dignitary.

DIGRAPH
 (n.) Two signs or characters combined to express a single articulated sound; as ea in head, or th in bath.

DIGRESS
 (v. i.) To turn aside from the right path; to transgress; to offend.

DILATER
 (n.) One who, or that which, dilates, expands, o r enlarges.

DILATOR
 (n.) One who, or that which, widens or expands.

DILEMMA
 (n.) An argument which presents an antagonist with two or more alternatives, but is equally conclusive against him, whichever alternative he chooses.

DILLING
 (n.) A darling; a favorite.

DILUENT
 (n.) That which dilutes.

DILUTER
 (n.) One who, or that which, dilutes or makes thin, more liquid, or weaker.

DIMORPH
 (n.) Either one of the two forms of a dimorphous substance; as, calcite and aragonite are dimorphs.

DINSOME
 (a.) Full of din.

DINTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Dint

DIOPTRE
 (n.) A unit employed by oculists in numbering glasses according to the metric system; a refractive power equal to that of a glass whose principal focal distance is one meter.

DIORISM
 (n.) Definition; logical direction.

DIPLOMA
 (n.) A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring some privilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degree conferred by a literary society or educational institution.

DIPPING
 (n.) The act of lifting or moving a liquid with a dipper, ladle, or the like.

DIPTYCH
 (n.) A picture or series of pictures painted on two tablets connected by hinges. See Triptych.

DIREFUL
 (a.) Dire; dreadful; terrible; calamitous; woeful; as, a direful fiend; a direful day.

DISAVOW
 (v. t.) To deny; to show the contrary of; to disprove.

DISBARK
 (v. t.) To strip of bark; to bark.

DISCERN
 (v. t.) To see by the eye or by the understanding; to perceive and recognize; as, to discern a difference.

DISCIND
 (v. t.) To part; to divide.

DISCOID
 (a.) Having the form of a disk, as those univalve shells which have the whorls in one plane, so as to form a disk, as the pearly nautilus.

DISCOST
 (v. i.) Same as Discoast.

DISCUSS
 (v. t.) To break up; to disperse; to scatter; to dissipate; to drive away; -- said especially of tumors.

DISDAIN
 (v. t.) That which is worthy to be disdained or regarded with contempt and aversion.

DISEASE
 (v. t.) To deprive of ease; to disquiet; to trouble; to distress.

DISGUST
 (v. t.) To provoke disgust or strong distaste in; to cause (any one) loathing, as of the stomach; to excite aversion in; to offend the moral taste of; -- often with at, with, or by.

DISHELM
 (v. t.) To deprive of the helmet.

DISLIKE
 (n.) Discord; dissension.

DISMAST
 (v. t.) To deprive of a mast of masts; to break and carry away the masts from; as, a storm dismasted the ship.

DISPART
 (n.) A piece of metal placed on the muzzle, or near the trunnions, on the top of a piece of ordnance, to make the line of sight parallel to the axis of the bore; -- called also dispart sight, and muzzle sight.

DISPLAY
 (v. t.) To extend the front of (a column), bringing it into line.

DISPLAY
 (v. i.) To make a display; to act as one making a show or demonstration.

DISPONE
 (v. t.) To make over, or convey, legally.

DISPORT
 (v. i.) To divert or amuse; to make merry.

DISPOSE
 (v. t.) To distribute and put in place; to arrange; to set in order; as, to dispose the ships in the form of a crescent.

DISPOSE

 (a.) Lying apart.

 (a.) Reserved or repelling in manners; cold; not cordial; somewhat haughty; as, a distant manner.

DISTEND
 (v. t.) To extend in some one direction; to lengthen out; to stretch.

 (a.) Having two columns in front; -- said of a temple, portico, or the like.

DIURNAL
 (a.) Relating to the daytime; belonging to the period of daylight, distinguished from the night; -- opposed to nocturnal; as, diurnal heat; diurnal hours.

DIURNAL
 (a.) A small volume containing the daily service for the little hours, viz., prime, tierce, sext, nones, vespers, and compline.

DIVERSE
 (a.) Capable of various forms; multiform.

DIVIDER

DIVORCE

DRAUGHT

DRAUGHT

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Draw

DRAWBAR

 (n.) Continuance; duration. See Endurance.

DUSKILY
 (adv.) In a dusky manner.

DUSTPAN
 (n.) A shovel-like utensil for conveying away dust brushed from the floor.

DVERGAR
 (pl. ) of Dvergr

DWARFED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Dwarf

DYNAMIC
 (a.) Alt. of Dynamical

DYSNOMY
 (n.) Bad legislation; the enactment of bad laws.

DYSURIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or afflicted with, dysury.

EAGLESS
 (n.) A female or hen eagle.

EARACHE
 (n.) Ache or pain in the ear.

EARDROP
 (n.) A species of primrose. See Auricula.

EARLOCK
 (n.) A lock or curl of hair near the ear; a lovelock. See Lovelock.

EARMARK
 (n.) A mark for identification; a distinguishing mark.

EARNEST
 (a.) Serious; important.

EARPICK
 (n.) An instrument for removing wax from the ear.

EARTHLY
 (adv.) In the manner of the earth or its people; worldly.

EASEFUL
 (a.) Full of ease; suitable for affording ease or rest; quiet; comfortable; restful.

EASTING
 (n.) The distance measured toward the east between two meridians drawn through the extremities of a course; distance of departure eastward made by a vessel.

EBONITE
 (n.) A hard, black variety of vulcanite. It may be cut and polished, and is used for many small articles, as combs and buttons, and for insulating material in electric apparatus.

ECDYSES
 (pl. ) of Ecdysis

ECHELON
 (n.) An arrangement of a body of troops when its divisions are drawn up in parallel lines each to the right or the left of the one in advance of it, like the steps of a ladder in position for climbing. Also used adjectively; as, echelon distance.

ECHIDNA
 (n.) A genus of Monotremata found in Australia, Tasmania, and New Guinea. They are toothless and covered with spines; -- called also porcupine ant- eater, and Australian ant-eater.

ECHINUS
 (n.) A genus of echinoderms, including the common edible sea urchin of Europe.

ECONOMY
 (n.) The management of domestic affairs; the regulation and government of household matters; especially as they concern expense or disbursement; as, a careful economy.

ECSTASY
 (n.) Violent distraction of mind; violent emotion; excessive grief of anxiety; insanity; madness.

EDACITY
 (n.) Greediness; voracity; ravenousness; rapacity.

EDENTAL
 (a.) See Edentate, a.

EDICTAL
 (a.) Relating to, or consisting of, edicts; as, the Roman edictal law.

EDIFICE
 (n.) A building; a structure; an architectural fabric; -- chiefly applied to elegant houses, and other large buildings; as, a palace, a church, a statehouse.

EDITING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Edit

EFFORCE
 (v. t.) To force; to constrain; to compel to yield.

EFFULGE
 (v. i.) To shine forth; to beam.

EFTSOON
 (adv.) Alt. of Eftsoons

EIRENIC
 (a.) Pacific. See Irenic.

ELANCED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Elance

ELASTIC
 (a.) Springing back; having a power or inherent property of returning to the form from which a substance is bent, drawn, pressed, or twisted; springy; having the power of rebounding; as, a bow is elastic; the air is elastic; India rubber is elastic.

ELATERY
 (n.) Acting force; elasticity.

ELEATIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a certain school of Greek philosophers who taught that the only certain science is that which owes nothing to the senses, and all to the reason.

ELECTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Elect

ELECTOR
 (n.) One who elects, or has the right of choice; a person who is entitled to take part in an election, or to give his vote in favor of a candidate for office.

ELEGIAC
 (a.) Used in elegies; as, elegiac verse; the elegiac distich or couplet, consisting of a dactylic hexameter and pentameter.

ELEGIST
 (n.) A write of elegies.

ELEIDIN
 (n.) Lifeless matter deposited in the form of minute granules within the protoplasm of living cells.

ELEMENT
 (n.) One of the smallest natural divisions of the organism, as a blood corpuscle, a muscular fiber.

ELEMENT
 (n.) the conditions and movements of the air.

ELEMENT
 (v. t.) To constitute; to make up with elements.

ELEVATE
 (a.) Elevated; raised aloft.

ELEVATE
 (v. t.) To raise from a depressed state; to animate; to cheer; as, to elevate the spirits.

ELKWOOD
 (n.) The soft, spongy wood of a species of Magnolia (M. Umbrella).

ELLIPSE
 (n.) The elliptical orbit of a planet.

ELLWAND
 (n.) Formerly, a measuring rod an ell long.

ELOGIST
 (n.) One who pronounces an eloge.

ELUXATE
 (v. t.) To dislocate; to luxate.

ELZEVIR
 (a.) Applied to books or editions (esp. of the Greek New Testament and the classics) printed and published by the Elzevir family at Amsterdam, Leyden, etc., from about 1592 to 1680; also, applied to a round open type introduced by them.

EMBASSY
 (n.) The person or persons sent as ambassadors or envoys; the ambassador and his suite; envoys.

EMBLAZE
 (v. t.) To paint or adorn with armorial figures; to blazon, or emblazon.

EMBOLIC
 (a.) Embolismic.

EMBRACE
 (n.) To clasp in the arms with affection; to take in the arms; to hug.

EMBRACE
 (n.) To accept; to undergo; to submit to.

EMBRAWN
 (v. t.) To harden.

EMBROIL
 (v. t.) To throw into confusion or commotion by contention or discord; to entangle in a broil or quarrel; to make confused; to distract; to involve in difficulties by dissension or strife.

EMERALD
 (n.) A kind of type, in size between minion and nonpare/l. It is used by English printers.

EMERODS
 (n. pl.) Alt. of Emeroids

EMETINE
 (n.) A white crystalline bitter alkaloid extracted from ipecacuanha root, and regarded as its peculiar emetic principle.

EMGALLA
 (n.) The South African wart hog. See Wart hog.

EMINENT
 (a.) Being, metaphorically, above others, whether by birth, high station, merit, or virtue; high in public estimation; distinguished; conspicuous; as, an eminent station; an eminent historian, statements, statesman, or saint.

EMPANEL
 (n.) A list of jurors; a panel.

EMPEACH
 (v. t.) To hinder. See Impeach.

EMPERIL
 (v. t.) To put in peril. See Imperil.

EMPIGHT
 (a.) Fixed; settled; fastened.

EMPIRIC
 (n.) One who confines himself to applying the results of mere experience or his own observation; especially, in medicine, one who deviates from the rules of science and regular practice; an ignorant and unlicensed pretender; a quack; a charlatan.

EMPRESS
 (n.) The consort of an emperor.

EMPRISE
 (n.) The qualifies which prompt one to undertake difficult and dangerous exploits.

ENACTOR
 (n.) One who enacts a law; one who decrees or establishes as a law.

ENATION
 (n.) Any unusual outgrowth from the surface of a thing, as of a petal; also, the capacity or act of producing such an outgrowth.

ENCAUMA
 (n.) An ulcer in the eye, upon the cornea, which causes the loss of the humors.

ENCHAFE
 (v. t.) To chafe; to enrage; to heat.

ENCHANT
 (v. t.) To charm by sorcery; to act on by enchantment; to get control of by magical words and rites.

ENCHASE
 (v. t.) To incase or inclose in a border or rim; to surround with an ornamental casing, as a gem with gold; to encircle; to inclose; to adorn.

ENCHYMA
 (n.) The primitive formative juice, from which the tissues, particularly the cellular tissue, are formed.

ENCLOUD
 (v. t.) To envelop in clouds; to cloud.

ENCOLOR
 (v. t.) To color.

ENCRUST
 (v. t.) To incrust. See Incrust.

ENDABLE
 (a.) That may be ended; terminable.

ENDLESS
 (a.) Without profitable end; fruitless; unsatisfying.

ENDMOST
 (a.) Farthest; remotest; at the very end.

ENDOGEN
 (n.) A plant which increases in size by internal growth and elongation at the summit, having the wood in the form of bundles or threads, irregularly distributed throughout the whole diameter, not forming annual layers, and with no distinct pith. The lea

ENDURED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Endure

ENDWAYS
 (adv.) Alt. of Endwise

ENDYSIS
 (n.) The act of developing a new coat of hair, a new set of feathers, scales, etc.; -- opposed to ecdysis.

 (pl. ) of Enemy

ENFLESH
 (v. t.) To clothe with flesh.

ENFORCE
 (v. t.) To put in motion or action by violence; to drive.

ENFORCE

ENGAGED
 (a.) Pledged; promised; especially, having the affections pledged; promised in marriage; affianced; betrothed.

ENGAGER
 (n.) One who enters into an engagement or agreement; a surety.

ENGLISH
 (a.) Of or pertaining to England, or to its inhabitants, or to the present so-called Anglo-Saxon race.

ENGLISH
 (n.) A twist or spinning motion given to a ball in striking it that influences the direction it will take after touching a cushion or another ball.

ENGORGE
 (v. t.) To swallow with greediness or in large quantities; to devour.

ENGRAIN
 (v. t.) To incorporate with the grain or texture of anything; to infuse deeply. See Ingrain.

ENGRASP
 (v. t.) To grasp; to grip.

ENGROSS
 (v. t.) To copy or write in a large hand (en gross, i. e., in large); to write a fair copy of in distinct and legible characters; as, to engross a deed or like instrument on parchment.

ENLARGE
 (v. t.) To set at large or set free.

ENNOBLE

 (imp. & p. p.) of Enrage

 (v. t.) To rove over; to range.

ENRHEUM
 (v. i.) To contract a rheum.

ENTASIS
 (n.) A slight convex swelling of the shaft of a column.

ENTERED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Enter

ENTHUSE
 (v. t. & i.) To make or become enthusiastic.

ENTOZOA
 (n. pl.) A group of worms, including the tapeworms, flukes, roundworms, etc., most of which live parasitically in the interior of other animals; the Helminthes.

ENTOZOA
 (pl. ) of Entozoon

ENTREAT
 (v. t.) To treat with, or in respect to, a thing desired; hence, to ask earnestly; to beseech; to petition or pray with urgency; to supplicate; to importune.

ENTREAT
 (n.) Entreaty.

ENTRUST
 (v. t.) See Intrust.

ENVELOP
 (v. t.) To put a covering about; to wrap up or in; to inclose within a case, wrapper, integument or the like; to surround entirely; as, to envelop goods or a letter; the fog envelops a ship.

ENVELOP
 (n.) A curve or surface which is tangent to each member of a system of curves or surfaces, the form and position of the members of the system being allowed to vary according to some continuous law. Thus, any curve is the envelope of its tangents.

ENVIOUS
 (a.) Feeling or exhibiting envy; actuated or directed by, or proceeding from, envy; -- said of a person, disposition, feeling, act, etc.; jealously pained by the excellence or good fortune of another; maliciously grudging; -- followed by of, at, and aga

 (v. t.) To surround; to encompass; to encircle; to hem in; to be round about; to involve or envelop.

ENVOLUP
 (v. t.) To wrap up; to envelop.

ENVYNED
 (a.) Stored or furnished with wine.

EPAULET
 (n.) Alt. of Epaulette

EPHORAL
 (a.) Pertaining to an ephor.

EPIGENE
 (a.) Formed originating on the surface of the earth; -- opposed to hypogene; as, epigene rocks.

EPIGEUM
 (n.) See Perigee.

EPIGRAM
 (n.) A short poem treating concisely and pointedly of a single thought or event. The modern epigram is so contrived as to surprise the reader with a witticism or ingenious turn of thought, and is often satirical in character.

EPIMERA
 (n. pl.) See Epimeron.

EPITAPH
 (n.) An inscription on, or at, a tomb, or a grave, in memory or commendation of the one buried there; a sepulchral inscription.

EPITHET
 (n.) Term; expression; phrase.

EPITOME
 (n.) A work in which the contents of a former work are reduced within a smaller space by curtailment and condensation; a brief summary; an abridgement.

EPOZOIC
 (a.) Living upon the exterior of another animal; ectozoic; -- said of external parasites.

EPONYME
 (n.) A name, as of a people, country, and the like, derived from that of an individual.

EQUABLE
 (a.) Uniform in action or intensity; not variable or changing; -- said of the feelings or temper.

EQUERRY
 (n.) A large stable or lodge for horses.

EQUINOX
 (n.) Equinoctial wind or storm.

EQUITES
 (n. pl) An order of knights holding a middle place between the senate and the commonalty; members of the Roman equestrian order.

ERECTOR
 (n.) A muscle which raises any part.

EREMITE
 (n.) A hermit.

ERGOTIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, ergot; as, ergotic acid.

ERODENT
 (n.) A medicine which eats away extraneous growths; a caustic.

EROSIVE
 (a.) That erodes or gradually eats away; tending to erode; corrosive.

ERRANCY
 (n.) A wandering; state of being in error.

ERRATIC
 (a.) Having no certain course; roving about without a fixed destination; wandering; moving; -- hence, applied to the planets as distinguished from the fixed stars.

ERRATIC
 (n.) Any stone or material that has been borne away from its original site by natural agencies; esp., a large block or fragment of rock; a bowlder.

ERTHINE
 (n.) A medicine designed to be snuffed up the nose, to promote discharges of mucus; a sternutatory.

ESCALOP
 (n.) A bivalve shell of the genus Pecten. See Scallop.

ESCAPED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Escape

ESCHEAT
 (n.) The falling back or reversion of lands, by some casualty or accident, to the lord of the fee, in consequence of the extinction of the blood of the tenant, which may happen by his dying without heirs, and formerly might happen by corruption of blood

ESCRIPT
 (n.) A writing.

ESCROLL
 (n.) A scroll.

ESCULIN
 (n.) A glucoside obtained from the Aesculus hippocastanum, or horse-chestnut, and characterized by its fine blue fluorescent solutions.

ESERINE
 (n.) An alkaloid found in the Calabar bean, and the seed of Physostigma venenosum; physostigmine. It is used in ophthalmic surgery for its effect in contracting the pupil.

ESKIMOS
 (pl. ) of Eskimo

ESOPIAN
 (a.) Alt. of Esopic

ESPADON
 (n.) A long, heavy, two-handed and two-edged sword, formerly used by Spanish foot soldiers and by executioners.

ESQUIRE
 (n.) Originally, a shield-bearer or armor-bearer, an attendant on a knight; in modern times, a title of dignity next in degree below knight and above gentleman; also, a title of office and courtesy; -- often shortened to squire.

ESSENCE
 (n.) The constituent elementary notions which constitute a complex notion, and must be enumerated to define it; sometimes called the nominal essence.

ESSENCE
 (n.) Perfume; odor; scent; or the volatile matter constituting perfume.

ESTOILE
 (n.) A six-pointed star whose rays are wavy, instead of straight like those of a mullet.

ESTRICH
 (n.) Ostrich.

ESTUARY
 (n.) A place where water boils up; a spring that wells forth.

ESTUATE
 (v. i.) To boil up; to swell and rage; to be agitated.

ETACISM
 (n.) The pronunciation of the Greek / (eta) like the Italian e long, that is like a in the English word ate. See Itacism.

ETCHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Etch

ETERNAL
 (a.) Continued without intermission; perpetual; ceaseless; constant.

ETHENYL
 (n.) A trivalent hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C.

ETHMOID
 (a.) Alt. of Ethmoidal

ETOOLIN
 (n.) A yellowish coloring matter found in plants grown in darkness, which is supposed to be an antecedent condition of chlorophyll.

EUCALYN
 (n.) An unfermentable sugar, obtained as an uncrystallizable sirup by the decomposition of melitose; also obtained from a Tasmanian eucalyptus, -- whence its name.

EUGENIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, cloves; as, eugenic acid.

EUPATHY
 (n.) Right feeling.

EUPHROE
 (n.) A block or long slat of wood, perforated for the passage of the crowfoot, or cords by which an awning is held up.

EUPIONE
 (n.) A limpid, oily liquid obtained by the destructive distillation of various vegetable and animal substances; -- specifically, an oil consisting largely of the higher hydrocarbons of the paraffin series.

EURYALE
 (n.) A genus of ophiurans with much-branched arms.

EVENING
 (n.) The latter part and close of the day, and the beginning of darkness or night; properly, the decline of the day, or of the sum.

EVERICH
 (a.) Alt. of Everych

EVERNIC
 (a.) Pertaining to Evernia, a genus of lichens; as, evernic acid.

EVERTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Evert

 (v. t.) To shun; to avoid.

 (v. t.) To call out or forth; to summon; to evoke.

EXACTER
 (n.) An exactor.

 (a.) Raised to lofty height; elevated; extolled; refined; dignified; sublime.

EXEGETE

EXHAUST

EXHAUST
 (a.) Pertaining to steam, air, gas, etc., that is released from the cylinder of an engine after having preformed its work.

EXHIBIT
 (v. t.) To hold forth or present to view; to produce publicly, for inspection; to show, especially in order to attract notice to what is interesting; to display; as, to exhibit commodities in a warehouse, a picture in a gallery.

EXHUMED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Exhume

 (n.) Exigency; pressing necessity; decisive moment.

EXILITY
 (a.) Smallness; meagerness; slenderness; fineness, thinness.

EXISTER
 (n.) One who exists.

EXPIATE
 (a.) Terminated.

EXPLODE
 (v. t.) To bring into disrepute, and reject; to drive from notice and acceptance; as, to explode a scheme, fashion, or doctrine.

EXPLOIT
 (n.) Hence: To draw an illegitimate profit from; to speculate on; to put upon.

EXPOUND
 (v. t.) To lay open the meaning of; to explain; to clear of obscurity; to interpret; as, to expound a text of Scripture, a law, a word, a meaning, or a riddle.

EXPRESS
 (n.) A clear image or representation; an expression; a plain declaration.

EXPRESS
 (a.) To denote; to designate.

EXTANCE
 (n.) Outward existence.

EXTINCT
 (a.) Without a survivor; without force; dead; as, a family becomes extinct; an extinct feud or law.

EXTRACT
 (n.) A portion of a book or document, separately transcribed; a citation; a quotation.

EXTRACT
 (n.) A draught or copy of writing; certified copy of the proceedings in an action and the judgement therein, with an order for execution.

EXTREME
 (a.) The best of worst; most urgent; greatest; highest; immoderate; excessive; most violent; as, an extreme case; extreme folly.

EXTREME
 (n.) An extreme state or condition; hence, calamity, danger, distress, etc.

EXUTORY
 (n.) An issue.

EXUVIAE
 (n. pl.) The fossil shells and other remains which animals have left in the strata of the earth.

FEATHER

FEATHER
