FEATURE
 (n.) The make, form, or outward appearance of a person; the whole turn or style of the body; esp., good appearance.

FEDERAL
 (a.) Consisting or pertaining to such a government; as, the Federal Constitution; a Federal officer.

FEEDING
 (n.) That which is eaten; food.

FEELING
 (a.) Possessing great sensibility; easily affected or moved; as, a feeling heart.

FEELING
 (n.) Any state or condition of emotion; the exercise of the capacity for emotion; any mental state whatever; as, a right or a wrong feeling in the heart; our angry or kindly feelings; a feeling of pride or of humility.

FELONRY
 (n.) A body of felons; specifically, the convict population of a penal colony.

FELWORT

 (a.) Abounding in fens; fenny.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Feoff

FERMENT

FERRARY
 (n.) The art of working in iron.

FERREST
 (a. & adv.) superl. of Fer.

FERROUS
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, iron; -- especially used of compounds of iron in which the iron has its lower valence; as, ferrous sulphate.

FERRUGO
 (n.) A disease of plants caused by fungi, commonly called the rust, from its resemblance to iron rust in color.

FERRIED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Ferry

FERTILE
 (a.) Containing pollen; -- said of anthers.

FERVENT
 (a.) Hot; glowing; boiling; burning; as, a fervent summer.

FESTEYE
 (v. t.) To feast; to entertain.

FESTOON
 (n.) A garland or wreath hanging in a depending curve, used in decoration for festivals, etc.; anything arranged in this way.

FEVERET
 (n.) A slight fever.

FEWNESS
 (n.) The state of being few; smallness of number; paucity.

FIBRINE
 (a.) Belonging to the fibers of plants.

FIBROIN
 (n.) A variety of gelatin; the chief ingredient of raw silk, extracted as a white amorphous mass.

FICTION
 (n.) Fictitious literature; comprehensively, all works of imagination; specifically, novels and romances.

FIDDLER
 (n.) A burrowing crab of the genus Gelasimus, of many species. The male has one claw very much enlarged, and often holds it in a position similar to that in which a musician holds a fiddle, hence the name; -- called also calling crab, soldier crab, and

FIFTEEN
 (n.) The sum of five and ten; fifteen units or objects.

FIGURED
 (a.) Indicated or noted by figures.

FILARIA
 (n.) A genus of slender, nematode worms of many species, parasitic in various animals. See Guinea worm.

FILCHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Filch

FILICIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, ferns; as, filicic acid.

FILIETY
 (n.) The relation of a son to a father; sonship; -- the correlative of paternity.

FINANCE
 (n.) The science of raising and expending the public revenue.

FINCHED
 (a.) Same as Finchbacked.

FINDING
 (n.) The result of a judicial examination or inquiry, especially into some matter of fact; a verdict; as, the finding of a jury.

FINICAL
 (a.) Affectedly fine; overnice; unduly particular; fastidious.

FINPIKE

 (a.) Carnal; wordly; lascivious.

FLEXION
 (n.) The bending of a limb or joint; that motion of a joint which gives the distal member a continually decreasing angle with the axis of the proximal part; -- distinguished from extension.

FLEXURE
 (n.) The small distortion of an astronomical instrument caused by the weight of its parts; the amount to be added or substracted from the observed readings of the instrument to correct them for this distortion.

FLICKER
 (v. i.) To flutter; to flap the wings without flying.

 (a.) Indulging in flights, or wild and unrestrained sallies, of imagination, humor, caprice, etc.; given to disordered fancies and extravagant conduct; volatile; giddy; eccentric; slighty delirious.

 (a.) A young or untrained hawk or falcon.

 (n.) Holiness; sanctity; sacred oath; sacred things; sanctuary; -- used chiefly in oaths.

 (n.) An electro-negative element or radical, which, by combination with a metal, forms a haloid salt; especially, chlorine, bromine, and iodine; sometimes, also, fluorine and cyanogen. See Chlorine family, under Chlorine.

 (a.) Suspended from above; pendent; as, hanging shelves.

HANGMEN
 (pl. ) of Hangman

HANSARD
 (n.) A merchant of one of the Hanse towns. See the Note under 2d Hanse.

HAPLOMI
 (n. pl.) An order of freshwater fishes, including the T pikes, cyprinodonts, and blindfishes.

HAPPILY
 (adv.) In a happy manner or state; in happy circumstances; as, he lived happily with his wife.

HARDILY
 (adv.) Same as Hardly.

HARICOT
 (n.) The ripe seeds, or the unripe pod, of the common string bean (Phaseolus vulgaris), used as a vegetable. Other species of the same genus furnish different kinds of haricots.

HARMONY
 (n.) A succession of chords according to the rules of progression and modulation.

HARNESS
 (n.) Originally, the complete dress, especially in a military sense, of a man or a horse; hence, in general, armor.

HARNESS
 (v. t.) To dress in armor; to equip with armor for war, as a horseman; to array.

HARPOON
 (n.) A spear or javelin used to strike and kill large fish, as whales; a harping iron. It consists of a long shank, with a broad, fiat, triangular head, sharpened at both edges, and is thrown by hand, or discharged from a gun.

HARRIER
 (n.) One who harries.

HARSLET
 (n.) See Haslet.

HASHISH
 (n.) A slightly acrid gum resin produced by the common hemp (Cannabis saltiva), of the variety Indica, when cultivated in a warm climate; also, the tops of the plant, from which the resinous product is obtained. It is narcotic, and has long been used in

HASSOCK
 (n.) A small stuffed cushion or footstool, for kneeling on in church, or for home use.

HATCHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Hatch

HATCHER
 (n.) One who hatches, or that which hatches; a hatching apparatus; an incubator.

HAUBERK
 (v. t.) A coat of mail; especially, the long coat of mail of the European Middle Ages, as contrasted with the habergeon, which is shorter and sometimes sleeveless. By old writers it is often used synonymously with habergeon. See Habergeon.

HAULING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Haul

HAULAGE
 (n.) Act of hauling; as, the haulage of cars by an engine; charge for hauling.

HAUTBOY
 (n.) A wind instrument, sounded through a reed, and similar in shape to the clarinet, but with a thinner tone. Now more commonly called oboe. See Illust. of Oboe.

HAUTEUR
 (n.) Haughty manner or spirit; haughtiness; pride; arrogance.

HAYBOTE
 (n.) An allowance of wood to a tenant for repairing his hedges or fences; hedgebote. See Bote.

HAYRACK
 (n.) A frame mounted on the running gear of a wagon, and used in hauling hay, straw, sheaves, etc.; -- called also hay rigging.

HEADING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Head

HEADING
 (n.) The act or state of one who, or that which, heads; formation of a head.

HEADING
 (n.) That end of a stone or brick which is presented outward.

HEADMAN
 (n.) A head or leading man, especially of a village community.

HEADWAY
 (n.) Clear space under an arch, girder, and the like, sufficient to allow of easy passing underneath.

HEALALL
 (n.) A common herb of the Mint family (Brunela vulgaris), destitute of active properties, but anciently thought a panacea.

HEALTHY
 (superl.) Being in a state of health; enjoying health; hale; sound; free from disease; as, a healthy chid; a healthy plant.

HEARING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hear

HEARKEN
 (v. t.) To give heed to; to hear attentively.

HEARTED
 (a.) Shaped like a heart; cordate.

HEATHEN
 (a.) Barbarous; unenlightened; heathenish.

HEAVILY
 (adv.) In a heavy manner; with great weight; as, to bear heavily on a thing; to be heavily loaded.

HEEDING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Heed

HEELTAP
 (n.) A small portion of liquor left in a glass after drinking.

HEINOUS
 (a.) Hateful; hatefully bad; flagrant; odious; atrocious; giving great great offense; -- applied to deeds or to character.

HEIRESS
 (n.) A female heir.

HEKTARE
 (n.) Alt. of Hektometer

HELAMYS
 (n.) See Jumping hare, under Hare.

HELMING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Helm

HELMAGE
 (n.) Guidance; direction.

HEMATIN
 (n.) A bluish black, amorphous substance containing iron and obtained from blood. It exists the red blood corpuscles united with globulin, and the form of hemoglobin or oxyhemoglobin gives to the blood its red color.

HEMINAE
 (pl. ) of Hemina

HEMLOCK
 (n.) An evergreen tree common in North America (Abies, / Tsuga, Canadensis); hemlock spruce.

HENFISH
 (n.) A young bib. See Bib, n., 2.

HEPATIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, the plants called Hepaticae, or scale mosses and liverworts.

HEPTANE
 (n.) Any one of several isometric hydrocarbons, C7H16, of the paraffin series (nine are possible, four are known); -- so called because the molecule has seven carbon atoms. Specifically, a colorless liquid, found as a constituent of petroleum, in the ta

HERBAGE
 (n.) Herbs collectively; green food beasts; grass; pasture.

HERBIST
 (n.) A herbalist.

HERBLET
 (n.) A small herb.

HERBOUS
 (a.) Abounding with herbs.

HERETOG
 (n.) The leader or commander of an army; also, a marshal.

HERITOR
 (n.) A proprietor or landholder in a parish.

HERNIAL
 (a.) Of, or connected with, hernia.

HESSITE
 (n.) A lead-gray sectile mineral. It is a telluride of silver.

HEXACID
 (a.) Having six atoms or radicals capable of being replaced by acids; hexatomic; hexavalent; -- said of bases; as, mannite is a hexacid base.

HEXAPOD
 (n.) An animal having six feet; one of the Hexapoda.

HILLOCK
 (n.) A small hill.

HINGING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hinge

HIPHALT
 (a.) Lame in the hip.

HIPPISH
 (a.) Somewhat hypochondriac; melancholy. See Hyppish.

HIRSUTE
 (a.) Rough and coarse; boorish.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hiss

HISSING
 (n.) The act of emitting a hiss or hisses.

HOARDER
 (n.) One who hoards.

HOBBLER
 (n.) One who by his tenure was to maintain a horse for military service; a kind of light horseman in the Middle Ages who was mounted on a hobby.

HOBNAIL
 (v. t.) To tread down roughly, as with hobnailed shoes.

HOCKDAY
 (n.) A holiday commemorating the expulsion of the Danes, formerly observed on the second Tuesday after Easter; -- called also hocktide.

HOGGING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hog

 (n.) See Hogframe.

 (n.) The burden or chorus of a song.

 (a.) Occurring rarely; adapted for a special occasion.

HOLMIUM
 (n.) A rare element said to be contained in gadolinite.

HOLYDAY
 (n.) A religious festival.

HONESTY
 (a.) The quality or state of being honest; probity; fairness and straightforwardness of conduct, speech, etc.; integrity; sincerity; truthfulness; freedom from fraud or guile.

HOODING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hood

HOODLUM
 (n.) A young rowdy; a rough, lawless fellow.

HOOKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hook

HOPEFUL
 (a.) Full of hope, or agreeable expectation; inclined to hope; expectant.

HORDEIN
 (n.) A peculiar starchy matter contained in barley. It is complex mixture.

HORIZON
 (n.) The chief horizontal line in a picture of any sort, which determines in the picture the height of the eye of the spectator; in an extended landscape, the representation of the natural horizon corresponds with this line.

HORNISH
 (a.) Somewhat like horn; hard.

HORRENT
 (a.) Standing erect, as bristles; covered with bristling points; bristled; bristling.

HOSTAGE
 (n.) A person given as a pledge or security for the performance of the conditions of a treaty or stipulations of any kind, on the performance of which the person is to be released.

HOSTILE
 (n.) An enemy; esp., an American Indian in arms against the whites; -- commonly in the plural.

HOSTLER
 (n.) The person who takes charge of a locomotive when it is left by the engineer after a trip.

HOUGHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Hough

HOUSING
 (n.) A niche for a statue.

HOWADJI
 (n.) A traveler.

HOWEVER
 (conj.) Nevertheless; notwithstanding; yet; still; though; as, I shall not oppose your design; I can not, however, approve of it.

HUDDLED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Huddle

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hug

HUISHER
 (v. t.) To usher.

HUMBLES
 (n. pl.) Entrails of a deer.

HUMMOCK
 (n.) A rounded knoll or hillock; a rise of ground of no great extent, above a level surface.

HUMORAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, or proceeding from, the humors; as, a humoral fever.

HUMULIN
 (n.) An extract of hops.

HURLING
 (n.) The act of throwing with force.

HURRIED
 (a.) Urged on; hastened; going or working at speed; as, a hurried writer; a hurried life.

HURTFUL
 (a.) Tending to impair or damage; injurious; mischievous; occasioning loss or injury; as, hurtful words or conduct.

HUSBAND
 (n.) The male head of a household; one who orders the economy of a family.

HUSHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hush

HUSKILY
 (adv.) In a husky manner; dryly.

HUSSITE
 (n.) A follower of John Huss, the Bohemian reformer, who was adjudged a heretic and burnt alive in 1415.

HUSWIFE
 (v. t.) To manage with frugality; -- said of a woman.

HYDRATE
 (v. t.) To form into a hydrate; to combine with water.

HYDRIAD
 (n.) A water nymph.

HYDROID
 (n.) One of the Hydroideas.

HYGEIAN
 (a.) Relating to Hygeia, the goddess of health; of or pertaining to health, or its preservation.

HYLODES
 (n.) The piping frog (Hyla Pickeringii), a small American tree frog, which in early spring, while breeding in swamps and ditches, sings with high, shrill, but musical, notes.

HYMNODY
 (n.) Hymns, considered collectively; hymnology.

ICEBIRD
 (n.) An Arctic sea bird, as the Arctic fulmar.

ICINESS
 (n.) The state or quality of being icy or very cold; frigidity.

 (a.) Of or belonging to idyls.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Ignite

ILLNESS
 (n.) The condition of being ill, evil, or bad; badness; unfavorableness.

ILVAITE
 (n.) A silicate of iron and lime occurring in black prismatic crystals and columnar masses.

IMAGERY
 (n.) Fig.: Unreal show; imitation; appearance.

IMAGINE
 (v. t.) To form in the mind a notion or idea of; to form a mental image of; to conceive; to produce by the imagination.

 (v. t.) To plunge into anything that surrounds or covers, especially into a fluid; to dip; to sink; to bury; to immerge.

IMMIXED
 (a.) Unmixed.

 (a.) See Immobile.

IMPALLA
 (n.) The pallah deer of South Africa.

IMPASTO
 (n.) The thickness of the layer or body of pigment applied by the painter to his canvas with especial reference to the juxtaposition of different colors and tints in forming a harmonious whole.

IMPEACH
 (v. t.) To challenge or discredit the credibility of, as of a witness, or the validity of, as of commercial paper.

IMPEARL
 (v. t.) To form into pearls, or into that which resembles pearls.

IMPIETY

IMPLORE
 (n.) Imploration.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Imply

 (v. t.) To produce by pressure, as a mark, stamp, image, etc.; to imprint (a mark or figure upon something).

IMPRESS
 (n.) The act of impressing or making.

IMPREST
 (n.) To advance on loan.

IMPRINT
 (v. t.) To stamp or mark, as letters on paper, by means of type, plates, stamps, or the like; to print the mark (figures, letters, etc., upon something).

IMPROVE
 (v. i.) To advance or progress in bad qualities; to grow worse.

IMPULSE
 (n.) The action of a force during a very small interval of time; the effect of such action; as, the impulse of a sudden blow upon a hard elastic body.

INANITY
 (n.) An inane, useless thing or pursuit; a vanity; a silly object; -- chiefly in pl.; as, the inanities of the world.

INBEING
 (n.) Inherence; inherent existence.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Incite

 (n.) One who, or that which, incites.

INCLINE
 (v. i.) To deviate from a line, direction, or course, toward an object; to lean; to tend; as, converging lines incline toward each other; a road inclines to the north or south.

INCLINE
 (v. t.) To bend; to cause to stoop or bow; as, to incline the head or the body in acts of reverence or civility.

INCLOSE
 (v. t.) To put within a case, envelope, or the like; to fold (a thing) within another or into the same parcel; as, to inclose a letter or a bank note.

INCLUDE
 (v. t.) To confine within; to hold; to contain; to shut up; to inclose; as, the shell of a nut includes the kernel; a pearl is included in a shell.

INCLUSA
 (n. pl.) A tribe of bivalve mollusks, characterized by the closed state of the mantle which envelops the body. The ship borer (Teredo navalis) is an example.

INCOMER
 (n.) One who comes in.

INCRUST
 (v. t.) To cover or line with a crust, or hard coat; to form a crust on the surface of; as, iron incrusted with rust; a vessel incrusted with salt; a sweetmeat incrusted with sugar.

INCUBUS
 (n.) The nightmare. See Nightmare.

INDEXER
 (n.) One who makes an index.

INDICAN
 (n.) A glucoside obtained from woad (indigo plant) and other plants, as a yellow or light brown sirup. It has a nauseous bitter taste, a decomposes or drying. By the action of acids, ferments, etc., it breaks down into sugar and indigo. It is the source

INDICES
 (n. pl.) See Index.

INDITED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Indite

 (v. t.) To cover the back of; to load or burden.

INEPTLY
 (adv.) Unfitly; unsuitably; awkwardly.

INERTIA
 (n.) Inertness; indisposition to motion, exertion, or action; want of energy; sluggishness.

INFANCY
 (n.) The state or condition of one under age, or under the age of twenty-one years; nonage; minority.

INFANTE
 (n.) A title given to every one of sons of the kings of Spain and Portugal, except the eldest or heir apparent.

INFIDEL
 (n.) One who does not believe in the prevailing religious faith; especially, one who does not believe in the divine origin and authority of Christianity; a Mohammedan; a heathen; a freethinker.

 (a.) Dyed with grain, or kermes.

INTENSE
 (a.) Extreme in degree; excessive; immoderate; as: (a) Ardent; fervent; as, intense heat. (b) Keen; biting; as, intense cold. (c) Vehement; earnest; exceedingly strong; as, intense passion or hate. (d) Very severe; violent; as, intense pain or anguish.

JACOBUS
 (n.) An English gold coin, of the value of twenty-five shillings sterling, struck in the reign of James I.

JALAPIN
 (n.) A glucoside found in the stems of the jalap plant and scammony. It is a strong purgative.

 (n.) Same as Jemidar.

 (n.) The act of pulling, pushing, or throwing, with a jerk.

JEWFISH
 (n.) A very large serranoid fish (Promicrops itaiara) of Florida and the Gulf of Mexico. It often reaches the weight of five hundred pounds. Its color is olivaceous or yellowish, with numerous brown spots. Called also guasa, and warsaw.

 (pl. ) of Jimmy

JOINTED

JOLLITY

 (imp. & p. p.) of Jostle

 (a.) The record of daily proceedings, kept by the clerk.

JUNCITE
 (n.) A fossil rush.

JUPITER

JUSTICE
 (a.) Agreeableness to right; equity; justness; as, the justice of a claim.

JUSTIFY
 (a.) To pronounce free from guilt or blame; to declare or prove to have done that which is just, right, proper, etc.; to absolve; to exonerate; to clear.

JUTTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Jut

KAFILAH
 (n.) See Cafila.

KALASIE
 (n.) A long-tailed monkey of Borneo (Semnopithecus rubicundus). It has a tuft of long hair on the head.

KAOLINE
 (n.) A very pure white clay, ordinarily in the form of an impalpable powder, and used to form the paste of porcelain; China clay; porcelain clay. It is chiefly derived from the decomposition of common feldspar.

 (n.) A West Indian plant of the Pineapple family (Nidularium Karatas).

KIBITKA
 (n.) A tent used by the Kirghiz Tartars.

KILTING
 (n.) A perpendicular arrangement of flat, single plaits, each plait being folded so as to cover half the breadth of the preceding one.

KINEPOX
 (n.) See Kinetoscope.

KINGDOM
 (n.) The territory or country subject to a king or queen; the dominion of a monarch; the sphere in which one is king or has control.

KINGLET
 (n.) A little king; a weak or insignificant king.

KINKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Kink

KINSHIP
 (n.) Family relationship.

KIRMESS
 (n.) In Europe, particularly in Belgium and Holland, and outdoor festival and fair; in the United States, generally an indoor entertainment and fair combined.

KIRUMBO
 (n.) A bird of Madagascar (Leptosomus discolor), the only living type of a family allied to the rollers. It has a pair of loral plumes. The male is glossy green above, with metallic reflections; the female is spotted with brown and black.

KITCHEN
 (v. t.) To furnish food to; to entertain with the fare of the kitchen.

KITHARA
 (n.) See Cithara.

KNACKER
 (n.) a harness maker.

KNARLED
 (a.) Knotted. See Gnarled.

KNICKER
 (n.) A small ball of clay, baked hard and oiled, used as a marble by boys in playing.

KNITTLE
 (n.) See Nettles.

KNOCKED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Knock

KNOCKER
 (n.) One who, or that which, knocks; specifically, an instrument, or kind of hammer, fastened to a door, to be used in seeking for admittance.

KNOLLED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Knoll

KNOLLER
 (n.) One who tolls a bell.

KNOTTED
 (a.) Entangled; puzzling; knotty.

KNOWING
 (n.) Knowledge; hence, experience.

KNUCKLE
 (n.) The joint of a finger, particularly when made prominent by the closing of the fingers.

KNUCKLE
 (n.) A contrivance, usually of brass or iron, and furnished with points, worn to protect the hand, to add force to a blow, and to disfigure the person struck; as, brass knuckles; -- called also knuckle duster.

KYANIZE
 (v. t.) To render (wood) proof against decay by saturating with a solution of corrosive sublimate in open tanks, or under pressure.

LABELLA
 (pl. ) of Labellum

LABIATE
 (a.) Belonging to a natural order of plants (Labiatae), of which the mint, sage, and catnip are examples. They are mostly aromatic herbs.

LABORED
 (a.) Bearing marks of labor and effort; elaborately wrought; not easy or natural; as, labored poetry; a labored style.

LABROSE
 (a.) Having thick lips.

LACERTI
 (pl. ) of Lacertus

LACINIA
 (n.) The posterior, inner process of the stipes on the maxillae of insects.

LACTAGE
 (n.) The produce of animals yielding milk; milk and that which is made from it.

LACTEAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, milk; milky; as, the lacteal fluid.

LACTEAN
 (a.) Lacteal; conveying chyle.

LACTORY
 (a.) Lactiferous.

LACUNAL
 (a.) Alt. of Lacunar

LACUNAR
 (n.) One of the sunken panels in such a ceiling.

LADANUM
 (n.) A gum resin gathered from certain Oriental species of Cistus. It has a pungent odor and is chiefly used in making plasters, and for fumigation.

LAELAPS
 (n.) A genus of huge, carnivorous, dinosaurian reptiles from the Cretaceous formation of the United States. They had very large hind legs and tail, and are supposed to have been bipedal. Some of the species were about eighteen feet high.

LAGENAS
 (pl. ) of Lagena

LAGGARD
 (a.) Slow; sluggish; backward.

LAMAITE
 (n.) One who believes in Lamaism.

LAMBENT
 (a.) Twinkling or gleaming; fickering.

LAMELLA
 (n.) a thin plate or scale of anything, as a thin scale growing from the petals of certain flowers; or one of the thin plates or scales of which certain shells are composed.

LAMPATE
 (n.) A supposed salt of lampic acid.

LAMPING
 (a.) Shining; brilliant.

LAMPOON
 (n.) A personal satire in writing; usually, malicious and abusive censure written only to reproach and distress.

LANATED
 () Wooly; covered with fine long hair, or hairlike filaments.

LANCELY
 (a.) Like a lance.

LANDING
 (n.) A going or bringing on shore.

LANDMAN
 (n.) A man who lives or serves on land; -- opposed to seaman.

LANGATE
 (n.) A linen roller used in dressing wounds.

LANGUID
 (a.) Drooping or flagging from exhaustion; indisposed to exertion; without animation; weak; weary; heavy; dull.

LANGURE
 (v. i.) To languish.

LANIARY
 (a.) The shambles; a place of slaughter.

LANIOID
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the shrikes (family Laniidae).

LANOLIN
 (n.) A peculiar fatlike body, made up of cholesterin and certain fatty acids, found in feathers, hair, wool, and keratin tissues generally.

LANTERN
 (n.) A lantern pinion or trundle wheel. See Lantern pinion (below).

LANYARD
 (n.) A strong cord, about twelve feet long, with an iron hook at one end a handle at the other, used in firing cannon with a friction tube.

LAPPISH
 (n.) The language spoken by the Lapps in Lapland. It is related to the Finnish and Hungarian, and is not an Aryan language.

LAPSING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Lapse

LAPWING
 (n.) A small European bird of the Plover family (Vanellus cristatus, or V. vanellus). It has long and broad wings, and is noted for its rapid, irregular fight, upwards, downwards, and in circles. Its back is coppery or greenish bronze. Its eggs are the

LARMIER
 (n.) See Tearpit.

 (n.) The lading of a ship; also, ballast.

LASTING
 (a.) Existing or continuing a long while; enduring; as, a lasting good or evil; a lasting color.

LAUNDER
 (n.) A washerwoman.

LAVOLTA
 (n.) An old dance, for two persons, being a kind of waltz, in which the woman made a high spring or bound.

LAYLAND
 (n.) Land lying untilled; fallow ground.

LAYSHIP

 (a.) Capable of being read or deciphered; distinct to the eye; plain; -- used of writing or printing; as, a fair, legible manuscript.

LEGLESS
 (a.) Not having a leg.

 (a.) Unemployed; as, leisure hours.

 (n.) The act of one who lends.

LENIENT
 (a.) Mild; clement; merciful; not rigorous or severe; as, a lenient disposition; a lenient judge or sentence.

LENTIGO
 (n.) A freckly eruption on the skin; freckles.

LEONESE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Leon, in Spain.

LEOPARD
 (n.) A large, savage, carnivorous mammal (Felis leopardus). It is of a yellow or fawn color, with rings or roselike clusters of black spots along the back and sides. It is found in Southern Asia and Africa. By some the panther (Felis pardus) is regarded

LEUCITE
 (n.) A leucoplast.

LEUCOMA
 (n.) A white opacity in the cornea of the eye; -- called also albugo.

LEVATOR
 (n.) A muscle that serves to raise some part, as the lip or the eyelid.

LEVESEL
 (n.) A leafy shelter; a place covered with foliage.

LEXICON
 (n.) A vocabulary, or book containing an alphabetical arrangement of the words in a language or of a considerable number of them, with the definition of each; a dictionary; especially, a dictionary of the Greek, Hebrew, or Latin language.

LIBERAL
 (a.) Bestowed in a large way; hence, more than sufficient; abundant; bountiful; ample; profuse; as, a liberal gift; a liberal discharge of matter or of water.

LIBERAL
 (n.) One who favors greater freedom in political or religious matters; an opponent of the established systems; a reformer; in English politics, a member of the Liberal party, so called. Cf. Whig.

LIBERTY
 (n.) The state of a free person; exemption from subjection to the will of another claiming ownership of the person or services; freedom; -- opposed to slavery, serfdom, bondage, or subjection.

LIBERTY
 (n.) A certain amount of freedom; permission to go freely within certain limits; also, the place or limits within which such freedom is exercised; as, the liberties of a prison.

LIBRARY
 (n.) A building or apartment appropriated for holding such a collection of books.

LICENSE
 (n.) That deviation from strict fact, form, or rule, in which an artist or writer indulges, assuming that it will be permitted for the sake of the advantage or effect gained; as, poetic license; grammatical license, etc.

LICKING
 (n.) A flogging or castigation.

LIFLODE
 (n.) Livelihood.

LIGHTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Light

LIGHTEN
 (v. i.) To descend; to light.

LIGHTEN
 (v. t.) To make light or clear; to light; to illuminate; as, to lighten an apartment with lamps or gas; to lighten the streets.

LIGHTEN
 (v. t.) To make less burdensome or afflictive; to alleviate; as, to lighten the cares of life or the burden of grief.

LIGHTLY
 (adv.) Swiftly; nimbly; with agility.

LIGHTLY
 (adv.) Commonly; usually.

LIGNOSE
 (n.) See Lignin.

LIGULAS
 (pl. ) of Ligula

 (n.) The act, process, or art of one who limns; the picture or decoration so produced.

LIMOSIS
 (n.) A ravenous appetite caused by disease; excessive and morbid hunger.

LIMPKIN
 (n.) Either one of two species of wading birds of the genus Aramus, intermediate between the cranes and rails. The limpkins are remarkable for the great length of the toes. One species (A. giganteus) inhabits Florida and the West Indies; the other (A. s

LINEMAN
 (n.) One who carries the line in surveying, etc.

LINGISM
 (n.) A mode of treating certain diseases, as obesity, by gymnastics; -- proposed by Pehr Henrik Ling, a Swede. See Kinesiatrics.

LINGUAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the tongue; uttered by the aid of the tongue; glossal; as, the lingual nerves; a lingual letter.

LINKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Link

LINKAGE
 (n.) A system of straight lines or bars, fastened together by joints, and having certain of their points fixed in a plane. It is used to describe straight lines and curves in the plane.

LINSANG
 (n.) Any viverrine mammal of the genus Prionodon, inhabiting the East Indies and Southern Asia. The common East Indian linsang (P. gracilis) is white, crossed by broad, black bands. The Guinea linsang (Porana Richardsonii) is brown with black spots.

LIONCEL
 (n.) A small lion, especially one of several borne in the same coat of arms.

LIONISM
 (n.) An attracting of attention, as a lion; also, the treating or regarding as a lion.

LIPPING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Lip

LIPLESS
 (a.) Having no lips.

LIQUEFY
 (v. t.) To convert from a solid form to that of a liquid; to melt; to dissolve; and technically, to melt by the sole agency of heat.

LISTFUL
 (a.) Attentive.

LITERAL
 (a.) According to the letter or verbal expression; real; not figurative or metaphorical; as, the literal meaning of a phrase.

LITHATE
 (n.) A salt of lithic or uric acid; a urate.

LITHELY
 (adv.) In a lithe, pliant, or flexible manner.

LITOTES
 (n.) A diminution or softening of statement for the sake of avoiding censure or increasing the effect by contrast with the moderation shown in the form of expression; as, a citizen of no mean city, that is, of an illustrious city.

LIVABLE
 (a.) Such as in pleasant to live in; fit or suitable to live in.

 (a.) Having lobate toes, as a coot.

LOCULAR

LOGICAL

LOMBARD

LOOKING
 (n.) The act of one who looks; a glance.

 (n.) A tree, the top of which has been lopped off.

LORDKIN
 (n.) A little lord.

LORETTE
 (n.) In France, a name for a woman who is supported by her lovers, and devotes herself to idleness, show, and pleasure; -- so called from the church of Notre Dame de Lorette, in Paris, near which many of them resided.

 (a.) Detrimental.

 (n.) One who lounges; ar idler.

LOWBELL
 (n.) A bell used in fowling at night, to frighten birds, and, with a sudden light, to make them fly into a net.

LOWERED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Lower

LOWLAND
 (n.) Land which is low with respect to the neighboring country; a low or level country; -- opposed to highland.

LOZENGE

LUBBARD
 (n.) A lubber.

LUCENCY
 (n.) The quality of being lucent.

LUCIFER
 (n.) The planet Venus, when appearing as the morning star; -- applied in Isaiah by a metaphor to a king of Babylon.

LUNATIC
 (n.) A person affected by lunacy; an insane person, esp. one who has lucid intervals; a madman; a person of unsound mind.

LUNETTE
 (n.) A kind of watch crystal which is more than ordinarily flattened in the center; also, a species of convexoconcave lens for spectacles.

LURCHER
 (n.) One of a mongrel breed of dogs said to have been a cross between the sheep dog, greyhound, and spaniel. It hunts game silently, by scent, and is often used by poachers.

LUSTRED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Lustre

LUSTFUL
 (a.) Exciting lust; characterized by lust or sensuality.

LUSTILY
 (adv.) In a lusty or vigorous manner.

LUSTRAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a lustrum.

MACAUCO
 (n.) Any one of several species of small lemurs, as Lemur murinus, which resembles a rat in size.

MACHETE
 (n.) A large heavy knife resembling a broadsword, often two or three feet in length, -- used by the inhabitants of Spanish America as a hatchet to cut their way through thickets, and for various other purposes.

MACHINE
 (n.) A combination of persons acting together for a common purpose, with the agencies which they use; as, the social machine.

MACHINE
 (v. t.) To subject to the action of machinery; to effect by aid of machinery; to print with a printing machine.

MACULAE
 (pl. ) of Macula

MADONNA
 (n.) A picture of the Virgin Mary (usually with the babe).

MAESTRO
 (n.) A master in any art, especially in music; a composer.

MAGENTA

MAGICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to the hidden wisdom supposed to be possessed by the Magi; relating to the occult powers of nature, and the producing of effects by their agency.

MAGILPH
 (n.) See Megilp.

MAGNIFY
 (v. t.) To make great, or greater; to increase the dimensions of; to amplify; to enlarge, either in fact or in appearance; as, the microscope magnifies the object by a thousand diameters.

MAGNIFY
 (v. i.) To have effect; to be of importance or significance.

MAGUARI
 (n.) A South American stork (Euxenara maguari), having a forked tail.

MAHOUND
 (n.) A contemptuous name for Mohammed; hence, an evil spirit; a devil.

MAISTER
 (n.) Master.

MAJESTY
 (n.) Hence, used with the possessive pronoun, the title of an emperor, king or queen; -- in this sense taking a plural; as, their majesties attended the concert.

MAKARON
 (n.) See Macaroon, 2.

MALAISE
 (n.) An indefinite feeling of uneasiness, or of being sick or ill at ease.

MALARIA
 (n.) A morbid condition produced by exhalations from decaying vegetable matter in contact with moisture, giving rise to fever and ague and many other symptoms characterized by their tendency to recur at definite and usually uniform intervals.

MALAYAN
 (n.) The Malay language.

MALLEUS
 (n.) One of the hard lateral pieces of the mastax of Rotifera. See Mastax.

MALLOWS
 (n.) A genus of plants (Malva) having mucilaginous qualities. See Malvaceous.

MALTESE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Malta or to its inhabitants.

MALTMEN
 (pl. ) of Maltman

MANAGER
 (n.) A person who conducts business or household affairs with economy and frugality; a good economist.

MANBOTE
 (n.) A sum paid to a lord as a pecuniary compensation for killing his man (that is, his vassal, servant, or tenant).

MANDORE
 (n.) A kind of four-stringed lute.

MANDREL
 (n.) A bar of metal inserted in the work to shape it, or to hold it, as in a lathe, during the process of manufacture; an arbor.

MANGILY
 (adv.) In a mangy manner; scabbily.

 (a.) Resembling a human being in form or nature; human.

MANNITE
 (n.) A white crystalline substance of a sweet taste obtained from a so-called manna, the dried sap of the flowering ash (Fraxinus ornus); -- called also mannitol, and hydroxy hexane. Cf. Dulcite.

 (v. t.) To enter or note down upon the margin of a page; to margin.

MARITAL

MARLINE
 (v.) A small line composed of two strands a little twisted, used for winding around ropes and cables, to prevent their being weakened by fretting.

MARSHAL

 (a.) Of or pertaining to Freemasons or to their craft or mysteries.

 (a.) Forming, or consisting of, a large mass; compacted; weighty; heavy; massy.

MASTICH
 (n.) See Mastic.

MASTIFF
 (n.) A breed of large dogs noted for strength and courage. There are various strains, differing in form and color, and characteristic of different countries.

MASTOID
 (a.) Pertaining to, or in the region of, the mastoid process; mastoidal.

 (n.) The killer; the man appointed to kill the bull in bullfights.

 (a.) Full of substance or matter; important.

MATTING
 (n.) A dull, lusterless surface in certain of the arts, as gilding, metal work, glassmaking, etc.

MATWEED
 (n.) A name of several maritime grasses, as the sea sand-reed (Ammophila arundinacea) which is used in Holland to bind the sand of the seacoast dikes (see Beach grass, under Beach); also, the Lygeum Spartum, a Mediterranean grass of similar habit.

MAUNDER
 (v. i.) To beg.

MAWMISH
 (a.) Nauseous.

 (n.) The bone of either the upper or the under jaw.

MAYBIRD

MAYDUKE
 (n.) A large dark-red cherry of excellent quality.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to meadows; resembling, or consisting of, meadow.

 (a.) Winding; flexuous.

MEASURE
 (n.) Undefined quantity; extent; degree.

MEASURE
 (a.) The manner of ordering and combining the quantities, or long and short syllables; meter; rhythm; hence, a foot; as, a poem in iambic measure.

ABBATIAL
 (a.) Belonging to an abbey; as, abbatial rights.

 (a.) Producing abrasion.

ABRUPTLY
 (adv.) In an abrupt manner; without giving notice, or without the usual forms; suddenly.

ABSENTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Absent

ABSENTEE
 (n.) One who absents himself from his country, office, post, or duty; especially, a landholder who lives in another country or district than that where his estate is situated; as, an Irish absentee.

ABSOLUTE
 (a.) Loosed from, or unconnected by, dependence on any other being; self-existent; self-sufficing.

ABSTRACT
 (a.) Withdraw; separate.

ABSTRACT
 (a.) To separate, as the more volatile or soluble parts of a substance, by distillation or other chemical processes. In this sense extract is now more generally used.

ABSTRUSE
 (a.) Concealed or hidden out of the way.

ABUTILON
 (n.) A genus of malvaceous plants of many species, found in the torrid and temperate zones of both continents; -- called also Indian mallow.

ACADEMIC
 (n.) One holding the philosophy of Socrates and Plato; a Platonist.

ACARIDAN
 (n.) One of a group of arachnids, including the mites and ticks.

ACAULOUS
 (a.) Same as Acaulescent.

ACCEPTOR
 (n.) One who accepts

ACCIDENT
 (n.) Any accidental property, fact, or relation; an accidental or nonessential; as, beauty is an accident.

ACCOLADE
 (n.) A ceremony formerly used in conferring knighthood, consisting am embrace, and a slight blow on the shoulders with the flat blade of a sword.

ACCREDIT

ACCRUING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Accrue

ACOUSTIC
 (n.) A medicine or agent to assist hearing.

ACRANIAL
 (a.) Wanting a skull.

ACRIMONY
 (n.) Sharpness or severity, as of language or temper; irritating bitterness of disposition or manners.

ACRODONT
 (n.) One of a group of lizards having the teeth immovably united to the top of the alveolar ridge.

ACROSTIC
 (n.) A Hebrew poem in which the lines or stanzas begin with the letters of the alphabet in regular order (as Psalm cxix.). See Abecedarian.

ACROTISM
 (n.) Lack or defect of pulsation.

 (v. t.) To make active.

ACUATION
 (n.) Act of sharpening.

ADDITION
 (n.) That part of arithmetic which treats of adding numbers.

ADDUCTOR
 (n.) A muscle which draws a limb or part of the body toward the middle line of the body, or closes extended parts of the body; -- opposed to abductor; as, the adductor of the eye, which turns the eye toward the nose.

ADEQUATE
 (a.) Equal to some requirement; proportionate, or correspondent; fully sufficient; as, powers adequate to a great work; an adequate definition.

ADHAMANT
 (a.) Clinging, as by hooks.

ADHERENT
 (a.) Congenitally united with an organ of another kind, as calyx with ovary, or stamens with petals.

ADHESION
 (n.) Adherence; steady or firm attachment; fidelity; as, adhesion to error, to a policy.

ADHESIVE
 (a.) Apt or tending to adhere; clinging.

ADJUDGED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Adjudge

ADJUDGER
 (n.) One who adjudges.

ADJUTAGE
 (n.) Same as Ajutage.

ADJUVANT
 (n.) An assistant.

ADMITTER
 (n.) One who admits.

ADOPTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Adopt

ADOPTIVE
 (a.) Pertaining to adoption; made or acquired by adoption; fitted to adopt; as, an adoptive father, an child; an adoptive language.

ADRAGANT
 (n.) Gum tragacanth.

ADULTERY
 (n.) The intrusion of a person into a bishopric during the life of the bishop.

ADVISING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Advise

AEGILOPS
 (n.) An ulcer or fistula in the inner corner of the eye.

AERATION
 (n.) Exposure to the free action of the air; airing; as, aeration of soil, of spawn, etc.

AEROBIES
 (n. pl.) Microorganisms which live in contact with the air and need oxygen for their growth; as the microbacteria which form on the surface of putrefactive fluids.

AEROLITH
 (n.) Same as A/rolite.

AEROLOGY
 (n.) That department of physics which treats of the atmosphere.

AEROSTAT
 (n.) A balloon.

AESTIVAL
 (a.) Of or belonging to the summer; as, aestival diseases.

AESTUOUS
 (a.) Glowing; agitated, as with heat.

AFFIRMED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Affirm

AFFRIGHT
 (n.) The act of frightening; also, a cause of terror; an object of dread.

AFFUSION
 (n.) The act of pouring upon, or sprinkling with a liquid, as water upon a child in baptism.

AFLUTTER
 (adv. & a.) In a flutter; agitated.

AGAINBUY
 (v. t.) To redeem.

AGEDNESS
 (n.) The quality of being aged; oldness.

AGENESIS
 (n.) Any imperfect development of the body, or any anomaly of organization.

AGENTIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency.

AGGRIEVE
 (v. i.) To grieve; to lament.

AGITATOR
 (n.) One who agitates; one who stirs up or excites others; as, political reformers and agitators.

AGRARIAN
 (a.) Pertaining to fields, or lands, or their tenure; esp., relating to an equal or equitable division of lands; as, the agrarian laws of Rome, which distributed the conquered and other public lands among citizens.

AGRESTIC
 (a.) Pertaining to fields or the country, in opposition to the city; rural; rustic; unpolished; uncouth.

AGRIMONY
 (n.) The name is also given to various other plants; as, hemp agrimony (Eupatorium cannabinum); water agrimony (Bidens).

AGRONOMY
 (n.) The management of land; rural economy; agriculture.

AIGUILLE
 (n.) An instrument for boring holes, used in blasting.

ALACRIFY
 (v. t.) To rouse to action; to inspirit.

ALALONGA
 (n.) Alt. of Alilonghi

ALBANIAN
 (n.) A native of Albania.

ALBINESS
 (n.) A female albino.

ALBUMOSE
 (n.) A compound or class of compounds formed from albumin by dilute acids or by an acid solution of pepsin. Used also in combination, as antialbumose, hemialbumose.

 (n.) Same as Alkahest.

ALGIDITY
 (n.) Chilliness; coldness

ALGORISM
 (n.) Alt. of Algorithm

 (n.) Same as Cacodylic acid.

 (n.) Am eagle without beak or feet, with expanded wings.

 (v. t.) To connect by alliance; to ally.

ALLNIGHT
 (n.) Light, fuel, or food for the whole night.

ALLUDING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Allude

ALLUSIVE
 (a.) Having reference to something not fully expressed; containing an allusion.

ALLUVION
 (n.) An overflowing; an inundation; a flood.

ALLUVIUM
 (n.) Deposits of earth, sand, gravel, and other transported matter, made by rivers, floods, or other causes, upon land not permanently submerged beneath the waters of lakes or seas.

ALMIGHTY
 (a.) Great; extreme; terrible.

ALPHABET
 (v. t.) To designate by the letters of the alphabet; to arrange alphabetically.

ALTITUDE
 (n.) Space extended upward; height; the perpendicular elevation of an object above its foundation, above the ground, or above a given level, or of one object above another; as, the altitude of a mountain, or of a bird above the top of a tree.

ALTRUIST
 (n.) One imbued with altruism; -- opposed to egoist.

ALUMINIC
 (a.) Of or containing aluminium; as, aluminic phosphate.

 (n.) See Aluminium.

AMAZEFUL

 (a.) Like an amoeba in structure.

 (n.) An element that in combination produces amphid salt; -- applied by Berzelius to oxygen, sulphur, selenium, and tellurium.

ANABASIS
 (n.) A journey or expedition up from the coast, like that of the younger Cyrus into Central Asia, described by Xenophon in his work called The Anabasis.

ANALCITE
 (n.) Analcime.

ANALOGUE
 (n.) An organ which is equivalent in its functions to a different organ in another species or group, or even in the same group; as, the gill of a fish is the analogue of a lung in a quadruped, although the two are not of like structural relations.

ANALYSIS
 (n.) The separation of a compound substance, by chemical processes, into its constituents, with a view to ascertain either (a) what elements it contains, or (b) how much of each element is present. The former is called qualitative, and the latter quanti

ANAPHORA
 (n.) A repetition of a word or of words at the beginning of two or more successive clauses.

ANATHEMA
 (n.) A ban or curse pronounced with religious solemnity by ecclesiastical authority, and accompanied by excommunication. Hence: Denunciation of anything as accursed.

ANCHORED
 (a.) Having the extremities turned back, like the flukes of an anchor; as, an anchored cross.

ANCHUSIN
 (n.) A resinoid coloring matter obtained from alkanet root.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to the ancon or elbow.

 (a.) Alt. of Anginose

 (a.) Angulous.

 (v. t.) To record in annals.

ANNELIDA
 (n. pl.) A division of the Articulata, having the body formed of numerous rings or annular segments, and without jointed legs. The principal subdivisions are the Chaetopoda, including the Oligochaeta or earthworms and Polychaeta or marine worms; and the

ANNULATA
 (n. pl.) A class of articulate animals, nearly equivalent to Annelida, including the marine annelids, earthworms, Gephyrea, Gymnotoma, leeches, etc. See Annelida.

ANNULOSE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Annulosa.

ANOPHYTE
 (n.) A moss or mosslike plant which cellular stems, having usually an upward growth and distinct leaves.

 (n.) A medicine to alleviate pain; an anodyne.

 (n.) That of which the type is the pattern or representation; that which is represented by the type or symbol.

ANTRORSE
 (a.) Forward or upward in direction.

AORISTIC
 (a.) Indefinite; pertaining to the aorist tense.

 (pl. ) of Arboretum

 (n.) A dwarf tree, one in size between a shrub and a tree; a treelike shrub.

ARCHAEAN
 (n.) The earliest period in geological period, extending up to the Lower Silurian. It includes an Azoic age, previous to the appearance of life, and an Eozoic age, including the earliest forms of life.

ARCHNESS
 (n.) The quality of being arch; cleverness; sly humor free from malice; waggishness.

ARDENTLY
 (adv.) In an ardent manner; eagerly; with warmth; affectionately; passionately.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to silver; resembling, containing, or combined with, silver.

 (n.) A cephalopod of the genus Argonauta.

 (a.) Pertaining to the peculiar species of rhyme called assonance; not consonant.

 (a.) Characterized by, or pertaining to, debility; weak; debilitating.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to atoms.

ATOMIZER
 (n.) One who, or that which, atomizes; esp., an instrument for reducing a liquid to spray for disinfecting, cooling, or perfuming.

ATROPINE
 (n.) A poisonous, white, crystallizable alkaloid, extracted from the Atropa belladonna, or deadly nightshade, and the Datura Stramonium, or thorn apple. It is remarkable for its power in dilating the pupil of the eye. Called also daturine.

ATTAINED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Attain

AVERNIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Avernus, a lake of Campania, in Italy, famous for its poisonous vapors, which ancient writers fancied were so malignant as to kill birds flying over it. It was represented by the poets to be connected with the infernal regions.

BARBERRY

BARBACAN
 (n.) A tower or advanced work defending the entrance to a castle or city, as at a gate or bridge. It was often large and strong, having a ditch and drawbridge of its own.

BARNACLE
 (n.) Any cirriped crustacean adhering to rocks, floating timber, ships, etc., esp. (a) the sessile species (genus Balanus and allies), and (b) the stalked or goose barnacles (genus Lepas and allies). See Cirripedia, and Goose barnacle.

BARRATRY
 (n.) The practice of exciting and encouraging lawsuits and quarrels.

 (n.) A short sword or dagger, worn in the fifteenth century.

BASIHYAL
 (a.) Noting two small bones, forming the body of the inverted hyoid arch.

BASILICA
 (n.) A church building of the earlier centuries of Christianity, the plan of which was taken from the basilica of the Romans. The name is still applied to some churches by way of honorary distinction.

BASILISK
 (n.) A lizard of the genus Basiliscus, belonging to the family Iguanidae.

BASSWOOD

BIENNIAL

 (a.) Having, or consisting of, two branches.

BIRDBOLT
 (n.) Anything which smites without penetrating.

BIRDLIME
 (n.) An extremely adhesive viscid substance, usually made of the middle bark of the holly, by boiling, fermenting, and cleansing it. When a twig is smeared with this substance it will hold small birds which may light upon it. Hence: Anything which insna

BIRTHDAY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the day of birth, or its anniversary; as, birthday gifts or festivities.

BISCAYAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Biscay in Spain.

BISETOUS
 (a.) Having two bristles.

BISHOPED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Bishop

BITTERLY
 (adv.) In a bitter manner.

BIWEEKLY
 (a.) Occurring or appearing once every two weeks; fortnightly.

BLACKCAP
 (n.) The black raspberry.

BLACKLEG
 (n.) A disease among calves and sheep, characterized by a settling of gelatinous matter in the legs, and sometimes in the neck.

BLAMEFUL
 (a.) Attributing blame or fault; implying or conveying censure; faultfinding; censorious.

BLANCARD
 (n.) A kind of linen cloth made in Normandy, the thread of which is partly blanches before it is woven.

BLANDISH
 (v. t.) To make agreeable and enticing.

BLASTING
 (n.) A blast; destruction by a blast, or by some pernicious cause.

BLAZONRY
 (n.) A coat of arms; an armorial bearing or bearings.

BLEAREYE
 (n.) A disease of the eyelids, consisting in chronic inflammation of the margins, with a gummy secretion of sebaceous matter.

BLEEDING
 (n.) A running or issuing of blood, as from the nose or a wound; a hemorrhage; the operation of letting blood, as in surgery; a drawing or running of sap from a tree or plant.

BLENCHER
 (n.) One who blenches, flinches, or shrinks back.

BLENDING
 (n.) The act of mingling.

BLENNIID
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the blennies.

BLESSING
 (v. t.) The act of one who blesses.

BLOCKADE
 (v. t.) An obstruction to passage.

BLOEDITE
 (n.) A hydrous sulphate of magnesium and sodium.

BLOODILY
 (adv.) In a bloody manner; cruelly; with a disposition to shed blood.

BLOODLET
 (v. t. ) bleed; to let blood.

BLOODWIT
 (n.) A fine or amercement paid as a composition for the shedding of blood; also, a riot wherein blood was spilled.

BLOOMERY
 (n.) A furnace and forge in which wrought iron in the form of blooms is made directly from the ore, or (more rarely) from cast iron.

BLOWHOLE
 (n.) An air hole in a casting.

BLOWPIPE
 (n.) A tube for directing a jet of air into a fire or into the flame of a lamp or candle, so as to concentrate the heat on some object.

BLOWTUBE
 (n.) A similar instrument, commonly of tin, used by boys for discharging paper wads and other light missiles.

BLUBBERY
 (a.) Like blubber; gelatinous and quivering; as, a blubbery mass.

BLUECOAT
 (n.) One dressed in blue, as a soldier, a sailor, a beadle, etc.

BLUENESS
 (n.) The quality of being blue; a blue color.

BLUNGING
 (n.) The process of mixing clay in potteries with a blunger.

BLUNTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Blunt

BLUNTISH
 (a.) Somewhat blunt.

BOARFISH
 (n.) An Australian percoid fish (Histiopterus recurvirostris), valued as a food fish.

BOATABLE
 (a.) Navigable for boats, or small river craft.

BODILESS
 (a.) Having no body.

BOGBERRY
 (n.) The small cranberry (Vaccinium oxycoccus), which grows in boggy places.

BOHEMIAN
 (n.) The language of the Czechs (the ancient inhabitants of Bohemia), the richest and most developed of the dialects of the Slavic family.

BONEACHE
 (n.) Pain in the bones.

BONEFISH
 (n.) See Ladyfish.

BONIFORM
 (a.) Sensitive or responsive to moral excellence.

BONITARY
 (a.) Beneficial, as opposed to statutory or civil; as, bonitary dominion of land.

BONSMOTS
 (pl. ) of Bonmot

BOOBYISH
 (a.) Stupid; dull.

BOOHOOED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Boohoe

BOOKLAND
 (n.) Alt. of Bockland

BOOKWORM
 (n.) A student closely attached to books or addicted to study; a reader without appreciation.

BOOTJACK
 (n.) A device for pulling off boots.

BOTTOMED
 (a.) Having at the bottom, or as a bottom; resting upon a bottom; grounded; -- mostly, in composition; as, sharp-bottomed; well-bottomed.

BOUCHEES
 (n. pl.) Small patties.

BOUNDING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bound

BOUNDING
 (a.) Moving with a bound or bounds.

BOURGEON
 (v. i.) To sprout; to put forth buds; to shoot forth, as a branch.

BOYISHLY
 (adv.) In a boyish manner; like a boy.

BRACCHIA
 (pl. ) of Brachium

BRAHMANS
 (pl. ) of Brahmin

BRAINING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Brain

BRAINPAN
 (n.) The bones which inclose the brain; the skull; the cranium.

BRAKEMAN
 (n.) The man in charge of the winding (or hoisting) engine for a mine.

BRANDIED
 (a.) Mingled with brandy; made stronger by the addition of brandy; flavored or treated with brandy; as, brandied peaches.

BRANGLER
 (n.) A quarrelsome person.

BRASSAGE
 (n.) A sum formerly levied to pay the expense of coinage; -- now called seigniorage.

BREACHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Breach

BREAKAGE
 (n.) The act of breaking; a break; a breaking; also, articles broken.

BREAMING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bream

BREEDING
 (n.) Nurture; education; formation of manners.

BRETHREN
 (n.) pl. of Brother.

BREVIPED
 (n.) A breviped bird.

BRIAREAN
 (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, Briareus, a giant fabled to have a hundred hands; hence, hundred-handed or many-handed.

BRICKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Brick

BRIDALTY
 (n.) Celebration of the nuptial feast.

BRIEFMAN
 (n.) One who makes a brief.

BRIGHTEN
 (a.) To make acute or witty; to enliven.

BRIMMING
 (a.) Full to the brim; overflowing.

BROACHER
 (n.) A spit; a broach.

BROCADED
 (a.) Dressed in brocade.

BROCCOLI
 (n.) A plant of the Cabbage species (Brassica oleracea) of many varieties, resembling the cauliflower. The curd, or flowering head, is the part used for food.

BRONZINE
 (a.) Made of bronzine; resembling bronze; bronzelike.

BROOKLET
 (n.) A small brook.

BRETHREN
 (pl. ) of Brother

BROWNIST
 (n.) A follower of Robert Brown, of England, in the 16th century, who taught that every church is complete and independent in itself when organized, and consists of members meeting in one place, having full power to elect and depose its officers.

BROWPOST
 (n.) A beam that goes across a building.

BRUSSELS
 (n.) A city of Belgium, giving its name to a kind of carpet, a kind of lace, etc.

BUANSUAH
 (n.) The wild dog of northern India (Cuon primaevus), supposed by some to be an ancestral species of the domestic dog.

BUBALINE
 (a.) Resembling a buffalo.

BUILDING
 (n.) That which is built; a fabric or edifice constructed, as a house, a church, etc.

BULLFICE
 (n.) A kind of fungus. See Puffball.

BULLHEAD
 (n.) The black-bellied plover (Squatarola helvetica); -- called also beetlehead.

BULLPOUT
 (n.) See Bullhead, 1 (b).

BULLYRAG
 (v. t.) Same as Bullirag.

BUNGHOLE
 (n.) See Bung, n., 2.

BUOYANCY
 (n.) The property of floating on the surface of a liquid, or in a fluid, as in the atmosphere; specific lightness, which is inversely as the weight compared with that of an equal volume of water.

BURDENER
 (n.) One who loads; an oppressor.

BURGANET
 (n.) See Burgonet.

BURGONET
 (n.) A kind of helmet.

BUSINESS
 (n.) Affair; concern; matter; -- used in an indefinite sense, and modified by the connected words.

BUTTERIS
 (n.) A steel cutting instrument, with a long bent shank set in a handle which rests against the shoulder of the operator. It is operated by a thrust movement, and used in paring the hoofs of horses.

BUTTRESS
 (n.) A projecting mass of masonry, used for resisting the thrust of an arch, or for ornament and symmetry.

BYSSUSES
 (pl. ) of Byssus

CABALISM
 (n.) The secret science of the cabalists.

CABALIZE
 (v. i.) To use cabalistic language.

CABBLING
 (n.) The process of breaking up the flat masses into which wrought iron is first hammered, in order that the pieces may be reheated and wrought into bar iron.

CABOTAGE
 (n.) Navigation along the coast; the details of coast pilotage.

CACKEREL
 (n.) The mendole; a small worthless Mediterranean fish considered poisonous by the ancients. See Mendole.

CACODOXY
 (n.) Erroneous doctrine; heresy; heterodoxy.

CACOMIXL
 (n.) A North American carnivore (Bassaris astuta), about the size of a cat, related to the raccoons. It inhabits Mexico, Texas, and California.

CADEWORM
 (n.) A caddice. See Caddice.

CADUCARY
 (a.) Relating to escheat, forfeiture, or confiscation.

CAGELING
 (n.) A bird confined in a cage; esp. a young bird.

CAHINCIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, cahinca, the native name of a species of Brazilian Chiococca, perhaps C. racemosa; as, cahincic acid.

CAJOLING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cajole

CALAMBAC
 (n.) A fragrant wood; agalloch.

CALCIDEN
 (imp. & p. p.) of Calcine

CALENDAR
 (n.) An orderly arrangement of the division of time, adapted to the purposes of civil life, as years, months, weeks, and days; also, a register of the year with its divisions; an almanac.

CALENDER
 (n.) To press between rollers for the purpose of making smooth and glossy, or wavy, as woolen and silk stuffs, linens, paper, etc.

CALLIOPE
 (n.) One of the asteroids. See Solar.

CALLOSAN
 (a.) Of the callosum.

CALMUCKS
 (n. pl.) A branch of the Mongolian race inhabiting parts of the Russian and Chinese empires; also (sing.), the language of the Calmucks.

CALYMENE
 (n.) A genus of trilobites characteristic of the Silurian age.

CAMBRIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Cambria or Wales.

CAMISOLE
 (n.) A short dressing jacket for women.

CAMOMILE
 (n.) Alt. of Chamomile

CAMOUSLY
 (adv.) Awry.

CAMPAGNA
 (n.) An open level tract of country; especially Campagna di Roma. The extensive undulating plain which surrounds Rome.

CAMPAIGN
 (v. i.) To serve in a campaign.

CAMPHINE
 (n.) Rectified oil of turpentine, used for burning in lamps, and as a common solvent in varnishes.

CANCELLI
 (v. t.) The interlacing osseous plates constituting the elastic porous tissue of certain parts of the bones, esp. in their articular extremities.

CANCRINE
 (a.) Having the qualities of a crab; crablike.

CANDYING
 (p. pr & vb. n.) of Candy

CANNIBAL
 (n.) A human being that eats human flesh; hence, any that devours its own kind.

CANOEIST
 (n.) A canoeman.

CANSTICK
 (n.) Candlestick.

CANTICLE
 (n.) A psalm, hymn, or passage from the Bible, arranged for chanting in church service.

CANTONED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Canton

CANTONED
 (a.) Having the angles marked by, or decorated with, projecting moldings or small columns; as, a cantoned pier or pilaster.

CANTORIS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a cantor; as, the cantoris side of a choir; a cantoris stall.

CAPACITY
 (n.) The power of receiving and holding ideas, knowledge, etc.; the comprehensiveness of the mind; the receptive faculty; capability of undestanding or feeling.

CAPERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Caper

CAPITULE
 (n.) A summary.

CAPRIOLE
 (v. i.) To perform a capriole.

CAPSULAR
 (a.) Alt. of Capsulary

CAPUCHED
 (a.) Cover with, or as with, a hood.

CAPUCINE
 (n.) See Capuchin, 3.

CARACORE
 (n.) Alt. of Caracora

CARBOLIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an acid derived from coal tar and other sources; as, carbolic acid (called also phenic acid, and phenol). See Phenol.

CARELESS
 (a.) Without thought or purpose; without due care; without attention to rule or system; unstudied; inconsiderate; spontaneous; rash; as, a careless throw; a careless expression.

CARESSED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Caress

CARIBBEE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Caribs, to their islands (the eastern and southern West Indies), or to the sea (called the Caribbean sea) lying between those islands and Central America.

CARILLON
 (n.) A chime of bells diatonically tuned, played by clockwork or by finger keys.

CARNALLY
 (adv.) According to the flesh, to the world, or to human nature; in a manner to gratify animal appetites and lusts; sensually.

CARNIVAL
 (n.) Any merrymaking, feasting, or masquerading, especially when overstepping the bounds of decorum; a time of riotous excess.

CAROLING
 (n.) A song of joy or devotion; a singing, as of carols.

CARRIAGE
 (n.) That which is carried; burden; baggage.

CARRIAGE
 (n.) A part of a machine which moves and carries of supports some other moving object or part.

CARTBOTE
 (n.) Wood to which a tenant is entitled for making and repairing carts and other instruments of husbandry.

CARTOUCH
 (n.) A cantalever, console, corbel, or modillion, which has the form of a scroll of paper

CARUNCLE
 (n.) Alt. of Caruncula

CARYATID
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a caryatid.

CASEMATE
 (n.) A hollow molding, chiefly in cornices.

CASHMERE
 (n.) A rich stuff for shawls, scarfs, etc., originally made in Cashmere from the soft wool found beneath the hair of the goats of Cashmere, Thibet, and the Himalayas. Some cashmere, of fine quality, is richly embroidered for sale to Europeans.

CASTAWAY
 (n.) One who, or that which, is cast away or shipwrecked.

CASTLERY
 (n.) The government of a castle.

CASTRATE
 (v. t.) To cut or take out; esp. to remove anything erroneous, or objectionable from, as the obscene parts of a writing; to expurgate.

CATACOMB
 (n.) A cave, grotto, or subterraneous place of large extent used for the burial of the dead; -- commonly in the plural.

CATALYSE
 (pl. ) of Catalysis

CATAMITE
 (n.) A boy kept for unnatural purposes.

CATARACT
 (n.) A great fall of water over a precipice; a large waterfall.

CATCHFLY
 (n.) A plant with the joints of the stem, and sometimes other parts, covered with a viscid secretion to which small insects adhere. The species of Silene are examples of the catchfly.

CATENARY
 (n.) The curve formed by a rope or chain of uniform density and perfect flexibility, hanging freely between two points of suspension, not in the same vertical line.

CATHOLIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to, or affecting the Roman Catholics; as, the Catholic emancipation act.

CAUDICLE
 (n.) Alt. of Caudicula

CAUSATOR
 (n.) One who causes.

CAUSEFUL
 (n.) Having a cause.

CAUSEUSE
 (n.) A kind of sofa for two persons. A tete-/-tete.

CAUTIOUS
 (a.) Attentive to examine probable effects and consequences of acts with a view to avoid danger or misfortune; prudent; circumspect; wary; watchful; as, a cautious general.

CAVALIER
 (n.) A military man serving on horseback; a knight.

CAVALIER
 (a.) Supercilious; haughty; disdainful; curt; brusque.

CAVERNED
 (a.) Containing caverns.

CAVESSON
 (n.) Alt. of Cavezon

CELATURE
 (n.) That which is engraved.

CELIBACY
 (n.) The state of being unmarried; single life, esp. that of a bachelor, or of one bound by vows not to marry.

CELOTOMY
 (n.) The act or operation of cutting, to relieve the structure in strangulated hernia.

CENOZOIC
 (a.) Belonging to the most recent division of geological time, including the tertiary, or Age of mammals, and the Quaternary, or Age of man. [Written also caenozoic, cainozoic, kainozoic.] See Geology.

CENTAURY
 (n.) A gentianaceous plant not fully identified. The name is usually given to the Erytheraea Centaurium and the Chlora perfoliata of Europe, but is also extended to the whole genus Sabbatia, and even to the unrelated Centaurea.

CENTRING
 () of Centre

CENTIPED
 (n.) A species of the Myriapoda; esp. the large, flattened, venomous kinds of the order Chilopoda, found in tropical climates. they are many-jointed, and have a great number of feet.

CEPHALIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the head. See the Note under Anterior.

CERATINE
 (a.) Sophistical.

CERBERUS
 (n.) A monster, in the shape of a three-headed dog, guarding the entrance into the infernal regions, Hence: Any vigilant custodian or guardian, esp. if surly.

CEREALIN
 (n.) A nitrogenous substance closely resembling diastase, obtained from bran, and possessing the power of converting starch into dextrin, sugar, and lactic acid.

CEREMENT
 (n.) Any shroud or wrapping for the dead.

CERULEAN
 (a.) Sky-colored; blue; azure.

CERVELAT
 (n.) An ancient wind instrument, resembling the bassoon in tone.

CESSAVIT
 (n.) A writ given by statute to recover lands when the tenant has for two years failed to perform the conditions of his tenure.

CESSPIPE
 (n.) A pipe for carrying off waste water, etc., from a sink or cesspool.

CETEWALE
 (n.) Same as Zedoary.

CETRARIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, the lichen, Iceland moss (Cetaria Islandica).

CHALAZAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the chalaza.

CHALDEAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Chaldea.

CHALICED
 (a.) Having a calyx or cup; cup-shaped.

CHAMBREL
 (n.) Same as Gambrel.

CHANCERY
 (n.) In the Unites States, a court of equity; equity; proceeding in equity.

CHANDLER
 (n.) A maker or seller of candles.

CHAPLAIN
 (n.) An ecclesiastic who has a chapel, or who performs religious service in a chapel.

CHAPLESS
 (a.) Having no lower jaw; hence, fleshless.

CHARLOCK
 (n.) A cruciferous plant (Brassica sinapistrum) with yellow flowers; wild mustard. It is troublesome in grain fields. Called also chardock, chardlock, chedlock, and kedlock.

CHARNECO
 (n.) Alt. of Charnico

CHASIBLE
 (n.) See Chasuble.

CHASTELY
 (adv.) In a chaste manner; with purity.

CHASTISE
 (v. t.) To inflict pain upon, by means of stripes, or in any other manner, for the purpose of punishment or reformation; to punish, as with stripes.

CHASTITY
 (n.) The unmarried life; celibacy.

CHAWDRON
 (n.) Entrails.

CHECKAGE
 (n.) The items, or the amount, to which attention is called by a check or checks.

CHEERFUL
 (a.) Having or showing good spirits or joy; cheering; cheery; contented; happy; joyful; lively; animated; willing.

CHEMICAL
 (n.) A substance used for producing a chemical effect; a reagent.

CHERUBIM
 (pl. ) of Cherub

CHESSMEN
 (pl. ) of Chessman

CHESTNUT
 (n.) A bright brown color, like that of the nut.

CHETVERT
 (n.) A measure of grain equal to 0.7218 of an imperial quarter, or 01.05.95 Winchester bushels.

CHEVERIL
 (v. i.) Soft leather made of kid skin. Fig.: Used as a symbol of flexibility.

CHICCORY
 (n.) See Chicory.

CHIEFEST
 (a.) First or foremost; chief; principal.

CHILDING
 (v. i.) Bearing Children; (Fig.) productive; fruitful.

CHIPMUNK
 (n.) A squirrel-like animal of the genus Tamias, sometimes called the striped squirrel, chipping squirrel, ground squirrel, hackee. The common species of the United States is the Tamias striatus.

CHIRETTA
 (n.) A plant (Agathotes Chirayta) found in Northern India, having medicinal properties to the gentian, and esteemed as a tonic and febrifuge.

CHIVALRY
 (n.) A body or order of cavaliers or knights serving on horseback; illustrious warriors, collectively; cavalry.

CHLORINE
 (n.) One of the elementary substances, commonly isolated as a greenish yellow gas, two and one half times as heavy as air, of an intensely disagreeable suffocating odor, and exceedingly poisonous. It is abundant in nature, the most important compound be

CHOKEDAR
 (n.) A watchman; an officer of customs or police.

CHOLERIC
 (a.) Easily irritated; irascible; inclined to anger.

CHOPPING
 (a.) Stout or plump; large.

CHRISTEN
 (v. t.) To use for the first time.

CHRISTOM
 (n.) See Chrisom.

CHROMIUM
 (n.) A comparatively rare element occurring most abundantly in the mineral chromite. Atomic weight 52.5. Symbol Cr. When isolated it is a hard, brittle, grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty. Its chief commercial importance is for its compounds,

CHROMULE
 (n.) A general name for coloring matter of plants other than chlorophyll, especially that of petals.

CHRYSENE
 (n.) One of the higher aromatic hydrocarbons of coal tar, allied to naphthalene and anthracene. It is a white crystalline substance, C18H12, of strong blue fluorescence, but generally colored yellow by impurities.

CHTHONIC
 (a.) Pertaining to the earth; earthy; as, chthonic religions.

CHURCHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Church

CHURNING
 (n.) The quantity of butter made at one operation.

CIBORIUM
 (n.) The coffer or case in which the host is kept; the pyx.

CILICIAN
 (n.) A native or inhabitant of Cilicia.

CIMBRIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Cimbri.

CIMOLITE
 (n.) A soft, earthy, clayey mineral, of whitish or grayish color.

CINCTURE
 (n.) That which encompasses or incloses; an inclosure.

CINGULUM
 (n.) A distinct girdle or band of color; a raised spiral line as seen on certain univalve shells.

CINNAMYL
 (n.) The hypothetical radical, (C6H5.C2H2)2C, of cinnamic compounds.

CIRCULAR
 (a.) repeating itself; ending in itself; reverting to the point of beginning; hence, illogical; inconclusive; as, circular reasoning.

CIRRHOUS
 (a.) See Cirrose.

CITATION
 (n.) A reference to decided cases, or books of authority, to prove a point in law.

CIVICISM
 (n.) The principle of civil government.

CLAMBAKE
 (n.) The backing or steaming of clams on heated stones, between layers of seaweed; hence, a picnic party, gathered on such an occasion.

CLANGING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Clang

CLANSMAN
 (n.) One belonging to the same clan with another.

CLASSIFY
 (v. t.) To distribute into classes; to arrange according to a system; to arrange in sets according to some method founded on common properties or characters.

CLASSMAN
 (n.) A candidate for graduation in arts who is placed in an honor class, as opposed to a passman, who is not classified.

CLAVECIN
 (n.) The harpsichord.

CLAVISES
 (pl. ) of Clavis

CLEANING
 (n.) The act of making clean.

CLEARING
 (n.) A tract of land cleared of wood for cultivation.

CLEAVAGE
 (n.) Division into laminae, like slate, with the lamination not necessarily parallel to the plane of deposition; -- usually produced by pressure.

CLEMENCY
 (n.) Disposition to forgive and spare, as offenders; mildness of temper; gentleness; tenderness; mercy.

CLINCHER
 (n.) That which ends a dispute or controversy; a decisive argument.

CLINIQUE
 (n.) A clinic.

CLIPPING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Clip

CLOTHING
 (n.) See Card clothing, under 3d Card.

 (a.) Covered with growing clover.

CLOWNERY
 (n.) Clownishness.

CLUBBISH
 (a.) Disposed to club together; as, a clubbish set.

CLUCKING
 (p pr. & vb. n.) of Cluck

CLUSTERY
 (n.) Growing in, or full of, clusters; like clusters.

CLUTCHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Clutch

CLYSMIAN
 (a.) Connected with, or related to, the deluge, or to a cataclysm; as, clysmian changes.

CNIDARIA
 (n. pl.) A comprehensive group equivalent to the T Coelenterata, i. e., exclusive of the sponges. They are so named from presence of stinging cells (cnidae) in the tissues. See Coelenterata.

COALFISH
 (n.) The beshow or candlefish of Alaska.

COCKSHUT
 (n.) A kind of net to catch woodcock.

COCKWEED
 (n.) Peppergrass.

COCOBOLO
 (n.) Alt. of Cocobolas

CODIFIER
 (n.) One who codifies.

CODPIECE
 (n.) A part of male dress in front of the breeches, formerly made very conspicuous.

COERCION
 (n.) The act or process of coercing.

COGITATE
 (v. i.) To engage in continuous thought; to think.

COGNISEE
 (n.) See Cognizor, Cognizee.

COGNOMEN
 (n.) The last of the three names of a person among the ancient Romans, denoting his house or family.

COHERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cohere

COHESIVE
 (a.) Cohering, or sticking together, as in a mass; capable of cohering; tending to cohere; as, cohesive clay.

COINCIDE
 (n.) To occupy the same place in space, as two equal triangles, when placed one on the other.

COLANDER
 (n.) A utensil with a bottom perforated with little holes for straining liquids, mashed vegetable pulp, etc.; a strainer of wickerwork, perforated metal, or the like.

COLEWORT
 (n.) A variety of cabbage in which the leaves never form a compact head.

COLLAPSE
 (n.) Extreme depression or sudden failing of all the vital powers, as the result of disease, injury, or nervous disturbance.

COLLARED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Collar

COLLARED
 (a.) Wearing a collar; -- said of a man or beast used as a bearing when a collar is represented as worn around the neck or loins.

COLLATOR
 (n.) One who collates to a benefice.

COLLUDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Collude

COLORING
 (n.) The act of applying color to; also, that which produces color.

COLORMAN
 (n.) A vender of paints, etc.

COMATOSE
 (a.) Relating to, or resembling, coma; drowsy; lethargic; as, comatose sleep; comatose fever.

COMBATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Combat

COMBINER
 (n.) One who, or that which, combines.

COMEDIAN
 (n.) A writer of comedy.

COMEDIES
 (pl. ) of Comedy

COMITIAL
 (a.) Relating to the comitia, or popular assemblies of the Romans for electing officers and passing laws.

COMMENCE
 (v. i.) To have a beginning or origin; to originate; to start; to begin.

COMMONER
 (n.) One sharing with another in anything.

COMMUNED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Commune

COMPILED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Compile

COMPLAIN
 (v. i.) To give utterance to expression of grief, pain, censure, regret. etc.; to lament; to murmur; to find fault; -- commonly used with of. Also, to creak or squeak, as a timber or wheel.

COMPLINE
 (n.) Alt. of Complin

COMPOSED
 (a.) Free from agitation; calm; sedate; quiet; tranquil; self-possessed.

COMPOUND
 (v. i.) To effect a composition; to come to terms of agreement; to agree; to settle by a compromise; -- usually followed by with before the person participating, and for before the thing compounded or the consideration.

COMPRESS
 (v. t.) To press or squeeze together; to force into a narrower compass; to reduce the volume of by pressure; to compact; to condense; as, to compress air or water.

CONCLAVE
 (n.) The set of apartments within which the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church are continuously secluded while engaged in choosing a pope.

CONCLUDE
 (v. t.) To shut up; to inclose.

CONCLUDE
 (v. t.) To shut off; to restrain; to limit; to estop; to bar; -- generally in the passive; as, the defendant is concluded by his own plea; a judgment concludes the introduction of further evidence argument.

CONCRETE
 (n.) A mixture of gravel, pebbles, or broken stone with cement or with tar, etc., used for sidewalks, roadways, foundations, etc., and esp. for submarine structures.

CONCRETE
 (v. t.) To form into a mass, as by the cohesion or coalescence of separate particles.

CONDENSE
 (v. i.) To become more compact; to be reduced into a denser form.

CONDOLED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Condole

CONDYLAR
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a condyle.

CONFALON
 (n.) One of a fraternity of seculars, also called Penitents.

CONFERVA
 (n.) Any unbranched, slender, green plant of the fresh-water algae. The word is frequently used in a wider sense.

CONFIDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Confide

CONFIDER
 (n.) One who confides.

CONFINER
 (n.) One who, or that which, limits or restrains.

CONFOUND
 (v. t.) To destroy; to ruin; to waste.

CONFRACT
 (a.) Broken in pieces; severed.

CONFRIER
 (n.) A confr/re.

CONGRESS
 (n.) A meeting of individuals, whether friendly or hostile; an encounter.

CONGRESS
 (n.) The lower house of the Spanish Cortes, the members of which are elected for three years.

CONIDIUM
 (n.) A peculiar kind of reproductive cell found in certain fungi, and often containing zoospores.

CONJOINT
 (a.) United; connected; associated.

CONNIVED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Connive

CONQUEST
 (n.) The act or process of conquering, or acquiring by force; the act of overcoming or subduing opposition by force, whether physical or moral; subjection; subjugation; victory.

CONSERVE
 (n.) A conservatory.

CONSIDER
 (v. t.) To have regard to; to take into view or account; to pay due attention to; to respect.

CONSOLED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Console

CONSPIRE
 (v. i.) To concur to one end; to agree.

CONSTANT
 (n.) A quantity that does not change its value; -- used in countradistinction to variable.

CONSTRUE
 (v. t. ) To put a construction upon; to explain the sense or intention of; to interpret; to understand.

CONTEMPT
 (n.) The act of contemning or despising; the feeling with which one regards that which is esteemed mean, vile, or worthless; disdain; scorn.

CONTENTS
 (pl. ) of Content

CONTINUE
 (v. t.) To protract or extend in duration; to preserve or persist in; to cease not.

CONTLINE
 (n.) The space between the strands on the outside of a rope.

CONTRACT
 (n.) To draw together so as to wrinkle; to knit.

CONTRACT
 (v. i.) To make an agreement; to covenant; to agree; to bargain; as, to contract for carrying the mail.

CONTRARY
 (a.) Opposite; in an opposite direction; in opposition; adverse; as, contrary winds.

CONTRARY
 (n.) An opponent; an enemy.

CONTRAST
 (v. i.) To stand in opposition; to exhibit difference, unlikeness, or opposition of qualities.

CONTRITE
 (a.) Broken down with grief and penitence; deeply sorrowful for sin because it is displeasing to God; humbly and thoroughly penitent.

CONTRIVE
 (v. t.) To form by an exercise of ingenuity; to devise; to invent; to design; to plan.

CONVERSE
 (n.) Familiar discourse; free interchange of thoughts or views; conversation; chat.

CONVEYED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Convey

CONVEYER
 (n.) One who, or that which, conveys or carries, transmits or transfers.

CONVINCE
 (v. t.) To overpower; to overcome; to subdue or master.

CONVULSE
 (v. t.) To contract violently and irregulary, as the muscular parts of an animal body; to shake with irregular spasms, as in excessive laughter, or in agony from grief or pain.

COOPERED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Cooper

COOPTATE
 (v. t.) To choose; to elect; to coopt.

COPATAIN
 (a.) Having a high crown, or a point or peak at top.

COQUETRY
 (n.) Attempts to attract admiration, notice, or love, for the mere gratification of vanity; trifling in love.

CORACOID
 (n.) The coracoid bone or process.

CORANACH
 (n.) A lamentation for the dead; a dirge.

CORDOVAN
 (n.) Same as Cordwain. In England the name is applied to leather made from horsehide.

CORNETER
 (n.) One who blows a cornet.

CORNLOFT
 (n.) A loft for corn; a granary.

CORNUTOR
 (n.) A cuckold maker.

CORONARY
 (a.) Resembling, or situated like, a crown or circlet; as, the coronary arteries and veins of the heart.

CORPORAL
 (a.) Alt. of Corporale

COSECANT
 (n.) The secant of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. of Functions.

COSMICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to the solar system as a whole, and not to the earth alone.

COSTLEWE
 (a.) Costly.

COTENANT
 (n.) A tenant in common, or a joint tenant.

COTSWOLD
 (n.) An open country abounding in sheepcotes, as in the Cotswold hills, in Gloucestershire, England.

COTYLOID
 (a.) Shaped like a cup; as, the cotyloid cavity, which receives the head of the thigh bone.

COULISSE
 (n.) A piece of timber having a groove in which something glides.

COUNTESS
 (n.) The wife of an earl in the British peerage, or of a count in the Continental nobility; also, a lady possessed of the same dignity in her own right. See the Note under Count.

COURSING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Course

COURSING
 (n.) The pursuit or running game with dogs that follow by sight instead of by scent.

COURTEPY
 (n.) A short coat of coarse cloth.

COURTESY
 (n.) An act of civility or respect; an act of kindness or favor performed with politeness.

COURTESY
 (v. t.) To treat with civility.

COUSCOUS
 (n.) A kind of food used by the natives of Western Africa, made of millet flour with flesh, and leaves of the baobab; -- called also lalo.

COVENANT
 (n.) An agreement made by the Scottish Parliament in 1638 and by the English Parliament in 1643 to preserve the reformed religion in Scotland, and to extirpate popery and prelacy; -- usually called the Solemn League and Covenant.

COVERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cover

COVERLID
 (n.) A coverlet.

COVERTLY
 (adv.) Secretly; in private; insidiously.

COVINOUS
 (a.) Deceitful; collusive; fraudulent; dishonest.

COWARDIE
 (n.) Cowardice.

COWARDLY
 (adv.) In the manner of a coward.

COWERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cower

COWHIDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Cowhide

CRABBING
 (n.) The act or art of catching crabs.

CRACKNEL
 (v. t.) A hard brittle cake or biscuit.

CRADLING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cradle

CRADLING
 (n.) The act of using a cradle.

CRANTARA
 (n.) The fiery cross, used as a rallying signal in the Highlands of Scotland.

CRAWFISH
 (n.) Alt. of Crayfish

CREAMING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cream

CREATURE
 (n.) A general term among farmers for horses, oxen, etc.

CREDENCE
 (n.) The small table by the side of the altar or communion table, on which the bread and wine are placed before being consecrated.

CRENELLE
 (n.) Alt. of Crenel

CREOLEAN
 (a.) Alt. of Creolian

CREPITUS
 (n.) The noise produced by a sudden discharge of wind from the bowels.

CRESCENT
 (n.) The ancient symbol of Byzantium or Constantinople.

CRESCENT

CRETONNE
 (n.) A fabric with cotton warp and woolen weft.

CREVALLE
 (n.) The pompano (Trachynotus Carolinus).

CREVICED
 (a.) Having a crevice or crevices; as, a creviced structure for storing ears of corn.

CRIBBING

 (imp. & p. p.) of Cribble

 (a.) Guilty of crime or sin.
