 (v. t.) To give an advantage to; to further; to promote; to benefit; to profit.

ADVENTURE
 (n.) The encountering of risks; hazardous and striking enterprise; a bold undertaking, in which hazards are to be encountered, and the issue is staked upon unforeseen events; a daring feat.

ADVENTURE
 (v. i.) To try the chance; to take the risk.

ADVERTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Advert

ADVERTISE
 (v. t.) To give notice to; to inform or apprise; to notify; to make known; hence, to warn; -- often followed by of before the subject of information; as, to advertise a man of his loss.

ADVISEDLY
 (adv.) With deliberate purpose; purposely; by design.

AEROLOGIC
 (a.) Alt. of Aerological

AEROMETRY
 (n.) The science of measuring the air, including the doctrine of its pressure, elasticity, rarefaction, and condensation; pneumatics.

AEROPHYTE
 (n.) A plant growing entirely in the air, and receiving its nourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.

AESTHESIS
 (n.) Sensuous perception.

AETIOLOGY
 (n.) The science, doctrine, or demonstration of causes; esp., the investigation of the causes of any disease; the science of the origin and development of things.

AFFECTING
 (a.) Affected; given to F show.

AFFECTION
 (n.) Disease; morbid symptom; malady; as, a pulmonary affection.

AFFECTIVE
 (a.) Tending to affect; affecting.

AFFLUENCE
 (n.) An abundant supply, as of thought, words, feelings, etc.; profusion; also, abundance of property; wealth.

AFTERCLAP
 (n.) An unexpected subsequent event; something disagreeable happening after an affair is supposed to be at an end.

AFTERINGS
 (n. pl.) The last milk drawn in milking; strokings.

AGENNESIS
 (n.) Impotence; sterility.

AGGREGATE
 (a.) Formed by a collection of particulars into a whole mass or sum; collective.

AGITATION
 (n.) Excitement of public feeling by discussion, appeals, etc.; as, the antislavery agitation; labor agitation.

AGREEABLE
 (a.) In pursuance, conformity, or accordance; -- in this sense used adverbially for agreeably; as, agreeable to the order of the day, the House took up the report.

AGRIOLOGY
 (n.) Description or comparative study of the customs of savage or uncivilized tribes.

AIROMETER
 (n.) A hollow cylinder to contain air. It is closed above and open below, and has its open end plunged into water.

AITIOLOGY
 (n.) See Aetiology.

ALABASTER
 (n.) A box or vessel for holding odoriferous ointments, etc.; -- so called from the stone of which it was originally made.

ALILONGHI
 (n.) The tunny. See Albicore.

ALBERTYPE
 (n.) A picture printed from a kind of gelatine plate produced by means of a photographic negative.

ALCOHOLIC
 (n.) A person given to the use of alcoholic liquors.

ALECONNER
 (n.) Orig., an officer appointed to look to the goodness of ale and beer; also, one of the officers chosen by the liverymen of London to inspect the measures used in public houses. But the office is a sinecure. [Also called aletaster.]

ALKALIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Alkalize

ALLENARLY
 (adv.) Solely; only.

ALLEVIATE
 (v. t.) To extenuate; to palliate.

ALLIGATOR
 (n.) A large carnivorous reptile of the Crocodile family, peculiar to America. It has a shorter and broader snout than the crocodile, and the large teeth of the lower jaw shut into pits in the upper jaw, which has no marginal notches. Besides the common

ALLOGRAPH
 (n.) A writing or signature made by some person other than any of the parties thereto; -- opposed to autograph.

ALLOTMENT
 (n.) That which is allotted; a share, part, or portion granted or distributed; that which is assigned by lot, or by the act of God; anything set apart for a special use or to a distinct party.

ALLOTROPY
 (n.) The property of existing in two or more conditions which are distinct in their physical or chemical relations.

ALLOWANCE
 (n.) The act of allowing, granting, conceding, or admitting; authorization; permission; sanction; tolerance.

ALLOWANCE
 (n.) To put upon a fixed allowance (esp. of provisions and drink); to supply in a fixed and limited quantity; as, the captain was obliged to allowance his crew; our provisions were allowanced.

ALLUVIOUS
 (n.) Alluvial.

ALTERABLE
 (a.) Capable of being altered.

ALTERNATE
 (a.) Distributed, as leaves, singly at different heights of the stem, and at equal intervals as respects angular divergence.

ALTERNATE
 (v. i.) To happen, succeed, or act by turns; to follow reciprocally in place or time; -- followed by with; as, the flood and ebb tides alternate with each other.

ALTIMETRY
 (n.) The art of measuring altitudes, or heights.

AMAUROTIC
 (a.) Affected with amaurosis; having the characteristics of amaurosis.

AMBAGIOUS
 (a.) Circumlocutory; circuitous.

AMBITIOUS
 (a.) Possessing, or controlled by, ambition; greatly or inordinately desirous of power, honor, office, superiority, or distinction.

AMBLINGLY
 (adv.) With an ambling gait.

AMBLYPODA
 (n. pl.) A group of large, extinct, herbivorous mammals, common in the Tertiary formation of the United States.

AMBROSIAL
 (a.) Consisting of, or partaking of the nature of, ambrosia; delighting the taste or smell; delicious.

AMBUSCADE
 (v. t.) A place in which troops lie hid, to attack an enemy unexpectedly.

AMBUSCADO
 (n.) Ambuscade.

AMORPHISM
 (n.) A state of being amorphous; esp. a state of being without crystallization even in the minutest particles, as in glass, opal, etc.

AMPHIBIAL
 (a. & n.) Amphibian.

AMPHIBOLE
 (n.) A common mineral embracing many varieties varying in color and in composition. It occurs in monoclinic crystals; also massive, generally with fibrous or columnar structure. The color varies from white to gray, green, brown, and black. It is a silic

AMPLENESS
 (n.) The state or quality of being ample; largeness; fullness; completeness.

AMPLIFIER
 (n.) One who or that which amplifies.

AMPLITUDE
 (n.) State of being ample; extent of surface or space; largeness of dimensions; size.

AMPLITUDE
 (n.) The extent of a movement measured from the starting point or position of equilibrium; -- applied especially to vibratory movements.

ANACROTIC
 (a.) Pertaining to anachronism.

ANALECTIC
 (a.) Relating to analects; made up of selections; as, an analectic magazine.

ANALOGISM
 (n.) an argument from the cause to the effect; an a priori argument.

ANATOMIST
 (n.) One who is skilled in the art of anatomy, or dissection.

ANATOMIES
 (pl. ) of Anatomy

ANCESTRAL
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, derived from, or possessed by, an ancestor or ancestors; as, an ancestral estate.

ANCHORAGE
 (n.) The set of anchors belonging to a ship.

ANCIENTRY
 (n.) Antiquity; what is ancient.

ANECDOTIC
 (a.) Alt. of Anecdotical

ANGELHOOD
 (n.) The state of being an angel; angelic nature.

ANGIOLOGY
 (n.) That part of anatomy which treats of blood vessels and lymphatics.

ANGLEWORM
 (n.) A earthworm of the genus Lumbricus, frequently used by anglers for bait. See Earthworm.

ANGLICISM
 (n.) The quality of being English; an English characteristic, custom, or method.

ANHYDRITE
 (n.) A mineral of a white or a slightly bluish color, usually massive. It is anhydrous sulphate of lime, and differs from gypsum in not containing water (whence the name).

ANILENESS
 (n.) Anility.

ANIMATION
 (n.) The act of animating, or giving life or spirit; the state of being animate or alive.

ANIMOSITY
 (v. t.) Mere spiritedness or courage.

ANNELIDAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Annelida.

ANNULOIDA
 (n. pl.) A division of the Articulata, including the annelids and allied groups; sometimes made to include also the helminths and echinoderms.

ANOMALOUS
 (a.) Deviating from a general rule, method, or analogy; abnormal; irregular; as, an anomalous proceeding.

ANTALKALI
 (n.) Alt. of Antalkaline

ANTHOZOAN
 (a.) Pertaining to the Anthozoa.

ANTIMASON
 (n.) One opposed to Freemasonry.

ANTIMETER
 (n.) A modification of the quadrant, for measuring small angles.

ANTIPODES
 (n.) Anything exactly opposite or contrary.

ANTIQUARY
 (a.) Pertaining to antiquity.

ANTIQUITY
 (n.) The ancients; the people of ancient times.

ANTROVERT
 (v. t.) To bend forward.

ANXIETIES
 (pl. ) of Anxiety

ANXIOUSLY
 (adv.) In an anxious manner; with painful uncertainty; solicitously.

APERTNESS
 (n.) Openness; frankness.

APETALOUS
 (a.) Having no petals, or flower leaves. [See Illust. under Anther].

APHERESIS
 (n.) The dropping of a letter or syllable from the beginning of a word; e. g., cute for acute.

APHRODITE
 (n.) A large marine annelid, covered with long, lustrous, golden, hairlike setae; the sea mouse.

APLANATIC
 (a.) Having two or more parts of different curvatures, so combined as to remove spherical aberration; -- said of a lens.

APNEUMONA
 (n. pl.) An order of holothurians in which the internal respiratory organs are wanting; -- called also Apoda or Apodes.

APOTELESM
 (n.) The calculation and explanation of a nativity.

APPALLING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Appall

APPALLING
 (a.) Such as to appall; as, an appalling accident.

APPARATUS
 (pl. ) of Apparatus

APPEASIVE
 (a.) Tending to appease.

APPELLANT
 (n.) One who appealed to a general council against the bull Unigenitus.

APPENDANT
 (v. t.) Appended by prescription, that is, a personal usage for a considerable time; -- said of a thing of inheritance belonging to another inheritance which is superior or more worthy; as, an advowson, common, etc. , which may be appendant to a manor,

APPETENCY
 (n.) Natural tendency; affinity; attraction; -- used of inanimate objects.

APPLAUDER
 (n.) One who applauds.

APPLOTTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Applot

APPRAISED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Appraise

APPREHEND
 (v. t.) Hence: To take or seize (a person) by legal process; to arrest; as, to apprehend a criminal.

APPRISING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Apprise

APPROBATE
 (a.) Approved.

APRIORISM
 (n.) An a priori principle.

APYREXIAL
 (a.) Relating to apyrexy.

AQUATINTA
 (n.) A kind of etching in which spaces are bitten by the use of aqua fortis, by which an effect is produced resembling a drawing in water colors or India ink; also, the engraving produced by this method.

ARABINOSE
 (n.) A sugar of the composition C5H10O5, obtained from cherry gum by boiling it with dilute sulphuric acid.

ARACANESE
 (n. sing. & pl.) A native or natives of Aracan.

ARACHNOID
 (n.) The arachnoid membrane.

ARBITRARY
 (a.) Despotic; absolute in power; bound by no law; harsh and unforbearing; tyrannical; as, an arbitrary prince or government.

ARBORETUM
 (n.) A place in which a collection of rare trees and shrubs is cultivated for scientific or educational purposes.

ARCHELOGY
 (n.) The science of, or a treatise on, first principles.

ARCHIATER
 (n.) Chief physician; -- a term applied, on the continent of Europe, to the first or body physician of princes and to the first physician of some cities.

ARCHIVOLT
 (n.) The architectural member surrounding the curved opening of an arch, corresponding to the architrave in the case of a square opening.

ARDASSINE
 (n.) A very fine sort of Persian silk.

AREOMETER
 (n.) An instrument for measuring the specific gravity of fluids; a form hydrometer.

ARETOLOGY
 (n.) That part of moral philosophy which treats of virtue, its nature, and the means of attaining to it.

ARGENTINE
 (n.) A siliceous variety of calcite, or carbonate of lime, having a silvery-white, pearly luster, and a waving or curved lamellar structure.

ARMORICAN
 (n.) The language of the Armoricans, a Celtic dialect which has remained to the present times.

ARRAIMENT
 (v. t.) Alt. of Arrayment

ARRASWAYS
 (adv.) Placed in such a position as to exhibit the top and two sides, the corner being in front; -- said of a rectangular form.

ARROGATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Arrogate

ARROWROOT
 (n.) A nutritive starch obtained from the rootstocks of Maranta arundinacea, and used as food, esp. for children an invalids; also, a similar starch obtained from other plants, as various species of Maranta and Curcuma.

ARTEMISIA
 (n.) A genus of plants including the plants called mugwort, southernwood, and wormwood. Of these A. absinthium, or common wormwood, is well known, and A. tridentata is the sage brush of the Rocky Mountain region.

ARTICHOKE
 (n.) See Jerusalem artichoke.

ARTILLERY
 (n.) The men and officers of that branch of the army to which the care and management of artillery are confided.

ARTLESSLY
 (adv.) In an artless manner; without art, skill, or guile; unaffectedly.

ARUSPICES
 (pl. ) of Aruspex

ASCENSIVE
 (a.) Rising; tending to rise, or causing to rise.

ASCITICAL
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or affected by, ascites; dropsical.

ASCOSPORE
 (n.) One of the spores contained in the asci of lichens and fungi. [See Illust. of Ascus.]

ASEXUALLY
 (adv.) In an asexual manner; without sexual agency.

ASHAMEDLY
 (adv.) Bashfully.

ASHTAROTH
 (pl. ) of Ashtoreth

ASOMATOUS
 (a.) Without a material body; incorporeal.

ASPERGILL
 (n.) Alt. of Aspergillum

ASPHALTIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, of the nature of, or containing, asphalt; bituminous.

ASSAULTER
 (n.) One who assaults, or violently attacks; an assailant.

ASSAYABLE
 (a.) That may be assayed.

ASSERTION
 (n.) The act of asserting, or that which is asserted; positive declaration or averment; affirmation; statement asserted; position advanced.

ASSESSING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Assess

ASSESSION
 (n.) A sitting beside or near.

ASSIDUITY
 (n.) Studied and persevering attention to a person; -- usually in the plural.

ASSISTANT
 (a.) Of the second grade in the staff of the army; as, an assistant surgeon.

ASSOCIATE
 (v. t.) To join or connect; to combine in acting; as, particles of gold associated with other substances.

ASSOCIATE
 (a.) Connected by habit or sympathy; as, associate motions, such as occur sympathetically, in consequence of preceding motions.

ASSONANCE
 (n.) Incomplete correspondence.

ASSUMPSIT
 (n.) A promise or undertaking, founded on a consideration. This promise may be oral or in writing not under seal. It may be express or implied.

ASSURANCE
 (n.) Excess of boldness; impudence; audacity; as, his assurance is intolerable.

ASTRAKHAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Astrakhan in Russia or its products; made of an Astrakhan skin.

ASTRINGED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Astringe

ASTROGONY
 (n.) Same as Astrogeny.

ASTROLOGY
 (n.) In its etymological signification, the science of the stars; among the ancients, synonymous with astronomy; subsequently, the art of judging of the influences of the stars upon human affairs, and of foretelling events by their position and aspects.

ASTROPHEL
 (n.) See Astrofel.

ASYMMETRY
 (n.) Want of symmetry, or proportion between the parts of a thing, esp. want of bilateral symmetry.

ATHENAEUM
 (n.) A building or an apartment where a library, periodicals, and newspapers are kept for use.

ATMOMETER
 (n.) An instrument for measuring the rate of evaporation from a moist surface; an evaporometer.

ATOMICITY
 (n.) Degree of atomic attraction; equivalence; valence; also (a later use) the number of atoms in an elementary molecule. See Valence.

ATROCIOUS
 (a.) Very grievous or violent; terrible; as, atrocious distempers.

ATROPHIED
 (p. p.) of Atrophy

ATTEMPTER
 (n.) An assailant; also, a temper.

ATTENDANT
 (v. t.) Depending on, or owing duty or service to; as, the widow attendant to the heir.

ATTENTION

 (pl. ) of Attorney

ATTRAHENT
 (n.) That which attracts, as a magnet.

ATTRITION
 (n.) The state of being worn.

AUDIPHONE
 (n.) An instrument which, placed against the teeth, conveys sound to the auditory nerve and enables the deaf to hear more or less distinctly; a dentiphone.

AUGUSTINE
 (n.) Alt. of Augustinian

AURICULAR
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the ear, or to the sense of hearing; as, auricular nerves.

AURISCOPE
 (n.) An instrument for examining the condition of the ear.

AUSPICATE
 (v. t.) To foreshow; to foretoken.

AUTHENTIC
 (n.) Vested with all due formalities, and legally attested.

AUTHORESS
 (n.) A female author.

AUTHORITY
 (n.) Government; the persons or the body exercising power or command; as, the local authorities of the States; the military authorities.

AUTHORIZE
 (v. t.) To sanction or confirm by the authority of some one; to warrant; as, to authorize a report.

AUTOPHAGI
 (n. pl.) Birds which are able to run about and obtain their own food as soon as hatched.

AVOIDANCE
 (n.) A dismissing or a quitting; removal; withdrawal.

AVOUCHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Avouch

AZEDARACH
 (n.) The bark of the roots of the azedarach, used as a cathartic and emetic.

BABYRUSSA
 (n.) See Babyroussa.

BACCHANAL
 (a.) Relating to Bacchus or his festival.

BACCHICAL
 (a.) Of or relating to Bacchus; hence, jovial, or riotous,with intoxication.

BACKBITER
 (n.) One who backbites; a secret calumniator or detractor.

BACKPIECE
 (n.) Alt. of Backplate

BACKWARDS
 (adv.) Toward the back; toward the rear; as, to throw the arms backward.

BACKWATER
 (n.) Water thrown back by the turning of a waterwheel, or by the paddle wheels of a steamer.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Badger

 (n.) A rich brocade; baudekin.

BALISTOID
 (a.) Like a fish of the genus Balistes; of the family Balistidae. See Filefish.

 (adv.) In a manner to balk or frustrate.

BALLPROOF
 (a.) Incapable of being penetrated by balls from firearms.

 (n.) Alt. of Bandolier

BASTINADO

BATARDEAU

BATTALION

BICIPITAL
 (a.) Pertaining to a biceps muscle; as, bicipital furrows, the depressions on either side of the biceps of the arm.

 (n.) Altercation; wrangling.

BICOSTATE
 (a.) Having two principal ribs running longitudinally, as a leaf.

 (a.) Relating to bicycling.

BILABIATE

BLACKBALL
 (v. t.) To vote against, by putting a black ball into a ballot box; to reject or exclude, as by voting against with black balls; to ostracize.

BLACKFISH
 (n.) A small kind of whale, of the genus Globicephalus, of several species. The most common is G. melas. Also sometimes applied to other whales of larger size.

BLACKMAIL
 (n.) Payment of money exacted by means of intimidation; also, extortion of money from a person by threats of public accusation, exposure, or censure.

BLACKMOOR
 (n.) See Blackamoor.

BLACKTAIL
 (n.) The black-tailed deer (Cervus / Cariacus Columbianus) of California and Oregon; also, the mule deer of the Rocky Mountains. See Mule deer.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Blatter

BLEACHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bleach

BLEACHING
 (n.) The act or process of whitening, by removing color or stains; esp. the process of whitening fabrics by chemical agents.

BLENNIOID
 (a.) Alt. of Blenniid

BLESSEDLY
 (adv.) Happily; fortunately; joyfully.

BLINDNESS
 (n.) State or condition of being blind, literally or figuratively.

BLOCKADER
 (n.) One who blockades.

BLUESTONE
 (n.) A grayish blue building stone, as that commonly used in the eastern United States.

BOATSWAIN
 (n.) An officer who has charge of the boats, sails, rigging, colors, anchors, cables, cordage, etc., of a ship, and who also summons the crew, and performs other duties.

BODYGUARD
 (n.) Retinue; attendance; following.

BOLECTION
 (n.) A projecting molding round a panel. Same as Bilection.

BOLOMETER
 (n.) An instrument for measuring minute quantities of radiant heat, especially in different parts of the spectrum; -- called also actinic balance, thermic balance.

BOLSTERER
 (n.) A supporter.

BOLTSPRIT
 (n.) See Bowsprit.

BOMBAZINE
 (n.) A twilled fabric for dresses, of which the warp is silk, and the weft worsted. Black bombazine has been much used for mourning garments.

BONNINESS
 (n.) The quality of being bonny; gayety; handsomeness.

BOOKSHELF
 (n.) A shelf to hold books.

BOOTBLACK
 (n.) One who blacks boots.

BOSKINESS
 (n.) Boscage; also, the state or quality of being bosky.

BOTHERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Bother

BOTRYOGEN
 (n.) A hydrous sulphate of iron of a deep red color. It often occurs in botryoidal form.

BOUNDLESS
 (a.) Without bounds or confines; illimitable; vast; unlimited.

 (a.) Without a bourn or limit.

BREECHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Breech

BRILLIANT

BROADCAST

BRONCHIAL

BRUTALITY
 (n.) The quality of being brutal; inhumanity; savageness; pitilessness.

BUCKWHEAT
 (n.) The triangular seed used, when ground, for griddle cakes, etc.

BUGLEWEED
 (n.) A plant of the Mint family and genus Lycopus; esp. L. Virginicus, which has mild narcotic and astringent properties, and is sometimes used as a remedy for hemorrhage.

 (n.) A cellular, flinty rock, used for mill stones.

 (n.) A broad-leaved plant (Petasites vulgaris) of the Composite family, said to have been used in England for wrapping up pats of butter.

 (a.) Pertaining to, or situated near, the calcar of the brain.

CALEMBOUR
 (n.) A pun.

CALLOSITY
 (n.) A hard or thickened spot or protuberance; a hardening and thickening of the skin or bark of a part, eps. as a result of continued pressure or friction.

CALUMNIES
 (pl. ) of Calumny

CALVINISM
 (n.) The theological tenets or doctrines of John Calvin (a French theologian and reformer of the 16th century) and his followers, or of the so-called calvinistic churches.

CALYCINAL
 (a.) Alt. of Calycine

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Camber

CAMPANILE
 (n.) A bell tower, esp. one built separate from a church.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cancel

CANCERATE
 (v. i.) To grow into a canser; to become cancerous.

CANICULAR
 (a.) Pertaining to, or measured, by the rising of the Dog Star.

CANNINESS
 (n.) Caution; crafty management.

CANNONADE
 (n.) The act of discharging cannon and throwing ball, shell, etc., for the purpose of destroying an army, or battering a town, ship, or fort; -- usually, an attack of some continuance.

 (pl. ) of Carbonaro

CARBONIDE
 (n.) A carbide.

CARNATION
 (n.) Those parts of a picture in which the human body or any part of it is represented in full color; the flesh tints.

CARNOSITY
 (n.) Fleshy substance or quality; fleshy covering.

CAROTIDAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, or near, the carotids or one of them; as, the carotid gland.

 (n.) Alt. of Carrigeen

CARRONADE
 (n.) A kind of short cannon, formerly in use, designed to throw a large projectile with small velocity, used for the purpose of breaking or smashing in, rather than piercing, the object aimed at, as the side of a ship. It has no trunnions, but is suppor

CARTHAMIN
 (n.) A red coloring matter obtained from the safflower, or Carthamus tinctorius.

CARTRIDGE
 (n.) A complete charge for a firearm, contained in, or held together by, a case, capsule, or shell of metal, pasteboard, or other material.

CASSAREEP
 (n.) A condiment made from the sap of the bitter cassava (Manihot utilissima) deprived of its poisonous qualities, concentrated by boiling, and flavored with aromatics. See Pepper pot.

CASTELLAN
 (n.) A governor or warden of a castle.

CASTILLAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Castile, in Spain.

CASTORITE
 (n.) A variety of the mineral called petalite, from Elba.

 (a.) The science or doctrine of dealing with cases of conscience, of resolving questions of right or wrong in conduct, or determining the lawfulness or unlawfulness of what a man may do by rules and principles drawn from the Scriptures, from the laws of

CATACLYSM
 (n.) An extensive overflow or sweeping flood of water; a deluge.

CATAFALCO
 (n.) See Catafalque.

CATAMARAN
 (n.) Any vessel with twin hulls, whether propelled by sails or by steam; esp., one of a class of double-hulled pleasure boats remarkable for speed.

CATARRHAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, produced by, or attending, catarrh; of the nature of catarrh.

CATCHWORD
 (n.) The first word of any page of a book after the first, inserted at the right hand bottom corner of the preceding page for the assistance of the reader. It is seldom used in modern printing.

CATECHIZE
 (v. t.) See Catechise.

CATHARSIS
 (n.) A natural or artificial purgation of any passage, as of the mouth, bowels, etc.

CAUTERIZE
 (v. t.) To sear, as the conscience.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Caution

CAUTIONER
 (n.) A surety or sponsor.

CAVALIERO
 (n.) A cavalier; a gallant; a libertine.

CAVERNOUS
 (a.) Having a sound caused by a cavity.

CEASELESS
 (adv.) Without intermission or end.

CELANDINE
 (n.) A perennial herbaceous plant (Chelidonium majus) of the poppy family, with yellow flowers. It is used as a medicine in jaundice, etc., and its acrid saffron-colored juice is used to cure warts and the itch; -- called also greater celandine and swal

CELEBRATE
 (v. t.) To honor by solemn rites, by ceremonies of joy and respect, or by refraining from ordinary business; to observe duly; to keep; as, to celebrate a birthday.

CELEBRITY
 (n.) Celebration; solemnization.

CELESTIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the spiritual heaven; heavenly; divine.

CELESTITE
 (n.) Native strontium sulphate, a mineral so named from its occasional delicate blue color. It occurs crystallized, also in compact massive and fibrous forms.

CELLARAGE
 (n.) The space or storerooms of a cellar; a cellar.

CELTICISM
 (n.) A custom of the Celts, or an idiom of their language.

CENTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Centre

CENTURIST
 (n.) An historian who distinguishes time by centuries, esp. one of those who wrote the Magdeburg Centuries. See under Century.

CERATODUS
 (n.) A genus of ganoid fishes, of the order Dipnoi, first known as Mesozoic fossil fishes; but recently two living species have been discovered in Australian rivers. They have lungs so well developed that they can leave the water and breathe in air. In

CERBEREAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to, or resembling, Cerberus.

CERCARIAN
 (n.) One of the Cercariae.

CERTAINTY
 (n.) The quality, state, or condition, of being certain.

CERULEOUS
 (a.) Cerulean.

CHAETETES
 (n.) A genus of fossil corals, common in the lower Silurian limestones.

CHAETOPOD
 (n.) One of the Chaetopoda.

CHALLENGE
 (n.) An exception to a person as not legally qualified to vote. The challenge must be made when the ballot is offered.

CHALLENGE
 (n.) To question or demand the countersign from (one who attempts to pass the lines); as, the sentinel challenged us, with Who comes there?

CHALYBITE
 (n.) Native iron carbonate; -- usually called siderite.

CHAMBERED
 (a.) Having a chamber or chambers; as, a chambered shell; a chambered gun.

CHAMELEON
 (n.) A lizardlike reptile of the genus Chamaeleo, of several species, found in Africa, Asia, and Europe. The skin is covered with fine granulations; the tail is prehensile, and the body is much compressed laterally, giving it a high back.

CHAMPAGNE
 (n.) A light wine, of several kinds, originally made in the province of Champagne, in France.

CHARACTER
 (n.) Style of writing or printing; handwriting; the peculiar form of letters used by a particular person or people; as, an inscription in the Runic character.

CHARACTER
 (n.) A unique or extraordinary individuality; a person characterized by peculiar or notable traits; a person who illustrates certain phases of character; as, Randolph was a character; Caesar is a great historical character.

CHARLATAN
 (n.) One who prates much in his own favor, and makes unwarrantable pretensions; a quack; an impostor; an empiric; a mountebank.

CHARMLESS
 (a.) Destitute of charms.

CHARWOMAN
 (n.) A woman hired for odd work or for single days.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Cheapen

CHELONIAN
 (n.) One of the Chelonia.

CHERISING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cherish

CHEROKEES
 (n. pl.) An Appalachian tribe of Indians, formerly inhabiting the region about the head waters of the Tennessee River. They are now mostly settled in the Indian Territory, and have become one of the most civilized of the Indian Tribes.

CHEVELURE
 (n.) A hairlike envelope.

CHEVRETTE
 (n.) A machine for raising guns or mortar into their carriages.

CHICHLING
 (n.) Alt. of Chichling vetch

CHIDERESS
 (n.) She who chides.

 (n.) The state or relation of being a child.

CHILOPODA

CHIVALRIC
 (a.) Relating to chivalry; knightly; chivalrous.

CHLOROSIS
 (n.) A disease in plants, causing the flowers to turn green or the leaves to lose their normal green color.

CHOLERAIC
 (a.) Relating to, or resulting from, or resembling, cholera.

CHOLERINE
 (n.) The first stage of epidemic cholera.

CHOROIDAL
 (a.) Pertaining to the choroid coat.

CHRISTIAN
 (n.) One who believes, or professes or is assumed to believe, in Jesus Christ, and the truth as taught by Him; especially, one whose inward and outward life is conformed to the doctrines of Christ.

CHROMATIC
 (a.) Relating to color, or to colors.

CHRONICLE
 (n.) The two canonical books of the Old Testament in which immediately follow 2 Kings.

CHURCHMAN
 (n.) An ecclesiastic or clergyman.

CICATRICE
 (n.) A cicatrix.

CINERARIA
 (n.) A Linnaean genus of free-flowering composite plants, mostly from South Africa. Several species are cultivated for ornament.

CINGALESE
 (n. sing. & pl.) A native or natives of Ceylon descended from its primitive inhabitants

CIRCULATE
 (v. i.) To move in a circle or circuitously; to move round and return to the same point; as, the blood circulates in the body.

CLADOCERA
 (n. pl.) An order of the Entomostraca.

CLAMATION
 (n.) The act of crying out.

CLAPBOARD
 (v. t.) To cover with clapboards; as, to clapboard the sides of a house.

CLATTERER
 (n.) One who clatters.

CLEANLILY
 (adv.) In a cleanly manner.

CLEARNESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being clear.

CLEARWING
 (n.) A lepidopterous insect with partially transparent wings, of the family Aegeriadae, of which the currant and peach-tree borers are examples.

COARCTATE
 (a.) Pressed together; closely connected; -- applied to insects having the abdomen separated from the thorax only by a constriction.

 (adv.) Alt. of Coastways

COBALTITE
 (n.) A mineral of a nearly silver-white color, composed of arsenic, sulphur, and cobalt.

COCHLEARE
 (n.) A spoonful.

 (n.) An Australian parrot (Calopsitta Novae-Hollandiae); -- so called from its note.

COLEGOOSE
 (n.) See Coalgoose.

COLLATION
 (v. t.) The act of collating or comparing; a comparison of one copy er thing (as of a book, or manuscript) with another of a like kind; comparison, in general.

COLLATION
 (v. t.) The right which an heir has of throwing the whole heritable and movable estates of the deceased into one mass, and sharing it equally with others who are of the same degree of kindred.

COLLECTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Collect

COLLECTOR
 (n.) A compiler of books; one who collects scattered passages and puts them together in one book.

COLLIDINE
 (n.) One of a class of organic bases, C8H11N, usually pungent oily liquids, belonging to the pyridine series, and obtained from bone oil, coal tar, naphtha, and certain alkaloids.

COLLUSIVE
 (a.) Characterized by collusion; done or planned in collusion.

COLOCYNTH
 (n.) The light spongy pulp of the fruit of the bitter cucumber (Citrullus, / Cucumis, colocynthis), an Asiatic plant allied to the watermelon; coloquintida. It comes in white balls, is intensely bitter, and a powerful cathartic. Called also bitter apple

COLORABLE
 (a.) Specious; plausible; having an appearance of right or justice.

COLOSSEAN
 (a.) Colossal.

COLOSTRUM
 (n.) A mixture of turpentine and the yolk of an egg, formerly used as an emulsion.

COLUMBATE
 (n.) A salt of columbic acid; a niobate. See Columbium.

COLUMBIER
 (n.) See Colombier.

COLUMBIUM
 (n.) A rare element of the vanadium group, first found in a variety of the mineral columbite occurring in Connecticut, probably at Haddam. Atomic weight 94.2. Symbol Cb or Nb. Now more commonly called niobium.

COMATULID
 (n.) Any crinoid of the genus Antedon or allied genera.

COMBATANT
 (a.) Contending; disposed to contend.

COMBINING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Combine

COMBOLOIO
 (n.) A Mohammedan rosary, consisting of ninety-nine beads.

COMFORTER
 (n.) The Holy Spirit, -- referring to his office of comforting believers.

COMMENSAL
 (n.) One who eats at the same table.

COMMITTAL
 (n.) The act of committing, or the state of being committed; commitment.

COMMODATE
 (n.) A gratuitous loan.

COMMODORE
 (n.) An officer who ranks next above a captain; sometimes, by courtesy, the senior captain of a squadron. The rank of commodore corresponds with that of brigadier general in the army.

COMMORANT
 (n.) Ordinarily residing; inhabiting.

COMMOTION
 (n.) Disturbed or violent motion; agitation.

COMMUNITY

CONFLUENT
 (a.) Flowing together; meeting in their course; running one into another.

CONFUCIAN

 (a.) Of or relating to a feast or entertainment, or to eating and drinking, with accompanying festivity; festive; social; gay; jovial.

COOPERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cooper

COPESMATE
 (n.) An associate or companion; a friend; a partner.

COPYGRAPH
 (n.) A contrivance for producing manifold copies of a writing or drawing.

CORALLOID
 (a.) Having the form of coral; branching like coral.

CORCHORUS
 (n.) The common name of the Kerria Japonica or Japan globeflower, a yellow-flowered, perennial, rosaceous plant, seen in old-fashioned gardens.

CORDELIER
 (n.) A Franciscan; -- so called in France from the girdle of knotted cord worn by all Franciscans.

CORMORANT
 (n.) Any species of Phalacrocorax, a genus of sea birds having a sac under the beak; the shag. Cormorants devour fish voraciously, and have become the emblem of gluttony. They are generally black, and hence are called sea ravens, and coalgeese.

CORNERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Corner

CORNIFIED
 (a.) Converted into horn; horny.

CORNSHUCK
 (n.) The husk covering an ear of Indian corn.

CORRECTOR
 (n.) One who, or that which, corrects; as, a corrector of abuses; a corrector of the press; an alkali is a corrector of acids.

CORRODING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Corrode

CORROSIVE
 (a.) Having the quality of fretting or vexing.

CORTICOUS
 (a.) Relating to, or resembling, bark; corticose.

COSMOLOGY
 (n.) The science of the world or universe; or a treatise relating to the structure and parts of the system of creation, the elements of bodies, the modifications of material things, the laws of motion, and the order and course of nature.

COTILLION
 (n.) A tune which regulates the dance.

COTTAGELY
 (a.) Cottagelike; suitable for a cottage; rustic.

COTTONADE
 (n.) A somewhat stout and thick fabric of cotton.

COUNSELOR
 (n.) One whose profession is to give advice in law, and manage causes for clients in court; a barrister.

COURTSHIP
 (n.) The act of wooing in love; solicitation of woman to marriage.

COUSSINET
 (n.) A stone placed on the impost of a pier for receiving the first stone of an arch.

COVERTURE
 (n.) Covering; shelter; defense; hiding.

COVETABLE
 (a.) That may be coveted; desirable.

COWARDIZE
 (v. t. ) To render cowardly

CRACOVIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Cracow in Poland.

CRAMPOONS
 (n.) A clutch formed of hooked pieces of iron, like double calipers, for raising stones, lumber, blocks of ice, etc.

CRANNYING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cranny

CRAPULOUS
 (a.) Surcharged with liquor; sick from excessive indulgence in liquor; drunk; given to excesses.

CRATEROUS
 (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, a crater.

CRAVENING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Craven

CREATININ
 (n.) A white, crystalline, nitrogenous body closely related to creatin but more basic in its properties, formed from the latter by the action of acids, and occurring naturally in muscle tissue and in urine.

CREDITRIX
 (n.) A female creditor.

CREEKFISH
 (n.) The chub sucker.

CREMASTER
 (n.) A thin muscle which serves to draw up the testicle.

CRENATURE
 (n.) A rounded tooth or notch of a crenate leaf, or any part that is crenate; -- called also crenelle.

CRENULATE
 (a.) Alt. of Crenulated

CREPUSCLE
 (n.) Alt. of Crepuscule

CRESCENDO
 (a. & adv.) With a constantly increasing volume of voice; with gradually increasing strength and fullness of tone; -- a direction for the performance of music, indicated by the mark, or by writing the word on the score.

CRINOIDAL
 (a.) Of pertaining to crinoids; consisting of, or containing, crinoids.

CROCKETED
 (a.) Ornamented with crockets.

CROSIERED
 (a.) Bearing a crosier.

CROSSBILL
 (n.) A bird of the genus Loxia, allied to the finches. Their mandibles are strongly curved and cross each other; the crossbeak.

CROSSBRED
 (a.) Produced by mixing distinct breeds; mongrel.

CROSSETTE
 (n.) The shoulder of a joggled keystone.

CROSSHEAD
 (n.) A beam or bar across the head or end of a rod, etc., or a block attached to it and carrying a knuckle pin; as the solid crosspiece running between parallel slides, which receives motion from the piston of a steam engine and imparts it to the connec

CROSSJACK
 (n.) The lowest square sail, or the lower yard of the mizzenmast.

CROWBERRY
 (n.) A heathlike plant of the genus Empetrum, and its fruit, a black, scarcely edible berry; -- also called crakeberry.

CROWNWORK
 (n.) A work consisting of two or more bastioned fronts, with their outworks, covering an enceinte, a bridgehead, etc., and connected by wings with the main work or the river bank.

CRYPTICAL
 (a.) Hidden; secret; occult.

CRYPTOGAM
 (n.) A plant belonging to the Cryptogamia.

CTENOCYST
 (n.) An organ of the Ctenophora, supposed to be sensory.

CUCURBITE
 (n.) A vessel or flask for distillation, used with, or forming part of, an alembic; a matrass; -- originally in the shape of a gourd, with a wide mouth. See Alembic.

CULTIVATE
 (v. t.) To direct special attention to; to devote time and thought to; to foster; to cherish.

CUNEIFORM
 (n.) Alt. of Cuniform

CUPBEARER
 (n.) One of the attendants of a prince or noble, permanently charged with the performance of this office for his master.

CURCULIOS
 (pl. ) of Curculio

CURIOSITY
 (n.) That which is curious, or fitted to excite or reward attention.

CURIOUSLY
 (adv.) In a curious manner.

CURRYCOMB
 (n.) A kind of card or comb having rows of metallic teeth or serrated ridges, used in currying a horse.

CURSORIAL
 (a.) Adapted to running or walking, and not to prehension; as, the limbs of the horse are cursorial. See Illust. of Aves.

CURTAINED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Curtain

CUSTOMARY
 (a.) Agreeing with, or established by, custom; established by common usage; conventional; habitual.

CUTTHROAT
 (a.) Murderous; cruel; barbarous.

CYCLOIDEI
 (n. pl.) An order of fishes, formerly proposed by Agassiz, for those with thin, smooth scales, destitute of marginal spines, as the herring and salmon. The group is now regarded as artificial.

CYCLOPEAN
 (a.) Pertaining to the Cyclops; characteristic of the Cyclops; huge; gigantic; vast and rough; massive; as, Cyclopean labors; Cyclopean architecture.

CYNOSURAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a cynosure.

CYPRINOID
 (a.) Like the carp (Cyprinus).

CYSTICULE
 (n.) An appendage of the vestibular ear sac of fishes.

CYSTOCARP
 (n.) A minute vesicle in a red seaweed, which contains the reproductive spores.

DAEDALIAN
 (a.) Crafty; deceitful.

DALLIANCE
 (n.) Delay or procrastination.

DAMASCENE
 (a.) Of or relating to Damascus.

DAMASKEEN
 (v.) Alt. of Damasken

DAMIANIST
 (n.) A follower of Damian, patriarch of Alexandria in the 6th century, who held heretical opinions on the doctrine of the Holy Trinity.

DAMPENING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Dampen

DANCERESS
 (n.) A female dancer.

DANDIPRAT
 (n.) A little fellow; -- in sport or contempt.

DANGEROUS
 (a.) In a condition of danger, as from illness; threatened with death.

DASHBOARD
 (n.) A board placed on the fore part of a carriage, sleigh, or other vehicle, to intercept water, mud, or snow, thrown up by the heels of the horses; -- in England commonly called splashboard.

DASHINGLY
 (adv.) Conspicuously; showily.

DAWSONITE
 (n.) A hydrous carbonate of alumina and soda, occuring in white, bladed crustals.

DEATHLIKE
 (a.) Deadly.

DEBARKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Debark

DEBAUCHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Debauch

DECEASING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Decease

DECENNIAL
 (n.) A tenth year or tenth anniversary.

DECEPTION
 (n.) The state of being deceived or misled.

DECEPTORY
 (a.) Deceptive.

DECIDUATA
 (n. pl.) A group of Mammalia in which a decidua is thrown off with, or after, the fetus, as in the human species.

DECIMATOR
 (n.) One who decimates.

DECLAIMED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Declaim

DECLAIMER
 (n.) One who declaims; an haranguer.

DECLIVOUS
 (a.) Descending gradually; moderately steep; sloping; downhill.

DECRETIST
 (n.) One who studies, or professes the knowledge of, the decretals.

DECUSSATE
 (v. t.) To cross at an acute angle; to cut or divide in the form of X; to intersect; -- said of lines in geometrical figures, rays of light, nerves, etc.

DEDUCTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Deduct

DEDUCTION
 (n.) Act of deducting or taking away; subtraction; as, the deduction of the subtrahend from the minuend.

DEERGRASS
 (n.) An American genus (Rhexia) of perennial herbs, with opposite leaves, and showy flowers (usually bright purple), with four petals and eight stamens, -- the only genus of the order Melastomaceae inhabiting a temperate clime.

DEFAULTER
 (n.) One who fails to perform a duty; a delinquent; particularly, one who fails to account for public money intrusted to his care; a peculator; a defalcator.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Defeat

DEFLECTED
 (a.) Bent downward; deflexed.

 (a.) Pertaining to, savoring of, or consisting in, deism; as, a deistic writer; a deistical book.

DELAPSING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Delapse

DELICIOUS
 (a.) Affording exquisite pleasure; delightful; most sweet or grateful to the senses, especially to the taste; charming.

DELINEATE
 (v. t.) To portray to the mind or understanding by words; to set forth; to describe.

DELIQUATE
 (v. t.) To cause to melt away; to dissolve; to consume; to waste.

DELPHINIC
 (n.) Pertaining to, or derived from, the dolphin; phocenic.

DELUNDUNG
 (n.) An East Indian carnivorous mammal (Prionodon gracilis), resembling the civets, but without scent pouches. It is handsomely spotted.

DEMANTOID
 (n.) A yellow-green, transparent variety of garnet found in the Urals. It is valued as a gem because of its brilliancy of luster, whence the name.

DEMEANURE
 (n.) Behavior.

DEMERSION
 (n.) The act of plunging into a fluid; a drowning.

DEMILANCE
 (n.) A light lance; a short spear; a half pike; also, a demilancer.

DEMOCRACY
 (n.) Government by popular representation; a form of government in which the supreme power is retained by the people, but is indirectly exercised through a system of representation and delegated authority periodically renewed; a constitutional represent

DEMONIASM
 (n.) See Demonianism.

DEMONSHIP
 (n.) The state of a demon.

DENDRITIC
 (a.) Alt. of Dendritical

DENIGRATE
 (v. t.) Fig.: To blacken or sully; to defame.

DENITRIFY
 (v. t.) To deprive of, or free from, nitrogen.

DENTALISM
 (n.) The quality of being formed by the aid of the teeth.

DENTATELY
 (adv.) In a dentate or toothed manner; as, dentately ciliated, etc.

DENTICETE
 (n. pl.) The division of Cetacea in which the teeth are developed, including the sperm whale, dolphins, etc.

DENTIFORM
 (a.) Having the form of a tooth or of teeth; tooth-shaped.

DEOXIDIZE
 (v. t.) To deprive of oxygen; to reduce from the state of an oxide.

DEPARTURE
 (n.) Separation or removal from a place; the act or process of departing or going away.

DEPENDENT
 (a.) Hanging down; as, a dependent bough or leaf.

DEPLETION
 (n.) the act or process of diminishing the quantity of fluid in the vessels by bloodletting or otherwise; also excessive evacuation, as in severe diarrhea.

DEPLUMATE
 (a.) Destitute or deprived of features; deplumed.

DEPOSITUM
 (n.) Deposit.

DEPRESSED
 (a.) Having the vertical diameter shorter than the horizontal or transverse; -- said of the bodies of animals, or of parts of the bodies.

DEPRESSOR
 (n.) One who, or that which, presses down; an oppressor.

DERMATOID
 (a.) Resembling skin; skinlike.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Descant

 (a.) Meritorious.

 (a.) Furnished with a dewlap.

DEXTERITY
 (n.) Readiness in the use or control of the mental powers; quickness and skill in managing any complicated or difficult affair; adroitness.

DIABOLISM
 (n.) Possession by the devil.

DIACHYLUM
 (n.) A plaster originally composed of the juices of several plants (whence its name), but now made of an oxide of lead and oil, and consisting essentially of glycerin mixed with lead salts of the fat acids.

DIAGNOSIS
 (n.) Critical perception or scrutiny; judgment based on such scrutiny; esp., perception of, or judgment concerning, motives and character.

DIALECTIC
 (a.) Alt. of Dialectical

DIALECTOR
 (n.) One skilled in dialectics.

DIAMETRAL
 (n.) A diameter.

DIAPHANIC
 (a.) Having power to transmit light; transparent; diaphanous.

DICHOTOMY
 (n.) Successive division and subdivision, as of a stem of a plant or a vein of the body, into two parts as it proceeds from its origin; successive bifurcation.

DICLINOUS
 (a.) Having the stamens and pistils in separate flowers.

DICTYOGEN
 (n.) A plant with net-veined leaves, and monocotyledonous embryos, belonging to the class Dictyogenae, proposed by Lindley for the orders Dioscoreaceae, Smilaceae, Trilliaceae, etc.

DIDELPHID
 (n.) A marsupial animal.

 (pl. ) of Dietary

 (a.) Pertaining to digestion; having the power to cause or promote digestion; as, the digestive ferments.

 (v. t.) To deprive or clear of flesh.

 (n.) An objection; cavil; dissent; disapprobation; offense; cause of offense; -- usually followed by to or against.

EXCERPTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Excerpt

EXCERPTOR
 (n.) One who makes excerpts; a picker; a culler.

EXCHANGER
 (n.) One who exchanges; one who practices exchange.

EXCHEQUER
 (v. t.) To institute a process against (any one) in the Court of Exchequer.

EXCISABLE
 (a.) Liable or subject to excise; as, tobacco in an excisable commodity.

EXCITEFUL
 (n.) Full of exciting qualities; as, an exciteful story; exciteful players.

EXCLUSORY
 (a.) Able to exclude; excluding; serving to exclude.

EXCREABLE
 (a.) Capable of being discharged by spitting.

EXCRETIVE
 (a.) Having the power of excreting, or promoting excretion.

EXCULPATE
 (v. t.) To clear from alleged fault or guilt; to prove to be guiltless; to relieve of blame; to acquit.

EXECUTION
 (n.) That which is executed or accomplished; effect; effective work; -- usually with do.

EXEGETIST
 (n.) One versed in the science of exegesis or interpretation; -- also called exegete.

EXEMPLARY
 (a.) Serving as a pattern; deserving to be proposed for imitation; commendable; as, an exemplary person; exemplary conduct.

EXEQUATUR
 (n.) A written official recognition of a consul or commercial agent, issued by the government to which he is accredited, and authorizing him to exercise his powers in the place to which he is assigned.

EXERCISED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Exercise

EXERCISER
 (n.) One who exercises.

 (v. t.) To remove scales, laminae, or splinters from the surface of.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Exhibit

EXHIBITOR
 (n.) One who exhibits.

EXHUMATED
 (a.) Disinterred.

EXOLUTION
 (n.) See Exsolution.

EXORCISER
 (n.) An exorcist.

EXPANSION
 (n.) The operation of steam in a cylinder after its communication with the boiler has been cut off, by which it continues to exert pressure upon the moving piston.

EXPATIATE
 (v. i.) To enlarge in discourse or writing; to be copious in argument or discussion; to descant.

EXPECTANT
 (n.) One who waits in expectation; one held in dependence by hope of receiving some good.

EXPEDIENT
 (a.) Quick; expeditious.

EXPLETIVE
 (n.) A word, letter, or syllable not necessary to the sense, but inserted to fill a vacancy; an oath.

EXPLODING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Explode

EXPLOSION
 (n.) A violent outburst of feeling, manifested by excited language, action, etc.; as, an explosion of wrath.

EXPOUNDER
 (n.) One who expounds or explains; an interpreter.

EXPRESSLY
 (adv.) In an express manner; in direct terms; with distinct purpose; particularly; as, a book written expressly for the young.

EXQUISITE
 (a.) Carefully selected or sought out; hence, of distinguishing and surpassing quality; exceedingly nice; delightfully excellent; giving rare satisfaction; as, exquisite workmanship.

EXTENSION
 (v. t.) The straightening of a limb, in distinction from flexion.

EXTENUATE
 (v. i.) To become thinner; to make excuses; to advance palliating considerations.

EXTERMINE
 (v. t.) To exterminate; to destroy.

EXTORTION
 (n.) The act of extorting; the act or practice of wresting anything from a person by force, by threats, or by any undue exercise of power; undue exaction; overcharge.

EXTREMITY
 (n.) One of locomotive appendages of an animal; a limb; a leg or an arm of man.

EXTRICATE
 (v. t.) To cause to be emitted or evolved; as, to extricate heat or moisture.

EXUBERANT
 (a.) Characterized by abundance or superabundance; plenteous; rich; overflowing; copious or excessive in production; as, exuberant goodness; an exuberant intellect; exuberant foliage.

EYELETEER
 (n.) A small, sharp-pointed instrument used in piercing eyelet holes; a stiletto.

 (n.) The main constituent of the starch grain or granule, in distinction from the framework of cellulose. Unlike cellulose, it is colored blue by iodine, and is converted into dextrin and sugar by boiling acids and amylolytic ferments.

 (a.) Western; being in the west; occidental.

HESYCHAST
 (n.) One of a mystical sect of the Greek Church in the fourteenth century; a quietist.

HETEROPOD
 (n.) One of the Heteropoda.

HEXACHORD
 (n.) A series of six notes, with a semitone between the third and fourth, the other intervals being whole tones.

HEXANDRIA
 (n. pl.) A Linnaean class of plants having six stamens.

HEXASTYLE
 (a.) Having six columns in front; -- said of a portico or temple.

HIBERNIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Hibernia, now Ireland; Irish.

HIDEBOUND
 (a.) Having the skin adhering so closely to the ribs and back as not to be easily loosened or raised; -- said of an animal.

HIPPURITE
 (n.) A fossil bivalve mollusk of the genus Hippurites, of many species, having a conical, cup-shaped under valve, with a flattish upper valve or lid. Hippurites are found only in the Cretaceous rocks.

HIRCINOUS
 (a.) Of a strong goatish smell.

HISTOLOGY
 (n.) That branch of biological science, which treats of the minute (microscopic) structure of animal and vegetable tissues; -- called also histiology.

HISTORIAN
 (n.) One versed or well informed in history.

HISTORIZE
 (v. t.) To relate as history; to chronicle; to historicize.

HODOMETER
 (n.) See Odometer.

HOGRINGER
 (n.) One who puts rings into the snouts of hogs.

HOLLANDER
 (n.) A native or one of the people of Holland; a Dutchman.

HOLSTERED
 (a.) Bearing holsters.

HOMEOPATH
 (n.) A practitioner of homeopathy.

HOMESTALL
 (n.) Place of a home; homestead.

HOMODERMY
 (n.) Homology of the germinal layers.

HOMOPHONE
 (n.) A letter or character which expresses a like sound with another.

HOMOPHONY
 (n.) Sameness of sound; unison.

HONEYBIRD
 (n.) The honey guide.

HONEYWARE
 (n.) See Badderlocks.

HONORABLE
 (a.) Of reputable association or use; respectable.

HONORLESS
 (a.) Destitute of honor; not honored.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Horrify

HORSEHEAD
 (n.) The silver moonfish (Selene vomer).

 (n.) Rude, boisterous play.

HORTATION
 (n.) The act of exhorting, inciting, or giving advice; exhortation.

HOSTILIZE
 (v. t.) To make hostile; to cause to become an enemy.

HOUSEWIFE
 (n.) The wife of a householder; the mistress of a family; the female head of a household.

HOUSEWORK
 (n.) The work belonging to housekeeping; especially, kitchen work, sweeping, scrubbing, bed making, and the like.

HUFFINGLY
 (adv.) Blusteringly; arrogantly.

 (n.) The quality or state of being human.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Humbug

HUMECTIVE
 (a.) Tending to moisten.

HUMORLESS
 (a.) Destitute of humor.

HUNGARIAN
 (n.) A native or one of the people of Hungary.

HUSKINESS
 (n.) The state of being husky.

HUTTONIAN
 (a.) Relating to what is now called the Plutonic theory of the earth, first advanced by Dr. James Hutton.

HYDROCELE
 (n.) A collection of serous fluid in the areolar texture of the scrotum or in the coverings, especially in the serous sac, investing the testicle or the spermatic cord; dropsy of the testicle.

HYDROGODE
 (n.) The negative pole or cathode.

HYDROSOMA
 (n.) All the zooids of a hydroid colony collectively, including the nutritive and reproductive zooids, and often other kinds.

HYGIENIST
 (n.) One versed in hygiene.

HYOSTYLIC
 (a.) Having the mandible suspended by the hyomandibular, or upper part of the hyoid arch, as in fishes, instead of directly articulated with the skull as in mammals; -- said of the skull.

HYPERBOLA
 (n.) A curve formed by a section of a cone, when the cutting plane makes a greater angle with the base than the side of the cone makes. It is a plane curve such that the difference of the distances from any point of it to two fixed points, called foci,

HYPERDULY
 (n.) Hyperdulia.

HYPERNOEA
 (n.) Abnormal breathing, due to slightly deficient arterialization of the blood; -- in distinction from eupnoea. See Eupnoea, and Dispnoea.

HYPINOSIS
 (n.) A diminution in the normal amount of fibrin present in the blood.

HYPOARIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a hypoarion.

IANTHINAE
 (pl. ) of Ianthina

ICELANDIC
 (n.) The language of the Icelanders. It is one of the Scandinavian group, and is more nearly allied to the Old Norse than any other language now spoken.

ICHNEUMON
 (n.) Any hymenopterous insect of the family Ichneumonidae, of which several thousand species are known, belonging to numerous genera.

IDIOBLAST
 (n.) An individual cell, differing greatly from its neighbours in regard to size, structure, or contents.

IDIOPATHY
 (n.) A morbid state or condition not preceded or occasioned by any other disease; a primary disease.

IDRIALITE
 (n.) A bituminous substance obtained from the mercury mines of Idria, where it occurs mixed with cinnabar.

IGNESCENT
 (a.) Emitting sparks of fire when struck with steel; scintillating; as, ignescent stones.

IGNORAMUS
 (n.) We are ignorant; we ignore; -- being the word formerly written on a bill of indictment by a grand jury when there was not sufficient evidence to warrant them in finding it a T bill. The phrase now used is, No bill, No true bill, or Not found, thoug

ILEOCOLIC
 (a.) Pertaining to the ileum and colon; as, the ileocolic, or ileocaecal, valve, a valve where the ileum opens into the large intestine.

ILLIBERAL
 (a.) Indicating a lack of breeding, culture, and the like; ignoble; rude; narrow-minded; disingenuous.

 (a.) Imagining; conceiving.

 (n.) An imitatress.

 (a.) Not deferred by an interval of time; present; instant.

 (n.) Submersion in water for the purpose of Christian baptism, as, practiced by the Baptists.

 (n.) The act of immitting, or of sending or thrusting in; injection; -- the correlative of emission.

 (a.) Not mixable.

 (a.) Formed by implosion.

INCUMBENT
 (n.) A person who is in present possession of a benefice or of any office.

 (a.) Characterized by a current which flows inward; as, the incurrent orifice of lamellibranch Mollusca.

INDECORUM
 (n.) Want of decorum; impropriety of behavior; that in behavior or manners which violates the established rules of civility, custom, or etiquette; indecorousness.

INDELIBLE
 (a.) That can not be removed, washed away, blotted out, or effaced; incapable of being canceled, lost, or forgotten; as, indelible characters; an indelible stain; an indelible impression on the memory.

 (v. t.) To interweave or interlace.

 (v. t.) To thrust; to intrude; to between, either for aid or for troubling.

INTERPRET

INTERSECT
 (v. t.) To cut into or between; to cut or cross mutually; to divide into parts; as, any two diameters of a circle intersect each other at the center.

INTERVENE
 (n.) A coming between; intervention; meeting.

INTERVIEW
 (n.) A mutual sight or view; a meeting face to face; usually, a formal or official meeting for consultation; a conference; as, the secretary had an interview with the President.

INTESTINE
 (a.) The bowels; entrails; viscera.

INTORTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Intort

INTRINSIC
 (a.) Inward; internal; hence, true; genuine; real; essential; inherent; not merely apparent or accidental; -- opposed to extrinsic; as, the intrinsic value of gold or silver; the intrinsic merit of an action; the intrinsic worth or goodness of a person.

INTRODUCE
 (v. t.) To lead to and make known by formal announcement or recommendation; hence, to cause to be acquainted; as, to introduce strangers; to introduce one person to another.

INTROSUME
 (v. t.) To draw in; to swallow.

INTROVERT
 (v. t.) To turn or bend inward.

INTRUSION
 (n.) The entry of a stranger, after a particular estate or freehold is determined, before the person who holds in remainder or reversion has taken possession.

INUNCTION
 (n.) The act of anointing, or the state of being anointed; unction; specifically (Med.), the rubbing of ointments into the pores of the skin, by which medicinal agents contained in them, such as mercury, iodide of potash, etc., are absorbed.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Inveigh

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Invent

INVERSION
 (n.) A peculiar method of transformation, in which a figure is replaced by its inverse figure. Propositions that are T for the original figure thus furnish new propositions that are T in the inverse figure. See Inverse figures, under Inverse.

INVERSION
 (n.) The folding back of strata upon themselves, as by upheaval, in such a manner that the order of succession appears to be reversed.

INVISIBLE
 (n.) A Rosicrucian; -- so called because avoiding declaration of his craft.

INVOLVING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Involve

INWROUGHT

IRIDOLINE
 (n.) A nitrogenous base C10H9N, extracted from coal-tar naphtha, as an oily liquid. It is a member of the quinoline series, and is probably identical with lepidine.

 (n.) A sac containing small, calcareous concretions (otoliths). They are found in many Medusae, and other invertebrates, and are supposed to be auditory organs.

LITHOIDAL
 (a.) Like a stone; having a stony structure.

LITHOLOGY
 (n.) The science which treats of rocks, as regards their mineral constitution and classification, and their mode of occurrence in nature.

LITHOSIAN
 (n.) Any one of various species of moths belonging to the family Lithosidae. Many of them are beautifully colored.

LITIGATOR
 (n.) One who litigates.

LITURGIST
 (n.) One who favors or adheres strictly to a liturgy.

LIVERWORT
 (n.) A flowerless plant (Marchantia polymorpha), having an irregularly lobed, spreading, and forking frond.

LIXIVIATE
 (v. t.) To subject to a washing process for the purpose of separating soluble material from that which is insoluble; to leach, as ashes, for the purpose of extracting the alkaline substances.

LOATHNESS
 (n.) Unwillingness; reluctance.

LODESTONE
 (n.) Same as Loadstone.

LOGAOEDIC
 (a.) Composed of dactyls and trochees so arranged as to produce a movement like that of ordinary speech.

LOITERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Loiter

LONGITUDE
 (n.) Length; measure or distance along the longest line; -- distinguished from breadth or thickness; as, the longitude of a room; rare now, except in a humorous sense.

LOOSENESS
 (n.) The state, condition, or quality, of being loose; as, the looseness of a cord; looseness of style; looseness of morals or of principles.

LORGNETTE
 (n.) elaborate double eyeglasses.

LOWERMOST
 (superl.) Lowest.

LUCIFRIAN
 (a.) Luciferian; satanic.

LUDICROUS
 (a.) Adapted to excite laughter, without scorn or contempt; sportive.

LUNISOLAR
 (a.) Resulting from the united action, or pertaining to the mutual relations, of the sun and moon.

LUSTIHOOD
 (n.) State of being lusty; vigor of body.

LUSTRATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Lustrate

LUXURIATE
 (v. i.) To indulge with unrestrained delight and freedom; as, to luxuriate in description.

MACARONIC
 (n.) A heap of thing confusedly mixed together; a jumble.

MACHINERY
 (n.) The working parts of a machine, engine, or instrument; as, the machinery of a watch.

MADEGASSY
 (n. & a.) See Madecassee.

MAGAZINED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Magazine

MAGISTERY
 (n.) A precipitate; a fine substance deposited by precipitation; -- applied in old chemistry to certain white precipitates from metallic solutions; as, magistery of bismuth.

MAGISTRAL
 (n.) A sovereign medicine or remedy.

MAGNETICS
 (n.) The science of magnetism.

MAGNIFIED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Magnify

MAGNITUDE
 (n.) Greatness; grandeur.

MAKESHIFT
 (n.) That with which one makes shift; a temporary expedient.

MALANDERS
 (n. pl.) A scurfy eruption in the bend of the knee of the fore leg of a horse. See Sallenders.

MALETREAT
 (v. t.) See Maltreat.

MALIGNANT
 (n.) A man of extrems enmity or evil intentions.

MALIGNITY
 (n.) The state or quality of being malignant; disposition to do evil; virulent enmity; malignancy; malice; spite.

MALLEABLE
 (a.) Capable of being extended or shaped by beating with a hammer, or by the pressure of rollers; -- applied to metals.

MALLEOLUS
 (n.) A projection at the distal end of each bone of the leg at the ankle joint. The malleolus of the tibia is the internal projection, that of the fibula the external.

MANGANESE
 (n.) An element obtained by reduction of its oxide, as a hard, grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty, but easily oxidized. Its ores occur abundantly in nature as the minerals pyrolusite, manganite, etc. Symbol Mn. Atomic weight 54.8.

MANIPULAR
 (a.) Manipulatory; as, manipular operations.

MANZANITA
 (n.) A name given to several species of Arctostaphylos, but mostly to A. glauca and A. pungens, shrubs of California, Oregon, etc., with reddish smooth bark, ovate or oval coriaceous evergreen leaves, and bearing clusters of red berries, which are said

MARANATHA
 (n.) Our Lord cometh; -- an expression used by St. Paul at the conclusion of his first Epistle to the Corinthians (xvi. 22). This word has been used in anathematizing persons for great crimes; as much as to say, May the Lord come quickly to take vengean

MARCHPANE
 (n.) A kind of sweet bread or biscuit; a cake of pounded almonds and sugar.

MARGARATE
 (n.) A compound of the so-called margaric acid with a base.

MARGINATE
 (n.) Having a margin distinct in appearance or structure.

MARIMONDA
 (n.) A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Central and South America.

MARITATED
 (a.) Having a husband; married.

MARKETING
 (n.) Articles in, or from, a market; supplies.

MARMOLITE
 (n.) A thin, laminated variety of serpentine, usually of a pale green color.

MARONITES
 (pl. ) of Maronite

MARRIABLE
 (a.) Marriageable.

MARROWING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Marrow

MARRUBIUM
 (n.) A genus of bitter aromatic plants, sometimes used in medicine; hoarhound.

MARSDENIA
 (n.) A genus of plants of the Milkweed family, mostly woody climbers with fragrant flowers, several species of which furnish valuable fiber, and one species (Marsdenia tinctoria) affords indigo.

MARSHALED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Marshal

MARSHALER
 (n.) One who marshals.

MARSUPIAL
 (n.) One of the Marsupialia.

MARTYRDOM
 (n.) The condition of a martyr; the death of a martyr; the suffering of death on account of adherence to the Christian faith, or to any cause.

MARVELLED
 () of Marvel

MARVELOUS
 (n.) Partaking of the character of miracle, or supernatural power; incredible.

MASCULATE
 (v. t.) To make strong.

MASTERFUL
 (a.) Inclined to play the master; domineering; imperious; arbitrary.

MATCHLESS
 (a.) Having no equal; unequaled.

 (v. t.) To make a matron of; to make matronlike.

MATUTINAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the morning; early.

MAUSOLEAN
 (a.) Pertaining to a mausoleum; monumental.

MAXILLARY
 (a.) Pertaining to either the upper or the lower jaw, but now usually applied to the upper jaw only.

 (n.) The office of a mayor.

MAZEDNESS
 (n.) The condition of being mazed; confusion; astonishment.

MEANDROUS
 (a.) Alt. of Meandry

MECHANISM
 (n.) An ideal machine; a combination of movable bodies constituting a machine, but considered only with regard to relative movements.

MECHOACAN
 (n.) A species of jalap, of very feeble properties, said to be obtained from the root of a species of Convolvulus (C. Mechoacan); -- so called from Michoacan, in Mexico, whence it is obtained.

MECONINIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which occurs in opium, and which may be obtained by oxidizing narcotine.

MEDALLING
 () of Medal

MEDALLION
 (n.) A large medal or memorial coin.

MEDICALLY
 (adv.) In a medical manner; with reference to healing, or to the principles of the healing art.

MEDULLARY
 (a.) Filled with spongy pith; pithy.

MEGAFARAD
 (n.) One of the larger measures of electrical capacity, amounting to one million farads; a macrofarad.

MEGALONYX
 (n.) An extinct quaternary mammal, of great size, allied to the sloth.

MELANURIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid obtained by decomposition of melam, or of urea, as a white crystalline powder; -- called also melanurenic acid.

MELIORATE
 (v. i.) To grow better.

MELLITATE
 (n.) A salt of mellitic acid.

MELODIOUS
 (a.) Containing, or producing, melody; musical; agreeable to the ear by a sweet succession of sounds; as, a melodious voice.

MEMORANDA
 (pl. ) of Memorandum

MENDACITY
 (n.) A falsehood; a lie.

MENOPAUSE
 (n.) The period of natural cessation of menstruation. See Change of life, under Change.

MENSTRUAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the menses; as, menstrual discharges; the menstrual period.

MERCAPTAL
 (n.) Any one of a series of compounds of mercaptans with aldehydes.

MERCENARY
 (n.) One who is hired; a hireling; especially, a soldier hired into foreign service.

MERCURIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to, or containing, mercury; as, mercurial preparations, barometer. See Mercury, 2.

MESOBLAST
 (n.) The cell nucleus; mesoplast.

 (n.) The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the colon.

MESOSTATE
 (n.) A product of metabolic action.

 (pl. ) of Metabasis

 (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, a metal; metallic; as, metalline properties.

METALLIZE
 (v. t.) To impart metallic properties to; to impregnate with a metal.

METASTOMA
 (n.) Alt. of Metastome

METHODIOS
 (n.) The art and principles of method.

METHYLATE
 (n.) An alcoholate of methyl alcohol in which the hydroxyl hydrogen is replaced by a metal, after the analogy of a hydrate; as, sodium methylate, CH3ONa.

METROLOGY
 (n.) The science of, or a system of, weights and measures; also, a treatise on the subject.

METROPOLE
 (n.) A metropolis.

METROTOME
 (n.) An instrument for cutting or scarifying the uterus or the neck of the uterus.

MEZZANINE
 (n.) A partial story which is not on the same level with the story of the main part of the edifice, as of a back building, where the floors are on a level with landings of the staircase of the main house.

MICACEOUS
 (a.) Pertaining to, or containing, mica; splitting into laminae or leaves like mica.

MICRASTER
 (n.) A genus of sea urchins, similar to Spatangus, abounding in the chalk formation; -- from the starlike disposal of the ambulacral furrows.

MICROFORM
 (n.) A microscopic form of life; an animal or vegetable organism microscopic size.

MICROLITE
 (n.) A rare mineral of resinous luster and high specific gravity. It is a tantalate of calcium, and occurs in octahedral crystals usually very minute.

MICROLOGY
 (n.) Attention to petty items or differences.

MILESTONE
 (n.) A stone serving the same purpose as a milepost.

MILLBOARD
 (n.) A kind of stout pasteboard.

MILLENARY
 (a.) Consisting of a thousand; millennial.

MILLIGRAM
 (n.) Alt. of Milligramme

MILLIONTH
 (n.) The quotient of a unit divided by one million; one of a million equal parts.

MILTWASTE
 () A small European fern (Asplenium Ceterach) formerly used in medicine.

 (n.) Modernness; something modern.

 (n.) One who, or that which, moistens.

MOLECULAR
 (a.) Pertaining to, connected with, produced by, or consisting of, molecules; as, molecular forces; molecular groups of atoms, etc.

MOLLEMOKE
 (n.) Any one of several species of large pelagic petrels and fulmars, as Fulmarus glacialis, of the North Atlantic, and several species of Aestrelata, of the Southern Ocean. See Fulmar.

 (n.) Molybdic ocher.

MOMENTANY
 (a.) Momentary.

 (adv.) Having the equivalence or replacing power of an atom of hydrogen; univalent; as, the methyl radical is monatomic.

MONGOLOID
 (a.) Resembling a Mongol or the Mongols; having race characteristics, such as color, hair, and features, like those of the Mongols.

 (n.) A plant of the genus Aconitum; aconite. See Aconite.

MONOCULAR
 (a.) Having only one eye; with one eye only; as, monocular vision.

MONODICAL
 (a.) Homophonic; -- applied to music in which the melody is confined to one part, instead of being shared by all the parts as in the style called polyphonic.

MONOGRAPH
 (n.) A written account or description of a single thing, or class of things; a special treatise on a particular subject of limited range.

MONOMYARY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Monomya.

 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid of the alloxan group, obtained as a honey-yellow powder. Its solutions have a gelatinous consistency.

 (n.) The condition of being naked.

NAPHTHOIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, naphthalene; -- used specifically to designate any one of a series of carboxyl derivatives, called naphthoic acids.

NARCISSUS
 (n.) A genus of endogenous bulbous plants with handsome flowers, having a cup-shaped crown within the six-lobed perianth, and comprising the daffodils and jonquils of several kinds.

NASUTNESS
 (n.) Quickness of scent; hence, nice discernment; acuteness.

NATROLITE
 (n.) A zeolite occuring in groups of glassy acicular crystals, and in masses which often have a radiated structure. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and soda.

 (a.) Shaped like the hull of a ship.

NAVIGABLE
 (a.) Capable of being navigated; deep enough and wide enough to afford passage to vessels; as, a navigable river.

NESTORIAN
 (a.) relating to, or resembling, Nestor, the aged warior and counselor mentioned by Homer; hence, wise; experienced; aged; as, Nestorian caution.

NEUROPORE
 (n.) An opening at either end of the embryonic neural canal.

 (n.) A follower of Newton.

NICKELINE
 (n.) An alloy of nickel, a variety of German silver.

NIGHTWARD
 (a.) Approaching toward night.

NILOMETER
 (n.) An instrument for measuring the rise of water in the Nile during its periodical flood.

NINEHOLES
 (n. pl.) A game in which nine holes are made in the ground, into which a ball is bowled.

NOCTILUCA
 (n.) That which shines at night; -- a fanciful name for phosphorus.

NONPAREIL
 (a.) A beautifully colored finch (Passerina ciris), native of the Southern United States. The male has the head and neck deep blue, rump and under parts bright red, back and wings golden green, and the tail bluish purple. Called also painted finch.

NOPALRIES
 (pl. ) of Nopalry

NORTHEAST
 (n.) The point between the north and east, at an equal distance from each; the northeast part or region.

 (adv.) Alt. of Northwards

 (adv.) Toward the northwest.

 (n.) A native of Norway.

NOSTALGIA
 (n.) Homesickness; esp., a severe and sometimes fatal form of melancholia, due to homesickness.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Nourish

NOVELETTE
 (n.) A short novel.

 (n.) Hence: Time of probation in a religious house before taking the vows.

NUNDINARY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a fair, or to a market day.

 (n.) That which nourishes; anything which promotes growth and repairs the natural waste of animal or vegetable life; food; aliment.

 (n.) A South American bird of the genus Nyctibius, allied to the goatsuckers.

 (n.) Quality of being obese; obesity.

 (n.) The condition of being oblique; deviation from a right line; deviation from parallelism or perpendicularity; the amount of such deviation; divergence; as, the obliquity of the ecliptic to the equator.

OBLOCUTOR
 (n.) A disputer; a gainsayer.

OBSCENITY
 (n.) That quality in words or things which presents what is offensive to chasity or purity of mind; obscene or impure lanquage or acts; moral impurity; lewdness; obsceneness; as, the obscenity of a speech, or a picture.

OLECRANON
 (n.) The large process at the proximal end of the ulna which projects behind the articulation with the humerus and forms the bony prominence of the elbow.

OLEOGRAPH
 (n.) The form or figure assumed by a drop of oil when placed upon water or some other liquid with which it does not mix.

OLEORESIN
 (n.) A natural mixture of a terebinthinate oil and a resin.

OLFACTION
 (n.) The sense by which the impressions made on the olfactory organs by the odorous particles in the atmosphere are perceived.

OLIGARCHY
 (n.) A form of government in which the supreme power is placed in the hands of a few persons; also, those who form the ruling few.

OLUSATRUM

 (n.) Ordnance; cannon.

ORIENTATE
 (v. t.) To arrange in order; to dispose or place (a body) so as to show its relation to other bodies, or the relation of its parts among themselves.

 (n.) A follower of Origen of Alexandria.

ORIGINARY
 (a.) Primitive; primary; original.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Orphan
