 (n.) Orphanhood.

ORTHODOXY
 (n.) Soundness of faith; a belief in the doctrines taught in the Scriptures, or in some established standard of faith; -- opposed to heterodoxy or to heresy.

ORTHOTONE
 (a.) Retaining the accent; not enclitic; -- said of certain indefinite pronouns and adverbs when used interrogatively, which, when not so used, are ordinarilly enclitic.

OSCULATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Osculate

OSTENSIVE
 (a.) Showing; exhibiting.

OSTRACOID
 (n.) One of the Ostracoidea.

OTHERWISE
 (adv.) In other respects.

OUBLIETTE
 (n.) A dungeon with an opening only at the top, found in some old castles and other strongholds, into which persons condemned to perpetual imprisonment, or to perish secretly, were thrust, or lured to fall.

OUTBRAZEN
 (v. t.) To bear down with a brazen face; to surpass in impudence.

OUTJUGGLE
 (v. t.) To surpass in juggling.

OUTLINEAR
 (a.) Of or pertaining to an outline; being in, or forming, an outline.

OUTSPOKEN
 (a.) Speaking, or spoken, freely, openly, or boldly; as, an outspoken man; an outspoken rebuke.

OUTTRAVEL
 (v. t.) To exceed in speed o/ distance traveled.

OVERAWFUL
 (a.) Awful, or reverential, in an excessive degree.

OVERBUILD
 (v. t.) To build too much; to build beyond the demand.

OVERCARRY
 (v. t. & i.) To carry too far; to carry beyond the proper point.

OVERCLIMB
 (v. t.) To climb over.

OVERDTIVE
 (v. t. & i.) To drive too hard, or far, or beyond strength.

OVERFLOWN
 (p. p.) of Overfly

OVERGORGE
 (v. t.) To gorge to excess.

OVERHASTY
 (a.) Too hasty; precipitate; rash.

OVERLARGE
 (a.) Too large; too great.

OVERLAYER
 (n.) One who overlays; that with which anything is overlaid.

OVERLIGHT
 (n.) Too strong a light.

OVERLIVER
 (n.) A survivor.

OVERLUSTY
 (a.) Too lusty, or lively.

OVERMOUNT
 (v. t.) To mount over; to go higher than; to rise above.

OVERQUELL
 (v. t.) To quell or subdue completely.

OVERREACH
 (v. t.) To deceive, or get the better of, by artifice or cunning; to outwit; to cheat.

OVERSHINE
 (v. t.) To shine over or upon; to illumine.

OVERSHOOT
 (v. t.) To exceed; as, to overshoot the truth.

OVERSLIDE
 (v. t.) To slide over or by.

OVERSPEAK
 (v. t. & i.) To exceed in speaking; to speak too much; to use too many words.

OVERSTAND
 (v. t.) To stand on the price or conditions of, so as to lose a sale; to lose by an extravagant price or hard conditions.

OVERSTOCK
 (n.) Stock in excess.

OVERTHROW
 (n.) The act of overthrowing; the state of being overthrow; ruin.

OVERWATCH
 (v. t.) To weary or exhaust by watching.

OVERWHELM
 (n.) The act of overwhelming.

OVIPARITY
 (n.) Generation by means of ova. See Generation.

OXALURATE
 (n.) A salt of oxaluric acid.

OXANILIDE
 (n.) a white crystalline substance, resembling oxanilamide, obtained by heating aniline oxalate, and regarded as a double anilide of oxalic acid; -- called also diphenyl oxamide.

OXIDIZING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Oxidize

OXYACETIC
 (a.) Hydroxyacetic; designating an acid called also glycolic acid.

OXYGENOUS
 (a.) Oxygenic.

PAGANICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to pagans or paganism; heathenish; paganish.

PALACIOUS
 (a.) Palatial.

PALANQUIN
 (n.) An inclosed carriage or litter, commonly about eight feet long, four feet wide, and four feet high, borne on the shoulders of men by means of two projecting poles, -- used in India, China, etc., for the conveyance of a single person from place to p

PALFREYED
 (a.) Mounted on a palfrey.

PALLADIUM
 (n.) Any statue of the goddess Pallas; esp., the famous statue on the preservation of which depended the safety of ancient Troy.

PALLIDITY
 (n.) Pallidness; paleness.

PALLOMETA
 (n.) A pompano.

PALPATION
 (n.) Examination of a patient by touch.

PALTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Palter

PANDARISM
 (n.) Same as Panderism.

PANEGYRIC
 (a.) An oration or eulogy in praise of some person or achievement; a formal or elaborate encomium; a laudatory discourse; laudation. See Synonym of Eulogy.

PANOISTIC
 (a.) Producing ova only; -- said of the ovaries of certain insects which do not produce vitelligenous cells.

PANTOMIME
 (n.) A universal mimic; an actor who assumes many parts; also, any actor.

PAPILLOMA
 (n.) A tumor formed by hypertrophy of the papillae of the skin or mucous membrane, as a corn or a wart.

PAPPIFORM
 (a.) Resembling the pappus of composite plants.

PARABOLIC
 (a.) Alt. of Parabolical

PARACONIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained as a deliquescent white crystalline substance, and isomeric with itaconic, citraconic, and mesaconic acids.

PARAGNATH
 (n.) Same as Paragnathus.

PARAGOGIC
 (a.) Alt. of Paragogical

PARAGRAPH
 (n.) Originally, a marginal mark or note, set in the margin to call attention to something in the text, e. g., a change of subject; now, the character /, commonly used in the text as a reference mark to a footnote, or to indicate the place of a division

PARAGRAPH
 (v. t.) To mention in a paragraph or paragraphs

PARALYTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to paralysis; resembling paralysis.

PARAMETER
 (n.) A term applied to some characteristic magnitude whose value, invariable as long as one and the same function, curve, surface, etc., is considered, serves to distinguish that function, curve, surface, etc., from others of the same kind or family.

PARBUCKLE
 (n.) A kind of purchase for hoisting or lowering a cylindrical burden, as a cask. The middle of a long rope is made fast aloft, and both parts are looped around the object, which rests in the loops, and rolls in them as the ends are hauled up or payed o

PARCENARY
 (n.) The holding or occupation of an inheritable estate which descends from the ancestor to two or more persons; coheirship.

PARDONING
 (a.) Relating to pardon; having or exercising the right to pardon; willing to pardon; merciful; as, the pardoning power; a pardoning God.

PAREGORIC
 (n.) A medicine that mitigates pain; an anodyne; specifically, camphorated tincture of opium; -- called also paregoric elexir.

PAREMBOLE
 (n.) A kind of parenthesis.

PARENESIS
 (n.) Exhortation.

PARGETORY
 (n.) Something made of, or covered with, parget, or plaster.

PARIGENIN
 (n.) A curdy white substance, obtained by the decomposition of parillin.

PARKESINE
 (n.) A compound, originally made from gun cotton and castor oil, but later from different materials, and used as a substitute for vulcanized India rubber and for ivory; -- called also xylotile.

PAROCHIAN
 (n.) A parishioner.

PAROSTEAL
 () Of or pertaining to parostosis; as, parosteal ossification.

PAROTITIS
 (n.) Inflammation of the parotid glands.

PARQUETRY
 (n.) A species of joinery or cabinet-work consisting of an inlay of geometric or other patterns, generally of different colors, -- used especially for floors.

PARSONAGE
 (n.) A certain portion of lands, tithes, and offerings, for the maintenance of the parson of a parish.

PARTAKING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Partake

PARTITION
 (v.) A score.

PARTITIVE
 (n.) A word expressing partition, or denoting a part.

PASSENGER
 (n.) A passer or passer-by; a wayfarer.

PASSIONAL
 (n.) A passionary.

PASSIVITY
 (n.) The tendency of a body to remain in a given state, either of motion or rest, till disturbed by another body; inertia.

PASTORALE
 (n.) A composition in a soft, rural style, generally in 06.08.02 or 12.08.02 time.

PASTURAGE
 (n.) Grass growing for feed; grazing.

PATCHOULY
 (n.) A mintlike plant (Pogostemon Patchouli) of the East Indies, yielding an essential oil from which a highly valued perfume is made.

PATHETISM
 (n.) See Mesmerism.

PATRICIAN
 (n.) One familiar with the works of the Christian Fathers; one versed in patristic lore.

PATROLMAN
 (n.) One who patrols; a watchman; especially, a policeman who patrols a particular precinct of a town or city.

PATRONAGE
 (n.) The right of nomination to political office; also, the offices, contracts, honors, etc., which a public officer may bestow by favor.

PATTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Patter

PAUHAUGEN
 (n.) The menhaden; -- called also poghaden.

PAUROPODA
 (n. pl.) An order of small myriapods having only nine pairs of legs and destitute of tracheae.

PEARLWORT
 (n.) A name given to several species of Sagina, low and inconspicuous herbs of the Chickweed family.

PECTINEAL
 (a.) Relating to, or connected with, the pubic bone.

PECUNIARY
 (a.) Relating to money; monetary; as, a pecuniary penalty; a pecuniary reward.

PEDANEOUS
 (a.) Going on foot; pedestrian.

PEDANTISM
 (n.) The office, disposition, or act of a pedant; pedantry.

PEGTATOID
 (a.) Resembling pegmatite; pegmatic.

PEMPHIGUS
 (n.) A somewhat rare skin disease, characterized by the development of blebs upon different part of the body.

PENCILING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Pencil

PENCILING
 (n.) Lines of white or black paint drawn along a mortar joint in a brick wall.

PENDULOUS
 (a.) Depending; pendent loosely; hanging; swinging.

PENETRATE
 (v. i.) To pass; to make way; to pierce. Also used figuratively.

PENITENCE
 (n.) The quality or condition of being penitent; the disposition of a penitent; sorrow for sins or faults; repentance; contrition.

PENNACHED
 (a.) Variegated; striped.

PENSIONER
 (n.) In the university of Cambridge, England, one who pays for his living in commons; -- corresponding to commoner at Oxford.

PENTECOST
 (n.) A festival of the Roman Catholic and other churches in commemoration of the descent of the Holy Spirit on the apostles; which occurred on the day of Pentecost; -- called also Whitsunday.

PENURIOUS
 (a.) Destitute of money; suffering extreme want.

PEPPERING
 (a.) Hot; pungent; peppery.

PERBROMIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, the highest oxygen acid, HBrO4, of bromine.

 (n. pl.) Same as Perciformes.

PERDICINE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the family Perdicidae, or partridges.

PERFECTLY
 (adv.) In a perfect manner or degree; in or to perfection; completely; wholly; throughly; faultlessly.

PERIBOLOS
 (n.) In ancient architecture, an inclosed court, esp., one surrounding a temple.

 (pl. ) of Perigynium

PERIMETER

PERIODATE

 (a.) Having the shadow moving all around.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Persist

 (n.) Form, appearance, or belongings of a person; the external appearance, stature, figure, air, and the like, of a person.

PERSONATE
 (v. t.) To personify; to typify; to describe.

PERSONNEL
 (n.) The body of persons employed in some public service, as the army, navy, etc.; -- distinguished from materiel.

PERSUADER
 (n.) One who, or that which, persuades or influences.

PERTURBER

PESSIMIST
 (n.) One who advocates the doctrine of pessimism; -- opposed to optimist.

PESTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Pester

PESTHOUSE
 (n.) A house or hospital for persons who are infected with any pestilential disease.

PESTILENT
 (a.) Pestilential; noxious; pernicious; mischievous.

PETAURIST
 (n.) Any flying marsupial of the genera Petaurus, Phalangista, Acrobata, and allied genera. See Flying mouse, under Flying, and Phalangister.

PETIOLARY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to petiole, or proceeding from it; as, a petiolar tendril; growing or supported upon a petiole; as, a petiolar gland; a petiolar bud.

PETIOLULE
 (n.) A small petiole, or the petiole of a leaflet.

PETULCITY
 (n.) Wantonness; friskiness.

PHACOLITE
 (n.) A colorless variety of chabazite; the original was from Leipa, in Bohemia.

PHAGOCYTE
 (n.) A leucocyte which plays a part in retrogressive processes by taking up (eating), in the form of fine granules, the parts to be removed.

PHALANGER
 (n.) Any marsupial belonging to Phalangista, Cuscus, Petaurus, and other genera of the family Phalangistidae. They are arboreal, and the species of Petaurus are furnished with lateral parachutes. See Flying phalanger, under Flying.

PHANERITE
 (a.) Evident; visible.

PHARISAIC
 (a.) Alt. of Pharisaical

PHASEOLUS
 (n.) A genus of leguminous plants, including the Lima bean, the kidney bean, the scarlet runner, etc. See Bean.

PHENICINE
 (n.) A purple powder precipitated when a sulphuric solution of indigo is diluted with water.

PHENOLATE
 (n.) A compound of phenol analogous to a salt.

PHILOGYNY
 (n.) Fondness for women; uxoriousness; -- opposed to misogyny.

PHLOGOTIC
 (n.) Of or pertaining to phlogisis.

PHOLADEAN
 (n.) Pholad.

PHONETISM
 (n.) The science which treats of vocal sounds.

PHONOLOGY
 (n.) The science or doctrine of the elementary sounds uttered by the human voice in speech, including the various distinctions, modifications, and combinations of tones; phonetics. Also, a treatise on sounds.

PHOTOPSIA
 (n.) An affection of the eye, in which the patient perceives luminous rays, flashes, coruscations, etc. See phosphene.

PHTHALIDE
 (n.) A lactone obtained by reduction of phthalyl chloride, as a white crystalline substance; hence, by extension, any one of the series of which phthalide proper is the type.

PHYLACTER
 (n.) A phylactery.

 (pl. ) of Phyllodium

PHYSICIAN

 (a.) Made up of parts or pieces; single; separate.

PIEDSTALL
 (n.) See Pedestal.

PIEPOWDER
 (n.) An ancient court of record in England, formerly incident to every fair and market, of which the steward of him who owned or had the toll was the judge.

PLACODERM
 (n.) One of the Placodermi.

PLAGUEFUL
 (a.) Abounding, or infecting, with plagues; pestilential; as, plagueful exhalations.

 (n.) One who commences a personal action or suit to obtain a remedy for an injury to his rights; -- opposed to defendant.

PLANETARY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the planets; as, planetary inhabitants; planetary motions; planetary year.

PLANIFORM
 (a.) Having a plane surface; as, a planiform, gliding, or arthrodial articulation.

PLASMOGEN
 (n.) The important living portion of protoplasm, considered a chemical substance of the highest elaboration. Germ plasm and idioplasm are forms of plasmogen.

PLATINOUS
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or containing, platinum; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which the element has a lower valence, as contrasted with the platinic compounds; as, platinous chloride (PtCl2).

 (v. t.) To explain by, or accomodate to, the Platonic philosophy.

PLENARILY

 (a.) Yielding abundance; prolific; fruitful.

PLETINIAN

PREDATION
 (n.) The act of pillaging.

PREDEFINE
 (v. t.) To define beforehand.

PREDICANT
 (a.) Predicating; affirming; declaring; proclaiming; hence; preaching.

PREDICATE
 (v. t.) That which is affirmed or denied of the subject. In these propositions, Paper is white, Ink is not white, whiteness is the predicate affirmed of paper and denied of ink.

PREDILECT
 (v. t.) To elect or choose beforehand.

PREJUDICE
 (n.) Foresight.

PREJUDICE
 (n.) To obstruct or injure by prejudices, or by previous bias of the mind; hence, generally, to hurt; to damage; to injure; to impair; as, to prejudice a good cause.

PRELECTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Prelect

PRELUDIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a prelude; of the nature of a prelude; introductory.

PREMATURE
 (a.) Happening, arriving, existing, or performed before the proper or usual time; adopted too soon; too early; untimely; as, a premature fall of snow; a premature birth; a premature opinion; premature decay.

PREOCULAR
 (a.) Placed just in front of the eyes, as the antennae of certain insects.

PREOPTION
 (n.) Right of first choice.

PREPUTIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the prepuce.

PRESBYTER
 (n.) One ordained to the second order in the ministry; -- called also priest.

PRESCRIBE
 (v. i.) To write or to give medical directions; to indicate remedies; as, to prescribe for a patient in a fever.

PRESCUTUM
 (n.) The first of the four pieces composing the dorsal part, or tergum, of a thoracic segment of an insect. It is usually small and inconspicuous.

PRESIDENT
 (n.) Precedent.

PRESULTOR
 (n.) A leader in the dance.

PRETENDER
 (n.) The pretender (Eng. Hist.), the son or the grandson of James II., the heir of the royal family of Stuart, who laid claim to the throne of Great Britain, from which the house was excluded by law.

PREVENTER
 (n.) An auxiliary rope to strengthen a mast.

PRICELESS
 (a.) Too valuable to admit of being appraised; of inestimable worth; invaluable.

PRIDELESS
 (a.) Without pride.

PRIESTCAP
 (n.) A form of redan, so named from its shape; -- called also swallowtail.

PRIESTISM
 (n.) The influence, doctrines, principles, etc., of priests or the priesthood.

PRIMITIAS
 (pl. ) of Primitia

PRINCIPAL
 (n.) A leader, chief, or head; one who takes the lead; one who acts independently, or who has controlling authority or influence; as, the principal of a faction, a school, a firm, etc.; -- distinguished from a subordinate, abettor, auxiliary, or assista

PRINCIPAL
 (n.) In English organs the chief open metallic stop, an octave above the open diapason. On the manual it is four feet long, on the pedal eight feet. In Germany this term corresponds to the English open diapason.

PRINTLESS
 (a.) Making no imprint.

PRISONING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Prison

PRIVATION
 (n.) The act of depriving, or taking away; hence, the depriving of rank or office; degradation in rank; deprivation.

PRIVATIVE
 (n.) A term indicating the absence of any quality which might be naturally or rationally expected; -- called also privative term.

PROBOSCIS
 (n.) By extension, applied to various tubelike mouth organs of the lower animals that can be everted or protruded.

PROCOELIA
 (n.) Same as Procoele.

PROCTITIS
 (n.) Inflammation of the rectum.

PROCTUCHA
 (n. pl.) A division of Turbellaria including those that have an intestine terminating posteriorly.

PROCURACY
 (n.) Authority to act for another; a proxy.

PROFANING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Profane

PROFANITY
 (n.) That which is profane; profane language or acts.

PROFUSELY
 (adv.) In a profuse manner.

PROJECTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Project

PROLATION
 (n.) The act of deferring; delay.

PROMENADE
 (n.) A place for walking; a public walk.

PROMEROPS
 (n.) Any one of several species of very brilliant birds belonging to Promerops, Epimarchus, and allied genera, closely related to the paradise birds, and mostly native of New Guinea. They have a long curved beak and a long graduated tail.

PROMUSCIS
 (n.) The proboscis of hemipterous insects. See Illust. under Hemiptera.

PRONENESS
 (n.) The state of lying with the face down; -- opposed to supineness.

PRONOUNCE
 (v. t.) To declare or affirm; as, he pronounced the book to be a libel; he pronounced the act to be a fraud.

PROPAGATE
 (v. t.) To spread from person to person; to extend the knowledge of; to originate and spread; to carry from place to place; to disseminate; as, to propagate a story or report; to propagate the Christian religion.

PROPELLED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Propel

PROPHETIC
 (a.) Alt. of Prophetical

PROPIDENE
 (n.) The unsymmetrical hypothetical hydrocarbon radical, CH3.CH2.CH, analogous to ethylidene, and regarded as the type of certain derivatives of propane; -- called also propylidene.

PROPODIUM
 (n.) The segment which forms the posterior part of the thorax of a hymenopterous insect.

PROPYLENE
 (n.) A colorless gaseous hydrocarbon (C3H6) of the ethylene series, having a garlic odor. It occurs in coal gas, and is produced artificially in various ways. Called also propene.

PRORATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Prorate

PRORHINAL
 (a.) Situated in front of the nasal chambers.

PROSCOLEX
 (n.) An early larval form of a trematode worm; a redia. See Redia.

PROSCRIPT
 (n.) One who is proscribed.

PROSECUTE
 (v. t.) To seek to obtain by legal process; as, to prosecute a right or a claim in a court of law.

PROSELYTE
 (v. t.) To convert to some religion, opinion, or system; to bring over.

PROSINESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being prosy; tediousness; tiresomeness.

PROSODIAN
 (n.) A prosodist.

PROSTRATE
 (a.) Lying at length, or with the body extended on the ground or other surface; stretched out; as, to sleep prostrate.

PROSTRATE
 (v. t.) to overthrow; to demolish; to destroy; to deprive of efficiency; to ruin; as, to prostrate a village; to prostrate a government; to prostrate law or justice.

PROTHESIS
 (n.) A credence table; -- so called by the Eastern or Greek Church.

PROTOSALT
 (n.) A salt derived from a protoxide base.

PROTOTYPE
 (n.) An original or model after which anything is copied; the pattern of anything to be engraved, or otherwise copied, cast, or the like; a primary form; exemplar; archetype.

PROTOZOAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Protozoa.

PROVISION
 (n.) That which is stipulated in advance; a condition; a previous agreement; a proviso; as, the provisions of a contract; the statute has many provisions.

PROVOKING
 (a.) Having the power or quality of exciting resentment; tending to awaken passion or vexation; as, provoking words or treatment.

PRUDISHLY
 (adv.) In a prudish manner.

PTERYGIUM
 (n.) A superficial growth of vascular tissue radiating in a fanlike manner from the cornea over the surface of the eye.

PUBLICIST
 (n.) A writer on the laws of nature and nations; one who is versed in the science of public right, the principles of government, etc.

PUDDERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Pudder

PULMONATE
 (n.) One of the Pulmonata.

PULSATILE
 (a.) Capable of being struck or beaten; played by beating or by percussion; as, a tambourine is a pulsatile musical instrument.

PULSATIVE
 (a.) Beating; throbbing.

PUMICEOUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to pumice; resembling pumice.

PUNCTATOR
 (n.) One who marks with points. specifically, one who writes Hebrew with points; -- applied to a Masorite.

PUPPETISH
 (a.) Resembling a puppet in appearance or action; of the nature of a puppet.

PURCELANE
 (n.) Purslane.

PURCHASER
 (n.) One who acquires an estate in lands by his own act or agreement, or who takes or obtains an estate by any means other than by descent or inheritance.

PURGAMENT
 (n.) A cathartic; a purgative.

PURPURATE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to purpura.

PURVEANCE
 (n.) Alt. of Purveiaunce

PUTRESCIN
 (n.) A nontoxic diamine, C4H12N2, formed in the putrefaction of the flesh of mammals and some other animals.

PUTTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Putter

PYROMANIA
 (n.) An insane disposition to incendiarism.

PYROMETRY
 (n.) The art of measuring degrees of heat, or the expansion of bodies by heat.

PYROPHANE
 (n.) A mineral which is opaque in its natural state, but is said to change its color and become transparent by heat.

PYTHONESS
 (n.) The priestess who gave oracular answers at Delphi in Greece.

QUADRIFID
 (a.) Divided, or deeply cleft, into four parts; as, a quadrifid perianth; a quadrifid leaf.

QUAINTISE
 (n.) Elegance; beauty.

QUAKETAIL
 (n.) A wagtail.

QUARTERLY
 (n.) A periodical work published once a quarter, or four times in a year.

QUARTERON
 (n.) A quarter; esp., a quarter of a pound, or a quarter of a hundred.

QUARTETTE
 (n.) A composition in four parts, each performed by a single voice or instrument.

QUARTZITE
 (n.) Massive quartz occurring as a rock; a metamorphosed sandstone; -- called also quartz rock.

QUAVEMIRE
 (n.) See Quagmire.

QUEENHOOD
 (n.) The state, personality, or character of a queen; queenliness.

QUERULOUS
 (v.) Expressing complaint; fretful; whining; as, a querulous tone of voice.

QUESTUARY
 (a.) Studious of profit.

QUICKNESS
 (n.) Sharpness; pungency of taste.

QUIESCENT
 (a.) Not sounded; silent; as, y is quiescent in day and say.

QUINTETTE
 (n.) A composition for five voices or instruments; also, the set of five persons who sing or play five-part music.

QUITTANCE
 (v. t.) Recompense; return; repayment.

RABBETING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Rabbet

RABBINISM
 (n.) The teachings and traditions of the rabbins.

RABIDNESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being rabid.

RACHITOME
 (n.) A dissecting instrument for opening the spinal canal.

RADICALLY
 (adv.) In a radical manner; at, or from, the origin or root; fundamentally; as, a scheme or system radically wrong or defective.

RADIOLITE
 (n.) A hippurite.

RAININESS
 (n.) The state of being rainy.

RAMPARTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Rampart

RAMUSCULE
 (n.) A small ramus, or branch.

RANTERISM
 (n.) The practice or tenets of the Ranters.

RAPACIOUS
 (a.) Given to plunder; disposed or accustomed to seize by violence; seizing by force.

RAPTORIAL
 (a.) Adapted for seizing prey; -- said of the legs, claws, etc., of insects, birds, and other animals.

RAPTURING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Rapture

RASPBERRY
 (n.) The thimble-shaped fruit of the Rubus Idaeus and other similar brambles; as, the black, the red, and the white raspberry.

RATEPAYER
 (n.) One who pays rates or taxes.

RATTLEBOX
 (n.) An American herb (Crotalaria sagittalis), the seeds of which, when ripe, rattle in the inflated pod.

RAVISHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Ravish

RAZORBILL
 (n.) A species of auk (Alca torda) common in the Arctic seas. See Auk, and Illust. in Appendix.

REACHABLE
 (a.) Being within reach.

REALIZING
 (a.) Serving to make real, or to impress on the mind as a reality; as, a realizing view of the danger incurred.

REALMLESS
 (a.) Destitute of a realm.

REARDORSE

 (n.) Alt. of Reremouse

 (n.) A second baptism.

REBELLION

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Rebut

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Recant

RECAPTURE
 (n.) The act of retaking or recovering by capture; especially, the retaking of a prize or goods from a captor.

RECENSION
 (n.) The result of such a work; a text established by critical revision; an edited version.

RECEPTION
 (n.) The state of being received.

RECHERCHE
 (a.) Sought out with care; choice. Hence: of rare quality, elegance, or attractiveness; peculiar and refined in kind.

RECKONING
 (n.) An account of time

RECLAIMED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Reclaim

RECLINATE
 (a.) Reclined, as a leaf; bent downward, so that the point, as of a stem or leaf, is lower than the base.

RECLUSELY
 (adv.) In a recluse or solitary manner.

RECOGNIZE
 (v. t.) To acknowledge acquaintance with, as by salutation, bowing, or the like.

RECOLLECT
 (n.) A friar of the Strict Observance, -- an order of Franciscans.

 (v. t.) To make acceptable; to attract favor to.

 (v. i.) To become reconciled.

RECONJOIN
 (v. t.) To join or conjoin anew.

RECONVERT
 (v. t.) To convert again.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Recover

RECOVEREE
 (n.) The person against whom a judgment is obtained in common recovery.

RECREMENT
 (n.) A substance secreted from the blood and again absorbed by it.

RECTIFIER
 (n.) Specifically: (a) (Naut.) An instrument used for determining and rectifying the variations of the compass on board ship. (b) (Chem.) A rectificator.

RECTORESS
 (n.) A governess; a rectrix.

RECURSION
 (n.) The act of recurring; return.

REDACTEUR
 (n.) See Redactor.

REDDENDUM
 (n.) A clause in a deed by which some new thing is reserved out of what had been granted before; the clause by which rent is reserved in a lease.

REDELIVER
 (v. t.) To deliver or give back; to return.

REDEPOSIT
 (v. t.) To deposit again.

REDUCTION
 (v. t.) The process of making a copy of something, as a figure, design, or draught, on a smaller scale, preserving the proper proportions.

 (v.) (b)

REFECTIVE
 (n.) That which refreshes.

REFERENCE
 (n.) The act of submitting a matter in dispute to the judgment of one or more persons for decision.

REFLECTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Reflect

REFLEXIVE
 (a.) Having for its direct object a pronoun which refers to the agent or subject as its antecedent; -- said of certain verbs; as, the witness perjured himself; I bethought myself. Applied also to pronouns of this class; reciprocal; reflective.

REFORMADO
 (v. t.) An officer who, in disgrace, is deprived of his command, but retains his rank, and sometimes his pay.

REFRACTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Refract

REPRINTER
 (n.) One who reprints.

REPRODUCE
 (v. t.) To produce again, by generation or the like; to cause the existence of (something of the same class, kind, or nature as another thing); to generate or beget, as offspring; as, to reproduce a rose; some animals are reproduced by gemmation.

REPUDIATE

REPULSIVE
 (a.) Cold; forbidding; offensive; as, repulsive manners.

REQUISITE

RESCUSSEE
 (n.) The party in whose favor a rescue is made.

RESENTIVE
 (a.) Resentful.

RESERVOIR
 (n.) A small intercellular space, often containing resin, essential oil, or some other secreted matter.

RESIDENCE
 (n.) The place where anything rests permanently.

RESIDUARY
 (a.) Consisting of residue; as, residuary matter; pertaining to the residue, or part remaining; as, the residuary advantage of an estate.

RESOLUBLE
 (a.) Admitting of being resolved; resolvable; as, bodies resoluble by fire.

RESPONSAL
 (n.) Response.

RESTRAINT
 (n.) That which restrains, as a law, a prohibition, or the like; limitation; restriction.

RESULTATE
 (n.) A result.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Retard

RETENTION
 (n.) The right of withholding a debt, or of retaining property until a debt due to the person claiming the right be duly paid; a lien.

RETINITIS
 (n.) Inflammation of the retina.

RETRACTOR
 (n.) In breech-loading firearms, a device for withdrawing a cartridge shell from the barrel.

REVELLENT
 (n.) A revulsive medicine.

REVENGING
 (a.) Executing revenge; revengeful.

REVERSELY
 (adv.) In a reverse manner; on the other hand; on the opposite.

REVERSION
 (n.) The act of returning, or coming back; return.

REVERTENT
 (n.) A remedy which restores the natural order of the inverted irritative motions in the animal system.

REVISABLE
 (a.) That may be revised.

REVULSIVE
 (n.) That which causes revulsion; specifically (Med.), a revulsive remedy or agent.

RHACHILLA
 (n.) A branch of inflorescence; the zigzag axis on which the florets are arranged in the spikelets of grasses.

RHAPHIDES
 (n. pl.) Minute transparent, often needle-shaped, crystals found in the tissues of plants.

RHETORIZE
 (v. i.) To play the orator.

RHOPALIUM
 (n.) One of the marginal sensory bodies of medusae belonging to the Discophora.

RIBBONMAN
 (n.) A member of the Ribbon Society. See Ribbon Society, under Ribbon.

RIDERLESS
 (a.) Having no rider; as, a riderless horse.

RIGHTWISE
 (a.) Righteous.

RIGMAROLE
 (a.) Consisting of rigmarole; frovolous; nonsensical; foolish.

RITUALISM
 (n.) A system founded upon a ritual or prescribed form of religious worship; adherence to, or observance of, a ritual.

RIVERLING
 (n.) A rivulet.

ROBBERIES
 (pl. ) of Robbery

ROCAMBOLE
 (n.) A name of Allium Scorodoprasum and A. Ascalonium, two kinds of garlic, the latter of which is also called shallot.

ROMPINGLY
 (adv.) In a romping manner.

ROSMARINE
 (n.) Rosemary.

ROTUNDATE
 (a.) Rounded; especially, rounded at the end or ends, or at the corners.

 (v. t.) To plaster with a mixture of lime and shells or pebbles; as, to roughcast a building.

ROUGHHEWN
 (a.) Hewn coarsely without smoothing; unfinished; not polished.

ROUGHTAIL
 (n.) Any species of small ground snakes of the family Uropeltidae; -- so called from their rough tails.

ROUNDNESS
 (n.) Fullness; smoothness of flow; as, the roundness of a period; the roundness of a note; roundness of tone.

ROUNDWORM
 (n.) A nematoid worm.

RUBRICITY
 (n.) Redness.

RUCTATION

RUSHINESS
 (n.) The quality or state of abounding with rushes.

RUSTICATE
 (v. i.) To go into or reside in the country; to ruralize.

SABADILLA
 (n.) A Mexican liliaceous plant (Schoenocaulon officinale); also, its seeds, which contain the alkaloid veratrine. It was formerly used in medicine as an emetic and purgative.

SABOTIERE
 (n.) A kind of freezer for ices.

SACCHOLIC
 (a.) Saccholactic.

SACRARIUM
 (n.) A sort of family chapel in the houses of the Romans, devoted to a special divinity.

SALMONOID
 (n.) Any fish of the family Salmonidae.

SALTATION
 (n.) A leaping or jumping.

SALTMOUTH
 (n.) A wide-mouthed bottle with glass stopper for holding chemicals, especially crystallized salts.

SAMARITAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Samaria, in Palestine.

SAMOYEDES
 (n. pl.) An ignorant and degraded Turanian tribe which occupies a portion of Northern Russia and a part of Siberia.

SANCTUARY
 (n.) The most retired part of the temple at Jerusalem, called the Holy of Holies, in which was kept the ark of the covenant, and into which no person was permitted to enter except the high priest, and he only once a year, to intercede for the people; al

SANDGLASS
 (n.) An instrument for measuring time by the running of sand. See Hourglass.

SANDSTONE
 (n.) A rock made of sand more or less firmly united. Common or siliceous sandstone consists mainly of quartz sand.

SAPIENTLY
 (adv.) In a sapient manner.

SAPOGENIN
 (n.) A white crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of saponin.

SAPORIFIC
 (a.) Having the power to produce the sensation of taste; producing taste, flavor, or relish.

SARDINIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the island, kingdom, or people of Sardinia.

SARRASINE
 (n.) A portcullis, or herse.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Satiate

SATRAPESS
 (n.) A female satrap.

 (a.) Having its affinity satisfied; combined with all it can hold; -- said of certain atoms, radicals, or compounds; thus, methane is a saturated compound. Contrasted with unsaturated.

SATURNIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Saturn, whose age or reign, from the mildness and wisdom of his government, is called the golden age.

SATURNINE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to lead; characterized by, or resembling, lead, which was formerly called Saturn.

SCAPEGOAT

SCAPULARY

SCLEROTIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from ergot or the sclerotium of a fungus growing on rye.

SCOPELOID
 (a.) Like or pertaining to fishes of the genus Scopelus, or family Scopelodae, which includes many small oceanic fishes, most of which are phosphorescent.

ABSOLUTIST

 (a.) Conveying or containing air; air-bearing; as, the windpipe is an aeriferous tube.

AEROBIOTIC
 (a.) Related to, or of the nature of, aerobies; as, aerobiotic plants, which live only when supplied with free oxygen.

 (n.) Alt. of Esthetics

 (adv.) In an affected manner; hypocritically; with more show than reality.

 (p. pr. / vb. n.) of Affiance

 (a.) Capable of being affiliated to or on, or connected with in origin.

 (a.) Grievously painful; distressing; afflictive; as, an afflicting event. -- Af*flict"ing*ly, adv.

 (p. p.) Made friends; reconciled.

 (n.) A diffusible substance formed from albumin by the action of natural or artificial gastric juice. See Peptone.

 (n.) One who adheres to the letter of the Koran, rejecting all traditions.

 (a.) Pertaining to, or like, an alderman.

ALISANDERS
 (n.) A name given to two species of the genus Smyrnium, formerly cultivated and used as celery now is; -- called also horse parsely.

 (a.) Walking.

ANAGLYPHIC
 (a.) Alt. of Anaglyphical

 (a.) Of or pertaining to analysis; resolving into elements or constituent parts; as, an analytical experiment; analytic reasoning; -- opposed to synthetic.

 (a.) Without, or not developing, an amnion.

 (n.) A silicate of aluminium, occurring usually in thick rhombic prisms, nearly square, of a grayish or pale reddish tint. It was first discovered in Andalusia, Spain.

CARPINTERO
 (n.) A california woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus), noted for its habit of inserting acorns in holes which it drills in trees. The acorns become infested by insect larvae, which, when grown, are extracted for food by the bird.

CARPOPHORE
 (n.) A slender prolongation of the receptacle as an axis between the carpels, as in Geranium and many umbelliferous plants.

CASSINETTE

 (n.) A chalklike concretion, consisting mainly of urate of sodium, found in and about the small joints, in the external ear, and in other situations, in those affected with gout; a tophus.

 (n.) An edible species of mushroom (Agaricus campestris).

 (a.) Fortuitous; casual.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Channel

 (n.) A constellation. See Auriga, and Wagones.

 (a.) Dictated by kindness; favorable; lenient.

CHASTENESS
 (n.) Chastity; purity.

CHATTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Chatter

CHAUVINISM
 (n.) Blind and absurd devotion to a fallen leader or an obsolete cause; hence, absurdly vainglorious or exaggerated patriotism.

CHECKMATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Checkmate

CHEERINESS
 (n.) The state of being cheery.

CHEVROTAIN
 (n.) A small ruminant of the family Tragulidae a allied to the musk deer. It inhabits Africa and the East Indies. See Kanchil.

CHICKASAWS
 (n. pl.) A tribe of North American Indians (Southern Appalachian) allied to the Choctaws. They formerly occupied the northern part of Alabama and Mississippi, but now live in the Indian Territory.

CHIFFONIER
 (n.) Alt. of niere

CHIMPANZEE
 (n.) An african ape (Anthropithecus troglodytes or Troglodytes niger) which approaches more nearly to man, in most respects, than any other ape. When full grown, it is from three to four feet high.

CHINCHILLA
 (n.) A small rodent (Chinchilla lanigera), of the size of a large squirrel, remarkable for its fine fur, which is very soft and of a pearly gray color. It is a native of Peru and Chili.

CHINQUAPIN
 (n.) A branching, nut-bearing tree or shrub (Castanea pumila) of North America, from six to twenty feet high, allied to the chestnut. Also, its small, sweet, edible nat.

CHIRPINGLY
 (adv.) In a chirping manner.

CHONDRITIS
 (n.) An inflammation of cartilage.

CHOPCHURCH
 (n.) An exchanger or an exchange of benefices.

CHORIAMBIC
 (a.) Pertaining to a choriamb.

CHOROGRAPH
 (n.) An instrument for constructing triangles in marine surveying, etc.

CHROMATISM
 (n.) An abnormal coloring of plants.

CHRONOGRAM
 (n.) The record or inscription made by a chronograph.

CICISBEISM
 (n.) The state or conduct of a cicisbeo.

CINQUEFOIL
 (n.) An ornamental foliation having five points or cups, used in windows, panels, etc.

CIRCENSIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to, or held in, the Circus, In Rome.

CIRCUMDUCE
 (v. t.) To declare elapsed, as the time allowed for introducing evidence.

CIRCUMFLEX
 (a.) Moving or turning round; circuitous.

CIRRIPEDIA
 (n. pl.) An order of Crustacea including the barnacles. When adult, they have a calcareous shell composed of several pieces. From the opening of the shell the animal throws out a group of curved legs, looking like a delicate curl, whence the name of the

CISMONTANE
 (a.) On this side of the mountains. See under Ultramontane.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Cistercians.

 (n.) A female citizen.

 (a.) Descending from the same stock or ancestor, but not in the same line or branch or one from the other; -- opposed to lineal.

COLLECTIVE

COLLEGIATE

COLLIMATOR
 (n.) A tube having a convex lens at one end and at the other a small opening or slit which is at the principal focus of the lens, used for producing a beam of parallel rays; also, a lens so used.

COLLOPHORE

 (a.) Capable of combining; consistent with.

COMMISSION

COMMISSIVE
 (a.) Relating to commission; of the nature of, or involving, commission.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Commit

COMMODIOUS
 (a.) Adapted to its use or purpose, or to wants and necessities; serviceable; spacious and convenient; roomy and comfortable; as, a commodious house.

COMMONNESS

COMMONWEAL

COMPARATOR
 (n.) An instrument or machine for comparing anything to be measured with a standard measure; -- applied especially to a machine for comparing standards of length.

COMPARISON

COMPATRIOT

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Concern

CONCERNING

CONCERTINA
 (n.) A small musical instrument on the principle of the accordion. It is a small elastic box, or bellows, having free reeds on the inside, and keys and handles on the outside of each of the two hexagonal heads.

CONCESSION
 (n.) A thing yielded; an acknowledgment or admission; a boon; a grant; esp. a grant by government of a privilege or right to do something; as, a concession to build a canal.

CONCILIARY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to, or issued by, a council.

 (a.) Meeting in one point.

CONDOLENCE

 (n.) A vegetable alkaloid found with conine in the poison hemlock (Conium maculatum). It is a white crystalline substance, C8H17NO, easily convertible into conine.

CONSENSUAL

CONSEQUENT

CONSISTENT
 (a.) Having agreement with itself or with something else; having harmony among its parts; possesing unity; accordant; harmonious; congruous; compatible; uniform; not contradictory.

CONSISTORY
 (n.) The spiritual court of a diocesan bishop held before his chancellor or commissioner in his cathedral church or elsewhere.

DIFFORMITY

DIMINUTIVE

 (n.) Want of honesty, probity, or integrity in principle; want of fairness and straightforwardness; a disposition to defraud, deceive, or betray; faithlessness.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Dislodge

 (n.) The quality of being dismal; gloominess.

 (a.) Giving dismission.

 (n.) One who disobliges.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Disperse

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Distill

DISTRICTLY
 (adv.) Strictly.

DISUNIFORM
 (a.) Not uniform.

DITEREBENE
 (n.) See Colophene.

DITROCHEAN
 (a.) Containing two trochees.

DIURETICAL
 (a.) Diuretic.

DIURNATION
 (n.) The condition of sleeping or becoming dormant by day, as is the case of the bats.

DIVARICATE
 (v. i.) To diverge; to be divaricate.

DIVERGENCY
 (n.) A receding from each other in moving from a common center; the state of being divergent; as, an angle is made by the divergence of straight lines.

DIVESTMENT
 (n.) The act of divesting.

DIVINISTRE
 (n.) A diviner.

DIVISIONAL
 (a.) That divides; pertaining to, making, or noting, a division; as, a divisional line; a divisional general; a divisional surgeon of police.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Domicile

 (n.) The act of dominating; exercise of power in ruling; dominion; supremacy; authority; often, arbitrary or insolent sway.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Domineer

 (a.) Bearing gifts.

 (n.) (Anat.) See Meson.

 (adv.) In a doubtful manner.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Dovetail

 (n.) The severe persecution of French Protestants under Louis XIV., by an armed force, usually of dragoons; hence, a rapid and devastating incursion; dragoonade.

 () of Drivel

 (a.) Relating to the money of the Easterlings, or Baltic traders. See Sterling.

 (pl. ) of Ecchymosis

 (n.) One of the Echinodermata.

ECONOMICAL
 (a.) Relating to domestic economy, or to the management of household affairs.

 (a.) Of or relating to the ectoderm.

ECUMENICAL
 (a.) General; universal; in ecclesiastical usage, that which concerns the whole church; as, an ecumenical council.

EFFECTIBLE
 (a.) Capable of being done or achieved; practicable; feasible.

 (v. i.) To grow womanish or weak.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Ejaculate

EKASILICON
 (n.) The name of a hypothetical element predicted and afterwards discovered and named germanium; -- so called because it was a missing analogue of the silicon group. See Germanium, and cf. Ekabor.

EMASCULATE
 (a.) Deprived of virility or vigor; unmanned; weak.

 (pl. ) of Emergence

 (n.) The method or practice of an empiric; pursuit of knowledge by observation and experiment.

EMPOWERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Empower

ENABLEMENT
 (n.) The act of enabling, or the state of being enabled; ability.

 (n.) A detailed exposition; relation.

ENCAMPMENT
 (n.) The place where an army or a company is encamped; a camp; tents pitched or huts erected for temporary lodgings.

ENCASEMENT
 (n.) An old theory of generation similar to embo/tement. See Ovulist.

ENCRINITIC
 (a.) Alt. of Encrinitical

ENCYSTMENT
 (n.) A process by which many internal parasites, esp. in their larval states, become inclosed within a cyst in the muscles, liver, etc. See Trichina.

 (n.) The act of endearing or the state of being endeared; also, that which manifests, excites, or increases, affection.

ENDIADEMED

EPICHIREMA
 (n.) A syllogism in which the proof of the major or minor premise, or both, is introduced with the premises themselves, and the conclusion is derived in the ordinary manner.

EPICTETAIN
 (a.) Pertaining to Epictetus, the Roman Stoic philosopher, whose conception of life was to be passionless under whatever circumstances.

EPIDEMICAL
 (a.) Common to, or affecting at the same time, a large number in a community; -- applied to a disease which, spreading widely, attacks many persons at the same time; as, an epidemic disease; an epidemic catarrh, fever, etc. See Endemic.

EPIDERMOSE
 (n.) Keratin.

 () Pertaining to, or having the nature of, an epiphysis.

 (n.) An external application to the skin, which produces a puriform or serous discharge by exciting inflammation; a vesicatory.

EQUESTRIAN
 (a.) Being or riding on horseback; mounted; as, an equestrian statue.

 (n.) A combining unit, whether an atom, a radical, or a molecule; as, in acid salt two or more equivalents of acid unite with one or more equivalents of base.

EQUIVOCACY
 (n.) Equivocalness.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Eradicate

 (a.) Red in color.

ERYTHROGEN
 (n.) A crystalline substance obtained from diseased bile, which becomes blood-red when acted on by nitric acid or ammonia.

ESENTIALLY
 (adv.) In an essential manner or degree; in an indispensable degree; really; as, essentially different.

ESTEEMABLE
 (a.) Worthy of esteem; estimable.

ESTIMATION
 (v. t.) An opinion or judgment of the worth, extent, or quantity of anything, formed without using precise data; valuation; as, estimations of distance, magnitude, amount, or moral qualities.

ETERNALIST
 (n.) One who holds the existence of matter to be from eternity.

ETHYLAMINE
 (n.) A colorless, mobile, inflammable liquid, C2H5.NH2, very volatile and with an ammoniacal odor. It is a strong base, and is a derivative of ammonia. Called also ethyl carbamine, and amido ethane.

EUCHLORINE
 (n.) A yellow or greenish yellow gas, first prepared by Davy, evolved from potassium chlorate and hydrochloric acid. It is supposed to consist of chlorine tetroxide with some free chlorine.

EUCOPEPODA
 (n. pl.) A group which includes the typical copepods and the lerneans.

EUDEMONISM
 (n.) Alt. of Eudaemonism

EUPHONICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, or exhibiting, euphony; agreeable in sound; pleasing to the ear; euphonious; as, a euphonic expression; euphonical orthography.

 (a.) Having equanimity.

 (a.) Living always; immoral; eternal; as, the everliving God.

 (a.) External; public; suitable to be imparted to the public; hence, capable of being readily or fully comprehended; -- opposed to esoteric, or secret.

 (a.) Representing by a figure, or by resemblance; typical; representative.

FIGUREHEAD

 (a.) Gluttonous; greedy.

 (pl. ) of Groggery

 (n.) Same as Hectare, Hectogram, Hectoliter, and Hectometer.

HELICONIAN
 (a.) Like or pertaining to the butterflies of the genus Heliconius.

HELIOGRAPH
 (n.) A picture taken by heliography; a photograph.

HELIOLATRY
 (n.) Sun worship. See Sabianism.

HELIOSCOPE
 (n.) A telescope or instrument for viewing the sun without injury to the eyes, as through colored glasses, or with mirrors which reflect but a small portion of light.

HELLDOOMED
 (a.) Doomed to hell.

HEMATOIDIN
 (n.) A crystalline or amorphous pigment, free from iron, formed from hematin in old blood stains, and in old hemorrhages in the body. It resembles bilirubin. When present in the corpora lutea it is called haemolutein.

HEMELYTRUM
 (n.) One of the partially thickened anterior wings of certain insects, as of many Hemiptera, the earwigs, etc.

HEMIHEDRAL
 (a.) Having half of the similar parts of a crystals, instead of all; consisting of half the planes which full symmetry would require, as when a cube has planes only on half of its eight solid angles, or one plane out of a pair on each of its edges; or a

HEMITROPAL
 (a.) Alt. of Hemitropous

HENPECKING
 (p. pr. & vb.) of Henpeck

HEPATOCELE
 (n.) Hernia of the liver.

HEPTASTICH
 (n.) A composition consisting of seven lines or verses.

HERBOROUGH
 (n.) A harbor.

HERMETICAL
 (a.) Made perfectly close or air-tight by fusion, so that no gas or spirit can enter or escape; as, an hermetic seal. See Note under Hermetically.

HESITANTLY
 (adv.) With hesitancy or doubt.

HESITATION
 (n.) The act of hesitating; suspension of opinion or action; doubt; vacillation.

HESPERIDES
 (n. pl.) The garden producing the golden apples.

HETEROGAMY
 (n.) That form of alternate generation in which two kinds of sexual generation, or a sexual and a parthenogenetic generation, alternate; -- in distinction from metagenesis, where sexual and asexual generations alternate.

HEULANDITE
 (n.) A mineral of the Zeolite family, often occurring in amygdaloid, in foliated masses, and also in monoclinic crystals with pearly luster on the cleavage face. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime.

HEXAGYNIAN
 (a.) Alt. of Hexagynous

HEXDECYLIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, hexdecyl or hecdecane; as, hexdecylic alcohol.

HIEROGLYPH
 (a.) Alt. of Hieroglyphic

HIEROLATRY
 (n.) The worship of saints or sacred things.

HIEROTHECA
 (n.) A receptacle for sacred objects.

HIGHLANDRY
 (n.) Highlanders, collectively.

HIGHWAYMAN
 (n.) One who robs on the public road; a highway robber.

HINDUSTANI
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Hindoos or their language.

HIPPOGRIFF
 (n.) A fabulous winged animal, half horse and half griffin.

HIPPOPHAGY
 (n.) The act or practice of feeding on horseflesh.

HOBBLINGLY
 (adv.) With a limping step.

HODGEPODGE
 (n.) A mixed mass; a medley. See Hotchpot.

HOIDENHOOD
 (n.) State of being a hoiden.

HOLOPHYTIC
 (a.) Wholly or distinctively vegetable.

HOMODYNAMY
 (n.) The homology of metameres. See Metamere.

HOMOGONOUS
 (a.) Having all the flowers of a plant alike in respect to the stamens and pistils.

HOMOLOGOUS
 (a.) Corresponding in relative position and proportion.

HOMOPLASTY
 (n.) The formation of homologous tissues.

HOMOSTYLED
 (a.) Having only one form of pistils; -- said of the flowers of some plants.

HOROGRAPHY
 (n.) The art of constructing instruments for making the hours, as clocks, watches, and dials.

HORSEFLIES
 (pl. ) of Horsefly

HORSEWOMAN
 (n.) A woman who rides on horseback.

HUMANISTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to humanity; as, humanistic devotion.

HYALOGRAPH
 (n.) An instrument for tracing designs on glass.

 () Alt. of Hybernation

HYDRAGOGUE
 (a.) Causing a discharge of water; expelling serum effused into any part of the body, as in dropsy.

HYDROLYTIC
 (a.) Tending to remove or separate water; eliminating water.

HYDROMETER
 (n.) An instrument for determining the specific gravities of liquids, and thence the strength spirituous liquors, saline solutions, etc.

HYDROMETRY
 (n.) The art of determining the specific gravity of liquids, and thence the strength of spirituous liquors, saline solutions, etc.

HYDROPIPER
 (n.) A species (Polygonum Hydropiper) of knotweed with acrid foliage; water pepper; smartweed.

HYDRORHIZA
 (n.) The rootstock or decumbent stem by which a hydroid is attached to other objects. See Illust. under Hydroidea.

HYGROSCOPE
 (n.) An instrument which shows whether there is more or less moisture in the atmosphere, without indicating its amount.

HYLOTHEIST
 (n.) One who believes in hylotheism.

HYPERAEMIA
 (n.) A superabundance or congestion of blood in an organ or part of the body.

HYPOCLEIDA
 (pl. ) of Hypocleidium

HYPODERMIS

 (a.) Not divided, or not to be divided; existing as one entity, or distinct being or object; single; one; as, an individual man, animal, or city.

INDOBRITON
 (n.) A person born in India, of mixed Indian and British blood; a half-caste.

INDOPHENOL
 (n.) Any one of a series of artificial blue dyestuffs, resembling indigo in appearance, and obtained by the action of phenol on certain nitrogenous derivatives of quinone. Simple indophenol proper has not yet been isolated.

INDUCEMENT
 (n.) The act of inducing, or the state of being induced.

 (v. t.) To indulge.

 (n.) State of being indurated, or of having become hard.

 (n.) Want of power to produce the desired or proper effect; inefficiency; ineffectualness; futility; uselessness; fruitlessness; as, the inefficacy of medicines or means.

INELUDIBLE
 (a.) Incapable of being eluded or evaded; unvoidable.

INEQUALITY
 (n.) Variableness; changeableness; inconstancy; lack of smoothness or equability; deviation; unsteadiness, as of the weather, feelings, etc.

INERRINGLY
 (adv.) Without error, mistake, or deviation; unerringly.

INEVASIBLE
 (a.) Incapable of being evaded; inevitable; unavoidable.

INEVITABLY
 (adv.) Without possibility of escape or evasion; unavoidably; certainly.

INEXISTANT
 (a.) Inexistent; not existing.

INEXORABLE
 (a.) Not to be persuaded or moved by entreaty or prayer; firm; determined; unyielding; unchangeable; inflexible; relentless; as, an inexorable prince or tyrant; an inexorable judge.

INEXPECTED
 (a.) Unexpected.

INEXPIABLE
 (a.) Incapable of being mollified or appeased; relentless; implacable.

 (a.) Not fallible; not capable of erring; entirely exempt from liability to mistake; unerring; inerrable.

 (a.) Capable of being easily diffused or spread; sympathetic; readily communicated; as, infectious mirth.

LEMNISCATE
 (n.) A curve in the form of the figure 8 with both parts symmetrical, generated by the point in which a tangent to an equilateral hyperbola meets the perpendicular on it drawn from the center.

LEMUROIDEA

LENTICELLE
 (n.) Lenticel.

LEPIDOLITE
 (n.) A species of mica, of a lilac or rose-violet color, containing lithia. It usually occurs in masses consisting of small scales. See Mica.

LERNAEACEA
 (n. pl.) A suborder of copepod Crustacea, including a large number of remarkable forms, mostly parasitic on fishes. The young, however, are active and swim freely. See Illustration in Appendix.

LETTERLESS
 (a.) Illiterate.

LEUCOPATHY
 (n.) The state of an albino, or of a white child of black parents.

LEVOGYRATE
 (a.) Turning or twisting the plane of polarization towards the left, as levulose, levotartaric acid, etc.

 (n.) A writer of a lexicon.

LIABLENESS
 (n.) Quality of being liable; liability.

LIBIDINOUS
 (a.) Having lustful desires; characterized by lewdness; sensual; lascivious.

LICENSABLE
 (a.) That can be licensed.

LICENTIATE
 (n.) One who acts without restraint, or takes a liberty, as if having a license therefor.

 (n.) A person employed on, or who manages, a lighter.

LIMITATION
 (v. t.) A limited time within or during which something is to be done.

LIMULOIDEA
 (n. pl.) An order of Merostomata, including among living animals the genus Limulus, with various allied fossil genera, mostly of the Carboniferous period. Called also Xiphosura.

LINGUIFORM
 (a.) Having the form of the tongue; tongue-shaped.

LITERATURE
 (n.) The collective body of literary productions, embracing the entire results of knowledge and fancy preserved in writing; also, the whole body of literary productions or writings upon a given subject, or in reference to a particular science or branch

LITHOGRAPH
 (v. t.) To trace on stone by the process of lithography so as to transfer the design to paper by printing; as, to lithograph a design; to lithograph a painting. See Lithography.

LITHOTYPIC
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or produced by, lithotypy.

LIVELINESS
 (n.) Briskness; activity; effervescence, as of liquors.

LIVINGNESS
 (n.) The state or quality of being alive; possession of energy or vigor; animation; quickening.

LOCOMOTION
 (n.) The power of moving from place to place, characteristic of the higher animals and some of the lower forms of plant life.

LOCULAMENT
 (n.) The cell of a pericarp in which the seed is lodged.

LOGOGRAPHY
 (n.) A mode of reporting speeches without using shorthand, -- a number of reporters, each in succession, taking down three or four words.

LONELINESS
 (n.) A feeling of depression resulting from being alone.

LONGIMETRY
 (n.) The art or practice of measuring distances or lengths.

LUBRICATOR
 (n.) A contrivance, as an oil cup, for supplying a lubricant to machinery.

LUCIFERIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Lucifer; having the pride of Lucifer; satanic; devilish.

LUMINARIES
 (pl. ) of Luminary

LUMINOSITY
 (n.) The quality or state of being luminous; luminousness.

LUSTERLESS
 (a.) Alt. of Lustreless

LUXURIANCY
 (n.) The state or quality of being luxuriant; luxuriance.

MACADAMIZE
 (v. t.) To cover, as a road, or street, with small, broken stones, so as to form a smooth, hard, convex surface.

MACEDONIAN
 (a.) Belonging, or relating, to Macedonia.

MACKINTOSH
 (n.) A waterproof outer garment; -- so called from the name of the inventor.

MACROFARAD
 (n.) See Megafarad.

MACROSPORE
 (n.) One of the specially large spores of certain flowerless plants, as Selaginella, etc.

MACULATORY
 (a.) Causing a spot or stain.

MADDERWORT
 (n.) A name proposed for any plant of the same natural order (Rubiaceae) as the madder.

MADECASSEE
 (n.) A native or inhabitant of Madagascar, or Madecassee; the language of the natives of Madagascar. See Malagasy.

MAGNETICAL
 (a.) Having, susceptible to, or induced by, animal magnetism, so called; as, a magnetic sleep. See Magnetism.

MAGNETIZEE
 (n.) A person subjected to the influence of animal magnetism.

MAIDENHEAD
 (n.) The state of being a maiden; maidenhood; virginity.

MAINTAINER
 (n.) One who maintains.

MAJUSCULAE
 (n. pl.) Capital letters, as found in manuscripts of the sixth century and earlier.

MALCONTENT
 (a.) discontented; uneasy; dissatisfied; especially, dissatisfied with the government.

MALIGNANCY
 (n.) The state or quality of being malignant; extreme malevolence; bitter enmity; malice; as, malignancy of heart.

MALINGERER
 (n.) In the army, a soldier who feigns himself sick, or who induces or protracts an illness, in order to avoid doing his duty; hence, in general, one who shirks his duty by pretending illness or inability.

MALLEATION
 (n.) The act or process of beating into a plate, sheet, or leaf, as a metal; extension by beating.

MALLOPHAGA
 (n. pl.) An extensive group of insects which are parasitic on birds and mammals, and feed on the feathers and hair; -- called also bird lice. See Bird louse, under Bird.

MALTREATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Maltreat

MAMMILLATE
 (a.) Alt. of Mammillated

MANDUCATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Manducate

MANEUVERER
 (n.) Alt. of Manoeuvrer

MANGOSTEEN
 (n.) Alt. of Mangostan

MANICHAEAN
 (a.) Alt. of Manichean

MANIFOLDLY
 (adv.) In a manifold manner.

MANQUELLER
 (n.) A killer of men; a manslayer.

MANUMITTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Manumit

MANUREMENT
 (n.) Cultivation.

MANUSCRIPT
 (a.) A literary or musical composition written with the hand, as distinguished from a printed copy.

MARBLEIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Marbleize

MARCANTANT
 (n.) A merchant.

MARCESCENT
 (a.) Withering without/ falling off; fading; decaying.

MARGINGING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Margin

MARIONETTE
 (n.) A puppet moved by strings, as in a puppet show.

MARMOROSIS
 (n.) The metamorphism of limestone, that is, its conversion into marble.

MARSHINESS
 (n.) The state or condition of being marshy.

MARTIALISM
 (n.) The quality of being warlike; exercises suitable for war.

MASKINONGE
 (n.) The muskellunge.

MASQUERADE
 (n.) An assembly of persons wearing masks, and amusing themselves with dancing, conversation, or other diversions.

MASQUERADE
 (v. i.) To frolic or disport in disquise; to make a pretentious show of being what one is not.

MASTERSHIP
 (n.) An ironical title of respect.

MASTICATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Masticate

MATERIATED
 (a.) Consisting of matter.

MATURATION
 (n.) The process of bringing, or of coming, to maturity; hence, specifically, the process of suppurating perfectly; the formation of pus or matter.

MEASURABLE
 (a.) Moderate; temperate; not excessive.

MEDIATIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Mediatize

MEDIATRESS
 (n.) Alt. of Mediatrix

MEDICORNUA
 (pl. ) of Medicornu

MEDIOCRITY
 (n.) Moderation; temperance.

MEDUSIFORM
 (a.) Resembling a medusa in shape or structure.

MEERSCHAUM
 (n.) A fine white claylike mineral, soft, and light enough when in dry masses to float in water. It is a hydrous silicate of magnesia, and is obtained chiefly in Asia Minor. It is manufacturd into tobacco pipes, cigar holders, etc. Also called sepiolite

MEGAPHYTON
 (n.) An extinct genus of tree ferns with large, two-ranked leaves, or fronds.

MELANCHOLY
 (n.) Ill nature.

MELANISTIC
 (a.) Affected with melanism; of the nature of melanism.

MELIPHAGAN
 (n.) Any bird of the genus Meliphaga and allied genera; a honey eater; -- called also meliphagidan.

MELOCOTOON
 (n.) A quince.

MELOPLASTY
 (n.) The process of restoring a cheek which has been destroyed wholly or in part.

MEMBRANOUS
 (a.) Membranaceous.

MEMORIZING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Memorize

MENACINGLY
 (adv.) In a threatening manner.

MENINGITIS
 (n.) Inflammation of the membranes of the brain or spinal cord.

MENOBRANCH
 (n.) Alt. of Menobranchus

MENTIONING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Mention

MEPHITICAL
 (a.) Offensive to the smell; as, mephitic odors.

MERCENARIA
 (n.) The quahog.

MERENCHYMA
 (n.) Tissue composed of spheroidal cells.

MERIDIONAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the meridian.

MESENTERON
 (n.) All that part of the alimentary canal which is developed from the primitive enteron and is lined with hypoblast. It is distinguished from the stomod/ um, a part at the anterior end of the canal, including the cavity of the mouth, and the proctod/um

MESMERIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Mesmerize

MESODERMAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, the mesoderm; as, mesodermal tissues.

MESOSAURIA
 (n.) Same as Mosasauria.

METABOLIAN
 (n.) An insect which undergoes a metamorphosis.

METALEPSES
 (pl. ) of Metalepsis

METAPHRASE
 (n.) A verbal translation; a version or translation from one language into another, word for word; -- opposed to paraphrase.

METAPHYSIC
 (n.) See Metaphysics.

METASTASIS
 (n.) A spiritual change, as during baptism.

METATHESES
 (pl. ) of Metathesis

METATHORAX
 (n.) The last or posterior segment of the thorax in insects. See Illust. of Coleoptera.

METEORICAL
 (a.) Meteoric.

METICULOUS
 (a.) Timid; fearful.

MEXICANIZE
 (v. i.) To become like the Mexicans, or their country or government.

MIASMATIST
 (n.) One who has made a special study of miasma.

MICROCOCCI
 (pl. ) of Micrococcus

MICROPHONE
 (n.) An instrument for intensifying and making audible very feeble sounds. It produces its effects by the changes of intensity in an electric current, occasioned by the variations in the contact resistance of conducting bodies, especially of imperfect c

MICROSCOPE
 (n.) An optical instrument, consisting of a lens, or combination of lenses, for making an enlarged image of an object which is too minute to be viewed by the naked eye.

MICROWEBER
 (n.) The millionth part of one weber.

MIDDLEMOST
 (a.) Being in the middle, or nearest the middle; midmost.

MIDFEATHER
 (n.) A vertical water space in a fire box or combustion chamber.

MIGNONETTE
 (n.) A plant (Reseda odorata) having greenish flowers with orange-colored stamens, and exhaling a delicious fragrance. In Africa it is a low shrub, but further north it is usually an annual herb.

MILITIAMEN
 (pl. ) of Militiaman

MILLENNIUM
 (n.) A thousand years; especially, the thousand years mentioned in the twentieth chapter in the twentieth chapter of Revelation, during which holiness is to be triumphant throughout the world. Some believe that, during this period, Christ will reign on

MIMEOGRAPH
 (n.) An autographic stencil copying device invented by Edison.

MINATORILY
 (adv.) In a minatory manner; with threats.

MINERALIST
 (n.) One versed in minerals; mineralogist.

MINERALIZE
 (v. t.) To impregnate with a mineral; as, mineralized water.

MINIMIZIMG
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Minimize

MINIONSHIP
 (n.) State of being a minion.

MIRACULOUS
 (a.) Of the nature of a miracle; performed by supernatural power; effected by the direct agency of almighty power, and not by natural causes.

MISARCRIBE
 (v. t.) To ascribe wrongly.

MISBELIEVE
 (v. i.) To believe erroneously, or in a F religion.

MISCOMFORT
 (n.) Discomfort.

MISEDITION
 (n.) An incorrect or spurious edition.

MISFEATURE
 (n.) Ill feature.

MISOBSERVE
 (v. t.) To observe inaccurately; to mistake in observing.

MISSIONARY
 (n) One who is sent on a mission; especially, one sent to propagate religion.

MISSPELLED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Misspell

MISUSEMENT
 (n.) Misuse.

MISWORSHIP
 (v. t.) To worship wrongly.

MITIGATION
 (n.) The act of mitigating, or the state of being mitigated; abatement or diminution of anything painful, harsh, severe, afflictive, or calamitous; as, the mitigation of pain, grief, rigor, severity, punishment, or penalty.

MODERATISM
 (n.) Moderation in doctrines or opinion, especially in politics or religion.

MODERNNESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being modern; recentness; novelty.

MOLLIFYING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Mollify

MONARCHIAL
 (a.) Monarchic.

MONOCOTYLE
 (a.) Monocotyledonous.

MONOECIOUS
 (a.) Having the sexes united in one individual, as when male and female flowers grow upon the same individual plant; hermaphrodite; -- opposed to dioecious.

MONOGAMIST
 (n.) One who practices or upholds monogamy.

MONOGENISM
 (n.) The theory or doctrine that the human races have a common origin, or constitute a single species.

MONOGRAPHY
 (n.) A monograph.

MONOLOGIST
 (n.) One who soliloquizes; esp., one who monopolizes conversation in company.

MONOMEROUS
 (a.) Having but one joint; -- said of the foot of certain insects.

MONOPTERAL
 (a.) Round and without a cella; consisting of a single ring of columns supporting a roof; -- said esp. of a temple.

MONOVALENT
 (a.) Having a valence of one; univalent. See Univalent.

MOONFLOWER
 (n.) The oxeye daisy; -- called also moon daisy.

MOONSTRUCK
 (a.) Made sick by the supposed influence of the moon, as a human being; made unsuitable for food, as fishes, by such supposed influence.

MORBILLOUS
 (a.) Pertaining to the measles; partaking of the nature of measels, or resembling the eruptions of that disease; measly.

MOROXYLATE
 (n.) A morate.

MORPHOLOGY
 (n.) That branch of biology which deals with the structure of animals and plants, treating of the forms of organs and describing their varieties, homologies, and metamorphoses. See Tectology, and Promorphology.

MORTGAGEOR
 (n.) Alt. of Mortgagor

MOTHERHOOD
 (n.) The state of being a mother; the character or office of a mother.

MOUNTAINER
 (n.) A mountaineer.

MUCKMIDDEN
 (n.) A dunghill.

MUDDLEHEAD
 (n.) A stupid person.

MULLIGRUBS
 (n.) A griping of the intestines; colic.

MULTIAXIAL
 (a.) Having more than one axis; developing in more than a single line or plain; -- opposed to monoaxial.

MULTICOLOR
 (a.) Having many, or several, colors.

MULTIPLIER
 (n.) One who, or that which, multiplies or increases number.

MULTIVALVE
 (a.) Alt. of Multivalvular

MULTOCULAR
 (a.) Having many eyes, or more than two.

MUNIFICENT
 (a.) Very liberal in giving or bestowing; lavish; as, a munificent benefactor.

MUSCARDINE
 (n.) A disease which is very destructive to silkworms, and which sometimes extends to other insects. It is attended by the development of a fungus (provisionally called Botrytis bassiana). Also, the fungus itself.

MYOGRAPHIC
 (a.) Alt. of Myographical

MYSTAGOGUE
 (n.) One who keeps and shows church relics.

MYTHOLOGIC
 (a.) Alt. of Mythological

NARCOTINIC
 (a.) Pertaining to narcotine.

NASALIZING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Nasalize

NASTURTIUM
 (n.) A genus of cruciferous plants, having white or yellowish flowers, including several species of cress. They are found chiefly in wet or damp grounds, and have a pungent biting taste.

NATATORIAL
 (a.) Inclined or adapted to swim; swimming; as, natatorial birds.

NATIVISTIC
 (a.) Relating to nativism.

NAUSEATION
 (n.) The act of nauseating, or the state of being nauseated.

NAZARITISM
 (n.) The vow and practice of a Nazarite.

NECROLATRY
 (n.) The worship of the dead; manes worship.

NEEDLEBOOK
 (n.) A book-shaped needlecase, having leaves of cloth into which the needles are stuck.

NEEDLEWORK
 (n.) The combination of timber and plaster making the outside framework of some houses.

NEGATIVELY
 (adv.) In a negative manner; with or by denial.

NEGLECTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Neglect

NEGLIGENCE
 (n.) The quality or state of being negligent; lack of due diligence or care; omission of duty; habitual neglect; heedlessness.

NEGOTIATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Negotiate

NEGOTIATOR
 (n.) One who negotiates; a person who treats with others, either as principal or agent, in respect to purchase and sale, or public compacts.

NEMATOCYST
 (n.) A lasso cell, or thread cell. See Lasso cell, under Lasso.

NEMATOIDEA
 (n. pl.) An order of worms, having a long, round, and generally smooth body; the roundworms. they are mostly parasites. Called also Nematodea, and Nematoda.

NEOPLASTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to neoplasty, or neoplasia.

NETHERMOST
 (a.) Lowest; as, the nethermost abyss.

NEUROCHORD
 (a.) Alt. of Neurochordal

NEWFANGLED
 (a.) Newmade; formed with the affectation of novelty.

NICOLAITAN
 (n.) One of certain corrupt persons in the early church at Ephesus, who are censured in rev. ii. 6 15.

NIDIFICATE
 (v. i.) To make a nest.

NIGGARDISH
 (a.) Somewhat niggard.

NINETEENTH
 (n.) An interval of two octaves and a fifth.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Nitrify

NOMINATIVE
 (n.) The nominative case.

NONABILITY
 (n.) Want of ability.

NOSOGRAPHY
 (n.) A description or classification of diseases.

NOTABILITY
 (n.) Quality of being notable.

NOTOPODIUM
 (n.) The dorsal lobe or branch of a parapodium. See Parapodium.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Novelize

NUBIGENOUS
 (a.) Born of, or produced from, clouds.

NUDIBRANCH
 (n.) One of the Nudibranchiata.

NUMBEDNESS
 (n.) Numbness.

NUMERATION
 (n.) The act or art of reading numbers when expressed by means of numerals. The term is almost exclusively applied to the art of reading numbers written in the scale of tens, by the Arabic method.

NURSERYMEN
 (pl. ) of Nurseryman

 (pl. ) of Obituary

OBJECTABLE
 (a.) Such as can be presented in opposition; that may be put forward as an objection.

OBLIGATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Obligate

OBLIGATION
 (n.) A bond with a condition annexed, and a penalty for nonfulfillment. In a larger sense, it is an acknowledgment of a duty to pay a certain sum or do a certain things.

OBLITERATE
 (a.) Scarcely distinct; -- applied to the markings of insects.

OBLONGNESS
 (n.) State or quality of being oblong.

OBSERVANCY
 (n.) Observance.

OBSTRUCTER
 (n.) One who obstructs or hinders.

OCCULTNESS
 (n.) State or quality of being occult.

OCTAVALENT
 (a.) Having a valence of eight; capable of being combined with, exchanged for, or compared with, eight atoms of hydrogen; -- said of certain atoms or radicals.

OCTOCERATA
 (n.pl.) A suborder of Cephalopoda including Octopus, Argonauta, and allied genera, having eight arms around the head; -- called also Octopoda.

ODONTALGIA
 (n.) Toothache.

ODONTOCETE
 (n.pl.) A subdivision of Cetacea, including the sperm whale, dolphins, etc.; the toothed whales.

ODONTOLCAE
 (n. pl.) An extinct order of ostrichlike aquatic birds having teeth, which are set in a groove in the jaw. It includes Hesperornis, and allied genera. See Hesperornis.

OFFICIALLY
 (adv.) By the proper officer; by virtue of the proper authority; in pursuance of the special powers vested in an officer or office; as, accounts or reports officially vertified or rendered; letters officially communicated; persons officially notified.

OFFSETTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Offset

OLIGOCHETE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Oligochaeta.

OLIVACEOUS

OMNIFEROUS
 (a.) All-bearing; producing all kinds.

OMNISCIOUS
 (a.) All-knowing.

ORNAMENTAL

ORTHOCLASE
 (n.) Common or potash feldspar crystallizing in the monoclinic system and having two cleavages at right angles to each other. See Feldspar.

ORTHODOXAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, or evincing, orthodoxy; orthodox.

ORTHOPTERA

 (n.) An old name for paleontology.

PACHACAMAC
 (n.) A divinity worshiped by the ancient Peruvians as the creator of the universe.

PALEACEOUS
 (a.) Chaffy; resembling or consisting of paleae, or chaff; furnished with chaff; as, a paleaceous receptacle.

PALIMPSEST
 (n.) A parchment which has been written upon twice, the first writing having been erased to make place for the second.

PALINODIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a palinode, or retraction.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Palpitate

PANGENESIS
 (n.) An hypothesis advanced by Darwin in explanation of heredity.

PAPAVEROUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the poppy; of the nature of the poppy.

PARABOLISM
 (n.) The division of the terms of an equation by a known quantity that is involved in the first term.

PARADISIAL
 (a.) Alt. of Paradisian

PARAGUAYAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Paraguay.

PARALOGISM
 (n.) A reasoning which is F in point of form, that is, which is contrary to logical rules or formulae; a formal fallacy, or pseudo-syllogism, in which the conclusion does not follow from the premises.

PARALYZING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Paralyze

PARAMALEIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from malic acid, and now called fumaric acid.

PARAPHRASE
 (v. t.) To express, interpret, or translate with latitude; to give the meaning of a passage in other language.

PARAPHYSES
 (pl. ) of Paraphysis

PARAPODIUM
 (n.) One of the lateral appendages of an annelid; -- called also foot tubercle.

PARASELENE
 (n.) A mock moon; an image of the moon which sometimes appears at the point of intersection of two lunar halos. Cf. Parhelion.

PARASITISM
 (n.) The state or behavior of a parasite; the act of a parasite.

PARASTICHY
 (n.) A secondary spiral in phyllotaxy, as one of the evident spirals in a pine cone.

PARATHESIS
 (n.) A parenthetical notice, usually of matter to be afterward expanded.

PARAXYLENE
 (n.) A hydrocarbon of the aromatic series obtained as a colorless liquid by the distillation of camphor with zinc chloride. It is one of the three metamers of xylene. Cf. Metamer, and Xylene.

PARCELLING
 () of Parcel

PARETHMOID
 (a.) Near or beside the ethmoid bone or cartilage; -- applied especially to a pair of bones in the nasal region of some fishes, and to the ethmoturbinals in some higher animals.

PARLIAMENT
 (n.) The assembly of the three estates of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, viz., the lords spiritual, lords temporal, and the representatives of the commons, sitting in the House of Lords and the House of Commons, constituting the legisl

PARTIALITY
 (n.) A predilection or inclination to one thing rather than to others; special taste or liking; as, a partiality for poetry or painting.

PARTICIPLE
 (a.) Anything that partakes of the nature of different things.

PARTICULAR
 (a.) Relating to a part or portion of anything; concerning a part separated from the whole or from others of the class; separate; sole; single; individual; specific; as, the particular stars of a constellation.

PARTICULAR
 (n.) A separate or distinct member of a class, or part of a whole; an individual fact, point, circumstance, detail, or item, which may be considered separately; as, the particulars of a story.

PARTURIENT
 (a.) Bringing forth, or about to bring forth, young; fruitful.

PATAGONIAN
 (n.) A native of Patagonia.

 (pl. ) of Patellula

 (a.) Alt. of Pathological

 (imp. & p. p.) of Patronize

 (a.) Destitute of a patron.
