 (n.) Brevity in speech.

PECTINATED
 (a.) Having very narrow, close divisions, in arrangement and regularity resembling those of a comb; comblike; as, a pectinate leaf; pectinated muscles. See Illust. (e) of Antennae.

PECTORALLY
 (adv.) As connected with the breast.

PEDIGEROUS
 (a.) Bearing or having feet or legs.

PEDOMETRIC
 (a.) Alt. of Pedometrical

PELECYPODA
 (n. pl.) Same as Lamellibranchia.

PENDENTIVE
 (n.) The portion of a vault by means of which the square space in the middle of a building is brought to an octagon or circle to receive a cupola.

PENETRANCY
 (n.) The quality or state of being penetrant; power of entering or piercing; penetrating power of quality; as, the penetrancy of subtile effluvia.

PENNATULAE
 (pl. ) of Pennatula

PENSIONARY
 (a.) Maintained by a pension; receiving a pension; as, pensionary spies.

PENTACHORD
 (n.) An order or system of five sounds.

PENTAMERAN
 (n.) One of the Pentamera.

PENTANDRIA
 (n. pl.) A Linnaean class of plants having five separate stamens.

PENTASTICH
 (n.) A composition consisting of five verses.

PENTELICAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Mount Pentelicus, near Athens, famous for its fine white marble quarries; obtained from Mount Pentelicus; as, the Pentelic marble of which the Parthenon is built.

PERCEPTIVE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the act or power of perceiving; having the faculty or power of perceiving; used in perception.

PEREMPTORY
 (a.) Precluding debate or expostulation; not admitting of question or appeal; positive; absolute; decisive; conclusive; final.

PERFORATOR
 (n.) One who, or that which, perforates; esp., a cephalotome.

PERICARDIC
 (a.) Pericardiac.

PERICHAETH
 (n.) The leafy involucre surrounding the fruit stalk of mosses; perichaetium; perichete.

PERIMYSIUM
 (n.) The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a muscle, and sends partitions inwards between the bundles of muscular fibers.

PERIODICAL
 (n.) A magazine or other publication which appears at stated or regular intervals.

PERIOSTEUM
 (n.) The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely invests all bones except at the articular surfaces.

PERISHABLY
 (adv.) In a perishable degree or manner.

PERJURIOUS
 (a.) Alt. of Perjurous

PERLACEOUS
 (a.) Pearly; resembling pearl.

PERMANENCE
 (n.) Alt. of Permanency

PEROXIDIZE
 (v. t.) To oxidize to the utmost degree, so as to form a peroxide.

PERPETUATE
 (v. t.) To make perpetual; to cause to endure, or to be continued, indefinitely; to preserve from extinction or oblivion; to eternize.

PERSECUTED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Persecute

PERSECUTOR
 (n.) One who persecutes, or harasses.

PERSONALTY
 (n.) The state of being a person; personality.

PERSUASION
 (n.) The power or quality of persuading; persuasiveness.

PERTURBATE
 (a.) Perturbed; agitated.

PERVERSITY
 (n.) The quality or state of being perverse; perverseness.

PETRIFYING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Petrify

PETTYCHAPS
 (n.) Any one of several species of small European singing birds of the subfamily Sylviinae, as the willow warbler, the chiff-chaff, and the golden warbler (Sylvia hortensis).

PEUCEDANIN
 (n.) A tasteless white crystalline substance, extracted from the roots of the sulphurwort (Peucedanum), masterwort (Imperatoria), and other related plants; -- called also imperatorin.

PHALANGIST
 (n.) Any arboreal marsupial of the genus Phalangista. The vulpine phalangist (P. vulpina) is the largest species, the full grown male being about two and a half feet long. It has a large bushy tail.

PHALLICISM
 (n.) See Phallism.

PHARYNGEAL
 (n.) A pharyngeal bone or cartilage; especially, one of the lower pharyngeals, which belong to the rudimentary fifth branchial arch in many fishes, or one of the upper pharyngeals, or pharyngobranchials, which are the dorsal elements in the complete bra

PHENOMENON
 (n.) That which strikes one as strange, unusual, or unaccountable; an extraordinary or very remarkable person, thing, or occurrence; as, a musical phenomenon.

PHILIPPIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Philippi, a city of ancient Macedonia.

PHILIPPIZE
 (v. i.) To support or advocate the cause of Philip of Macedon.

PHILISTINE
 (a.) Uncultured; commonplace.

PHILOSOPHY
 (n.) Practical wisdom; calmness of temper and judgment; equanimity; fortitude; stoicism; as, to meet misfortune with philosophy.

PHLEGMATIC
 (a.) Not easily excited to action or passion; cold; dull; sluggish; heavy; as, a phlegmatic person.

PHOENICIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Phoenica.

PHONOTYPIC
 (a.) Alt. of Phonotypical

PHOSPHATIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or containing, phosphorus, phosphoric acid, or phosphates; as, phosphatic nodules.

PHOSPHONIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, certain derivatives of phosphorous acid containing a hydrocarbon radical, and analogous to the sulphonic acid.

PHOSPHORUS
 (n.) Hence, any substance which shines in the dark like phosphorus, as certain phosphorescent bodies.

PHOTODROME
 (n.) An apparatus consisting of a large wheel with spokes, which when turning very rapidly is illuminated by momentary flashes of light passing through slits in a rotating disk. By properly timing the succession of flashes the wheel is made to appear to

PHOTOGRAPH
 (v. t.) To take a picture or likeness of by means of photography; as, to photograph a view; to photograph a group.

PHTHISICKY
 (a.) Having phthisis, or some symptom of it, as difficulty in breathing.

PHYLACTERY
 (n.) Among the primitive Christians, a case in which the relics of the dead were inclosed.

PHYTOPHAGY
 (n.) The eating of plants.

PIANOFORTE
 (a.) A well-known musical instrument somewhat resembling the harpsichord, and consisting of a series of wires of graduated length, thickness, and tension, struck by hammers moved by keys.

PICAYUNISH
 (a.) Petty; paltry; mean; as, a picayunish business.

PICKANINNY
 (n.) A small child; especially, a negro or mulatto infant.

PICTOGRAPH
 (n.) A picture or hieroglyph representing and expressing an idea.

PIEZOMETER
 (n.) A gauge connected with a water main to show the pressure at that point.

PIGMENTARY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to pigments; furnished with pigments.

PILGRIMAGE
 (n.) The journey of a pilgrim; a long journey; especially, a journey to a shrine or other sacred place. Fig., the journey of human life.

PILIFEROUS
 (a.) Beset with hairs.

PISTILLODY
 (n.) The metamorphosis of other organs into pistils.

PITYRIASIS
 (n.) A superficial affection of the skin, characterized by irregular patches of thin scales which are shed in branlike particles.

PLANETICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to planets.

PLASTERING
 (n.) A covering of plaster; plasterwork.

PLATYPTERA
 (n. pl.) A division of Pseudoneuroptera including the species which have four broad, flat wings, as the termites, or white-ants, and the stone flies (Perla).

PLAUDITORY
 (a.) Applauding; commending.

PLEBEIANCE
 (n.) Plebeians, collectively.

PLEDGELESS
 (a.) Having no pledge.

PLEUROCARP
 (n.) Any pleurocarpic moss.

PLEXIMETER
 (n.) A small, hard, elastic plate, as of ivory, bone, or rubber, placed in contact with body to receive the blow, in examination by mediate percussion.

PLIOSAURUS
 (n.) An extinct genus of marine reptiles allied to Plesiosaurus, but having a much shorter neck.

PLOUGHGANG
 (n.) Same as Plowgate.

PLUNDERAGE
 (n.) The embezzlement of goods on shipboard.

PLUPERFECT
 (n.) The pluperfect tense; also, a verb in the pluperfect tense.

PNEUMATICS
 (n.) The scientific study or knowledge of spiritual beings and their relations to God, angels, and men.

POINTLETED
 (a.) Having a small, distinct point; apiculate.

POISONSOME
 (a.) Poisonous.[Obs.] Holland.

 (n.) A polemic.

 (n.) The act of polishing, or the state of being polished.

 (a.) See Polyhedral.

 (n.) One who practices or advocates polygyny.

POLYHEDRON
 (n.) A body or solid contained by many sides or planes.

POLYMEROUS
 (a.) Polymeric.

POLYNOMIAL
 (a.) Containing many names or terms; multinominal; as, the polynomial theorem.

POLYPODIUM
 (n.) A genus of plants of the order Filices or ferns. The fructifications are in uncovered roundish points, called sori, scattered over the inferior surface of the frond or leaf. There are numerous species.

POLYPTERUS
 (n.) An African genus of ganoid fishes including the bichir.

POLYSPERMY
 (n.) Fullness of sperm, or seed; the passage of more than one spermatozoon into the vitellus in the impregnation of the ovum.

PTERANODON
 (n.) A genus of American Cretaceous pterodactyls destitute of teeth. Several species are known, some of which had an expanse of wings of twenty feet or more.

 (pl. ) of Retinaculum

RETIREMENT
 (n.) The act of retiring, or the state of being retired; withdrawal; seclusion; as, the retirement of an officer.

RETRIEVING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Retrieve

RETROGRADE
 (a.) Apparently moving backward, and contrary to the succession of the signs, that is, from east to west, as a planet.

RETURNABLE
 (a.) Legally required to be returned, delivered, given, or rendered; as, a writ or precept returnable at a certain day; a verdict returnable to the court.

REVEALMENT
 (n.) Act of revealing.

REVELATION
 (n.) That which is revealed.

REVERENCED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Reverence

REVILEMENT
 (n.) The act of reviling; also, contemptuous language; reproach; abuse.

REVIVEMENT
 (n.) Revival.

REVOCATION
 (n.) The act of calling back, or the state of being recalled; recall.

REVOLUTION
 (n.) A fundamental change in political organization, or in a government or constitution; the overthrow or renunciation of one government, and the substitution of another, by the governed.

RHABDOMERE
 (n.) One of the several parts composing a rhabdom.

RHAPSODIST
 (n.) Hence, one who recites or sings poems for a livelihood; one who makes and repeats verses extempore.

RHAPSODIES
 (pl. ) of Rhapsody

RHEOMETRIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a rheometer or rheometry.

RHEUMATISM
 (n.) A general disease characterized by painful, often multiple, local inflammations, usually affecting the joints and muscles, but also extending sometimes to the deeper organs, as the heart.

RHINESTONE
 (n.) A colorless stone of high luster, made of paste. It is much used as an inexpensive ornament.

RHIZOPHORA
 (n.) A genus of trees including the mangrove. See Mangrove.

RHIZOTAXIS
 (n.) The arrangement of the roots of plants.

RICINOLEIN
 (n.) The glycerin salt of ricinoleic acid, occuring as a characteristic constituent of castor oil; -- formerly called palmin.

RINDERPEST
 (n.) A highly contagious distemper or murrain, affecting neat cattle, and less commonly sheep and goats; -- called also cattle plague, Russian cattle plague, and steppe murrain.

RITORNELLO
 (n.) A short return or repetition; a concluding symphony to an air, often consisting of the burden of the song.

ROSANILINE
 (n.) A complex nitrogenous base, C20H21N3O, obtained by oxidizing a mixture of aniline and toluidine, as a colorless crystalline substance which forms red salts. These salts are essential components of many of the socalled aniline dyes, as fuchsine, ani

ROSTRIFORM
 (a.) Having the form of a beak.

ROUGHENING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Roughen

ROUGHRIDER
 (n.) One who breaks horses; especially (Mil.), a noncommissioned officer in the British cavalry, whose duty is to assist the riding master.

ROUNDABOUT
 (n.) A short, close jacket worn by boys, sailors, etc.

ROUNDHOUSE
 (n.) A cabin or apartament on the after part of the quarter-deck, having the poop for its roof; -- sometimes called the coach.

RUBEDINOUS
 (a.) Reddish.

RUBYTHROAT
 (n.) Any one of numerous species of humming birds belonging to Trochilus, Calypte, Stellula, and allies, in which the male has on the throat a brilliant patch of red feathers having metallic reflections; esp., the common humming bird of the Eastern Unit

RUFFIANOUS
 (a.) Ruffianly.

RUFTERHOOD
 (n.) A kind of hood for a hawk.

RUMINANTLY
 (adv.) In a ruminant manner; by ruminating, or chewing the cud.

RURICOLIST
 (n.) An inhabitant of the country.

RUSSOPHILE
 (n.) Alt. of Russophilist

SACCHARIFY
 (v. t.) To convert into, or to impregnate with, sugar.

SACCHAROID
 (a.) Alt. of Saccharoidal

SACCHARONE
 (n.) An oily liquid, C6H10O2, obtained by the reduction of saccharin.

SACRIFICAL
 (a.) Employed in sacrifice.

SADDLEBACK
 (n.) The great blackbacked gull (Larus marinus).

SALAERATUS
 (n.) See Saleratus.

SALAMANDER
 (n.) Solidified material in a furnace hearth.

SALESWOMAN
 (n.) A woman whose occupation is to sell goods or merchandise.

SALICYLITE
 (n.) A compound of salicylal; -- named after the analogy of a salt.

SALIFIABLE
 (a.) Capable of neutralizing an acid to form a salt; -- said of bases; thus, ammonia is salifiable.

SALIVATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Salivate

SALUBRIOUS
 (a.) Favorable to health; healthful; promoting health; as, salubrious air, water, or climate.

SAMELINESS
 (n.) Sameness, 2.

SANCTIFIED
 (a.) Made holy; also, made to have the air of sanctity; sanctimonious.

SANCTITIES
 (pl. ) of Sanctity

SANDALWOOD
 (n.) The red wood of a kind of buckthorn, used in Russia for dyeing leather (Rhamnus Dahuricus).

SANDNECKER
 (n.) A European flounder (Hippoglossoides limandoides); -- called also rough dab, long fluke, sand fluke, and sand sucker.

SANGUINARY
 (a.) The yarrow.

SANGUISUGE
 (n.) A bloodsucker, or leech.

SANITARIUM
 (n.) A health station or retreat; a sanatorium.

SAPONIFIED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Saponify

SAPPHIRINE
 (n.) Resembling sapphire; made of sapphire; having the color, or any quality of sapphire.

SARCOCOLLA
 (n.) A gum resin obtained from certain shrubs of Africa (Penaea), -- formerly thought to cause healing of wounds and ulcers.

SARCOPHILE
 (n.) A flesh-eating animal, especially any one of the carnivorous marsupials.

SAUERKRAUT
 (n.) Cabbage cut fine and allowed to ferment in a brine made of its own juice with salt, -- a German dish.

SAUNTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Saunter

SAVINGNESS
 (n.) Tendency to promote salvation.

SCABREDITY
 (n.) Roughness; ruggedness.

SCANDALOUS
 (a.) Disgraceful to reputation; bringing shame or infamy; opprobrious; as, a scandalous crime or vice.

SCANSORIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Scansores. See Illust.. under Aves.

SCARCENESS
 (n.) Alt. of Scarcity

SCATTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Scatter

SCEPTICISM
 () etc. See Skeptic, Skeptical, Skepticism, etc.

SCHOLASTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the schoolmen and divines of the Middle Ages (see Schoolman); as, scholastic divinity or theology; scholastic philosophy.

SCHOOLDAME
 (n.) A schoolmistress.

SCHOOLMATE
 (n.) A pupil who attends the same school as another.

SCOFFINGLY
 (adv.) In a scoffing manner.

SCORIFYING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Scorify

SCOTOGRAPH
 (n.) An instrument for writing in the dark, or without seeing.

SCOTTERING
 (n.) The burning of a wad of pease straw at the end of harvest.

SCRAMBLING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Scramble

SCRUPULOUS
 (a.) Careful; cautious; exact; nice; as, scrupulous abstinence from labor; scrupulous performance of duties.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Sculpture

SEBIFEROUS
 (a.) Producing vegetable tallow.

SECULARISM
 (n.) The tenets or principles of the secularists.

SECULARIZE
 (v. t.) To convert from spiritual or common use; as, to secularize a church, or church property.

SECUREMENT
 (n.) The act of securing; protection.

SELENOLOGY
 (n.) That branch of astronomy which treats of the moon.

SEMBLATIVE
 (a.) Resembling.

SEMICIRCLE
 (n.) The half of a circle; the part of a circle bounded by its diameter and half of its circumference.

SEMIDITONE
 (n.) A lesser third, having its terms as 6 to 5; a hemiditone.

SEMIFLEXED
 (a.) Half bent.

SEMISAVAGE
 (n.) One who is half savage.

SENATORIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a senator, or a senate; becoming to a senator, or a senate; as, senatorial duties; senatorial dignity.

SENTENTIAL
 (a.) Comprising sentences; as, a sentential translation.

SENTIENTLY
 (adv.) In a sentient or perceptive way.

SEPARATION
 (n.) Chemical analysis.

SEPARATRIX
 (n.) The decimal point; the dot placed at the left of a decimal fraction, to separate it from the whole number which it follows. The term is sometimes also applied to other marks of separation.

SEPTENNIAL
 (a.) Happening or returning once in every seven years; as, septennial elections in England.

SEPULCHRAL
 (a.) Unnaturally low and grave; hollow in tone; -- said of sound, especially of the voice.

SEQUENTIAL
 (a.) Succeeding or following in order.

SEQUESTRAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a sequestrum.

SERALBUMEN
 (n.) Serum albumin.

SERAPHICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a seraph; becoming, or suitable to, a seraph; angelic; sublime; pure; refined.

SERENENESS
 (n.) Serenity.

SERMONICAL
 (a.) Like, or appropriate to, a sermon; grave and didactic.

SETIPAROUS
 (a.) Producing setae; -- said of the organs from which the setae of annelids arise.

SETTLEMENT
 (n.) That which settles, or is settled, established, or fixed.

SEVENTIETH
 (n.) One next in order after the sixty-ninth.

SEXAGENARY
 (n.) A sexagenarian.

SHEEPSHANK
 (n.) A hitch by which a rope may be temporarily shortened.

SHELLPROOF
 (a.) Capable of resisting bombs or other shells; bombproof.

SHELTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Shelter

SHEPHERDED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Shepherd

SHIBBOLETH
 (n.) A word which was made the criterion by which to distinguish the Ephraimites from the Gileadites. The Ephraimites, not being able to pronounce sh, called the word sibboleth. See Judges xii.

SHIELDLESS
 (a.) Destitute of a shield, or of protection.

SHIFTINESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being shifty.

SHOPLIFTER
 (n.) One who steals anything in a shop, or takes goods privately from a shop; one who, under pretense of buying goods, takes occasion to steal.

SHOVELBILL
 (n.) The shoveler.

SHOVELHEAD
 (n.) A shark (Sphryna tiburio) allied to the hammerhead, and native of the warmer parts of the Atlantic and Pacific oceans; -- called also bonnet shark.

SHROUDLESS
 (a.) Without a shroud.

SICILIENNE
 (n.) A kind of rich poplin.

SIDEROSTAT
 (n.) An apparatus consisting essentially of a mirror moved by clockwork so as to throw the rays of the sun or a star in a fixed direction; -- a more general term for heliostat.

SIGAULTIAN
 (a.) Pertaining to Sigault, a French physician. See Symphyseotomy.

SIGNALLING
 () of Signal

SIGNIORIZE
 (v. i.) To exercise dominion; to seigniorize.

SILVERFISH
 (n.) A white variety of the goldfish.

SILVERLING
 (n.) A small silver coin.

SILVERWEED
 (n.) A perennial rosaceous herb (Potentilla Anserina) having the leaves silvery white beneath.

SIMILATIVE
 (a.) Implying or indicating likeness or resemblance.

SIMPLENESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being simple; simplicity.

SIMPLICITY
 (n.) Artlessness of mind; freedom from cunning or duplicity; lack of acuteness and sagacity.

SINEWINESS
 (n.) Quality of being sinewy.

SINGULARLY
 (adv.) So as to express one, or the singular number.

SIPHONIATA
 (n. pl.) Same as Siphonata.

 (a.) Cunning; dexterous.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Solemnize

 (a.) Holding the tenets of Solifidians; of or pertaining to the solifidians.

SOLIVAGOUS
 (a.) Solivagant.

SOLUBILITY
 (n.) The quality, condition, or degree of being soluble or solvable; as, the solubility of a salt; the solubility of a problem or intricate difficulty.

SOMNIATORY
 (a.) Pertaining to sleep or dreams; somnial.

SORBONICAL
 (a.) Belonging to the Sorbonne or to a Sorbonist.

SOUTHWARDS
 (adv.) Toward the south, or toward a point nearer the south than the east or west point; as, to go southward.

SPADICEOUS
 (a.) Bearing flowers on a spadix; of the nature of a spadix.

SPARSENESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being sparse; as, sparseness of population.

SPATHIFORM
 (a.) Resembling spar in form.

SPECIALISM
 (n.) Devotion to a particular and restricted part or branch of knowledge, art, or science; as, medical specialism.

SPECULATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Speculate

SPECULATOR
 (n.) One who forms theories; a theorist.

SPELLBOUND
 (a.) Bound by, or as by, a spell.

SPENSERIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the English poet Spenser; -- specifically applied to the stanza used in his poem The Faerie Queene.

SPERMATIZE
 (v. i.) To yield seed; to emit seed, or sperm.

SPHENISCAN
 (n.) Any species of penguin.

SPHEROIDIC
 (a.) Alt. of Spheroidical

SPHEROSOME
 (n.) The body wall of any radiate animal.

SPIDERLIKE
 (a.) Like a spider.

SPIRITLESS
 (a.) Having no breath; extinct; dead.

SPIRITUOUS
 (a.) Having the quality of spirit; tenuous in substance, and having active powers or properties; ethereal; immaterial; spiritual; pure.

SPIROYLOUS
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, a substance now called salicylal.

SPLENITIVE
 (a.) Splenetic.

SPLENOLOGY
 (n.) The branch of science which treats of the spleen.

SPOLIATION
 (v. t.) A process for possession of a church in a spiritual court.

SPONDAICAL
 (a.) Containing spondees in excess; marked by spondees; as, a spondaic hexameter, i. e., one which has a spondee instead of a dactyl in the fifth foot.

SPOROPHORE
 (n.) That alternately produced form of certain cryptogamous plants, as ferns, mosses, and the like, which is nonsexual, but produces spores in countless numbers. In ferns it is the leafy plant, in mosses the capsule. Cf. Oophore.

SPOUSELESS
 (a.) Destitute of a spouse; unmarried.

SPRINKLING
 (n.) The act of one who, or that which, sprinkles.

SPURGEWORT
 (n.) Any euphorbiaceous plant.

SQUALIDITY
 (n.) The quality or state of being squalid; foulness; filthiness.

SQUAMIFORM
 (a.) Having the shape of a scale.

SQUAWBERRY
 (n.) A local name for the partridge berry; also, for the deerberry.

SQUETEAGUE
 (n.) An American sciaenoid fish (Cynoscion regalis), abundant on the Atlantic coast of the United States, and much valued as a food fish. It is of a bright silvery color, with iridescent reflections. Called also weakfish, squitee, chickwit, and sea trou

 (n.) A pendent cone or cylinder of calcium carbonate resembling an icicle in form and mode of attachment. Stalactites are found depending from the roof or sides of caverns, and are produced by deposition from waters which have percolated through, and pa

STEALINGLY

STEAMINESS

STENOGRAPH

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Stiffen

STIFFENING
 (n.) Something used to make anything stiff.

STILLBIRTH

STILLIFORM

STILLSTAND
 (n.) A standstill.

STIPELLATE
 (a.) Having stipels.

STONEHATCH
 (n.) The ring plover, or dotterel.

STRABISMUS
 (n.) An affection of one or both eyes, in which the optic axes can not be directed to the same object, -- a defect due either to undue contraction or to undue relaxation of one or more of the muscles which move the eyeball; squinting; cross-eye.

STRAIGHTEN
 (v. t.) A variant of Straiten.

STRAIGHTLY
 (adv.) A variant of Straitly. See 1st Straight.

STRAMAZOUN
 (n.) A direct descending blow with the edge of a sword.

STRATIFIED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Stratify

STREETWARD
 (n.) An officer, or ward, having the care of the streets.

STRENGTHEN
 (v. i.) To grow strong or stronger.

STRIDULATE
 (v. t.) to make a shrill or musical sound, such as is made by the males of many insects.

STRUCTURAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to organit structure; as, a structural element or cell; the structural peculiarities of an animal or a plant.

STURIONIAN
 (n.) One of the family of fishes of which the sturgeon is the type.

STUTTERING
 (n.) The act of one who stutters; -- restricted by some physiologists to defective speech due to inability to form the proper sounds, the breathing being normal, as distinguished from stammering.

SUBASHDARY
 (n.) Alt. of Subashship

SUBAQUEOUS
 (a.) Formed in or under water; as, subaqueous deposits.

SUBCLAVIAN
 (a.) Situated under the clavicle, or collar bone; as, the subclavian arteries.

SUBCORDATE
 (a.) Somewhat cordate; somewhat like a heart in shape.

SUBDECUPLE
 (a.) Containing one part of ten.

SUBFIBROUS
 (a.) Somewhat fibrous.

SUBGLACIAL
 (a.) Pertaining or belonging to the under side of a glacier; being beneath a glacier; as, subglacial streams.

SUBJECTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Subject

SUBJECTIVE
 (a.) Modified by, or making prominent, the individuality of a writer or an artist; as, a subjective drama or painting; a subjective writer.

SUBMERGING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Submerge

SUBMERSION
 (n.) The act of submerging, or putting under water or other fluid, or of causing to be overflowed; the act of plunging under water, or of drowning.

SUBNUVOLAR
 (a.) Under the clouds; attended or partly covered or obscured by clouds; somewhat cloudy.

SUBOFFICER
 (n.) An under or subordinate officer.

SUBORBITAR
 (a.) Situated under or below the orbit.

SUBRIGUOUS
 (a.) Watered or wet beneath; well-watered.

SUBSISTENT
 (a.) Having real being; as, a subsistent spirit.

SUBSTITUTE

 (a.) Subsultory.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Subtend

SUBTERRANY
 (n.) A subterranean place.

SUBVERTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Subvert

SUCCESSION
 (n.) The act of succeeding, or following after; a following of things in order of time or place, or a series of things so following; sequence; as, a succession of good crops; a succession of disasters.

SUCCIDUOUS
 (a.) Ready to fall; falling.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Succumb

SUFFERANCE
 (n.) Loss; damage; injury.

 (a.) Capable of meeting obligations; responsible.

 (v. t.) To summer-fallow.

SUNSETTING
 (n.) The descent of the sun below the horizon; also, the time when the sun sets; evening. Also used figuratively.

SUPERBIATE
 (v. t.) To make (a person) haughty.

SUPERIORLY
 (adv.) In a superior position or manner.

SUPPLEMENT
 (v. t.) That which supplies a deficiency, or meets a want; a store; a supply.

SUPPLICANT
 (a.) Entreating; asking submissively.

SUPPLICATE
 (v. i.) To make petition with earnestness and submission; to implore.

SUPPRESSOR
 (n.) One who suppresses.

SURANGULAR
 (n.) The surangular bone.

SURCHARGER
 (n.) One who surcharges.

SURMOUNTED
 (a.) Having its vertical height greater than the half span; -- said of an arch.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Surpass

SUSCEPTIVE
 (a.) Susceptible.

SUSCITATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Suscitate

SUSPENSION
 (n.) Of punishment, or sentence of punishment.

SUSPENSION
 (n.) The prolongation of one or more tones of a chord into the chord which follows, thus producing a momentary discord, suspending the concord which the ear expects. Cf. Retardation.

SUSPENSORY
 (a.) Fitted or serving to suspend; suspending; as, a suspensory muscle.

SUSTENANCE
 (n.) That which supports life; food; victuals; provisions; means of living; as, the city has ample sustenance.

SUSTENTION
 (n.) Sustentation.

SUTLERSHIP
 (n.) The condition or occupation of a sutler.

SWARMSPORE
 (n.) One of the minute flagellate germs produced by the sporulation of a protozoan; -- called also zoospore.

SWEEPSTAKE
 (n.) A winning of all the stakes or prizes.

SWOOPSTAKE
 (adv.) Altogether; indiscriminately.

SYCOPHANCY
 (n.) The character or characteristic of a sycophant.

SYLLABUSES
 (pl. ) of Syllabus

SYMMETRIZE
 (v. t.) To make proportional in its parts; to reduce to symmetry.

SYMPATHIZE
 (v. i.) To have a common feeling, as of bodily pleasure or pain.

SYMPHYTISM
 (n.) Coalescence; a growing into one with another word.

SYNCARPIUM
 (n.) Same as Syncarp.

SYNCHRONAL
 (a.) Happening at, or belonging to, the same time; synchronous; simultaneous.

SYNCRETIST
 (n.) an adherent of George Calixtus and other Germans of the seventeenth century, who sought to unite or reconcile the Protestant sects with each other and with the Roman Catholics, and thus occasioned a long and violent controversy in the Lutheran chur

SYNDACTYLE
 (n.) Any bird having syndactilous feet.

SYNOECIOUS
 (a.) Having stamens and pistil in the same head, or, in mosses, having antheridia and archegonia on the same receptacle.

SYNTERETIC
 (a.) Preserving health; prophylactic.

SYNTHESIST
 (n.) One who employs synthesis, or who follows synthetic methods.

SYPHILITIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to syphilis; of the nature of syphilis; affected with syphilis.

SYSTEMLESS
 (a.) Not having any of the distinct systems or types of structure, as the radiate, articulate, etc., characteristic of organic nature; as, all unicellular organisms are systemless.

TABERNACLE
 (n.) Hence, the Jewish temple; sometimes, any other place for worship.

TABERNACLE
 (n.) A seat or stall in a choir, with its canopy.

TABULATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Tabulate

TACAMAHACA
 (n.) Any tree yielding tacamahac resin, especially, in North America, the balsam poplar, or balm of Gilead (Populus balsamifera).

TAMBOURINE
 (n.) A small drum, especially a shallow drum with only one skin, played on with the hand, and having bells at the sides; a timbrel.

TANTAMOUNT
 (v. i.) To be tantamount or equivalent; to amount.

TAPESTRIED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Tapestry

TARDIGRADE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Tardigrada.

TARTAREOUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Tartarus; hellish.

TARTUFFISH
 (a.) Alt. of Tartufish

TAUTOLOGIC
 (a.) Tautological.

TAUTOZONAL
 (a.) Belonging to the same zone; as, tautozonal planes.

TEASELLING
 () of Teasel

TELEOSTEAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the teleosts.

TELESCOPIC
 (a.) Alt. of Telescopical

TEMPERANCE
 (v. t.) State with regard to heat or cold; temperature.

TENDERLOIN
 (n.) A strip of tender flesh on either side of the vertebral column under the short ribs, in the hind quarter of beef and pork. It consists of the psoas muscles.

TENEBRIOUS
 (a.) Tenebrous.

TENTHMETER
 (n.) Alt. of Tenthmetre

TERRIFYING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Terrify

TETRACHORD
 (n.) A scale series of four sounds, of which the extremes, or first and last, constituted a fourth. These extremes were immutable; the two middle sounds were changeable.

TETRAGONAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a tetragon; having four angles or sides; thus, the square, the parallelogram, the rhombus, and the trapezium are tetragonal fingers.

TETRAMETER
 (n.) A verse or line consisting of four measures, that is, in iambic, trochaic, and anapestic verse, of eight feet; in other kinds of verse, of four feet.

TETRATOMIC
 (a.) Having a valence of four; quadrivalent; tetravalent; sometimes, in a specific sense, having four hydroxyl groups, whether acid or basic.

TEXTUARIST
 (n.) A textuary.

THECOPHORA
 (n. pl.) A division of hydroids comprising those which have the hydranths in thecae and the gonophores in capsules. The campanularians and sertularians are examples. Called also Thecata. See Illust. under Hydroidea.

THEOBROMIC
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid extracted from cacao butter (from the Theobroma Cacao), peanut oil (from Arachis hypogaea), etc., as a white waxy crystalline substance.

THEOLOGIZE
 (v. i.) To frame a system of theology; to theorize or speculate upon theological subjects.

THEOPHANIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a theopany; appearing to man, as a god.

THEORETICS
 (n.) The speculative part of a science; speculation.

THERMOPILE
 (n.) An instrument of extreme sensibility, used to determine slight differences and degrees of heat. It is composed of alternate bars of antimony and bismuth, or any two metals having different capacities for the conduction of heat, connected with an as

THERMOTYPY
 (n.) The art or process of obtaining thermotypes.

THIMBLERIG
 (n.) A sleight-of-hand trick played with three small cups, shaped like thimbles, and a small ball or little pea.

THIONOLINE
 (n.) A beautiful fluorescent crystalline substance, intermediate in composition between thionol and thionine.

THIRTEENTH
 (n.) The interval comprising an octave and a sixth.

THOUGHTFUL
 (a.) Full of thought; employed in meditation; contemplative; as, a man of thoughtful mind.

THOUSANDTH
 (a.) Occurring as being one of, or the last one of, a very great number; very small; minute; -- used hyperbolically; as, to do a thing for the thousandth time.

THREADBARE
 (a.) Worn to the naked thread; having the nap worn off; threadbare clothes.

THREADFISH
 (n.) The cutlass fish.

THREATENER
 (n.) One who threatens.

THRENODIST
 (n.) One who composes, delivers, or utters, a threnode, or threnody.

THRIFTLESS
 (a.) Without thrift; not prudent or prosperous in money affairs.

THROUGHOUT
 (prep.) Quite through; from one extremity to the other of; also, every part of; as, to search throughout the house.

THUMBSCREW
 (n.) A screw having a flat-sided or knurled head, so that it may be turned by the thumb and forefinger.

THUNDERING
 (n.) Thunder.

TILIACEOUS
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a natural order of plants (Tiliaceae) of which the linden (Tilia) is the type. The order includes many plants which furnish a valuable fiber, as the jute.

TIMBERLING
 (n.) A small tree.

TIMEKEEPER
 (n.) One who marks the time in musical performances.

TIMOCRATIC
 (a.) Belonging to, or constituted by, timocracy.

TIRRALIRRA
 (n.) A verbal imitation of a musical sound, as of the note of a lark or a horn.

TITHINGMAN
 (n.) A peace officer; an under constable.

TITTIMOUSE
 (n.) Titmouse.

TOBOGGANER
 (n.) Alt. of Tobogganist

TOLERATION
 (n.) The act of tolerating; the allowance of that which is not wholly approved.

TOMFOOLERY
 (n.) Folly; trifling.

TONGUELESS
 (a.) Hence, speechless; mute.

TONSILITIC
 (a.) Tonsilar.

TOPGALLANT
 (n.) Fig.: Anything elevated or splendid.

TORPIDNESS
 (n.) The qualityy or state of being torpid.

TORPORIFIC
 (a.) Tending to produce torpor.

TOUCHINESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being touchy peevishness; irritability; irascibility.

TOURMALINE
 (n.) A mineral occurring usually in three-sided or six-sided prisms terminated by rhombohedral or scalenohedral planes. Black tourmaline (schorl) is the most common variety, but there are also other varieties, as the blue (indicolite), red (rubellite),

TOWARDNESS
 (n.) Quality or state of being toward.

TOXIPHOBIA
 (n.) An insane or greatly exaggerated dread of poisons.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Tractarians, or their principles.

TRADESFOLK
 (n.) People employed in trade; tradesmen.

TRADUCTION
 (n.) Translation from one language to another.

TRAGEDIOUS
 (a.) Like tragedy; tragical.

TRAJECTORY
 (n.) The curve which a body describes in space, as a planet or comet in its orbit, or stone thrown upward obliquely in the air.

TRAMONTANE
 (a.) Lying or being beyond the mountains; coming from the other side of the mountains; hence, foreign; barbarous.

TRANSHUMAN
 (a.) More than human; superhuman.

TRANSITION
 (n.) Change from one form to another.

TRANSSHAPE
 (v. t.) To change into another shape or form; to transform.

TRAVELLING
 () of Travel

TRAVERTINE
 (n.) A white concretionary form of calcium carbonate, usually hard and semicrystalline. It is deposited from the water of springs or streams holding lime in solution. Extensive deposits exist at Tivoli, near Rome.

TRAWLERMAN
 (n.) A fisherman who used unlawful arts and engines to catch fish.

TREADWHEEL
 (n.) A wheel turned by persons or animals, by treading, climbing, or pushing with the feet, upon its periphery or face. See Treadmill.

TREASURESS
 (n.) A woman who is a treasurer.

TRICHOGYNE
 (n.) The slender, hairlike cell which receives the fertilizing particles, or antherozoids, in red seaweeds.

TRICOCCOUS
 (a.) Having three cocci, or roundish carpels.

TRICOSTATE
 (a.) Three-ribbed; having three ribs from the base.

TRIDENTINE
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Trent, or the general church council held in that city.

TRIERARCHY
 (n.) The office duty of a trierarch.

TRIGEMINAL
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or designating, the fifth pair of cranial nerves, which divide on each side of the head into three main branches distributed to the orbits, jaws, and parts of the mouth; trifacial.

TRIGRAMMIC
 (a.) Same as Trigrammatic.

TRINOCTIAL
 (a.) Lasting during three nights; comprising three nights.

UNEMPLOYED
 (a.) Not employed in manual or other labor; having no regular work.

 (a.) Having no father; fatherless; hence, born contrary to nature.

 (n.) Infirmness.

 (a.) Resembling a bladder; utricular; utriculate.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to uxoricide; tending to uxoricide.

VATICANISM
 (n.) The doctrine of papal supremacy; extreme views in support of the authority of the pope; ultramontanism; -- a term used only by persons who are not Roman Catholics.

VEGETARIAN
 (n.) One who holds that vegetables and fruits are the only proper food for man. Strict vegetarians eat no meat, eggs, or milk.

VELIVOLANT
 (a.) Flying with sails; passing under full sail.

VINCENTIAN

WRAPRASCAL

XANTHIDIUM
 (n.) A genus of minute unicellular algae of the desmids. These algae have a rounded shape and are armed with glochidiate or branched aculei. Several species occur in ditches, and others are found fossil in flint or hornstone.

 (n.) The quality or state of being yeasty, or frothy.

AFFIRMATIVE
 (a.) That affirms; asserting that the fact is so; declaratory of what exists; answering yes to a question; -- opposed to negative; as, an affirmative answer; an affirmative vote.

AFFIRMATIVE

AFFREIGHTER
 (n.) One who hires or charters a ship to convey goods.

 (n.) That which aggravates.

 (a.) Taken together; collective.

 (n.) Arrangement in a group or in groups; grouping.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to the allantois.

 (a.) Belonging to, or consisting of, allegory; of the nature of an allegory; describing by resemblances; figurative.

ALLOCHROOUS
 (a.) Changing color.

ALLOTROPIZE
 (v. t.) To change in physical properties but not in substance.

ALTERCATIVE
 (a.) Characterized by wrangling; scolding.

ALTERNATION
 (n.) Permutation.

ALTERNATIVE

 (a.) High-sounding; pompous in speech.

ALUMINIFORM

 (a.) Unfading, as the poetic amaranth; undying.

AMENORRHOEA
 (n.) Retention or suppression of the menstrual discharge.

AMICABILITY
 (n.) The quality of being amicable; friendliness; amicableness.

AMOROUSNESS
 (n.) The quality of being amorous, or inclined to sexual love; lovingness.

AMORTIZABLE
 (a.) Capable of being cleared off, as a debt.

AMPEREMETER
 (n.) Alt. of Amperometer

AMPHIGAMOUS
 (a.) Having a structure entirely cellular, and no distinct sexual organs; -- a term applied by De Candolle to the lowest order of plants.

AMPHIGENOUS
 (a.) Increasing in size by growth on all sides, as the lichens.

AMPHISBAENA
 (n.) A fabled serpent with a head at each end, moving either way.

AMPHITROPAL
 (a.) Alt. of Amphitropous

AMPLEXICAUL
 (a.) Clasping or embracing a stem, as the base of some leaves.

AMPULLIFORM
 (a.) Flask-shaped; dilated.

AMYLOBACTER
 (n.) A microorganism (Bacillus amylobacter) which develops in vegetable tissue during putrefaction.

ANACANTHOUS
 (a.) Spineless, as certain fishes.

ANACHRONOUS
 (a.) Containing an anachronism; anachronistic.

ANACOLUTHIC
 (a.) Lacking grammatical sequence.

ANAESTHETIC
 (a.) Capable of rendering insensible; as, anaesthetic agents.

ANAGLYPTICS
 (n.) The art of carving in low relief, embossing, etc.

ANAPNOGRAPH
 (n.) A form of spirometer.

ANASTOMOSIS
 (n.) The inosculation of vessels, or intercommunication between two or more vessels or nerves, as the cross communication between arteries or veins.

ANDRANATOMY
 (n.) The dissection of a human body, especially of a male; androtomy.

ANDROSPHINX
 (n.) A man sphinx; a sphinx having the head of a man and the body of a lion.

ANELECTRODE
 (n.) The positive pole of a voltaic battery.

ANEMOGRAPHY
 (n.) A description of the winds.

ANGUSTATION
 (n.) The act of making narrow; a straitening or contacting.

ANIMALCULUM
 (n.) An animalcule.

ANISOMETRIC
 (a.) Not isometric; having unsymmetrical parts; -- said of crystals with three unequal axes.

ANNIHILABLE
 (a.) Capable of being annihilated.

 (n. pl.) A group of wingless insects, of which the flea in the type. See Flea.

 (a.) Pertaining to Aphrodite or Venus. Aphrodisian dames [that is, courtesans].

APLACENTATA
 (n. pl.) Mammals which have no placenta.

APODICTICAL
 (a.) Self-evident; intuitively true; evident beyond contradiction.

APODYTERIUM
 (n.) The apartment at the entrance of the baths, or in the palestra, where one stripped; a dressing room.

APOLOGETICS
 (n.) That branch of theology which defends the Holy Scriptures, and sets forth the evidence of their divine authority.

APONEUROTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to an aponeurosis.

APOPLECTOID
 (a.) Resembling apoplexy.

APOSIOPESIS
 (n.) A figure of speech in which the speaker breaks off suddenly, as if unwilling or unable to state what was in his mind; as, I declare to you that his conduct -- but I can not speak of that, here.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Apostatize

 (a.) Of or pertaining to a chain of mountains in the United States, commonly called the Allegheny mountains.

 (n.) Accusation.

 (a.) Common, as opposed to proper; denominative of a class.

APPELLATORY
 (a.) Containing an appeal.

 (n.) The thing applied.

ASTIGMATISM
 (n.) A defect of the eye or of a lens, in consequence of which the rays derived from one point are not brought to a single focal point, thus causing imperfect images or indistinctness of vision.

ASTRONOMIZE
 (v. i.) To study or to talk astronomy.

CLIMACTERIC
 (n.) A period in human life in which some great change is supposed to take place in the constitution. The critical periods are thought by some to be the years produced by multiplying 7 into the odd numbers 3 5 7 and 9; to which others add the 81st year.

CLOSEHAULED
 (a.) Under way and moving as nearly as possible toward the direction from which the wind blows; -- said of a sailing vessel.

CLOTHESLINE
 (n.) A rope or wire on which clothes are hung to dry.

 (n.) Manner of acting; behavior; bearing.

COMPOSITION
 (n.) The act or art of composing, or forming a whole or integral, by placing together and uniting different things, parts, or ingredients.

COMPOSITION
 (n.) The state of being put together or composed; conjunction; combination; adjustment.

COMPOSITION
 (n.) The adjustment of a debt, or avoidance of an obligation, by some form of compensation agreed on between the parties; also, the sum or amount of compensation agreed upon in the adjustment.

COMPOSITOUS
 (a.) Belonging to the Compositae; composite.

COMPROMISER
 (n.) One who compromises.

COMPURGATOR
 (n.) One who bears testimony or swears to the veracity or innocence of another. See Purgation; also Wager of law, under Wager.

CONCAMERATE
 (v. t.) To arch over; to vault.

CONCEALABLE
 (a.) Capable of being concealed.

CONCEALMENT
 (n.) A secret; out of the way knowledge.

CONCEITEDLY
 (adv.) Fancifully; whimsically.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Concentre

CONCENTRATE
 (v. t.) To bring to, or direct toward, a common center; to unite more closely; to gather into one body, mass, or force; to fix; as, to concentrate rays of light into a focus; to concentrate the attention.

CONCHOMETER
 (n.) An instrument for measuring shells, or the angle of their spire.

CONCILIABLE
 (n.) A small or private assembly, especially of an ecclesiastical nature.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Conciliate

 (n.) One who conciliates.

CONCLUSIBLE
 (a.) Demonstrable; determinable.

CONCORDANCE
 (n.) An alphabetical verbal index showing the places in the text of a book where each principal word may be found, with its immediate context in each place.

CONCURRENCE
 (n.) A meeting of minds; agreement in opinion; union in design or act; -- implying joint approbation.

CONDEMNABLE
 () Worthy of condemnation; blamable; culpable.

CONDENSABLE
 (a.) Capable of being condensed; as, vapor is condensable.

CONDISCIPLE
 (n.) A schoolfellow; a fellow-student.

CONDITIONAL
 (n.) A conditional word, mode, or proposition.

CONFABULATE
 (v. i.) To talk familiarly together; to chat; to prattle.

CONFEDERACY
 (n.) A league or compact between two or more persons, bodies of men, or states, for mutual support or common action; alliance.

CONFEDERATE
 (n.) One who is united with others in a league; a person or a nation engaged in a confederacy; an ally; also, an accomplice in a bad sense.

CONFEDERATE
 (v. i.) To unite in a league; to join in a mutual contract or covenant; to band together.

 (adv.) With confidence; with strong assurance; positively.

 (a.) That may be confirmed.

 (a.) Dependent on conjecture; fancied; imagined; guessed at; undetermined; doubtful.

 (a.) Implying something additional; illative.

 (a.) Following as a consequence or result; actually or logically dependent; consequential; succeeding.

 (n.) A proposition collected from the agreement of other previous propositions; any conclusion which results from reason or argument; inference.

CONSIMILITY

 (n.) A degree of firmness, density, or spissitude.

 (a.) Capable of being continued

 (n.) A dark blue, edible berry with a white bloom, and its shrub (Gaylussacia frondosa) closely allied to the common huckleberry. The bush is also called blue tangle, and is found from New England to Kentucky, and southward.

 (n.) The unconscious saying, in speech or in writing, of that which one does not intend to say; -- frequently the very reverse of the thought which is present to consciousness.

HETEROPTERA
 (n. pl.) A suborder of Hemiptera, in which the base of the anterior wings is thickened. See Hemiptera.

HEXAGONALLY
 (adv.) In an hexagonal manner.

HEXASTICHON
 (n.) A poem consisting of six verses or lines.

HIBERNATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hibernate

HIBERNICISM
 (n.) Alt. of Hibernianism

HICCOUGHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hiccough

HIERONYMITE
 (n.) See Jeronymite.

HIPPOCAMPUS
 (n.) A genus of lophobranch fishes of several species in which the head and neck have some resemblance to those of a horse; -- called also sea horse.

HIPPOCRATIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Hippocrates, or to his teachings.

HISPANICIZE
 (v. t.) To give a Spanish form or character to; as, to Hispanicize Latin words.

HISTRIONIZE
 (v. t.) To act; to represent on the stage, or theatrically.

HOLOBLASTIC
 (a.) Undergoing complete segmentation; composed entirely of germinal matter, the whole of the yolk undergoing fission; -- opposed to meroblastic.

HOLOTHURIAN
 (n.) One of the Holothurioidea.

HOMEOPATHIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to homeopathy; according to the principles of homeopathy.

HOMOEOPATHY
 (n.) Same as Homeopathic, Homeopathist, Homeopathy.

HOMOGENEOUS
 (a.) Of the same kind of nature; consisting of similar parts, or of elements of the like nature; -- opposed to heterogeneous; as, homogeneous particles, elements, or principles; homogeneous bodies.

HOMOPHONOUS
 (a.) Originally, sounding alike; of the same pitch; unisonous; monodic.

HOMOPLASTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to homoplasty; as, homoplasticorgans; homoplastic forms.

HOMOTHERMIC
 (a.) Alt. of Homothermous

HOMOTROPOUS
 (a.) Having the radicle of the seed directed towards the hilum.

HONESTATION
 (n.) The act of honesting; grace; adornment.

HONEYCOMBED
 (a.) Formed or perforated like a honeycomb.

HORRISONOUS
 (a.) Sounding dreadfully; uttering a terrible sound.

HOSPITALISM
 (n.) A vitiated condition of the body, due to long confinement in a hospital, or the morbid condition of the atmosphere of a hospital.

HOUSEKEEPER
 (n.) One who exercises hospitality, or has a plentiful and hospitable household.

HUCKLEBERRY
 (n.) The shrub that bears the berries. Called also whortleberry.

HUMILIATION
 (n.) The act of humiliating or humbling; abasement of pride; mortification.

HUSBANDABLE
 (a.) Capable of being husbanded, or managed with economy.

HYACINTHINE
 (a.) Belonging to the hyacinth; resemblingthe hyacinth; in color like the hyacinth.

HYALESCENCE
 (n.) The process of becoming, or the state of being, transparent like glass.

HYBERNATION
 () See Hibernacle, Hibernate, Hibernation.

HYDRACRYLIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an isomeric variety of lastic acid that breaks down into acrylic acid and water.

HYDRAULICON
 (n.) An ancient musical instrument played by the action of water; a water organ.

HYDROFLUATE
 (n.) A supposed compound of hydrofluoris acid and a base; a fluoride.

HYDROGENIDE
 (n.) A binary compound containing hydrogen; a hydride. [R.] See Hydride.

HYDROGENOUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to hydrogen; containing hydrogen.

HYDRORHIZAE
 (pl. ) of Hydrorhiza

HYDROSORBIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from sorbic acid when this takes up hydrogen; as, hydrosorbic acid.

HYLOPHAGOUS
 (a.) Eating green shoots, as certain insects do.

HYOGANOIDEI
 (n. pl.) A division of ganoid fishes, including the gar pikes and bowfins.

HYPERBOLIST
 (n.) One who uses hyperboles.

HYPERBOLOID
 (n.) A surface of the second order, which is cut by certain planes in hyperbolas; also, the solid, bounded in part by such a surface.

HYPERBOREAN
 (n.) An inhabitant of the most northern regions.

HYPERCRITIC
 (n.) One who is critical beyond measure or reason; a carping critic; a captious censor.

HYPEROARTIA
 (n. pl.) An order of marsipobranchs including the lampreys. The suckerlike moth contains numerous teeth; the nasal opening is in the middle of the head above, but it does not connect with the mouth. See Cyclostoma, and Lamprey.

HYPNOLOGIST
 (n.) One who is versed in hypnology.

HYPNOTIZING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hypnotize

HYPOBLASTIC
 (a.) Relating to, or connected with, the hypoblast; as, the hypoic sac.

HYPOCARPIUM
 (n.) A fleshy enlargement of the receptacle, or for the stem, below the proper fruit, as in the cashew. See Illust. of Cashew.

HYPOCRISIES
 (pl. ) of Hypocrisy

HYPONITRITE
 (n.) A salt of hyponitrous acid.

HYPOSTROPHE
 (n.) The act of a patient turning himself.

HYPOTHETIST
 (n.) One who proposes or supports an hypothesis.

HYPOXANTHIN
 (n.) A crystalline, nitrogenous substance, closely related to xanthin and uric acid, widely distributed through the animal body, but especially in muscle tissue; -- called also sarcin, sarkin.

HYSTEROTOMY
 (n.) The Caesarean section. See under Caesarean.

IATRALIPTIC
 (a.) Treating diseases by anointing and friction; as, the iatraliptic method.

ICHTHYOHAGY
 (n.) The practice of eating, or living upon, fish.

ICOSAHEDRON
 (n.) A solid bounded by twenty sides or faces.

IDIOMORPHIC
 (a.) Idiomorphous.

IDIOPHANOUS
 (a.) Exhibiting interference figures without the aid of a polariscope, as certain crystals.

IDOLATRICAL
 (a.) Idolatrous.

IGNOBLENESS
 (n.) State or quality of being ignoble.

IGNORANTISM
 (n.) The spirit of those who extol the advantage to ignorance; obscuriantism.

ILIOFEMORAL
 (a.) Pertaining to the ilium and femur; as, iliofemoral ligaments.

ILLAQUEATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Illaqueate

ILLEGALIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Illegalize

ILLIMITABLE
 (a.) Incapable of being limited or bounded; immeasurable; limitless; boundless; as, illimitable space.

ILLUMINATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Illuminate

ILLUSTRIOUS
 (a.) Possessing luster or brightness; brilliant; luminous; splendid.

IMAGINATION
 (n.) The representative power; the power to reconstruct or recombine the materials furnished by direct apprehension; the complex faculty usually termed the plastic or creative power; the fancy.

IMAGINATIVE
 (a.) Proceeding from, and characterized by, the imagination, generally in the highest sense of the word.

IMBRICATION
 (n.) An overlapping of the edges, like that of tiles or shingles; hence, intricacy of structure; also, a pattern or decoration representing such a structure.

IMBURSEMENT
 (n.) The act of imbursing, or the state of being imbursed.

IMITATIONAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, or employed in, imitation; as, imitational propensities.

IMMEDIATELY
 (adv.) Without interval of time; without delay; promptly; instantly; at once.

IMMELODIOUS
 (a.) Not melodious.

IMMOMENTOUS
 (a.) Not momentous; unimportant; insignificant.

IMMORTALITY
 (n.) Exemption from oblivion; perpetuity; as, the immortality of fame.

IMMORTALIZE
 (v. t.) To exempt from oblivion; to perpetuate in fame.

IMPALATABLE
 (a.) Unpalatable.

IMPANELMENT
 (n.) The act or process of impaneling, or the state of being impaneled.

IMPARTATION
 (n.) The act of imparting, or the thing imparted.

IMPARTIALLY
 (a.) In an impartial manner.

IMPATIENTLY
 (adv.) In an impatient manner.

IMPEACHMENT
 (n.) Hindrance; impediment; obstruction.

IMPERATIVAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the imperative mood.

IMPERFORATA
 (n. pl.) A division of Foraminifera, including those in which the shell is not porous.

IMPERIALIZE
 (v. t.) To invest with imperial authority, character, or style; to bring to the form of an empire.

IMPERTINENT
 (a.) Not pertinent; not pertaining to the matter in hand; having no bearing on the subject; not to the point; irrelevant; inapplicable.

IMPERTURBED
 (a.) Not perturbed.

IMPETRATION
 (n.) The obtaining of benefice from Rome by solicitation, which benefice belonged to the disposal of the king or other lay patron of the realm.

IMPLEADABLE
 (a.) Not admitting excuse, evasion, or plea; rigorous.

IMPLICATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Implicate

IMPLICATIVE
 (a.) Tending to implicate.

IMPLORATORY
 (a.) Supplicatory; entreating.

IMPONDEROUS
 (a.) Imponderable.

IMPORTATION
 (v. t.) That which is imported; commodities or wares introduced into a country from abroad.

IMPORTUNACY
 (n.) The quality of being importunate; importunateness.

IMPRECATORY
 (a.) Of the nature of, or containing, imprecation; invoking evil; as, the imprecatory psalms.

IMPREGNABLE
 (a.) Capable of being impregnated, as the egg of an animal, or the ovule of a plant.

IMPRESARIOS
 (pl. ) of Impresario

IMPRESSMENT
 (n.) The act of seizing for public use, or of impressing into public service; compulsion to serve; as, the impressment of provisions or of sailors.

IMPROBATORY
 (a.) Implying, or tending to, improbation.

IMPROPRIETY
 (n.) The quality of being improper; unfitness or unsuitableness to character, time place, or circumstances; as, impropriety of behavior or manners.

IMPROVEMENT
 (n.) Increase; growth; progress; advance.

IMPROVISATE
 (a.) Unpremeditated; impromptu; extempore.

INALIENABLE
 (a.) Incapable of being alienated, surrendered, or transferred to another; not alienable; as, in inalienable birthright.

INALTERABLE
 (a.) Not alterable; incapable of being altered or changed; unalterable.

INATTENTIVE
 (a.) Not attentive; not fixing the mind on an object; heedless; careless; negligent; regardless; as, an inattentive spectator or hearer; an inattentive habit.

INAUGURATOR
 (n.) One who inaugurates.

INAUSPICATE
 (a.) Inauspicious.

INCALESCENT
 (a.) Growing warm; increasing in heat.

INCANESCENT
 (a.) Becoming hoary or gray; canescent.

INCARCERATE
 (v. t.) To imprison; to confine in a jail or prison.

INCARNADINE
 (v. t.) To dye red or crimson.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Incarnate

 (n.) An incarnate form; a personification; a manifestation; a reduction to apparent from; a striking exemplification in person or act.

 (adv.) In an inclusive manner.

 (n.) Alt. of Incoherency

INCOMMODITY
 (n.) Inconvenience; trouble; annoyance; disadvantage; encumbrance.

INCOMPETENT
 (a.) Wanting the legal or constitutional qualifications; inadmissible; as, a person professedly wanting in religious belief is an incompetent witness in a court of law or equity; incompetent evidence.

INCONFUSION
 (n.) Freedom from confusion; distinctness.

INCONGRUENT
 (a.) Incongruous.

INCONGRUOUS
 (a.) Not congruous; reciprocally disagreeing; not capable of harmonizing or readily assimilating; inharmonious; inappropriate; unsuitable; not fitting; inconsistent; improper; as, an incongruous remark; incongruous behavior, action, dress, etc.

INCONSCIOUS
 (a.) Unconscious.

INCONSTANCY
 (n.) The quality or state of being inconstant; want of constancy; mutability; fickleness; variableness.

INCONTESTED
 (a.) Not contested.

INCONTINENT
 (a.) Not continent; uncontrolled; not restraining the passions or appetites, particularly the sexual appetite; indulging unlawful lust; unchaste; lewd.

INCORPORATE
 (a.) Corporate; incorporated; made one body, or united in one body; associated; mixed together; combined; embodied.

INCORPORATE
 (v. t.) To unite with, or introduce into, a mass already formed; as, to incorporate copper with silver; -- used with with and into.

INCRASSATED
 (a.) Thickened; becoming thicker.

INCREDULOUS
 (a.) Indicating, or caused by, disbelief or incredulity.

 (n.) A teaching and impressing by frequent repetitions.

 (a.) Having no decidua; nondeciduate.

 (a.) Not defective; perfect; complete.

 (a.) Defenseless.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Indemnify

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Indenture

INDEPENDENT
 (a.) Not subject to bias or influence; not obsequious; self-directing; as, a man of an independent mind.

INDEPENDENT
 (a.) Not bound by party; exercising a free choice in voting with either or any party.

INDEPOSABLE
 (a.) Incapable of being deposed.

INDIFFERENT
 (a.) Not mal/ing a difference; having no influence or preponderating weight; involving no preference, concern, or attention; of no account; without significance or importance.

INDIFFERENT
 (adv.) To a moderate degree; passably; tolerably.

INDIGITATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Indigitate

INDIGNATION
 (n.) The feeling excited by that which is unworthy, base, or disgraceful; anger mingled with contempt, disgust, or abhorrence.

INDILIGENCE
 (n.) Want of diligence.

INDIRECTION
 (n.) Oblique course or means; dishonest practices; indirectness.

INDIVIDABLE
 (a.) Indivisible.

INDIVIDUATE
 (a.) Undivided.

INDIVISIBLE
 (a.) Not capable of exact division, as one quantity by another; incommensurable.

INDOMITABLE
 (a.) Not to be subdued; untamable; invincible; as, an indomitable will, courage, animal.

INDUCTRICAL
 (a.) Acting by, or in a state of, induction; relating to electrical induction.

INDUPLICATE
 (a.) Having the edges bent abruptly toward the axis; -- said of the parts of the calyx or corolla in aestivation.

INEBRIATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Inebriate

INEFFICIENT
 (a.) Incapable of, or indisposed to, effective action; habitually slack or remiss; effecting little or nothing; as, inefficient workmen; an inefficient administrator.

INELEGANCES
 (pl. ) of Inelegancy

INESTIMABLY
 (adv.) In a manner, or to a degree, above estimation; as, things inestimably excellent.

INEXCUSABLE
 (a.) Not excusable; not admitting excuse or justification; as, inexcusable folly.

INEXECUTION
 (n.) Neglect of execution; nonperformance; as, the inexecution of a treaty.

INEXPENSIVE
 (a.) Not expensive; cheap.

INFORMATIVE

INFRACTIBLE
 (a.) Capable of being broken.

INFRALABIAL
 (a.) Below the lower lip; -- said of certain scales of reptiles and fishes.

INFRASPINAL
 (a.) Below the spine; infraspinate; infraspinous.

INFREQUENCY
 (n.) The state of rarely occuring; uncommonness; rareness; as, the infrquence of his visits.

INFRUCTUOSE
 (a.) Not producing fruit; unfruitful; unprofitable.

INGANNATION

INGREDIENCE
 (n.) Alt. of Ingrediency

INHABITABLE
 (a.) Not habitable; not suitable to be inhabited.

INHERITABLE
 (a.) Capable of taking by inheritance, or of receiving by descent; capable of succeeding to, as an heir.

INHERITANCE
 (n.) Possession; ownership; acquisition.

INIMICALITY
 (n.) The state or quality of being inimical or hostile; hostility; unfriendliness.

INJUDICIOUS
 (a.) Not according to sound judgment or discretion; unwise; as, an injudicious measure.

INNERVATION
 (n.) Special activity excited in any part of the nervous system or in any organ of sense or motion; the nervous influence necessary for the maintenance of life,and the functions of the various organs.

INOBEDIENCE
 (n.) Disobedience.

INOFFENSIVE
 (a.) Not obstructing; presenting no interruption bindrance.

INOFFICIOUS
 (a.) Regardless of natural obligation; contrary to natural duty; unkind; -- commonly said of a testament made without regard to natural obligation, or by which a child is unjustly deprived of inheritance.

INOPERCULAR
 (a.) Alt. of Inoperculate

INQUISITION
 (n.) The finding of a jury, especially such a finding under a writ of inquiry.

INQUISITIVE
 (a.) Disposed to ask questions, especially in matters which do not concern the inquirer.

INSCRIPTION
 (n.) A line of division or intersection; as, the tendinous inscriptions, or intersections, of a muscle.

INSECTIVORA
 (n. pl.) An order of mammals which feed principally upon insects.

INSICCATION
 (n.) The act or process of drying in.

INSINUATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Insinuate

INSINUATION
 (n.) The act of gaining favor, affection, or influence, by gentle or artful means; -- formerly used in a good sense, as of friendly influence or interposition.

INSIPIDNESS
 (n.) The quality or state of being insipid; vapidity.

INSPECTRESS
 (n.) A female inspector.

INSPIRATION
 (n.) A supernatural divine influence on the prophets, apostles, or sacred writers, by which they were qualified to communicate moral or religious truth with authority; a supernatural influence which qualifies men to receive and communicate divine truth;

INSPIRITING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Inspirit

INSTALLMENT
 (n.) A portion of a debt, or sum of money, which is divided into portions that are made payable at different times. Payment by installment is payment by parts at different times, the amounts and times being often definitely stipulated.

INSTIGATION
 (n.) The act of instigating, or the state of being instigated; incitement; esp. to evil or wickedness.

INSTIMULATE
 (v. t.) Not to stimulate; to soothe; to quiet.

INSTITUTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Institute

INSTITUTION
 (n.) The act or ceremony of investing a clergyman with the spiritual part of a benefice, by which the care of souls is committed to his charge.

INSTITUTION
 (n.) That which institutes or instructs; a textbook; a system of elements or rules; an institute.

INSTRUCTION
 (n.) The act of instructing, teaching, or furnishing with knowledge; information.

INSTRUCTIVE
 (a.) Conveying knowledge; serving to instruct or inform; as, experience furnishes very instructive lessons.

INSULTATION
 (n.) The act of insulting; abusive or insolent treatment; insult.

INTEGRATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Integrate

INTEGRATION
 (n.) The operation of finding the primitive function which has a given function for its differential coefficient. See Integral.

INTELLIGENT
 (a.) Endowed with the faculty of understanding or reason; as, man is an intelligent being.

INTEMPERATE
 (a.) Specifically, addicted to an excessive or habitual use of alcoholic liquors.

INTENSATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Intensate

INTENSIFIER
 (n.) One who or that which intensifies or strengthens; in photography, an agent used to intensify the lights or shadows of a picture.

INTERAGENCY
 (n.) Intermediate agency.

INTERCALARY
 (a.) Inserted or introduced among others in the calendar; as, an intercalary month, day, etc.; -- now applied particularly to the odd day (Feb. 29) inserted in the calendar of leap year. See Bissextile, n.

INTERCALATE
 (v. t.) To insert among others, as a verse in a stanza; specif. (Geol.), to introduce as a bed or stratum, between the layers of a regular series of rocks.

INTERCHANGE
 (n.) The mutual exchange of commodities between two persons or countries; barter; commerce.

INTERDENTAL
 (a.) Situated between teeth; as, an interdental space, the space between two teeth in a gear wheel.

INTERESTING
 (a.) Engaging the attention; exciting, or adapted to excite, interest, curiosity, or emotion; as, an interesting story; interesting news.

INTERFERANT
 (n.) One of the contestants in interference before the Patent Office.

INTERFLUOUS
 (a.) Flowing between or among; intervening.

INTERMINATE

INTERREGENT

INTERRUPTED

IRREDUCIBLE

ISOCHRONOUS

 (n.) A similarity of crystalline form between substances of similar composition, as between the sulphates of barium (BaSO4) and strontium (SrSO4). It is sometimes extended to include similarity of form between substances of unlike composition, which is

ISOPODIFORM
 (a.) Having the shape of an isopod; -- said of the larvae of certain insects.

ISRAELITISH
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Israel, or to the Israelites; Jewish; Hebrew.

 (imp. & p. p.) of Jacobinize

 (n.) A dreamy, idle fellow.

LACHRYMABLE

LACTESCENCE
 (n.) The latex of certain plants. See Latex.

LACTIFEROUS
 (a.) Bearing or containing milk or a milky fluid; as, the lactiferous vessels, cells, or tissue of various vascular plants.

LACTUCARIUM
 (n.) The inspissated juice of the common lettuce, sometimes used as a substitute for opium.

LAMMERGEIER
 (n.) A very large vulture (Gypaetus barbatus), which inhabits the mountains of Southern Europe, Asia, and Northern Africa. When full-grown it is nine or ten feet in extent of wings. It is brownish black above, with the under parts and neck rusty yellow;

LANCINATION
 (n.) A tearing; laceration.

LANGUISHING
 (a.) Becoming languid and weak; pining; losing health and strength.

LAPIDARIOUS
 (a.) Consisting of stones.

LAPIDIFICAL
 (a.) Forming or converting into stone.

LARYNGOLOGY
 (n.) Systematized knowledge of the action and functions of the larynx; in pathology, the department which treats of the diseases of the larynx.

LASCIVIENCY
 (n.) Lasciviousness; wantonness.

 (a.) Alt. of Latifolious

 (n.) A large sea turtle (Sphargis coriacea), having no bony shell on its back. It is common in the warm and temperate parts of the Atlantic, and sometimes weighs over a thousand pounds; -- called also leather turtle, leathery turtle, leather-backed tort

LEATHERNECK
 (n.) The sordid friar bird of Australia (Tropidorhynchus sordidus).

LECANOMANCY
 (n.) divination practiced with water in a basin, by throwing three stones into it, and invoking the demon whose aid was sought.

 (a.) Like or pertaining to the dragon flies.

 (n.) A mineral of an olive-green color, commonly in orthorhombic crystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of copper.
