 (a.) Divided into, or consisting of, five parts; also, arranged in sets, with five parts in each set, as a flower with five sepals, five petals, five, or twice five, stamens, and five pistils.

PENTECOSTAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Pentecost or to Whitsuntide.

PEPPERGRASS
 (n.) Any herb of the cruciferous genus Lepidium, especially the garden peppergrass, or garden cress, Lepidium sativum; -- called also pepperwort. All the species have a pungent flavor.

PERAMBULATE
 (v. t.) To walk through or over; especially, to travel over for the purpose of surveying or examining; to inspect by traversing; specifically, to inspect officially the boundaries of, as of a town or parish, by walking over the whole line.

PERCEPTIBLE
 (a.) Capable of being perceived; cognizable; discernible; perceivable.

PERCOLATION
 (n.) The act or process of percolating, or filtering; filtration; straining. Specifically (Pharm.), the process of exhausting the virtues of a powdered drug by letting a liquid filter slowly through it.

PEREGRINITY
 (n.) Travel; wandering.

PERFECTIBLE
 (a.) Capable of becoming, or being made, perfect.

PERFORMANCE
 (n.) That which is performed or accomplished; a thing done or carried through; an achievement; a deed; an act; a feat; esp., an action of an elaborate or public character.

PERFUNCTORY
 (a.) Done merely to get rid of a duty; performed mechanically and as a thing of rote; done in a careless and superficial manner; characterized by indifference; as, perfunctory admonitions.

PERICLINIUM
 (n.) The involucre which surrounds the common receptacle in composite flowers.

PERICRANIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the pericranium.

PERIENTERON
 (n.) The primitive perivisceral cavity.

PERIPATETIC
 (n.) One who walks about; a pedestrian; an itinerant.

PERIPHERIES
 (pl. ) of Periphery

PERIPTEROUS
 (a.) Peripteral.

PERISPOMENA
 (pl. ) of Perispomenon

PERISTALTIC
 (a.) Applied to the peculiar wormlike wave motion of the intestines and other similar structures, produced by the successive contraction of the muscular fibers of their walls, forcing their contents onwards; as, peristaltic movement.

PERITONAEUM
 (n.) Same as Peritoneum.

PERMISSIBLE
 (a.) That may be permitted; allowable; admissible.

PERMUTATION
 (n.) The arrangement of any determinate number of things, as units, objects, letters, etc., in all possible orders, one after the other; -- called also alternation. Cf. Combination, n., 4.

PERSISTENCY
 (n.) Visual persistence, or persistence of the visual impression; auditory persistence, etc.

PERSONALITY
 (n.) That quality of a law which concerns the condition, state, and capacity of persons.

PERSONATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Personate

PERSPECTIVE
 (n.) Pertaining to the art, or in accordance with the laws, of perspective.

PERSPECTIVE
 (a.) A drawing in linear perspective.

PERSPICABLE
 (a.) Discernible.

PERSPICUOUS
 (a.) Capable of being through; transparent; translucent; not opaque.

PERSUASIBLE
 (a.) Persuasive.

PERSULPHIDE
 (n.) A sulphide containing more sulphur than some other compound of the same elements; as, iron pyrites is a persulphide; -- formerly called persulphuret.

PESTILATION
 (n.) The act of pounding and bruising with a pestle in a mortar.

PETIOLULATE
 (a.) Supported by its own petiolule.

PETITIONARY
 (a.) Supplicatory; making a petition.

PETTIFOGGER
 (n.) A lawyer who deals in petty cases; an attorney whose methods are mean and tricky; an inferior lawyer.

PHAENOGAMIC
 (a.) Same as Phaenogamous.

PHALANSTERY
 (n.) The dwelling house of a Fourierite community.

PHANTOMATIC
 (a.) Phantasmal.

PHASSACHATE
 (n.) The lead-colored agate; -- so called in reference to its color.

PHENOGAMIAN
 (a.) Alt. of Phenogamous

PHENYLAMINE
 (n.) Any one of certain class of organic bases regarded as formed from ammonia by the substitution of phenyl for hydrogen.

PHILLIPSITE
 (n.) A hydrous silicate of aluminia, lime, and soda, a zeolitic mineral commonly occurring in complex twin crystals, often cruciform in shape; -- called also christianite.

PHILOMATHIC
 (a.) Having love of learning or letters.

PHILOSOPHER
 (n.) An alchemist.

PHOTOPHOBIA
 (n.) A dread or intolerance of light.

PHOTOSPHERE
 (n.) A sphere of light; esp., the luminous envelope of the sun.

PHRENOLOGIC
 (a.) Phrenological.

PHTHALIMIDE
 (n.) An imido derivative of phthalic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance, C6H4.(CO)2NH, which has itself (like succinimide) acid properties, and forms a series of salts. Cf. Imido acid, under Imido.

PHYLLOTAXIS
 (n.) The order or arrangement of leaves on the stem; the science of the relative position of leaves.

PHYSICOLOGY
 (n.) Physics.

PHYSIOGNOMY
 (n.) The art telling fortunes by inspection of the features.

PHYSOCLISTI
 (n. pl.) An order of teleost in which the air bladder has no opening.

PHYTIVOROUS
 (a.) Feeding on plants or herbage; phytophagous; as, phytivorous animals.

PIGNORATION
 (n.) The act of pledging or pawning.

PILOCARPINE
 (n.) An alkaloid extracted from jaborandi (Pilocarpus pennatifolius) as a white amorphous or crystalline substance which has a peculiar effect on the vasomotor system.

PIPERACEOUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the order of plants (Piperaceae) of which the pepper (Piper nigrum) is the type. There are about a dozen genera and a thousand species, mostly tropical plants with pungent and aromatic qualities.

PLACENTALIA
 (n. pl.) A division of Mammalia including those that have a placenta, or all the orders above the marsupials.

PLAGIARIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Plagiarize

PLAGIHEDRAL
 (a.) Having an oblique spiral arrangement of planes, as levogyrate and dextrogyrate crystals.

PLANISPHERE
 (n.) The representation of the circles of the sphere upon a plane; especially, a representation of the celestial sphere upon a plane with adjustable circles, or other appendages, for showing the position of the heavens, the time of rising and setting of

PLANTIGRADE
 (a.) Having the foot so formed that the heel touches the ground when the leg is upright.

PLEASURABLE
 (a.) Capable of affording pleasure or satisfaction; gratifying; abounding in pleasantness or pleasantry.

PLEISTOCENE
 (n.) The Pleistocene epoch, or deposits.

PLEOCHROOUS
 (a.) Pleochroic.

PLESSIMETER
 (n.) See Pleximeter.

PLOUGHPOINT
 (n.) A detachable share at the extreme front end of the plow body.

PLUMILIFORM
 (a.) Having the of a plume or feather.

PLUMULARIAN
 (n.) Any Plumularia. Also used adjectively.

PNEUMATICAL
 (a.) Moved or worked by pressure or flow of air; as, a pneumatic instrument; a pneumatic engine.

PNEUMOGRAPH
 (n.) Same as Pneumatograph.

PNEUMONITIS
 (n.) Inflammation of the lungs; pneumonia.

PNEUMOPHORA
 (n. pl.) A division of holothurians having an internal gill, or respiratory tree.

PODOPHYLLIN
 (n.) A brown bitter gum extracted from the rootstalk of the May apple (Podophyllum peltatum). It is a complex mixture of several substances.

POLARISCOPE
 (n.) An instrument consisting essentially of a polarizer and an analyzer, used for polarizing light, and analyzing its properties.

POLYARCHIST
 (n.) One who advocates polyarchy; -- opposed to monarchist.

POLYCHROISM
 (n.) Same as Pleochroism.

POLYCYSTINE
 (n.) One of the Polycystina.

POLYMATHIST
 (n.) One versed in many sciences; a person of various learning.

POLYMORPHIC
 (a.) Polymorphous.

POLYPHAGOUS
 (a.) Eating, or subsisting on, many kinds of food; as, polyphagous animals.

POLYPHONIST
 (n.) A proficient in the art of multiplying sounds; a ventriloquist.

POLYPLASTIC
 (a.) Assuming, or having the power of assuming, many forms; as, a polyplastic element which does not preserve its original shape.

PONDEROSITY
 (n.) The quality or state of being ponderous; weight; gravity; heaviness, ponderousness; as, the ponderosity of gold.

POPULARIZER
 (n.) One who popularizes.

PORNOGRAPHY
 (n.) A treatise on prostitutes, or prostitution.

PORTABILITY
 (n.) The quality or state of being portable; fitness to be carried.

PORTRAITURE
 (v. t.) To represent by a portrait, or as by a portrait; to portray.

POSSIBILITY
 (n.) That which is possible; a contingency; a thing or event that may not happen; a contingent interest, as in real or personal estate.

POSTFRONTAL
 (a.) Situated behind the frontal bone or the frontal region of the skull; -- applied especially to a bone back of and below the frontal in many animals.

POSTGLENOID
 (a.) Situated behind the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone.

POTASSAMIDE
 (n.) A yellowish brown substance obtained by heating potassium in ammonia.

PRACTICABLE
 (a.) That may be practiced or performed; capable of being done or accomplished with available means or resources; feasible; as, a practicable method; a practicable aim; a practicable good.

PRACTICALLY
 (adv.) Almost.

PRAGMATICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to business or to affairs; of the nature of business; practical; material; businesslike in habit or manner.

PRECEDENTLY
 (adv.) Beforehand; antecedently.

PRECELLENCY
 (n.) Excellence; superiority.

PRECIPITANT
 (a.) Unexpectedly or foolishly brought on or hastened; rashly hurried; hasty; sudden; reckless.

PRECIPITATE
 (a.) Lacking due deliberation or care; hurried; said or done before the time; as, a precipitate measure.

PRECIPITATE
 (v. i.) To hasten without preparation.

PRECIPITOUS
 (a.) Headlong; as, precipitous fall.

PRECOGITATE
 (v. t.) To cogitate beforehand.

PRECONTRACT
 (n.) A contract preceding another

PREDESTINED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Predestine

PREDICAMENT
 (n.) A class or kind described by any definite marks; hence, condition; particular situation or state; especially, an unfortunate or trying position or condition.

PREDICATIVE
 (a.) Expressing affirmation or predication; affirming; predicating, as, a predicative term.

PREELECTION
 (n.) Election beforehand.

PREEXAMINED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Preexamine

PREFATORIAL
 (a.) Prefatory.

PREFIGURATE
 (v. t.) To prefigure.

PRELIBATION
 (n.) A pouring out, or libation, before tasting.

PREMONISHED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Premonish

PRENOMINATE
 (v. t.) To forename; to name beforehand; to tell by name beforehand.

PRENUNCIOUS
 (a.) Announcing beforehand; presaging.

PREOCCUPATE
 (v. t.) To prepossess; to prejudice.

PREORDINATE
 (a.) Preordained.

PREPARATION
 (n.) That which makes ready, prepares the way, or introduces; a preparatory act or measure.

PREPARATIVE
 (a.) Tending to prepare or make ready; having the power of preparing, qualifying, or fitting; preparatory.

PREPARATORY
 (a.) Preparing the way for anything by previous measures of adaptation; antecedent and adapted to what follows; introductory; preparative; as, a preparatory school; a preparatory condition.

PREPOSITIVE
 (a.) Put before; prefixed; as, a prepositive particle.

PRESCAPULAR
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the prescapula; supraspinous.

PRESENTIFIC
 (a.) Making present.

PRESENTMENT
 (n.) Setting forth to view; delineation; appearance; representation; exhibition.

PRESERVABLE
 (a.) Capable of being preserved; admitting of preservation.

PRESPHENOID
 (n.) The presphenoid bone.

PRESUMPTION
 (n.) The act of presuming, or believing upon probable evidence; the act of assuming or taking for granted; belief upon incomplete proof.

PRESUMPTIVE
 (a.) Presumptuous; arrogant.

PRETEMPORAL
 (a.) Situated in front of the temporal bone.

PRETENDENCE
 (n.) The act of pretending; pretense.

PRETERITION
 (n.) The omission by a testator of some one of his heirs who is entitled to a portion.

PREVARICATE
 (v. t.) To evade by a quibble; to transgress; to pervert.

PRICKLEBACK
 (n.) Alt. of Pricklefish

PRIESTCRAFT
 (n.) Priestly policy; the policy of a priesthood; esp., in an ill sense, fraud or imposition in religious concerns; management by priests to gain wealth and power by working upon the religious motives or credulity of others.

PRIMIGENIAL
 (a.) First born, or first of all; original; primary. See Primogenial.

PRIMITIVELY
 (adv.) According to the original rule or ancient practice; in the ancient style.

PRIMORDIATE
 (a.) Primordial.

PRINCIPALLY
 (adv.) In a principal manner; primarily; above all; chiefly; mainly.

PRINCIPIANT
 (a.) Relating to principles or beginnings.

PRINCIPLING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Principle

PROBABILIST
 (n.) One who maintains that a man may do that which has a probability of being right, or which is inculcated by teachers of authority, although other opinions may seem to him still more probable.

PROBATIONER
 (n.) One who is undergoing probation; one who is on trial; a novice.

PROCEPHALIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or forming, the front of the head.

PROCRASTINE
 (v. t.) To procrastinate.

PRODIGALIZE
 (v. t.) To expend lavishly.

PRODUCEMENT
 (n.) Production.

PROEMPTOSIS
 (n.) The addition of a day to the lunar calendar.

PROGRESSING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Progress

PROGRESSION
 (n.) Course; passage; lapse or process of time.

PROJECTMENT
 (n.) Design; contrivance; projection.

PROLETARIAT
 (n.) The indigent class in the State; the body of proletarians.

PROLIFERATE
 (v. t.) To produce or form cells; especially, to produce cells rapidly.

PROLIFEROUS
 (a.) Producing young by budding.

PROLONGATED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Prolongate

PRONOUNGING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Pronounce

PROPAGATION
 (n.) The spreading abroad, or extension, of anything; diffusion; dissemination; as, the propagation of sound; the propagation of the gospel.

PROPINQUITY
 (n.) Nearness in time.

PROPITIABLE
 (a.) Capable of being propitiated.

PROPLASTICS
 (n.) The art of making molds for castings.

PROPOSITION
 (n.) The act of setting or placing before; the act of offering.

PROPOSITION
 (n.) That which is offered or affirmed as the subject of the discourse; anything stated or affirmed for discussion or illustration.

PROPRIETARY
 (n.) A proprietor or owner; one who has exclusive title to a thing; one who possesses, or holds the title to, a thing in his own right.

PROROGATION
 (n.) The act of counting in duration; prolongation.

PROSECUTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Prosecute

PROSELYTING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Proselyte

PROSEMINARY
 (n.) A seminary which prepares pupils for a higher institution.

PROSENCHYMA
 (n.) A general term applied to the tissues formed of elongated cells, especially those with pointed or oblique extremities, as the principal cells of ordinary wood.

PROSPECTIVE
 (n.) The scene before or around, in time or in space; view; prospect.

PROSTATITIS
 (n.) Inflammation of the prostate.

PROSTRATION
 (n.) The act of falling down, or of bowing in humility or adoration; primarily, the act of falling on the face, but usually applied to kneeling or bowing in reverence and worship.

PROTAGONIST
 (n.) One who takes the leading part in a drama; hence, one who takes lead in some great scene, enterprise, conflict, or the like.

PROTEOLYSIS
 (n.) The digestion or dissolving of proteid matter by proteolytic ferments.

PROTONOTARY
 (n.) A chief notary or clerk.

PROTOCOLIST
 (n.) One who draughts protocols.

PROTOMARTYR
 (n.) The first martyr; the first who suffers, or is sacrificed, in any cause; -- applied esp. to Stephen, the first Christian martyr.

PROTONOTARY
 (n.) Same as Prothonotary.

PROTRACTION
 (n.) A drawing out, or continuing; the act of delaying the termination of a thing; prolongation; continuance; delay; as, the protraction of a debate.

PROTRUDABLE
 (a.) That may be protruded; protrusile.

PROTUBERATE
 (v. i.) To swell, or be prominent, beyond the adjacent surface; to bulge out.

PROVIDENTLY
 (adv.) In a provident manner.

PROVOCATION
 (n.) Such prior insult or injury as may be supposed, under the circumstances, to create hot blood, and to excuse an assault made in retort or redress.

PROVOCATORY
 (a.) Provocative.

PRURIGINOUS
 (a.) Tending to, or caused by, prurigo; affected by, or of the nature of, prurigo.

PSEUDOMORPH
 (n.) An irregular or deceptive form.

PSILOMELANE
 (n.) A hydrous oxide of manganese, occurring in smooth, botryoidal forms, and massive, and having an iron-black or steel-gray color.

PSYCHAGOGUE
 (n.) A necromancer.

PSYCHOLOGUE
 (n.) A psychologist.

PSYCHOMETRY
 (n.) The art of measuring the duration of mental processes, or of determining the time relations of mental phenomena.

PTENOGLOSSA
 (n. pl.) A division of gastropod mollusks having the teeth of the radula arranged in long transverse rows, somewhat like the barbs of a feather.

PTEROPODOUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Pteropoda.

PTEROSTIGMA
 (n.) A thickened opaque spot on the wings of certain insects.

PTILOPAEDIC
 (a.) Having nearly the whole surface of the skin covered with down; dasypaedic; -- said of the young of certain birds.

PUBLICATION
 (n.) An act done in public.

PUBLISHMENT
 (n.) The act or process of making publicly known; publication.

PUERILENESS
 (n.) The quality of being puerile; puerility.

PUNCTICULAR
 (a.) Comprised in, or like, a point; exact.

PUNCTUATIVE
 (a.) Of or belonging to points of division; relating to punctuation.

PURGATORIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to purgatory; expiatory.

PURPORTLESS
 (a.) Without purport or meaning.

PURSIVENESS
 (n.) Pursiness.

PYOXANTHOSE
 (n.) A greenish yellow crystalline coloring matter found with pyocyanin in pus.

PYRAMIDALLY
 (adv.) Like a pyramid.

PYROLIGNOUS
 (a.) Same as Pyroligneous.

PYROXANTHIN
 (n.) A yellow crystalline hydrocardon extracted from crude wood spirit; -- called also eblanin.

PYTHAGOREAN
 (n.) A follower of Pythagoras; one of the school of philosophers founded by Pythagoras.

QUADRENNIUM
 (n.) A space or period of four years.

QUADRIVALVE
 (a.) Dehiscent into four similar parts; four-valved; as, a quadrivalve pericarp.

QUARTERFOIL
 (n.) An ornamental foliation having four lobes, or foils.

QUERMONIOUS
 (a.) Complaining; querulous; apt to complain.

QUESTIONARY
 (a.) Inquiring; asking questions; testing.

QUIBBLINGLY
 (adv.) Triflingly; evasively.

QUINCUNCIAL
 () Having the leaves of a pentamerous calyx or corolla so imbricated that two are exterior, two are interior, and the other has one edge exterior and one interior; as, quincuncial aestivation.

QUINDECAGON
 (n.) A plane figure with fifteen angles, and consequently fifteen sides.

QUINQUEREME
 (n.) A galley having five benches or banks of oars; as, an Athenian quinquereme.

QUINQUEVIRI
 (pl. ) of Quinquevir

QUIRITATION
 (n.) A crying for help.

RADIOLARIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Radiolaria.

RATIONALISM
 (n.) The doctrine or system of those who deduce their religious opinions from reason or the understanding, as distinct from, or opposed to, revelation.

RATIONALITY
 (n.) The quality or state of being rational; agreement with reason; possession of reason; due exercise of reason; reasonableness.

RATIONALIZE
 (v. t.) To render rational; to free from radical signs or quantities.

RATTLEWINGS
 (n.) The golden-eye.

REACTIONARY
 (a.) Being, causing, or favoring reaction; as, reactionary movements.

READMISSION
 (n.) The act of admitting again, or the state of being readmitted; as, the readmission of fresh air into an exhausted receiver; the readmission of a student into a seminary.

REAPPORTION
 (v. t.) To apportion again.

RECEPTACULA
 (pl. ) of Receptaculum

RECEPTIVITY
 (n.) The power or capacity of receiving impressions, as those of the external senses.

RECIPROCATE
 (v. t.) To give and return mutually; to make return for; to give in return; to interchange; to alternate; as, to reciprocate favors.

RECLAIMABLE
 (a.) That may be reclaimed.

RECLAMATION
 (n.) Representation made in opposition; remonstrance.

RECLINATION
 (n.) The angle which the plane of the dial makes with a vertical plane which it intersects in a horizontal line.

RECLUSENESS
 (n.) Quality or state of being recluse.

RECOMPENSED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Recompense

RECOURSEFUL
 (a.) Having recurring flow and ebb; moving alternately.

RECOVERABLE
 (a.) Capable of being recovered or regained; capable of being brought back to a former condition, as from sickness, misfortune, etc.; obtainable from a debtor or possessor; as, the debt is recoverable; goods lost or sunk in the ocean are not recoverable

RECTILINEAL
 (a.) Alt. of Rectilinear

REDOUBTABLE
 (a.) Formidable; dread; terrible to foes; as, a redoubtable hero; hence, valiant; -- often in contempt or burlesque.

REDUCTIVELY
 (adv.) By reduction; by consequence.

REDUPLICATE
 (a.) Valvate with the margins curved outwardly; -- said of the /stivation of certain flowers.

REENACTMENT
 (n.) The enacting or passing of a law a second time; the renewal of a law.

REFORMATORY
 (a.) Tending to produce reformation; reformative.

REFRACTABLE
 (a.) Capable of being refracted.

REFRENATION
 (v. t.) The act of refraining.

REFRESHMENT
 (n.) The act of refreshing, or the state of being refreshed; restoration of strength, spirit, vigor, or liveliness; relief after suffering; new life or animation after depression.

REFRIGERANT
 (a.) Cooling; allaying heat or fever.

REFRIGERIUM
 (n.) Cooling refreshment; refrigeration.

REGENERATOR
 (n.) A device used in connection with hot-air engines, gas-burning furnaces, etc., in which the incoming air or gas is heated by being brought into contact with masses of iron, brick, etc., which have been previously heated by the outgoing, or escaping,

REGISTERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Register

REGISTERING
 (a.) Recording; -- applied to instruments; having an apparatus which registers; as, a registering thermometer. See Recording.

REGULARNESS
 (n.) Regularity.

 (a.) Admitting of being compared; like.

 (adv.) With deep sense or strong perception.

 (n.) Something withheld, either not expressed or disclosed, or not given up or brought forward.

RESERVATION
 (n.) The portion of the sacramental elements reserved for purposes of devotion and for the communion of the absent and sick.

RESIDENTIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to a residence or residents; as, residential trade.

RESIGNATION
 (n.) The state of being resigned or submissive; quiet or patient submission; unresisting acquiescence; as, resignation to the will and providence of God.

RESINACEOUS
 (a.) Having the quality of resin; resinous.

RESPECTUOUS
 (a.) Respectable.

RESPITELESS
 (a.) Without respite.

RESTITUTION
 (v.) The act of restoring anything to its rightful owner, or of making good, or of giving an equivalent for any loss, damage, or injury; indemnification.

RESTRAINING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Restrain

RETARDATIVE
 (a.) Tending, or serving, to retard.

RETICULARIA
 (n. pl.) An extensive division of rhizopods in which the pseudopodia are more or less slender and coalesce at certain points, forming irregular meshes. It includes the shelled Foraminifera, together with some groups which lack a T shell.

RETICULATED
 (a.) Having veins, fibers, or lines crossing like the threads or fibers of a network; as, a reticulate leaf; a reticulated surface; a reticulated wing of an insect.

RETINACULUM
 (n.) A small gland or process to which bodies are attached; as, the glandular retinacula to which the pollinia of orchids are attached, or the hooks which support the seeds in many acanthaceous plants.

RETRACTABLE
 (a.) Capable of being retracted; retractile.

RETRENCHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Retrench

RETRIBUTORY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to retribution; of the nature of retribution; involving retribution or repayment; as, retributive justice; retributory comforts.

RETROVERTED
 (a.) In a state of retroversion.

REVALESCENT
 (a.) Growing well; recovering strength.

REVENGEABLE
 (a.) Capable of being revenged; as, revengeable wrong.

REVERBERATE
 (v. i.) To be driven back; to be reflected or repelled, as rays of light; to be echoed, as sound.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Reverence

REVERSELESS
 (a.) Irreversible.

 (n.) Alt. of Rhabarbarine

RHABDOMANCY

RHACHIALGIA

RHIPIPTERAN
 (n.) Same as Rhipipter.

RHOPALOCERA
 (n. pl.) A division of Lepidoptera including all the butterflies. They differ from other Lepidoptera in having club-shaped antennae.

RIGHTEOUSED
 (a.) Made righteous.

RINFORZANDO
 (a.) Increasing; strengthening; -- a direction indicating a sudden increase of force (abbreviated rf., rfz.) Cf. Forzando, and Sforzando.

RODOMONTADE
 (v. i.) To boast; to brag; to bluster; to rant.

ROSICRUCIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Rosicrucians, or their arts.

RUBBLESTONE
 (n.) See Rubble, 1 and 2.

RUBEFACIENT
 (n.) An external application which produces redness of the skin.

RUSTICATION
 (n.) The act of rusticating, or the state of being rusticated; specifically, the punishment of a student for some offense, by compelling him to leave the institution for a time.

SABBATARIAN
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Sabbath, or the tenets of Sabbatarians.

SABBATHLESS
 (a.) Without Sabbath, or intermission of labor; hence, without respite or rest.

SACCHULMATE
 (n.) A salt of sacchulmic acid.

SACCOGLOSSA
 (n. pl.) Same as Pellibranchiata.

SACRAMENTAL
 (a.) Bound by a sacrament.

SACRIFICANT
 (n.) One who offers a sacrifice.

SACRIFICIAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to sacrifice or sacrifices; consisting in sacrifice; performing sacrifice.

SADDLECLOTH
 (n.) A cloth under a saddle, and extending out behind; a housing.

 (a.) Same as Saltatorious.

 (n.) The character and qualities of a scholar; attainments in science or literature; erudition; learning.

SCHOTTISCHE
 (n.) A Scotch round dance in 02.04.02 time, similar to the polka, only slower; also, the music for such a dance; -- not to be confounded with the Ecossaise.

 (a.) Pertaining to, or traversed in, six hours, or in half the time between the rising and setting of a heavenly body; as, a semidiurnal arc.

 (adv.) In a semimonthly manner; at intervals of half a month.

 (n.) A genus of climbing asclepiadaceous shrubs, of Madagascar, Malaya, etc. They have fleshy or coriaceous opposite leaves, and large white waxy flowers in cymes.

 (n.) Any picture, or pair of pictures, prepared for exhibition in the stereoscope. Stereographs are now commonly made by means of photography.

TEREBRATULA
 (n.) A genus of brachiopods which includes many living and some fossil species. The larger valve has a perforated beak, through which projects a short peduncle for attachment. Called also lamp shell.

TERMINOLOGY

TERRAQUEOUS

THUNDERBIRD
 (n.) An Australian insectivorous singing bird (Pachycephala gutturalis). The male is conspicuously marked with black and yellow, and has a black crescent on the breast. Called also white-throated thickhead, orange-breasted thrust, black-crowned thrush,

THUNDERHEAD
 (n.) A rounded mass of cloud, with shining white edges; a cumulus, -- often appearing before a thunderstorm.

THYSANUROUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Thysanura.

TIBIOTARSUS
 (n.) The large bone between the femur and tarsometatarsus in the leg of a bird. It is formed by the union of the proximal part of the tarsus with the tibia.

 (n.) That which occasions distress, trouble, or vexation; severe affliction.

 (a.) Of or pertaining to tribunes; befitting a tribune; as, tribunitial power or authority.

TRICHOPHORE
 (n.) The special cell in red algae which produces or bears a trichogyne. See Illust. of Trichogyne.

TRIMORPHOUS
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or characterized by, trimorphism; -- contrasted with monomorphic, dimorphic, and polymorphic.

TRIPLOIDITE
 (n.) A manganese phosphate near triplite, but containing hydroxyl instead of fluorine.

TRIRADIATED
 (a.) Having three rays.

TRISPERMOUS
 (a.) Containing three seeds; three-seeded; as, a trispermous capsule.

TROGLODYTES
 (n.) A genus of apes including the chimpanzee.

TROTHPLIGHT
 (a.) Betrothed; espoused; affianced.

TRUCULENTLY
 (adv.) In a truculent manner.

TRUMPETWEED
 (n.) An herbaceous composite plant (Eupatorium purpureum), often having hollow stems, and bearing purplish flowers in small corymbed heads.

TRUNDLEHEAD
 (n.) One of the disks forming the ends of a lantern wheel or pinion.

TRUTINATION
 (n.) The act of weighing.

TUBICORNOUS
 (a.) Having hollow horns.

 (n.) The practice of seeking after, and hanging on, noblemen, or persons of quality, especially in English universities.

 (a.) Having woolly or crispy hair; -- opposed to leiotrichous.

 (a.) Casting or making a shade; umbrageous.

 (a.) Contrary to Christianity; not like or becoming a Christian; as, unchristian conduct.

UNCONSCIOUS
 (a.) Not conscious; having no consciousness or power of mental perception; without cerebral appreciation; hence, not knowing or regarding; ignorant; as, an unconscious man.

UNCONTINENT
 (a.) Not continent; incontinent.

UNCONVERTED
 (a.) Not persuaded of the truth of the Christian religion; heathenish.

 (a.) Incapable of being daunted; intrepid; fearless; indomitable.

 (a.) Arbitrary; despotic.

ARBORESCENCE
 (n.) The state of being arborescent; the resemblance to a tree in minerals, or crystallizations, or groups of crystals in that form; as, the arborescence produced by precipitating silver.

ARBORIZATION
 (n.) The appearance or figure of a tree or plant, as in minerals or fossils; a dendrite.

ARCHIPELAGIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to an archipelago.

ARCHITECTIVE
 (a.) Used in building; proper for building.

ARCHITEUTHIS
 (n.) A genus of gigantic cephalopods, allied to the squids, found esp. in the North Atlantic and about New Zealand.

ARGUMENTABLE
 (a.) Admitting of argument.

ARISTOCRATIC
 (a.) Alt. of Aristocratical

ARISTOPHANIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to Aristophanes, the Athenian comic poet.

ARITHMETICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to arithmetic; according to the rules or method of arithmetic.

ARITHMOMANCY
 (n.) Arithmancy.

ARTHROGRAPHY
 (n.) The description of joints.

ARTHROPLEURA
 (n.) The side or limb-bearing portion of an arthromere.

ARTHROPOMATA
 (n. pl.) One of the orders of Branchiopoda. See Branchiopoda.

ARTICULATELY
 (adv.) Article by article; in distinct particulars; in detail; definitely.

ARTICULATION
 (n.) A joint or juncture between bones in the skeleton.

ARTICULATION
 (n.) One of the parts intercepted between the joints; also, a subdivision into parts at regular or irregular intervals as a result of serial intermission in growth, as in the cane, grasses, etc.

ARTICULATION
 (n.) The utterance of the elementary sounds of a language by the appropriate movements of the organs, as in pronunciation; as, a distinct articulation.

ARTIFICIALLY
 (adv.) Ingeniously; skillfully.

ARTIODACTYLE
 (n.) One of the Artiodactyla.

ASCIDIOZOOID
 (n.) One of the individual members of a compound ascidian. See Ascidioidea.

ASSASSINATOR
 (n.) An assassin.

ASSESSORSHIP
 (n.) The office or function of an assessor.

ASSEVERATION
 (n.) The act of asseverating, or that which is asseverated; positive affirmation or assertion; solemn declaration.

ASSIMILATION
 (n.) The act or process of assimilating or bringing to a resemblance, likeness, or identity; also, the state of being so assimilated; as, the assimilation of one sound to another.

ASSIMILATORY
 (a.) Tending to assimilate, or produce assimilation; as, assimilatory organs.

ASSIMULATION
 (n.) Assimilation.

ASTIPULATION
 (n.) Stipulation; agreement.

ASTONISHMENT
 (n.) The overpowering emotion excited when something unaccountable, wonderful, or dreadful is presented to the mind; an intense degree of surprise; amazement.

ASTRONOMICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to astronomy; in accordance with the methods or principles of astronomy.

ATHEROMATOUS
 (a.) Of, pertaining to, or having the nature of, atheroma.

ATTORNEYSHIP
 (n.) The office or profession of an attorney; agency for another.

ATTRIBUTABLE
 (a.) Capable of being attributed; ascribable; imputable.

AUGMENTATION
 (n.) The state of being augmented; enlargement.

AUGMENTATION
 (n.) The stage of a disease in which the symptoms go on increasing.

AUGMENTATIVE
 (n.) A word which expresses with augmented force the idea or the properties of the term from which it is derived; as, dullard, one very dull. Opposed to diminutive.

AUSCULTATION
 (n.) The act of listening or hearkening to.

AUSCULTATORY
 (a.) Of or pertaining to auscultation.

AUTHENTICITY
 (n.) The quality of being authentic or of established authority for truth and correctness.

AUTOMORPHISM
 (n.) Automorphic characterization.

AVAILABILITY
 (n.) The quality of being available; availableness.

BACCHANALIAN
 (n.) A bacchanal; a drunken reveler.

BACTERICIDAL

 (n. pl.) An order of Entomostraca; -- so named from the feet of branchiopods having been supposed to perform the function of gills. It includes the fresh-water genera Branchipus, Apus, and Limnadia, and the genus Artemia found in salt lakes. It is also

COELENTERATA
 (n. pl.) A comprehensive group of Invertebrata, mostly marine, comprising the Anthozoa, Hydrozoa, and Ctenophora. The name implies that the stomach and body cavities are one. The group is sometimes enlarged so as to include the sponges.

 (n.) A state of the bowels in which the evacuations are infrequent and difficult, or the intestines become filled with hardened faeces; costiveness.

 (n.) That which is contributed; -- either the portion which an individual furnishes to the common stock, or the whole which is formed by the gifts of individuals.

CONTRIBUTORY
 (a.) Contributing to the same stock or purpose; promoting the same end; bringing assistance to some joint design, or increase to some common stock; contributive.

CONTRITENESS
 (n.) Deep sorrow and penitence for sin; contrition.

CONTRITURATE
 (v. t.) To triturate; to pulverize.

CONTROLLABLE
 (a.) Capable of being controlled, checked, or restrained; amenable to command.

CONTROVERSAL
 (a.) Controversial.

 (n.) A controverser.

 (a.) Living or messing together; familiar; in companionship.

 (a.) Exhibiting contumely; rudely contemptuous; insolent; disdainful.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Convalesce

CONVALESCENT
 (a.) Of or pertaining to convalescence.

CONVECTIVELY
 (adv.) In a convective manner.

CONVENTIONAL
 (a.) Formed by agreement or compact; stipulated.

CONVENTIONAL
 (a.) Abstracted; removed from close representation of nature by the deliberate selection of what is to be represented and what is to be rejected; as, a conventional flower; a conventional shell. Cf. Conventionalize, v. t.

CONVERSATION
 (n.) General course of conduct; behavior.

CONVERSATION

 (pl. ) of Convolvulus

CONVULSIVELY
 (adv.) in a convulsive manner.

COUNTTENANCE

 (p. p.) of Counterdraw

 (a.) Adorned with flowers (usually fleurs-de-lis) so divided that the tops appear on one side and the bottoms on the others; -- said of any ordinary.

 (n.) An opposing force.

 (n.) A marching back; retrocession.

 (n.) An opposite point

 (n.) Music in parts; part writing; harmony; polyphonic music. See Polyphony.

COUNTERPOISE
 (n.) A weight sufficient to balance another, as in the opposite scale of a balance; an equal weight.

COUNTERSCALE

COUNTERSHAFT

COUNTERSTAND
 (n.) Resistance; opposition; a stand against.

COUNTERWHEEL
 (v. t.) To cause to wheel or turn in an opposite direction.

 (a.) Having a curved or crooked tail.

DYNAMOMETRIC
 (a.) Alt. of Dynamometrical

DYSTELEOLOGY
 (n.) The doctrine of purposelessness; a term applied by Haeckel to that branch of physiology which treats of rudimentary organs, in view of their being useless to the life of the organism.

EBULLIOSCOPE
 (n.) An instrument for observing the boiling point of liquids, especially for determining the alcoholic strength of a mixture by the temperature at which it boils.

ECCENTRICITY

ECCENTRICITY
 (n.) The distance of the center of figure of a body, as of an eccentric, from an axis about which it turns; the throw.

ECCLESIASTIC

ECHINODERMAL
 (a.) Relating or belonging to the echinoderms.

ECSTATICALLY
 (adv.) Rapturously; ravishingly.

ECTOPARASITE
 (n.) Any parasite which lives on the exterior of animals; -- opposed to endoparasite.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Effloresce

 (a.) Of or pertaining to electrogenesis; as, an electrogenic condition.

ELEXTROMETRY
 (n.) The art or process of making electrical measurements.

ELECTROPHORI
 (pl. ) of Electrophorus

ELECTROPLATE
 (v. t.) To plate or cover with a coating of metal, usually silver, nickel, or gold, by means of electrolysis.

ELECTROSCOPE
 (n.) An instrument for detecting the presence of electricity, or changes in the electric state of bodies, or the species of electricity present, as by means of pith balls, and the like.

ELEEMOSYNARY
 (a.) Given in charity or alms; having the nature of alms; as, eleemosynary assistance.

ELEEMOSYNARY
 (n.) One who subsists on charity; a dependent.

ELEMENTALITY
 (n.) The condition of being composed of elements, or a thing so composed.

ELLIPTICALLY
 (adv.) In the form of an ellipse.

ELLIPTOGRAPH
 (n.) Same as Ellipsograph.

ELOCUTIONIST
 (n.) One who is versed in elocution; a teacher of elocution.

EMANCIPATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Emancipate

EMARGINATION
 (n.) The act of notching or indenting the margin, or the state of being so notched; also, a notch or shallow sinus in a margin.

EMASCULATION
 (n.) The act of depriving of virility, or the state of being so deprived; castration.

EMASCULATORY
 (a.) Serving or tending to emasculate.

EMBATTLEMENT
 (n.) An intended parapet; a battlement.

EMBLAZONRIES
 (pl. ) of Emblazonry

EMBLEMATICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, containing, or consisting in, an emblem; symbolic; typically representative; representing as an emblem; as, emblematic language or ornaments; a crown is emblematic of royalty; white is emblematic of purity.

EMBLEMATIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Emblematize

EMBROIDERING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Embroider

EMBROIDERIES
 (pl. ) of Embroidery

EMBRYOGRAPHY
 (n.) The general description of embryos.

EMBRYOLOGIST
 (n.) One skilled in embryology.

EMBRYONIFORM
 (a.) Like an embryo in form.

EMISSARYSHIP
 (n.) The office of an emissary.

EMPASSIONATE
 (a.) Strongly affected.

EMPHATICALLY
 (adv.) With emphasis; forcibly; in a striking manner or degree; preeminently.

EMPOISONMENT
 (n.) The act of poisoning.

EMPYREUMATIC
 (a.) Alt. of Empyreumatical

ENALIOSAURIA
 (n. pl.) An extinct group of marine reptiles, embracing both the Ichthyosauria and the Plesiosauria, now regarded as distinct orders.

ENANTIOPATHY
 (n.) Allopathy; -- a term used by followers of Hahnemann, or homeopathists.

ENCLITICALLY
 (adv.) In an enclitic manner; by throwing the accent back.

ENCRINITICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to encrinites; encrinal.

ENCROACHMENT
 (n.) That which is taken by encroaching on another.

ENCYCLOPEDIC
 (a.) Alt. of Encyclopedical

ENDENIZATION
 (n.) The act of naturalizing.

ENDERMICALLY
 (adv.) By the endermic method; as, applied endermically.

ENDOGENOUSLY
 (adv.) By endogenous growth.

ENDOMETRITIS
 (n.) Inflammation of the endometrium.

ENDOPHYLLOUS
 (a.) Wrapped up within a leaf or sheath.

ENDOSKELETON
 (n.) The bony, cartilaginous, or other internal framework of an animal, as distinguished from the exoskeleton.

ENFEEBLEMENT
 (n.) The act of weakening; enervation; weakness.

ENFRANCHISER
 (n.) One who enfranchises.

ENGLISHWOMAN
 (n.) Fem. of Englishman.

ENGRAFTATION
 (n.) Alt. of Engraftment

ENHARMONICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to a scale of perfect intonation which recognizes all the notes and intervals that result from the exact tuning of diatonic scales and their transposition into other keys.

ENKERCHIEFED
 (a.) Bound with a kerchief; draped; hooded; covered.

ENORMOUSNESS
 (n.) The state of being enormous.

ENSLAVEDNESS
 (n.) State of being enslaved.

ENSWATHEMENT
 (n.) The act of enswathing, or the state of being enswathed.

ENTANGLEMENT
 (n.) State of being entangled; intricate and confused involution; that which entangles; intricacy; perplexity.

ENTERPRISING
 (a.) Having a disposition for enterprise; characterized by enterprise; resolute, active or prompt to attempt; as, an enterprising man or firm.

ENTHRONEMENT
 (n.) The act of enthroning, or state of being enthroned.

ENTHRONIZING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Enthronize

ENTOMOLOGIES
 (pl. ) of Entomology

ENTOMOPHAGAN
 (a.) Relating to the Entomophaga.

ENTOPLASTRON
 (n.) The median plate of the plastron of turtles; -- called also entosternum.

ENTRANCEMENT
 (n.) The act of entrancing, or the state of trance or ecstasy.

EPANASTROPHE
 (n.) Same as Anadiplosis.

EPANORTHOSIS
 (n.) A figure by which a speaker recalls a word or words, in order to substitute something else stronger or more significant; as, Most brave! Brave, did I say? most heroic act!

EPENCEPHALIC
 (a.) Situated on or over the brain.

EPIBRANCHIAL
 (a.) Pertaining to the segment between the ceratobranchial and pharyngobranchial in a branchial arch.

EPICHIREMATA
 (pl. ) of Epichirema

EPICYCLOIDAL
 (a.) Pertaining to the epicycloid, or having its properties.

EPIGRAPHICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to epigraphs or to epigraphy; as, an epigraphic style; epigraphical works or studies.

EPIPEDOMETRY
 (n.) The mensuration of figures standing on the same base.

EPISCOPALIAN
 (a.) Pertaining to bishops, or government by bishops; episcopal; specifically, of or relating to the Protestant Episcopal Church.

EPISCOPICIDE
 (n.) The killing of a bishop.

EPISYLLOGISM
 (n.) A syllogism which assumes as one of its premises a proposition which was the conclusion of a preceding syllogism, called, in relation to this, the prosyllogism.

EPITROCHLEAR
 (a.) Relating to the epitrochlea.

EQUALITARIAN
 (n.) One who believes in equalizing the condition of men; a leveler.

EQUALIZATION
 (n.) The act of equalizing, or state of being equalized.

EQUESTRIENNE
 (n.) A woman skilled in equestrianism; a horsewoman.

EQUIMOMENTAL
 (a.) Having equal moments of inertia.

EQUIPOLLENCY
 (n.) Sameness of signification of two or more propositions which differ in language.

EQUISETIFORM
 (a.) Having the form of the equisetum.

EQUIVALVULAR
 (a.) Same as Equivalve or Equivalved.

EQUIVOCATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Equivocate

EQUIVOCATION
 (n.) The use of expressions susceptible of a double signification, with a purpose to mislead.

ERYTHROXYLON
 (n.) A genus of shrubs or small trees of the Flax family, growing in tropical countries. E. Coca is the source of cocaine. See Coca.

ESOPHAGOTOMY
 (n.) The operation of making an incision into the esophagus, for the purpose of removing any foreign substance that obstructs the passage.

ESOTERICALLY
 (adv.) In an esoteric manner.

ESSENTIATING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Essentiate

ESTABLISHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Establish

ETERNIZATION
 (n.) The act of eternizing; the act of rendering immortal or famous.

ETHEOSTOMOID
 (n.) Any fish of the genus Etheostoma and related genera, allied to the perches; -- also called darter. The etheostomoids are small and often bright- colored fishes inhabiting the fresh waters of North America. About seventy species are known. See Darte

ETHERIZATION
 (n.) The state of the system under the influence of ether.

ETHNOGRAPHER
 (n.) One who investigates ethnography.

ETHNOLOGICAL
 (a) Of or pertaining to ethnology.

EUTHIOCHROIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or denoting, an acid so called.

EVANGELISTIC
 (a.) Pertaining to the four evangelists; designed or fitted to evangelize; evangelical; as, evangelistic efforts.

EVANGELIZING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Evangelize

EVISCERATION
 (a.) A disemboweling.

EVOLUTIONISM
 (n.) The theory of, or belief in, evolution. See Evolution, 6 and 7.

EXACERBATION
 (n.) The act rendering more violent or bitter; the state of being exacerbated or intensified in violence or malignity; as, exacerbation of passion.

EXACERVATION
 (n.) The act of heaping up.

EXAGGERATING
 (a.) That exaggerates; enlarging beyond bounds.

EXAGGERATION
 (n.) A representation of things beyond natural life, in expression, beauty, power, vigor.

EXAGGERATORY
 (a.) Containing, or tending to, exaggeration; exaggerative.

EXANTHEMATIC
 (a.) Alt. of Exanthematous

EXASPERATION
 (n.) The act of exasperating or the state of being exasperated; irritation; keen or bitter anger.

EXAUGURATION
 (n.) The act of exaugurating; desecration.

EXCALCEATION
 (n.) The act of depriving or divesting of shoes.

EXCALFACTORY
 (a.) Heating; warming.

EXCENTRICITY
 () Same as Eccentricity.

EXCHANGEABLY
 (adv.) By way of exchange.

 (a.) Tending to exclude; causing exclusion; exclusive.

 (a.) Serving to excrete; connected with excretion or excrement.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Excruciate

EXENTERATION
 (n.) Act of exenterating.

 (n.) exercise; practice; use.

 (a.) Derived from, or pertaining to, experience.

 (a.) Pertaining to experiment; founded on, or derived from, experiment or trial; as, experimental science; given to, or skilled in, experiment; as, an experimental philosopher.

EXPERRECTION
 (n.) A waking up or arousing.

EXPLICITNESS
 (n.) The quality of being explicit; clearness; directness.

EXPLOITATION
 (n.) The act of exploiting or utilizing.

EXPRESSIONAL
 (a.) Of, or relating to, expression; phraseological; also, vividly representing or suggesting an idea or sentiment.

EXPROBRATORY
 (a.) Expressing reproach; upbraiding; reproachful.

EXSANGUINITY
 (n.) Privation or destitution of blood; -- opposed to plethora.

EXSCRIPTURAL
 (a.) Not in accordance with the doctrines of Scripture; unscriptural.

EXSUFFLATION
 (n.) A kind of exorcism by blowing with the breath.

EXTEMPORIZED
 (imp. & p. p.) of Extemporize

EXTERMINATOR
 (n.) One who, or that which, exterminates.

EXTERRANEOUS
 (a.) Foreign; belonging to, or coming from, abroad.

EXTORTIONARY
 (a.) Extortionate.

 (a.) Subject, or liable, to extradition, as a fugitive from justice.

EXTRAMUNDANE
 (a.) Beyond the material world.

EXTRAREGULAR
 (a.) Not comprehended within a rule or rules.

EXTRAVAGANCE
 (n.) The state of being extravagant, wild, or prodigal beyond bounds of propriety or duty; want of moderation; excess; especially, undue expenditure of money; vaid and superfluous expense; prodigality; as, extravagance of anger, love, expression, imagin

EXTRAVERSION
 (n.) The act of throwing out; the state of being turned or thrown out.

EXTUBERATION
 (n.) Protuberance.

EXULCERATIVE
 (a.) Tending to cause ulcers; exulceratory.

FALSIFICATOR
 (n.) A falsifier.

FAMILIARNESS
 (n.) Familiarity.

FASTIDIOSITY
 (n.) Fastidiousness; squeamishness.

FEMINIZATION
 (n.) The act of feminizing, or the state of being feminized.

FENESTRATION
 (n.) The arrangement and proportioning of windows; -- used by modern writers for the decorating of an architectural composition by means of the window (and door) openings, their ornaments, and proportions.

FERMENTATIVE
 (a.) Causing, or having power to cause, fermentation; produced by fermentation; fermenting; as, a fermentative process.

FERRICYANATE
 (n.) A salt of ferricyanic acid; a ferricyanide.

FERRIPRUSSIC
 (a.) Ferricyanic.

FERROPRUSSIC
 (a.) Ferrocyanic.

FERRUGINATED
 (a.) Having the color or properties of the rust of iron.

FIDDLEDEEDEE
 (interj.) An exclamatory word or phrase, equivalent to nonsense!

FISSIROSTRES
 (n. pl.) A group of birds having the bill deeply cleft.

FISTULARIOID
 (a.) Like or pertaining to the genus Fistularia.

FLAMMABILITY
 (n.) The quality of being flammable; inflammability.

 (n.) A bat; a flittermouse.

FLITTERMOUSE
 (n.) A bat; -- called also flickermouse, flindermouse, and flintymouse.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Flocculate

FLOCCULATION
 (n.) The process by which small particles of fine soils and sediments aggregate into larger lumps.

 (n.) The cultivation of flowering plants.

FLUCTISONOUS
 (a.) Sounding like waves.

FLUORANTHENE
 (n.) A white crystalline hydrocarbon C/H/, of a complex structure, found as one ingrdient of the higher boiling portion of coal tar.

FLUSTERATION
 (n.) The act of flustering, or the state of being flustered; fluster.

FOLLICULATED
 (a.) Having follicles.

FORAMINIFERA
 (n. pl.) An extensive order of rhizopods which generally have a chambered calcareous shell formed by several united zooids. Many of them have perforated walls, whence the name. Some species are covered with sand. See Rhizophoda.

FORCIBLENESS
 (n.) The quality of being forcible.

FOREADMONISH
 (v. t.) To admonish beforehand, or before the act or event.

FOUNTAINLESS

 (a.) Exhibiting undue boldness of speculation; skeptical.

 (a.) Accessible.

FRUCTICULOSE

FRUMENTATION

FUNCTIONLESS
 (a.) Destitute of function, or of an appropriate organ. Darwin.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Gainstand

GALACTOMETER
 (n.) An instrument for ascertaining the quality of milk (i.e., its richness in cream) by determining its specific gravity; a lactometer.

GALLIGASKINS
 (n. pl.) Loose hose or breeches; leather leg quards. The word is used loosely and often in a jocose sense.

GAMOPETALOUS
 (a.) Having the petals united or joined so as to form a tube or cup; monopetalous.

GASTROTROCHA
 (n.) A form of annelid larva having cilia on the ventral side.

 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Gelatinate

 (adv.) In a geological manner.

 (a.) Alt. of Gladiatorian

 (n.) Quality of being glandulous; a collection of glands.

GLOSSARIALLY
 (adv.) In the manner of a glossary.

GLOSSOGRAPHY
 (n.) The writing of glossaries, glosses, or comments for illustrating an author.

GLYCOCHOLATE
 (n.) A salt of glycocholic acid; as, sodium glycocholate.

GLYCYRRHIZIN
 (n.) A glucoside found in licorice root (Glycyrrhiza), in monesia bark (Chrysophyllum), in the root of the walnut, etc., and extracted as a yellow, amorphous powder, of a bittersweet taste.

GLYPTOGRAPHY
 (n.) The art or process of engraving on precious stones.

GNOMOLOGICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to, of the nature of, or resembling, a gnomology.

GRAPHITOIDAL
 (a.) Resembling graphite or plumbago.

GRAVELLINESS
 (n.) State of being gravelly.

GRUDGINGNESS

GUILLOTINING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Guillotine

GYMNOBLASTEA
 (n. pl.) The Athecata; -- so called because the medusoid buds are not inclosed in a capsule.

GYMNOLAEMATA
 (n. pl.) An order of Bryozoa, having no epistome.

GYNANTHEROUS
 (a.) Pertaining to an abnormal condition of the flower, in which the stamens are converted into pistils.

HAEMASTATICS
 (n.) Same as Hemastatics.

HAEMATEMESIS
 (n.) Same as Hematemesis.

HAEMATOCRYAL
 (a.) Cold-blooded.

HAEMATOXYLON
 (n.) A genus of leguminous plants containing but a single species, the H. Campechianum or logwood tree, native in Yucatan.

HAGIOGRAPHER
 (n.) One of the writers of the hagiographa; a writer of lives of the saints.

HAIRSPLITTER
 (n.) One who makes excessively nice or needless distinctions in reasoning; one who quibbles.

HALLELUJATIC
 (a.) Pertaining to, or containing, hallelujahs.

HAMSTRINGING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hamstring

HANDKERCHIEF
 (n.) A piece of cloth, usually square and often fine and elegant, carried for wiping the face or hands.

HANDSOMENESS
 (n.) The quality of being handsome.

HEADFOREMOST
 (adv.) With the head foremost.

HEARTBURNING
 (n.) Same as Heartburn.

HEARTRENDING
 (a.) Causing intense grief; overpowering with anguish; very distressing.

HEDERIFEROUS
 (a.) Producing ivy; ivy-bearing.

HELIOGRAVURE
 (n.) The process of photographic engraving.

HEMADROMETRY
 (n.) Alt. of Hemadromometry

HEMAPOPHYSES
 (pl. ) of Hemapophysis

HEMASTATICAL
 (a. & n.) Same as Hemostatic.

HEMATOPHILIA
 (n.) A condition characterized by a tendency to profuse and uncontrollable hemorrhage from the slightest wounds.

HEMEROCALLIS
 (n.) A genus of plants, some species of which are cultivated for their beautiful flowers; day lily.

HEMIMELLITIC
 (a.) Having half as many (three) carboxyl radicals as mellitic acid; -- said of an organic acid.

HEMISPHERULE
 (n.) A half spherule.

HEMORRHOIDAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, hemorrhoids.

HEMSTITCHING
 (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Hemstitch

HEPATIZATION
 (n.) Conversion into a substance resembling the liver; a state of the lungs when gorged with effused matter, so that they are no longer pervious to the air.

HEPATOCYSTIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the liver and gall bladder; as, the hepatocystic ducts.

HEPATOGENOUS
 (a.) Arising from the liver; due to a condition of the liver; as, hepatogenic jaundice.

HEREDITARILY
 (adv.) By inheritance; in an hereditary manner.

HERITABILITY
 (n.) The state of being heritable.

HERMETICALLY
 (adv.) By fusion, so as to form an air-tight closure.

HESITATINGLY
 (adv.) With hesitation or doubt.

HETEROCLITIC
 (a.) Alt. of Heteroclitical

HETEROGAMOUS
 (a.) Characterized by heterogamy.

HETEROGENOUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to heterogenesis; heterogenetic.

HETEROGYNOUS
 (a.) Having females very unlike the males in form and structure; -- as certain insects, the males of which are winged, and the females wingless.

HETEROMEROUS
 (a.) With the parts not corresponding in number.

HETERONOMOUS
 (a.) Subject to the law of another.

HETEROOUSIAN
 (n.) One of those Arians who held that the Son was of a different substance from the Father.

HETEROPODOUS
 (a.) Of or pertaining to the Heteropoda.

HETEROSOMATI
 (n. pl.) An order of fishes, comprising the flounders, halibut, sole, etc., having the body and head asymmetrical, with both eyes on one side. Called also Heterosomata, Heterosomi.

HETEROSTYLED
 (a.) Having styles of two or more distinct forms or lengths.

HEXACAPSULAR
 (a.) Having six capsules or seed vessels.

HEXAMETRICAL
 (a.) Consisting of six metrical feet.

HEXAPETALOUS
 (a.) Having six petals.

HIBERNACULUM
 (n.) A little case in which certain insects pass the winter.

HIEROGLYPHIC
 (a.) Any character or figure which has, or is supposed to have, a hidden or mysterious significance; hence, any unintelligible or illegible character or mark.

HIEROGRAPHIC
 (a.) Alt. of Hierographical

HIEROPHANTIC
 (a.) Of or relating to hierophants or their teachings.

HIPPOCENTAUR
 (n.) Same as Centaur.

HIPPOCREPIAN
 (n.) One of an order of fresh-water Bryozoa, in which the tentacles are on a lophophore, shaped like a horseshoe. See Phylactolaema.

HIPPOPHAGISM
 (n.) Hippophagy.

HISTOGENESIS
 (n.) Germ history of cells, and of the tissues composed of cells.

HISTOGRAPHER
 (n.) One who describes organic tissues; an histologist.

HISTOLOGICAL
 (a.) Pertaining to histology, or to the microscopic structure of the tissues of living organisms.

HISTORICALLY
 (adv.) In the manner of, or in accordance with, history.

HISTORIOLOGY
 (n.) A discourse on history.

HOMOLOGATION
 (n.) Confirmation or ratification (as of something otherwise null and void), by a court or a grantor.

HOMOMORPHOUS
 (a.) Characterized by homomorphism.

HOMOMORPHISM
 (n.) The possession of but one kind of larvae or young, as in most insects.

HOMOSYSTEMIC
 (a.) Developing, in the case of multicellular organisms, from the same embryonic systems into which the secondary unit (gastrula or plant enbryo) differentiates.

HORIZONTALLY
 (adv.) In a horizontal direction or position; on a level; as, moving horizontally.

HOUSEBREAKER
 (n.) One who is guilty of the crime of housebreaking.

HOUSEKEEPING
 (n.) Hospitality; a liberal and hospitable table; a supply of provisions.

HOUSEWARMING
 (n.) A feast or merry-making made by or for a family or business firm on taking possession of a new house or premises.

HUMANITARIAN
 (n.) One who limits the sphere of duties to human relations and affections, to the exclusion or disparagement of the religious or spiritual.

HUMICUBATION
 (n.) The act or practice of lying on the ground.

HUMOROUSNESS
 (n.) Facetiousness; jocularity.

HYBRIDIZABLE
 (a.) Capable of forming a hybrid, or of being subjected to a hybridizing process; capable of producing a hybrid by union with another species or stock.

HYDRARGYRISM
 (n.) A diseased condition produced by poisoning with hydrargyrum, or mercury; mercurialism.

HYDROCYANIDE
 (n.) A compound of hydrocyanic acid with a base; -- distinguished from a cyanide, in which only the cyanogen so combines.

HYDROPATHIST
 (n.) One who practices hydropathy; a water-cure doctor.

HYDROSTATICS
 (n.) The branch of science which relates to the pressure and equilibrium of nonelastic fluids, as water, mercury, etc.; the principles of statics applied to water and other liquids.

HYDROTROPISM
 (n.) A tendency towards moisture.

HYMENOPTERAL
 (a.) Alt. of Hymenopterous

HYMNOGRAPHER
 (n.) A writer or composed of hymns.

HYPERKINETIC
 (a.) Of or pertaining to hyperkinesis.

HYPERMETROPY
 (n.) A condition of the eye in which, through shortness of the eyeball or fault of the refractive media, the rays of light come to a focus behind the retina; farsightedness; -- called also hyperopia. Cf. Emmetropia.

HYPERPLASTIC
 (a.) Tending to excess of formative action.

HYPERTHYRION
 (n.) That part of the architrave which is over a door or window.

HYPOCHONDRES
 (n. pl.) The hypochondriac regions. See Hypochondrium.

HYPOCHONDRIA
 (pl. ) of Hypochondrium

HYPODICROTIC
 (a.) Alt. of Hypodicrotous

HYPOSKELETAL
 (a.) Beneath the endoskeleton; hypaxial; as, the hyposkeletal muscles; -- opposed to episkeletal.

HYPOSTATICAL
 (a.) Relating to hypostasis, or substance; hence, constitutive, or elementary.

HYPOSULPHITE
 (n.) A salt of what was formerly called hyposulphurous acid; a thiosulphate.

HYPOTHECATOR
 (n.) One who hypothecates or pledges anything as security for the repayment of money borrowed.

HYSTEROPHYTE
 (n.) A plant, like the fungus, which lives on dead or living organic matter.

IATROCHEMIST
 (n.) A physician who explained or treated diseases upon chemical principles; one who practiced iatrochemistry.

ICHNOLOGICAL
 (a.) Of or pertaining to ichnology.

ICHTHYOLOGIC
 (a.) Alt. of Ichthyological

ICHTHYOSAURI
 (pl. ) of Ichthyosaurus

ICONOGRAPHIC
 (a.) Representing by means of pictures or diagrams; as, an icongraphic encyclopaedia.

IDEALIZATION
 (n.) The representation of natural objects, scenes, etc., in such a way as to show their most important characteristics; the study of the ideal.

IDEOGRAPHICS
 (n.) The system of writing in ideographic characters; also, anything so written.

IDIOCRATICAL
 (a.) Peculiar in constitution or temperament; idiosyncratic.

 (a.) Electric by virtue of its own peculiar properties; capable of becoming electrified by friction; -- opposed to anelectric.

 (a.) Having a form of its own.

 (a.) Idiopathic.

KALEIDOSCOPE
 (n.) An instrument invented by Sir David Brewster, which contains loose fragments of colored glass, etc., and reflecting surfaces so arranged that changes of position exhibit its contents in an endless variety of beautiful colors and symmetrical forms.

 (n.) The indirect division of cells in which, prior to division of the cell protoplasm, complicated changes take place in the nucleus, attended with movement of the nuclear fibrils; -- opposed to karyostenosis. The nucleus becomes enlarged and convolute
